HEADLINE: Senate Democrats to Press Inquiry Into High Energy Prices 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7 

 BODY:
With Democrats now in control of the Senate, its main investigating committee will focus on high energy prices. That will include conducting an inquiry into whether the federal agency that regulates electricity markets has been properly enforcing the law.
 The new chairman of the panel, the Governmental Affairs Committee, is Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, who said today that it would take on tough issues in a bipartisan manner. 
 "I will refuse to allow oversight to become overkill," Mr. Lieberman said at a news conference.
The committee's focus on energy is part of a larger strategy by Democrats to try to highlight their differences with the Bush administration.
The committee's first hearing will explore the effects of deregulation on natural gas and electricity prices. Among those testifying will be economists who recently advocated temporary curbs on prices in volatile wholesale electricity markets like that in California. 
Mr. Lieberman supports price caps as a temporary solution in such markets. The Bush administration opposes them on the grounds that they distort the market by inhibiting investment in new plants.
Mr. Lieberman also said he planned to examine "whether the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission was adequately carrying out its duties to ensure 'just and reasonable' electricity prices to consumers."
The commission, an independent agency that oversees a $250 billion industry, is charged with enforcing a 1935 law that calls for fair electricity prices. But as the energy markets have moved toward deregulation, the commission has tended to defer more to market forces, leading critics to question its enforcement of that law. 
Until this year, the commission had brought only one case asking for refunds in the electricity markets, collecting $598. More recently it sought $125 million in refunds from electricity generators for what it said were overcharges of California utilities. Mr. Lieberman said he would look at the commission's record under Democratic and Republican administrations.
He said he would also look at "serious allegations" raised by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, concerning the commission's relationship with the industry it regulates. Ms. Feinstein's concerns include a discussion earlier this year between the commission's chairman, Curt Hebert Jr., and Kenneth Lay, the chairman of the Enron Corporation, the nation's biggest electricity trader. They said they discussed commission-related issues and Mr. Hebert's continued tenure as its chairman, though they had different interpretations on the talks. 
Mr. Lieberman said the committee would use its subpoena power if it was needed to hear testimony from industry officials.

HEADLINE: Subject to Review 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7 

 BODY:
Almost nothing about the new tax law is irreversible. Even before President Bush signed it this morning with great fanfare at a White House ceremony, the politicians were talking about how to revise it.
 So this law -- Mr. Bush's top legislative priority -- will not necessarily lead to the kind of permanent change that would occur if Congress approved some of his other big policy proposals, like converting a part of Social Security into private savings accounts or requiring retirees on Medicare to shop for health insurance in the private market or installing a missile defense system. 
 Republican leaders in the House of Representatives have said they want to speed up the tax rate reductions and give new tax breaks to businesses, steps made harder by the new Democratic majority in the Senate.
Democrats in the Senate want to block some of the cuts in the new law before they take effect. Asked about this at his first news conference as majority leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota said: "I know we're going to revisit it. I just know that at some point that reality is going to come crashing down on all of us, and we're going to have to deal with it."
The law has the tax cuts going into effect gradually. That means they could be repealed before anyone could take advantage of most of them. Or they could be expanded.
As matters stand now, the lower tax rates will not become fully effective until 2006, the estate tax will not be fully repealed until 2010, the doubling of the tax credit for children will not take place until 2010 and new benefits for married couples will not begin until 2008.
And without changes, tens of millions of middle-class taxpayers will have most of their tax cuts eaten away by an arcane set of rules called the alternative minimum tax.
Most striking, all the tax cuts that became law today will expire on Dec. 31, 2010, and unless they are renewed, the tax law will revert to what it was this morning, before the president signed the new law. No one expects that to happen, but if it did, it would mean a sudden huge tax increase that could have disastrous economic consequences.
Most single income-taxpayers can count on a rebate check this year of $300. Single parents will get $500 and couples $600. But beyond that, little is certain. Year after year Congress will probably reconsider the law, and once tinkering with taxes begins, nothing in the tax code is immutable.
What gets changed will depend largely on unforeseeable political and economic circumstances. 
For example, if Democrats are in power, it is a safe bet that the repeal of the estate tax and the lowering of the top tax rate to 35 percent from the current 39.6 percent will never happen.
The only people who could benefit from these tax changes, which stand to cost the government tens of billions of dollars a year in lost revenue in the second decade of the century, are the wealthiest Americans. Democrats would rather spend the money on government programs.
If Republicans are in political control there is a good chance that the capital gains tax will be eliminated, or at least reduced, and that tax cuts will be expanded to include breaks for businesses.
Perhaps even more crucial to the fate of the tax cuts is what happens to the economy. The law was predicated on estimates by the Bush administration and the Congressional Budget Office that the government budget surplus would be $5.6 trillion over the next decade. 
Long-term forecasts like these are notoriously unreliable. Even the revised estimates due out this summer could be quite different from the ones made just last winter.
If, as the years go by, the surplus turns out to be larger than anticipated, the politicians will no doubt seek further tax cuts. But if it ends up being smaller, there will be strong pressure to renege on some of the tax reductions set to take effect late in the decade.
At this stage, it seems more likely that the surpluses will be smaller than that they will be larger. That is because the estimates assumed rigid limits on government spending that probably will not be maintained. Government spending is already smaller as a percentage of the national economy than at any other time since the 1960's, and the estimates of the surplus assume the proportion will drop another 25 percent in the next decade.
Furthermore, some expensive budget items are sure to be considered, like prescription drug coverage under Medicare and a missile defense shield. Future presidents and future Congresses may decide that the government would rather spend money on programs like these than let the tax cuts become effective.
And then there is the matter of the baby boomers. In 2010, this tax bill expires. The next year, the first of the baby boomers will reach 65 and become entitled to Social Security and Medicare. In the following years, the demands on the Treasury will begin to increase exponentially. It is difficult to imagine they can be met without higher taxes.
History has shown that politicians cannot keep their hands off the tax code.
The last big tax cut was in 1981, Ronald Reagan's first year as president. In 1982, 1983 and 1984, Congress approved tax increases that offset some of the Reagan cuts.
The Tax Reform Act of 1986 wiped out scores of tax breaks for people and businesses and in return gave everyone much lower tax rates. It was viewed at the time as a monumental, bipartisan legislative accomplishment. But it was not long before new tax breaks were introduced and higher tax rates were imposed.
The first President George Bush promised no new taxes and then approved them in 1990. President Bill Clinton campaigned for lower taxes in 1992 and then raised them in 1993.
At the White House today, President Bush called the new tax law "the first major achievement of a new era."
"More achievements are ahead," the president said.
Doubtless that is the case. The question is, how much will the new achievements undo the first one.

HEADLINE: President's Signature Turns Broad Tax Cut, and a Campaign Promise, Into Law 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7 

 BODY:
President Bush fulfilled a major promise of his campaign for president today, signing into law the most sweeping tax cut in two decades, which he called "the first major achievement of a new era."
 Mr. Bush signed the $1.35 trillion tax cut -- which provides for soon-to-be mailed rebate checks of $300 to $600 for almost every income-tax payer -- amid the kind of presidential pomp he usually disdains: a formal ceremony in the East Room, with a Marine Corps band playing "Hail to the Chief." 
 For Mr. Bush, the moment completed the first major victory of his first year in office and the vindication of a political strategy that appeared dubious to some strategists during the campaign and politically improbable even after he was declared the winner of the presidential election. But his own relentless salesmanship around the country and an economic slowdown, which he used to justify an economic stimulus, turned the idea into an inevitability, a piece of political jujitsu that his own aides fear will be hard to repeat on many other issues. 
"Across the board tax relief does not happen often in Washington, D.C.," Mr. Bush said this morning. "In fact, since World War II, it has happened only twice: President Kennedy's tax cut in the 60's and President Reagan's tax cuts in the 1980's. And now it's happening for the third time, and it's about time."
Mr. Bush was surrounded by Republicans who have long argued for such a cut and by conservative Democrats, like Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Zell Miller of Georgia, who made it possible.
But beneath the smiles was considerable discomfort among the Republican senators who lost their cherished committee chairmanships and leadership posts after Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont defected from the party, shifting control of the Senate to the Democrats.
Yet Mr. Bush seemed to show little concern today about his political situation, and his top aides were already talking about the next step: pushing through a corporate tax cut sometime next year.
In an interview today, Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, said: "I think that further reform on the business side is probably a good idea. We need to make it simpler and less costly."
In Congress today, a few Republicans talked about making the current bill permanent. An odd feature is that it expires on Dec. 31, 2010 -- a sunset provision put in because of Congressional rules governing spending more than a decade in the future. But the real effect is to disguise the true cost of the tax cut if Congress extends the bill, which it will be under great pressure to do.
Mr. Lindsey said today that he expected that the tax cut would be made permanent, "but not any time in the immediate future."
The final tax-cut legislation fell short of the reductions Mr. Bush wanted, by $250 billion. It lowered the top tax rate to 35 percent, not the 33 percent sought by Mr. Bush. It slowly winds down the estate tax, eliminating it in 2010. But the levy, which Republicans called the "death tax" to press their political case, will be fully restored in 2011, more than two years after Mr. Bush leaves office if he is re-elected.
"The White House does think the cuts should be permanent," Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said today. Mr. Fleischer noted that federal entitlement programs were permanent, while the tax cuts are not. "Washington was built to spend," he said. 
Following tradition in signing major legislation, Mr. Bush used a different pen for each letter of his name, then handed the pens to Republican Congressional leaders and a few Democrats whose support was critical.
Among them was Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the new chairman of the Finance Committee, whose decision to reach a compromise between his own party's more modest tax cut and Mr. Bush's more ambitious one angered leaders in his own party, including the new majority leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota. But tonight Mr. Daschle was headed to the White House for a private dinner with Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura, while Mr. Baucus said he did the right thing by striking a deal with Mr. Bush.
"Every day it looks like a better and better decision," Mr. Baucus said at the White House after the signing ceremony. "In many respects, I think politically I helped the party. We Democrats would have been in trouble in 2002 just saying no to every one of the president's proposals."
But other Democratic leaders continued to criticize Mr. Bush and argued that he had traded away deficit reduction. They predicted that the tax cut would have to be revised, but not soon.
For Republicans, the most politically beneficial moment may come this summer, when those who paid income taxes for last year begin to receive rebate checks, $300 for single filers and $600 for those who filed joint returns. (Some taxpayers, like children listed as dependents on their parents' returns, will not get rebates.)
Today, Representative J.C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, the fourth-ranking House Republican, told colleagues in a memorandum that as the refund checks are sent out, Republicans should remind taxpayers "who is working to give them more of their own money back to meet their own priorities, not Washington's."
Economists hope the rebates will spur consumer spending in the second half of the year, but the economic effect is hard to predict.
"I think it will create a big kick at the end of the year and then an additional four-tenths to five-tenths of growth next year," Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the president's council of economic advisers, said this evening.
Gradual cuts in tax rates will follow the rebate checks. A new 10 percent bottom rate will be created; the child credit will be increased gradually; and the amounts that can be contributed to individual retirement, 401(k) and educational accounts will be raised, deferring or reducing taxes.
While some Democrats were at the White House celebrating with Mr. Bush today, the bill's opponents were on Capitol Hill talking about its costs and promising to roll back some provisions.
Within an hour of the signing, the House minority leader, Representative Dick Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, who led opposition to the cut, was already talking about a rollback if the budget surplus that Mr. Bush counted on failed to materialize. But many Democrats concede in private that the debate is largely over for the immediate future. If the surpluses do not appear, Mr. Baucus agreed today, "then the surplus will get squeezed."
How much it will get squeezed will depend on the economic growth rate, how much the Treasury collects in capital gain taxes and other cyclical funds and how much Congress spends. And while all sides of that debate proffer numbers to prove their point, history suggests that any surplus or deficit projections beyond the next two or three years are unreliable. For example, in the Clinton years, the White House consistently underestimated revenues; today there is evidence that projections may be too optimistic.
Congress seems in a mood to break out of the spending limits it set for itself earlier this year.
Today the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, C.W. Bill Young, Republican of Florida, said "my position today" was that the 13 annual spending bills would honor the $661 billion total proposed by Bush administration and included in the 2002 budget Republicans pushed through Congress in April.
But that total excludes the administration's plans to overhaul military acquisitions, for a missile shield and for increases in education.
Today, an $18.9 billion spending bill that finances a host of conservation and energy programs sailed through a House subcommittee. It included $294 million more than Mr. Bush had requested for energy research and conservation, pushing the amount to nearly $1.8 billion.

HEADLINE: After Shift in Senate, Some in G.O.P. Are Fearing Wider Impact in 2002 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7 

 BODY:
Many prominent Republicans are worried that the unexpected switch of the Senate to Democratic control may carry enormous political consequences for their party that run far deeper than forfeiting the issue agenda on Capitol Hill.
 Republicans are concerned that the loss of the Senate -- even by the single defection of Senator James M. Jeffords -- will embolden Democrats and demoralize Republicans in the run-up to the critical midterm elections next year. 
 That, they said, could lead partisans to be less enthusiastic about making donations and working in the grass roots. And they expressed fears that the Republicans' minority status in the Senate might cause some senators not to seek re-election next year and could make it more difficult for the party to recruit the most formidable contenders.
Republicans also said the switch of the Senate raised the stakes of the two governors' races this year, in Virginia and New Jersey, where Republicans are already regarded as the underdogs. 
Those off-year races are not always a barometer of the political climate in the next year, but they can give the winning party an important psychological lift that helps fund-raising and stirs the activists. Even Republicans say they have an uphill climb to retain the governorships in those two states.
Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Republican Governors' Association, said of those races, and of the many more in 2002: "I don't stay awake late at night worrying about too many things, but this will keep me up. It's a very challenging time."
Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, chairman of the Republican National Committee, noted that the Democratic candidate to succeed him, Mark Warner, had far more campaign money than the Republican nominee, Mark L. Earley.
"We have to find some way to match the enormous wealth of the Democratic candidate," said Mr. Gilmore, who cannot run for re-election because Virginia bars governors from seeking consecutive terms. "That's hard to do."
Beyond the electoral worries, Republicans are engaged in a wrenching debate about how much President Bush and Republican lawmakers should moderate their positions now that Mr. Jeffords has defected.
Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, for one, said they should not budge at all. "They should not be swept up by the thought or fear that somehow the country is lurching way to the left of them," Mr. Keating said. "The country isn't -- the Democratic Party is."
But former Senator John C. Danforth, a moderate conservative from Missouri, countered that the party had better be more inclusive.
"I'm concerned that we're becoming too narrow," Mr. Danforth said. "Jeffords is a real loss. His membership in the Republican Party said that while we're basically conservative, we're big enough to have differences of opinion."
While attention has been fixed on the Senate, many Republicans -- already wary of Democrats deploring that Mr. Bush lost the popular vote last year -- said they were worried about internal and outside polls showing the president's approval ratings slipping.
A nationwide poll conducted by ABC News and The Washington Post this week found that Mr. Bush's job approval has dipped to 55 percent, a rating lower than seven of the previous nine presidents had at this point in their tenure.
Many Republicans say Mr. Bush's trip to California last week did him more harm than good. His approval rating among that state's voters is 43 percent, down from 56 percent two months ago, according to a survey by Fairbank, Maslin, Maullin & Associates.
"The party is on the defensive," said William J. Bennett, a former education secretary and national drug policy director.
Speaking of the president, Mr. Bennett said, "You know the honeymoon is over when the smiling face bringing you breakfast at your front door is Tom Daschle."
While some Republicans would discuss their dissatisfaction with the leadership of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, only privately, Mr. Bennett was not hesitant to speak out.
"He should consider maybe it's time for someone else to do this," he said. "We have a somewhat uncertain trumpet in the Senate."
Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald of Illinois complained of a lack of tolerance for diverse views among his party's leadership on Capitol Hill.
"We must come to grips with the fact that what it means to be a Republican in Vermont is not the same as what it means to be a Republican in Mississippi or Montana," Mr. Fitzgerald said. "You will see more willingness on the part of rank-and-file senators to question the infallibility of leaders."
That said, Mr. Fitzgerald added, "A Wall Street analyst would probably still call the Republican Party 'a buy.' We have the House. We have the White House. And we're only one vote away from a working majority in the Senate."
Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political adviser, said he was not worried. "You never know how these things are going to play out," Mr. Rove said. "But I feel confident about the state of the party. The enthusiasm about our agenda has a great deal to do with it."
Mr. Rove said people "overstate the dramatic change in the Senate -- it's still a place that's going to require 60 votes to get things passed."
Governor Gilmore was downright ebullient, saying: "Whatever you're hearing, it's just not right. For heaven's sake, today we just signed the biggest tax cut we've seen in a long, long time." 
It could be, of course, that the loss of the Senate emboldens Republicans, just as the Democrats recovered after their electoral setback in 1994. And for all the concerns about alienating moderates, the party has succeeded in the critical task of keeping its conservative base happy.
Still, many Republicans say they are nervous about possible reverberations from Capitol Hill.
"There's always a shakeout period where you go from a tremendous high to a little bit of a roller-coaster ride," said Tom Cole, a party strategist who stepped down this year as chief of staff of the Republican National Committee. "But the Jeffords departure and the loss of the Senate is something that disturbs Republicans and concerns them quite a bit."
Warning that the Democrats are far more energized than Republicans, Mr. Cole said: "There's a psychological mood that you've got to be careful of. You never want to appear to be losing ground or on the defensive because it affects everything from candidate recruitment to the willingness of people to commit their time and money. We've not established ourselves as a legitimate winner in the way that Ronald Reagan was a legitimate winner."
Former Vice President Dan Quayle said he was deeply worried about losing longtime senators who do not want to be in the minority.
"My biggest concern is that there's going to be this self-fulfilling prophecy that the Democrats are back, and Republican senators are going to look at their minority status and some are going to decide not to run," Mr. Quayle said.
His strongest counsel to Republicans was, "Don't panic."
Those who do seek re-election may find that political action committees, hedging their bets, will be more apt to give to Democrats.
"Senators who are up in 2002 may have more difficulty raising money out of their own states and from the Washington political action community," said Wayne Berman, a Republican strategist and fund-raiser. But he added that the Senate shift could spur more donations from smaller donors beyond Washington eager to do battle with the Democrats.
Worries about recruitment only exacerbate the challenges for Republicans, who were already on the defensive about next year's prospects because the party that wins the White House often suffers in the subsequent midterm elections. Of particular concern is that Republicans will lose their dominance of governorships. The party now has 29 governors, but 23 of those seats are being contested next year, and many Republicans say a third of those seats appear vulnerable.
Republicans fear losing governorships in some large states, including New York, Illinois, Massachusetts, Michigan and Pennsylvania.
"We're sort of the victims of our own success," said Mr. Rove, who noted that some incumbents were up against limits on the number of terms they could serve. "We're being as supportive as we can."
Even the most nervous Republicans seemed more inclined to criticize their leaders on Capitol Hill than Mr. Bush.
"I've had a lot of people say, 'We probably got what we deserved' because there's a feeling among a lot of Republicans that there was an unwillingness of some Republicans to compromise within the Senate," said Robert T. Bennett, chairman of the Republican Party in Ohio. "There has to be a sincere effort to address the concerns of everyday America."
Mr. Bennett and several other Republicans said their party should redouble its efforts and emphasize issues like the cost of prescription drugs and a patients' bill of rights.
"At the end of the day, the party in power still has to deliver," said Rusty Hills, chairman of the Republican Party in Michigan. "We've lost the Senate, but Bush is still the president, and we have got to deliver on issues like the patients' bill of rights, and we have to make sure the economy grows."
Other Republicans argue that the pressure is now on Democrats to perform. And rather than take the offensive, some seemed to be hanging their hopes on the possibility that Senate Democrats would alienate voters by overreaching in their agenda.
"If they're the architects of a destruction derby, they'll lose, and they'll lose big," Governor Keating said, referring to the parties' performance in next year's elections.
But if the Democrats are careful not to go too far? "Then they'll win," he said.

HEADLINE: City Insists on Administrative Cuts for School Board 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
City officials reassured the Board of Education yesterday that they would allocate additional money for instruction in the next school year if the board made cuts in its administrative costs over the summer.
 The proposal, which was still being hammered out yesterday as part of a budget agreement, could mean that the Board of Education would not have to ask school districts to make up to $200 million in cuts that would affect teachers, aides or academic programs. 
 Growing administrative costs have been at the center of a running dispute between Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The chancellor has maintained that administration represents a small fraction of costs, while the mayor has often spoken of a bloated bureaucracy at the board's headquarters that would have to be cut before the board could expect further spending increases. 
The City Council and the mayor agreed on a tentative budget on Wednesday. Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani dismissed the idea that the budget would create problems for the school system, saying the board's only challenge would be in reducing overhead costs. 
"That's a good problem to have," Mr. Giuliani said, "because the Board of Education has over $12 billion in city, state and federal money. And they should figure out how to spend that $12 billion effectively."
The budget calls for an increase of about $200 million -- about $50 million of that would come from city funds -- in the Board of Education's budget, bringing the allocation to about $11.5 billion, according to city officials. Board officials said that increase would actually mean a cut in the money available for programs after accounting for such things as mandated salary increases and the effects of inflation.
The City Council has come down on the mayor's side, insisting on administrative cuts. "We told them that if you can demonstrate you are trimming the central board's budget, then any instructional needs you have later in the year, we'll be happy to look at and fund," Jordan Barowitz, a Council spokesman, said yesterday.
It is not clear how much the board will have to cut from administrative costs to avoid reductions that would affect classroom services. "We don't have a hard target," Mr. Barowitz said. "We're looking for a good-faith effort."
City Council members were apparently reacting to the rapid increase in central administration costs this year. According to Board of Education budget figures, nonsalary expenses at the central board were budgeted at $50 million at the beginning of the current school year, which ends in June. But by the beginning of March, the expected level of those expenses for the entire year had ballooned to more than $110 million. Salary and fringe benefit costs were also higher than expected, at $83 million compared with an original budget figure of $50 million. Earlier this year, under pressure from City Hall, Mr. Levy laid out $22 million in cuts in central administration over two years.
Anthony Shorris, the deputy chancellor for management and policy, said yesterday that the board was waiting to see the language in the budget agreement before deciding where it would make spending cuts.

HEADLINE: More Cutbacks by Consultants As Accenture Trims Its Payroll 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Accenture, the consulting firm formerly known as Andersen Consulting, announced yesterday that it would lay off approximately 600 employees, mainly support staff, and encourage up to 800 consultants to take voluntary sabbaticals for up to one year in an effort to control costs.
 The steps are in response not only to a slowdown in client spending but also to a sharp decrease in the firm's attrition rate, which at this time last year topped 20 percent as consultants hopped jobs in search of dot-com glory. 
 Now, as employees see other job options vanish -- and as the prospect of Accenture's public stock offering beckons, though no date has been set -- attrition is 12 percent, said Roxanne Taylor, a spokeswoman for the firm. 
The cutbacks will be mainly in the United States, she said. Over all, the firm expects net growth of 9,000 new consultants this year, with much of the growth in Europe, she said.
Accenture is the latest consulting firm to show signs of strain because of uncertain economic conditions in the United States. Companies that hired the firms in past years are reluctant to spend as much now, industry officials say.
"They're not manufacturing a product, so the quickest way for them to cut costs is through head- count" reductions, said Jack Sweeney, the editor of Consulting Magazine. "At the same time, morale takes a pretty severe hit any time you have layoffs. They're getting creative to avoid that."
Accenture's sabbatical program, an effort to retain people with valuable experience but still cut wage costs, is unusual.
Available at the firm's discretion to consultants who sign up by the end of the month, the program pays participating employees 20 percent of their salary for 6 to 12 months and maintains benefits during that period. They are guaranteed a job when they return, Ms. Taylor said.
"The plus for us is, during this sort of economic slowdown, we save 80 percent of the salaries that people are making," Ms. Taylor said. When consultants come back from sabbatical, they do not have to be trained as new employees would, she added. 
Still, Accenture employees may want to consider the risks of participating, said Russell H. Miller, a partner at S.C.A. Consulting, a compensation advisory firm.
"When you say a job will be there in 12 months, the implicit understanding is it will be there if the business will support it," Mr. Miller said. "If the economy does not turn, I would make a strong case that these jobs will not be there just as they're not there now."
The 600 job cuts, less than 1 percent of Accenture's worldwide work force of 75,000, will focus on office support staff, according to Ms. Taylor. Most will be in the United States.
Other consulting firms have also announced staff reductions as business has slowed. In recent weeks the strategy consultant Booz-Allen & Hamilton announced layoffs, as did William M. Mercer, a human resources consulting firm.

HEADLINE: A Stanford Economist to Be No. 2 at I.M.F. 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7 

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had named Anne O. Krueger, a Stanford University economist and a strong proponent of global free trade, to serve as its No. 2 official, responsible for carrying out the fund's role as the world's financial firefighter.
 Ms. Krueger, 67, will replace Stanley Fischer, who during his seven years as deputy managing director, devised a series of financial rescue efforts for developing nations. The position is traditionally filled by an American who has the support of the White House. Until today's announcement, Ms. Krueger had been President Bush's choice for a seat on his Council of Economic Advisers. 
 The choice suggests that the Bush administration does not intend to try to radically reinvent the way the I.M.F. works. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and his top deputy for international matters, John Taylor, have in the past criticized the fund's bailouts.
Ms. Krueger, who served in the Reagan administration as chief economist at the World Bank, the I.M.F.'s sister agency, has echoed Mr. O'Neill's calls for better early warning of impending financial crises to prevent the need for multibillion-dollar rescue packages. But she has also defended the fund's rescue efforts in Asia in the late 1990's.
Horst Kohler, managing director of the I.M.F., had recommended naming Timothy Geithner, who served as under secretary of the Treasury for international affairs in the Clinton administration, to the No. 2 post, fund officials said. But Bush administration officials rejected that choice, the officials said, because Mr. Geithner was viewed as too closely associated with policies of the Clinton team.
The I.M.F. instead named Mr. Geithner as director of the policy development and review department, succeeding Jack Boorman. He had been considered for that position before Mr. Fischer announced his intention to resign.
Toward the end of the Clinton presidency, Mr. Geithner worked closely with Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers to shape recommendations for I.M.F. policies. Last year, he managed the American role in the contentious and prolonged process of selecting a new managing director. 
The I.M.F. announced two other appointments today. Kenneth S. Rogoff of Harvard University was selected to be chief economist, succeeding Michael Mussa. Mr. Rogoff worked at the fund in the early 1980's and has also worked at the Federal Reserve.
Gerd Hausler, former chairman of Dresdner Bank's investment banking arm, was appointed to head a new capital markets department. Mr. Hausler, a German, is expected to help the fund monitor stock, bond and currency markets and to provide more coordination between the fund and private financial companies.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne O. Krueger also served at the World Bank in the Reagan years. (Stanford News Service via Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: City Budget Seeks More Money for Child Care, Housing and Orderly Elections 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
There is an extra serving of money intended to prevent -- or at least minimize -- chaos at the polls this year. The dollars are still there to follow up on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's promise to build more low-cost housing. And nearly 11,000 more city children will be able to get subsidized day care.
 These are among the details that surfaced as the City Council moved yesterday toward adopting a $39.7 billion budget, following up on the accord reached with the mayor on Wednesday afternoon. 
 Not all the news was so rosy, though. There were signs yesterday that the city might have difficulty winning approval in Albany for part of a $500 million tax cut plan. There was also a chorus of criticism, once again, from fiscal monitors who warned that generous spending in the 2002 budget could create problems for the next mayor.
"There are enough clouds on the horizon economically that it does not seem prudent to put the city's payroll at the highest level in 25 years," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. 
Inside City Hall, these concerns, at least for now, did not interfere with the pleasure of completing work on what will be the Giuliani administration's final budget. The first order of business yesterday was nothing too exalted: printing the voluminous budget document so that the City Council members could actually see the plan before voting on it. 
"In so many areas, this is a document that makes a difference in people's lives," Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said. "The budget is the most important law that we pass." 
The budget, which would go into effect July 1, changed little from the plan outlined by the mayor in April. Changes were few even through the last few days' squabbling between the Council and administration about what sounds like a lot of money -- a couple of hundred million dollars -- but is actually less than 1 percent of the overall spending.
The Council persuaded the mayor to restore about $180 million in various cuts, from libraries to parks and cultural programs. The package also includes a collection of new items that should, at least in theory, improve some New Yorkers' lives.
There is enough city, state and federal money to add 10,618 subsidized child-care slots, a 12 percent increase. About 25,000 people are already on a city waiting list for child care vouchers. 
The city's investment in low- and moderate-priced housing will increase, by the administration's count, by about 25 percent in the coming year, with an extra 2,850 apartments or homes built or renovated as part of the mayor's housing initiative.
Mr. Giuliani said earlier this year that he would accept the extra city spending only if he won Council approval for changes in the city building code and in the regulation of the construction industry that would reduce the cost of building housing. He failed to win those concessions, but the money remained.
The budget also includes about $1.7 million extra for the Board of Elections, so it can try to prevent gridlock during the municipal elections this year. A call center would be set up to answer voters' questions on days when the polls are open. Extra mechanics would be hired to repair the city's aging voting machines. Interpreters who speak Korean and Chinese would be hired. And if legislation pending in Albany passes, pay for the nearly 30,000 poll workers will be increased, to a base wage of $250 for a day's work. 
Even with this extra spending, the administration expects to end the 2002 fiscal year with at least a $545 million surplus. The figure that concerns the fiscal monitors is a $2.7 billion deficit projected for the 2003 fiscal year, a number they consider dangerously high but that the Giuliani administration said can be taken care of without hardship.
On the revenue side, the final value of the tax cut package is still somewhat undecided. The small reduction in the city's personal income tax is assured, saving the average taxpayer $49 a year. About 3,000 businesses in Manhattan should no longer have to pay a city tax on their rent. Those two items constitute $205 million of the $500 million tax cut package, but all the rest needs Albany approval.
A tax credit for parents with children in child care and the elimination of the city sales tax on clothing may not be approved in Albany, because they will be part of a legislative bill that also includes the proposed elimination of a $2 fee on hotel rooms, a measure that the Assembly has opposed.
"The Assembly Democratic conference rejected a similar proposal last year, and there is no indication they have changed their position," Speaker Sheldon Silver said through a spokesman yesterday.
Adam L. Barsky, the director of the City Office of Management and Budget, said he remained hopeful that the tax plan would win full approval.
"This is not an election year for the Assembly, so maybe they will be more willing to back it," Mr. Barsky said. "And if it doesn't, we will find other taxes to cut. So we are not backing off."

HEADLINE: A Progressive Past 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your June 2 news article about the establishment of a "living wage" in New York City reminds us that this city used to be the nation's leader in terms of progressive social policy experiments. Indeed, in 1961, Mayor Robert F. Wagner signed the first such "living wage" law in the land, requiring city contractors to pay their workers no less than $1.50 per hour at a time when the minimum wage for most workers was just $1 per hour. 
 The current movement for a living wage has unified an unusually robust coalition of community, labor, nonprofit, religious and business leaders. Passage of this law will re-assert New York's historic role as a city where the nonwealthy also enjoy the fruits of our economy.

DAN CANTOR
Executive Director
Working Families Party
Brooklyn, June 5, 2001

PERSON: Henry Michel 

HEADLINE: Henry Michel, 76, Civil Engineer And Leader in Building Industry 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Henry Ludwig Michel, a globe-trotting civil engineer with a 50-year career that made him a leader in the construction industry, died on May 23 at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 76.
 The apparent cause was a heart attack, his family said. 
 Mr. Michel was chairman emeritus and a former president of Parsons Brinckerhoff, a Manhattan construction and consulting firm. He retired in 1994, after almost 30 years with the company, but he kept in close touch with it and the industry.
The firm, now 116 years old, designed the original IRT subway line in New York City. Mr. Michel oversaw the firm's work on more recent large-scale transportation projects, like Atlanta's rapid transit system, the first Caracas Metro line in Venezuela and the transit system of Taipei, Taiwan.
He was a native of Frankfurt am Main, Germany, and a 1949 civil-engineering graduate of Columbia University. Early in his career, he took part in a project designed to upgrade British fighter-bomber bases to NATO standards.
From England, he moved to Rome and started an engineering company that became a contractor at sites in Iran, Iraq, Kenya, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Tunisia. He helped develop the University of Baghdad, the Nigerian Parliament in Lagos, Tunis University and the World Health Organization headquarters in Geneva.
He returned to New York in 1965 and joined Parsons Brinckerhoff. He was made a partner in 1969 and, in 1975, led the traditional partnership's reorganization into an employee-owned corporation. He was its first president and chief executive and became chairman in 1990.
During his tenure, the firm went thoroughly international, with six offices overseas, and its work force grew to 4,000 from 500 employees. After stepping down as chairman, he continued to travel widely abroad on its behalf.
He also joined a new trouble-shooting venture, Global Construction Solutions, in Princeton, N.J. It brought together retired top industry executives and academics to advise companies facing problems in their foreign operations.
Similarly, he became a co-owner of Pegasus Consulting, also of Princeton, in which he teamed with two M.I.T. professors and a risk-management firm, among others. Pegasus provides assessments of political, social, economic and assorted other realities a company should be aware of before it invests in big overseas projects.
Mr. Michel was a founding member and former president of the Civil Engineering Research Foundation. He lectured at M.I.T., Columbia and other schools and was the recipient of many honors, including Columbia's Alumni Federation Medal and the Egleston Medal for distinguished engineering achievement.
Mr. Michel is survived by his wife of 57 years, Mary Elizabeth Strolis Michel; two daughters, Eve M. Milanese and Ann M. Wilde, both of Manhattan; a brother, Frank, of Dover, Mass.; and a granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Catching the Wave; 
Surfware Makers Rush to Cash In On a Growing Trend

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
From his salt-scented perch along the Atlantic Ocean in Narragansett, R.I., Tom Hogan has had a front-row seat for every surfing trend in the last 20 years. Mr. Hogan owns a surf shop called Warm Winds, where he sells boards, wax, sunscreen and surfer clothing. Especially, these days, the clothing. 
 In the last couple of years, he says, there has practically been a stampede into the store, particularly for women's and children's clothing. And customers want specific brands -- as in "Dude, where're my Hurley shorts?" Surfing's popularity has climbed recently, but the surfwear craze has taken off even faster, with a number of companies paddling hard to cash in, whether the shopper surfs or not. 
 To be sure, the trend has been pushed and pulled to try to make sales regardless of season and geography. Across the retail business, sales have slowed with the dips in the economy, and surfwear has another worry: how long the trend can last in a world of constantly shifting style, led by notoriously fickle teenagers. The hotter brands tend to be newer labels, like Hurley International, Volcom and Stussy, which emphasize a style somewhere between surfer and skateboarder. Some surfwear companies are adding clothes designed for skateboarders, on the theory that anyone can skateboard -- as long as there's a pavement nearby. 
Surfwear can range from bikinis printed with multiple hibiscus to fleece pullovers in drab winter-seascape colors. There are boardshorts -- those lace-up baggies mainly identified with surfers -- and long pants, suitable for the casual office. Accessories abound, like Pacific Sunwear's Venus zippered wallet, selling for $16, and Roxy's lines of makeup, jewelry and shoes.
"We used to have to search out women's wear," Mr. Hogan said. "Now we can get what people want from Billabong, Point Concepcion, Quiksilver, Rusty and companies like that." There are also plenty of clothes for young girls, led by Quiksilver's Roxy line, which started to build up steam five years ago. And in surfwear, it seems, there is an endless summer, or at least a full calendar's worth of sales. Mr. Hogan carries sweaters and other heavy clothes made by the same companies that issue wet suits, boardshorts and breezy cotton dresses. 
"The whole look and the image and the lifestyle that goes along with it are very popular," Mr. Hogan noted, "and people don't make any bones about spending for it."
While surfing itself is mainly confined to California, Florida and pockets of the Northeast, and surfwear sales are higher there, the clothes also turn up in the landlocked reaches of Ohio, Illinois and Minnesota. Department stores like Nordstrom's and Macy's, which is owned by Federated Department Stores, carry it. Big merchandisers like the Gap, Children's Place and Abercrombie & Fitch have generated their own versions of it. Mail-order icons like L. L. Bean and Lands' End sell it, as do mall-based chains like Pacific Sunwear and tourist destinations like the Typhoon Lagoon at Disney World. And next spring, there will be something of a surfwear milestone: the first Surf Expo dedicated to back-to-school shopping. 
Karen Bizer, a Manhattan mother of 9-year-old twins, shops for shorts and other surfwear made by Billabong and Quiksilver at Marsha D. D., a store on the Upper East Side. She was urged to buy the clothes by her children, she said, who liked them for their colors, comfort and distinctive style. "On some level, they have an innate appeal," she said. "They didn't know they were tied to surfing." 
Many of the purchases are made by the increasingly financially liberated teenager, who does not want to wear any old pair of shorts or T-shirt. 
"They are looking for the hot brands, and the hot brands obviously are the authentic brands," said Jim White, head of investor relations for Pacific Sunwear, a publicly traded company based in Anaheim, Calif.
Authentic can mean many things to many people. While Pacific Sunwear, with 500 stores considered responsible for taking surfwear to the masses, has had success with its store brands as well, such success is not easy to come by. Earlier this year, the company's sales suffered when it brought out what analysts call "the wrong pants" for its men's collection. Both Pacific Sunwear and Quiksilver have had wobbly sales as the economy cooled this spring. Quiksilver's share price closed yesterday at $24.55, down 15.7 percent from its 52-week high, and Pacific Sunwear's shares have dropped 41.6 percent since hitting a high in February of $35.875, closing yesterday at $20.95. 
But analysts say the trend remains strong. Fall orders from surf shops rose 20 percent this year, according to one analyst's survey. One reason is that surfing is having a mini-renaissance. Wet-suit sales, a key indicator, grew to 700,000 last year in the United States, up from 400,000 in 1992, according to the Surf Industry Manufacturers' Association, a California-based trade group.
Some of the growth is fueled by the rising number of women taking up surfing. Five or six years ago, women made up just 5 percent of surfers; now they account for 15 percent, said Michael Kingsbury, whose Huntington Beach, Calif., company represents amateur champions like Holly Beck. Companies like Quiksilver, one of the largest makers of the clothing, have rushed to sponsor champion female surfers who some consider more appealing than their male counterparts. One surfer, Lisa Anderson, had extra appeal to working mothers, since she traveled to various surfing competitions all over the world with both her surfboard and her child. 
"The women are very marketable," said Mr. Kingsbury, who also serves as spokesman for the trade group. "The guys tend to be spoiled and pampered. The women have had to struggle to get their contracts, and they are more outgoing, more articulate." 
Quiksilver has not wasted any time getting on that bandwagon. The company's Roxy division sponsors surf camps, contests and professional female surfers to both market and develop its clothing, said Dana Dartez, Roxy's design director. "I hang out at the high schools, the lunch places, the shopping malls and the surf shops," she said. "I try to be a sponge and see what they want." 
The interest in surfwear "is very much tied in to what's going on socially and politically," said Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a Manhattan consulting firm. "When we got richer and better and could be more cool about things, all of a sudden everybody could relax a little. You started to see slip dresses, and mules, and surfwear." 
For others, it is a constantly recurring summer theme. "You will see the beach and surf lifestyle almost every summer in our collection," said Rebecca Weill, a spokeswoman for the Gap. "We've got a graphic T-shirt this year with dolphins on it. To me, that is surfwear." 
Some say the bigger retailers have difficulty with the concept, possibly because surfwear's adherents are quick to sense whether something is "authentic." Last year, the Gap and its Old Navy division ran into trouble with their surfwear, said Jeffrey Klinefelter, an analyst for US Bancorp Piper Jaffray. "There wasn't enough of a mass appeal for nonauthentic surf products," he said. 
The look definitely does not appeal to everyone. In focus groups of New York area teenagers, a cultural divide emerged. "What we saw was that for the black kids, surfwear is totally irrelevant," said Faye I. Landes, who covers retail for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "And the white kids said that Quiksilver is what kids wear in California." 
Still, even small designers say they find a following, sometimes in unexpected places. Izzy Tihanyi, a 29-year-old surfer, started the Surf Diva surf school in La Jolla, Calif., five years ago to teach other women how to enjoy the sport. Many surf schools were "all about the testosterone challenge against the ocean, and that's not how women like to learn," she said. 
Along the way, she and her twin sister, Caroline, brought out a clothing line decorated with the Surf Diva logo. The line includes T-shirts, sweatshirts and rash guards -- lightweight nylon shirts. The rash guards come in batik prints and a snakeskin pattern, along with other colors. 
Orders have streamed in to the company's Web site from all over the country -- not just from surfers. "Some women are even wearing them out to clubs," Ms. Tihanyi said. "We're getting orders from Kansas." 
At Quiksilver, where sales have soared from $193 million in 1996 to $516 million last year, surfer style is seen as extending well beyond the beach. "We are an attitude," said Greg Ziegler, the Huntington Beach company's executive vice president for operations. "People enjoy getting outdoors, being in the sunshine, being active and living life. The clothes are a reflection of that attitude."
Within the last year, Quiksilver has expanded into golf apparel, come up with a new brand for post-college-age women and begun aggressively marketing a line named for Tony Hawk, a professional skateboarding star, which seeks to merge the worlds of surfing and skating -- many teenagers say they do both -- and snowboarding as well. At a store opening last fall in the Garden State Plaza mall in Paramus, N.J., thousands of teenagers turned out to see Mr. Hawk. 
It is hard to explain why other water-based life styles have not fueled fashion trends. No one has tried to mass-market Michigan lake-cottage clothes, for example, or Mississippi Delta resortwear. But Mr. Ziegler, who grew up in Indiana, says there is still a huge untapped market for surfwear in the heartland. 
"The challenge has always been, how do you get into that Midwestern kid's lifestyle?" he said. "Is it through Rolling Stone? Or MTV? We have had a big increase in those areas, but it's not anywhere near the levels we deal with on the coastal areas." 
What is considered "ripping" -- surfer talk for "great" -- in one place does not necessarily play elsewhere. Huntington Surf and Sport, a shop in Huntington Beach, opened a branch recently in Osaka, Japan, filled with racks of clothes from Stussy and Volcom as well as the store's private label. While tastes in Japan lag behind those in California by a year or so -- fluorescent T-shirts are still selling well in Osaka, but would be considered so last year in Huntington Beach -- both markets seek the latest and most surfer-oriented stuff. 
"It is very hard to come out with a new line and have it be successful," said the company's creative director, Dean Bradley. "The kids know what has been around and what supports the sport at its core." 
Marketing the surf look beyond its basic constituency is tricky. "You can't be some mainstream label that decides to shift its distribution toward this channel," said Mitchel Kummetz, a specialty retail analyst for A. G. Edwards & Sons. "A lot of these companies are owned or managed by former professional surfers."
Not all waves are meant to be shared, as any surf instructor will confirm, and no wave lasts forever.

PERSON: Victor Paz Estenssoro 

HEADLINE: Victor Paz Estenssoro, 93, 4-Time Bolivia Leader, Dies 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 8 

 BODY:
Victor Paz Estenssoro, who was president of Bolivia four times in a career that he began as a moderate leftist and ended as a conservative, and who went into exile three times, died on Thursday. He was 93.
 News service reports said Mr. Paz Estenssoro died where he was born, in Tarija, of complications from the amputation of his right leg because of circulatory problems. 
 Mr. Paz Estenssoro is best remembered for being a leader of a revolution in 1952, the defining political event in modern Bolivian history. He decreed a thorough land redistribution, nationalization of the mining industry and universal suffrage, including the Indian majority. Radical labor unions have been major figures in Bolivian politics since then.
Mr. Paz Estenssoro was born on Oct. 2, 1907, into a family of landowners in the southern wine region. He traveled to La Paz, the capital, planning to study law. But he specialized in economics and spent much of career as an economics adviser and professor.
In 1942, he helped found the Revolutionary Nationalist Movement, at first a motley coalition of radical urban professionals and military rightists, that remains an important center-left party.
He won a presidential election in 1951. But Congress handed over power to a military junta. After brief fighting in 1952 in La Paz and other cities, Mr. Paz Estenssoro returned from exile in Argentina and was sworn in as president. He, in turn, exiled many of his opponents.
The Eisenhower administration embraced the revolution as an alternative to Communism, and aid from Washington flowed. But hyperinflation eroded Mr. Paz Estenssoro's support among the middle class. In the election of 1956, he was replaced as president by another leader of his party. But he returned to office in 1960, and again in 1964. His third term was cut short after three months by a military coup.
Mr. Paz Estenssoro, who was ambassador to Britain and the Netherlands, was known as a reclusive man with simple tastes. He took part in few public events and left much of the work to his ministers, especially in his final term.
But Mr. Paz Estenssoro, nicknamed the Old Fox, was also known for toughness. One of many popular anecdotes began in an early term, when the leader of a mining union surprised Mr. Paz Estenssoro at a worker protest by stuffing a stick of dynamite in his belt and threatening to light it. "If you want to die, light it and we'll go together," Mr. Paz Estenssoro reportedly said. The miner backed down, and the uprising was over.
Mr. Paz Estenssoro was re-elected for a fourth time, in 1985, at age 77, when Bolivians turned to him at a time of economic and political turmoil made notable by an annual inflation rate of more than 25,000 percent. Mr. Paz Estenssoro then reversed some of the changes of his first presidency, privatizing the mines, cutting government deficits, overhauling tax collection, lifting price supports for food and floating the currency at a single unified rate. The inflation rate plummeted. 
He also drew closer to the United States in efforts to halt a growing cocaine industry, but he favored crop substitution and rural development over military efforts 
When tin prices collapsed, miners marched on La Paz in 1986, and Mr. Paz Estenssoro responded with authoritarian measures. He declared a state of siege, arrested union leaders and ordered the army to block the march. He was able to complete his term in 1989, the first elected leader to do so in a quarter-century.
Mr. Paz Estenssoro was married twice and had five children.

HEADLINE: Europe Union's Dreams Meet Electoral Reality 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 8 

 BODY:
The European Union's lofty project to embrace the formerly Communist nations of Central Europe, a project that would double the size of "Europe" as people now think of it, collided with a serious new obstacle put up today by Irish voters.
 In a shock to leaders across Europe, Irish voters resoundingly rejected a treaty that would redistribute power within the European Union and is intended to prevent paralysis if its membership climbs from 15 to as many as 27 countries. 
 Though Ireland has an economy that is smaller than many American cities, today's unexpected "no" vote threatened to tangle the European Union's entire effort to get its house in order in time for the new arrivals.
"We are very disappointed," said Goran Persson, Sweden's prime minister and the leader who currently holds the rotating presidency of the European Union. 
In rushed consultations by telephone this evening with Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, Mr. Persson suggested that Irish leaders would organize a second vote on the rejected measure, the Treaty of Nice.
But Mr. Persson, who issued a joint statement with the president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, quickly found himself struggling between the need to respect a democratic vote and the need to preserve an agreement that was only reached after months of closed-door power struggles.
While noting that "we fully respect the outcome of this democratic process," Mr. Persson and Mr. Prodi quickly added that they wanted to win approval for the treaty "without changing the substance" of it in the process. 
The democracy predicament is not new. When a top official at the European Commission casually suggested last year that German leaders might want to consult voters on the subject of enlargement, German government leaders were horrified at the thought of losing control over the process and vehemently denounced the idea.
The stakes are high, because leaders on both sides of the old East-West divide are convinced that the enlargement talks are beyond the point of no return. European leaders first dangled the prospect of membership nearly 11 years ago, when the old Communist governments were falling. Mainly because of those promises, countries like Poland, Hungary and even Slovakia have put themselves through wrenching reforms and are now in concrete negotiations for membership. In all, 12 countries have been accepted as potential candidates for membership, and the most advanced countries like Poland and Hungary are hoping to become members by 2005.
The Irish vote will probably not derail the process, but it could make it much more difficult. The Treaty of Nice must be ratified by all 15 nations in the European Union, but Ireland is the only country that has decided to ratify the treaty by means of a popular referendum.
Today's vote leaves European leaders with no easy options. The first would be to make changes in the treaty in a way that satisfies Irish voters, but does not unravel the delicate bargains that were worked out last year.
The other option is to have the second vote in Ireland, this time paving the way with a concerted promotional campaign. All three of Ireland's major parties support the treaty, and Ireland has generally been one of the most enthusiastic members of the European Union.
At its heart, the Treaty of Nice deals with the excruciatingly sensitive issue of power-sharing and sovereignty. To make decision-making less unwieldy with a much bigger membership, it would introduce qualified majority voting in which bigger countries would have more votes than smaller ones. It would also reform the distribution of top executive posts in the European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union, and smaller countries would no longer have an automatic right to name the director of at least one department. 
European and Central European leaders quickly asserted that today's vote will not slow down the enlargement negotiations now under way. "If the majority would be against the Nice Treaty, it would not affect the enlargement process," said Gunther Verheugen, the European Commission's top official in charge of negotiations with candidate countries, as he awaited final results in the Irish elections. "We would continue with the same speed and the same quality," Mr. Verheugen said during a visit in Slovenia.
To be sure, the expansion process had already become more bogged down and tense in recent months. Germany and Austria, frightened about being flooded with immigrants, recently persuaded other member countries to insist on a "transition period" of up to seven years before Central European workers would receive an automatic right to live and work anywhere in the European Union. Polish leaders insist that is unacceptable, but they have dragged their feet on a number of reform measures and have sought their own transition period before Western Europeans can buy Polish land.
Malgorzata Alterman, a spokeswoman for Poland's mission to the European Commission in Brussels, said the Irish vote was a surprise but not a catastrophe. "It is a serious matter, a matter of concern," she said. "But the European Union has managed problems in the past and we are confident that this one can be solved."

HEADLINE: 10,000 Plead To Be Exempt From Blackouts 

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 8 

 BODY:
The jockeying has begun among California businesses desperate to avoid blackouts this summer.
 More than 10,000 requests for exemptions have poured into the state's Public Utilities Commission in recent days, as businesses -- from oil refiners to farmers to drug makers -- lobby for relief from the hundreds of hours of darkness that experts predict California will experience if the state's energy crisis worsens. 
 The commission has hired a consulting firm to help evaluate the applications. But few executives are likely to be satisfied with the results. 
"In a way, the whole process is scary, because what this is ultimately about is telling people no," said Carl Wood, the utilities commissioner in charge of the process. "I argued with a lot of people whether we should go down this road. It is going to be messy."
Already, about 40 percent of consumers and businesses are exempt from blackouts, because they are hooked up to the same portions of the electric grid that serve operations deemed essential to health and safety, like hospitals and fire stations.
That leaves regulators little room to maneuver. The demands of grid management mean the state needs to be free to cut the power of at least 50 percent of all users.
How to choose? One criterion the commission has rejected is economic impact. "Everyone has a case for that," Mr. Wood said. The commission will also not consider claims that blackouts would inconvenience companies or their customers.
Some businesses have turned elsewhere for relief. The California Senate passed a bill Thursday that would let Universal Studios and its theme park switch power providers, from the beleaguered Southern California Edison to the more reliable Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. 
Several months ago, the Public Utilities Commission said oil refineries would not be exempt from rotating blackouts, despite a recommendation otherwise from the state energy commission. Refiners have also asked the Legislature to intervene.
Last week, David J. O'Reilly, chairman and chief executive of the Chevron Corporation, sent a letter to Gov. Gray Davis warning him of the economic damage that would befall the state if oil refineries were not exempted. Gasoline prices, already as high as $2 a gallon here, could go higher, Chevron executives have said, and fuel for airplanes and machinery could be in short supply. 
On Thursday, Governor Davis sent a letter of his own to the utilities commission, requesting that the refiners get their waiver.
Everyone seems to be asking for favorable treatment these days. Pharmaceutical companies have complained that sudden power outages can play havoc with sensitive technical equipment that takes days to reset, slowing medical tests and trials on important drugs. Farmers in the Central Valley have said their crops will wither and animals die without the electricity to pump water. And that, they said, will raise prices at the grocery store.
"It reflects the reality that a reliable electric supply is an essential underpinning of modern society," Mr. Wood said of the exemption requests. 
It was the state's biggest industrial users of electricity -- including oil refiners and farmers -- who pushed hardest for deregulation in the mid-1990's, hungry for the lower prices they thought would result.
"The bottom line is deregulation did not work out the way people thought," said Jack Kyser, chief economist of the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation. "The issue used to be about high prices. Now it's about reliability."
The Public Utilities Commission has begun releasing the names of those seeking relief -- from dentists to catering companies, pet hospitals to beauty salons, and churches, as well. The consulting firm will review the applications, and it may be early August, when summer is half over, before any exemptions are granted.
Mr. Wood said the requests being submitted "are all going to have good stories."
"All we are talking about is degrees," he said.

HEADLINE: Software Failure Halts Big Board Trading for Over an Hour 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
A failed software upgrade left investors unable to trade shares on the New York Stock Exchange for nearly an hour and a half yesterday morning.
 The shutdown, the second the exchange has suffered in three years, prevented many stocks from opening for trading. As a result, the exchange shut its trading floor at 10:10 a.m. Trading resumed in most stocks by 11:35 a.m., but shares in the most severely affected companies, including I.B.M. and Verizon Communications, did not open until the afternoon. 
 The Nasdaq, the other major United States market, remained open during the New York exchange's trading halt. But the shutdown made calculating market indexes like the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index impossible. 
When trading resumed, stocks on the exchange dropped broadly. The Dow Jones average, which mostly comprises exchange-traded companies, lost 100 points, or almost 1 percent of its value, in less than an hour. But the Nasdaq composite index was also down yesterday, and traders said the Big Board's sell-off was unrelated to the trading halt.
Traders scrambled to make up for the halt during the afternoon, but only about 726 million shares changed hands on the Big Board for the day, down from 1 billion one week ago. It was the slowest day on the exchange since Dec. 23.
The failed upgrade was part of the system that electronically directs orders from securities firms to the exchange. While the Big Board still has a trading floor and human specialists who match buyers and sellers, many smaller orders are forwarded to the exchange and matched automatically by computer.
"It was the equivalent of a drawbridge remaining up," said Richard Grasso, chairman of the Big Board, at a news conference yesterday to discuss the problem. Mr. Grasso said the exchange did not yet know why the upgrade had failed. "We've got to do a very comprehensive diagnostic," he said.
But Mr. Grasso said the problem was the fault of the exchange, not the hardware or software companies that sell equipment to the Big Board. "The responsibility for what happened today is right here," he said. "It happens to be my turn in the barrel."
The Securities and Exchange Commission said it would review the problems at the exchange after the Big Board analyzed the reasons for the failure.
The shutdown is embarrassing for the Big Board, which has a reputation for reliability and is the world's largest and most important stock market. The exchange has 2,600 companies with a total market value of $16 trillion. That figure is four times the market value of either the Nasdaq or the Tokyo Stock Exchange, its closest competitors.
Mr. Grasso said the exchange could have continued some trading using backup systems but had shut completely to be fair to individual investors. Larger investors like mutual funds sometimes go outside the exchange into regional markets like the Cincinnati Stock Exchange to route their trades of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange. By shutting down completely, the exchange caused the regional markets to halt their trading as well.
The Big Board's halt also crimped fast-growing electronic trading networks like Island ECN and Instinet. Those networks, which directly match buyers and sellers for both New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq stocks, remained open during the exchange's shutdown. But because most investors are used to trading Big Board stocks through the exchange, relatively few trades were made through the electronic networks before trading reopened, even in big companies like Verizon and I.B.M.
"We do more business, not more market share but more business, when the New York Stock Exchange stays open," said Doug Atkin, the chief executive of Instinet, the largest electronic trading network.
Once they learned what was happening, traders took the shutdown in stride, said Andrew Goldman, a spokesman for Island.
"There was initial confusion that folks weren't clear who was up and who was down," Mr. Goldman said. "Folks were trying to sort their way through what was going on in a very reasonable way."
Fridays during the summer are typically low-volume trading days in New York in any case, because many big investors and traders leave early to travel to summer homes.
Also, no major economic reports were released yesterday.
"Fortunately, it was a Friday," said Ayako Tsuboya, a trader at Daiwa Securities America. Volume is "really, really light."
David Colker, the chief executive of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, said the New York exchange was known for its expertise in information technology. But problems like yesterday's are always possible because the software that runs stock exchanges is incredibly complex, Mr. Colker said.
"You test this stuff for months, and there's always the risk when you put it in that you've missed something," he said.

HEADLINE: Former I.R.S. Chiefs Back Tax Haven Crackdown 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Seven former commissioners of the Internal Revenue Service urged Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill yesterday to withdraw his opposition to a proposed crackdown on Caribbean nations and others that are considered tax havens.
 A letter to Mr. O'Neill from the former commissioners preceded a meeting on the subject on Monday in Paris by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, whose 30 members are developed nations including the United States. 
 The organization, which has helped draft international polices on trade and governance, has already persuaded nine countries that it calls tax havens to cooperate with criminal tax investigations and to ease some of their bank-secrecy laws. But many of the countries it regards as offenders, including Panama and Turks and Caicos, have stiffened their opposition since Mr. O'Neill issued a statement on May 10 saying the Bush administration would not support an overly broad effort to impose sanctions on tax havens. 
Supporters of the initiative said that tax havens assisted tax cheats and thereby forced honest people and businesses to pay higher taxes. They also argue that tax havens distort trade, giving multinational corporations an advantage over domestic, and usually smaller, competitors.
But opponents, including many of the 35 nations that the international organization has listed as havens, say they have a right to sovereignty over tax policy and call the proposed crackdown an attempt to create a global tax cartel to maintain high tax rates in Europe, Japan, the United States and other industrial nations. The Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization in Washington, has also raised the specter of tax disclosures being used by governments to punish some of their own citizens.
In his statement in May, Mr. O'Neill said he was "troubled that low tax rates are somehow suspect" and he expressed concern about "potentially unfair treatment" of some countries. The Bush administration favors tax competition between nations, he said, and "it will not participate in any initiative to harmonize world tax systems."
While acknowledging that the administration "cannot turn a blind eye toward cheating in any form," he made clear that his preference was to pursue suspected tax criminals individually, then through bilateral treaties and only then through multinational organizations.
The bipartisan group of tax commissioners suggested that Mr. O'Neill was misinformed about the purpose of the campaign. The commissioners wrote that contrary to Mr. O'Neill's statement, the project explicitly rejects harmonizing tax codes and said that the countries had such diverse systems that any effort to unify tax rates would not work.
They then warned that "with increasing globalization and the use of the Internet, U.S. taxpayers seeking to evade U.S. taxes will have an increasing ability to transfer assets to tax havens further afield."
"These tax havens," the letter said, "are even less likely to bend to U.S. unilateral pressure. Conversely, they may well cooperate where 30 O.E.C.D. countries, some of which have close historical ties in addition to geographical proximity, act in concert." 
Urging a quick change in the Bush administration's stance, they stated that "we have never been closer to cracking down on tax abuse through the use of tax havens and that is especially important to the United States." 
The Democratic commissioners are Sheldon S. Cohen, Mortimer M. Caplin, Jerome Kurtz and Margaret M. Richardson, and the Republicans are Donald C. Alexander, Randolph W. Thrower and Johnnie M. Walters. The seven served in the Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter and Clinton administrations. 
Tara Bradshaw, a spokeswoman for Mr. O'Neill, said yesterday that the administration is "working to concentrate the project so that its work product improves our ability to enforce the U.S. tax laws." She said that Mr. O'Neill had been "very clear that he favored a more effective project" focused on limited disclosures in cases of suspected tax cheating without interfering with the tax practices of sovereign nations. The secretary, she added, is sending two officials to the meeting in Paris to "better focus the project."
