HEADLINE: A Hasidic Village Gets a Lesson In Bare-Knuckled Politicking 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: KIRYAS JOEL, N.Y., June 7 

 BODY:
When this Hasidic village was incorporated by the ultra-orthodox Satmars in 1977, its founding fathers hoped they would be able to replicate the intensely religious and insular enclave they had fashioned for themselves in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. And to a large degree, they have succeeded, as manifested by the dozens of shuls and the predominance of Yiddish spoken on the streets.
 But at least one ingredient of mainstream America has seeped into Kiryas Joel: suburban politics. 
 On Wednesday, this village of 13,000 in Orange County staged its first-ever contested elections for local office, as a small group of mavericks challenged the founding fathers. But far from the landslide some had predicted early in the campaign, the election turned out to be a very competitive affair that induced more than 90 percent of eligible voters to cast ballots. It followed a bare-knuckles campaign filled with inflammatory rhetoric, legal scuffles over voter eligibility and accusations of voter fraud and intimidation. 
In the end, the establishment slate, led by the mayor, Abraham Wieder, prevailed with roughly 57 percent of the vote. But the fact that there even was a contest suggests that the dissident faction, led by Mendel Schwimmer, promises to be a future electoral force. And both sides' emphasis on typical suburban issues like housing, public services, good government and the economy -- not religion, not Williamsburg -- underscores the extent to which this fast-changing, fast-growing community has evolved politically.
"Whether they like or not, and much as they may claim to the contrary, the larger society's influence has reached into the Satmar community as it does with everyone else," said William Helmreich, professor of sociology and Judaic studies at the City University of New York. 
"The kind of suburban politics that occurs everywhere else occurs in their community, too," Professor Helmreich said.
For years, local elections in this village 45 miles north of New York City were regarded as mere formalities, since no one dared to oppose the leadership's hand-picked slate, Professor Helmreich said. And though there was a small but vocal group of self-described dissidents here who opposed the village's religious and political leadership, they complained constantly of being intimidated. To speak out, they claimed, would be to risk their jobs, their connections, everything, said Joseph Waldman, the village's most outspoken dissident.
But this year, the dissidents, led by Mr. Schwimmer, a village trustee since 1990, decided to break with tradition and challenge Mr. Wieder, who was been near the nexus of power here since 1984. One reason, Mr. Waldman said, was fatigue from the village's protracted legal battle over the separate public school district it operates for its disabled children. But a far more important one, he said, was anger over the way Mr. Wieder had handled a new, $10 million public housing project.
Affordable housing is a crucial issue in Kiryas Joel, where 63 percent of the residents live below the poverty line, where the population grew by 76 percent in the 1990's, and where nearly half the families live in households with seven or more people, said Samuel C. Heilman, Harold Proshansky Professor of Jewish Studies and Sociology at CUNY.
"They are interested in their local issues, and that's very different from what's happening in Williamsburg," Professor Heilman said. 
And in this instance, the village had selected families for the 48-unit Atzei Timurim housing project through a lottery system conducted by an independent consulting firm. Of the 48 families selected, Mr. Waldman said, about half were generally considered dissidents. But to date, the units have been empty for more for than a year, and critics have accused Mr. Wieder's administration of preventing the families from moving in.
During a campaign that blanketed the 1.1-square-mile village with Yiddish posters, Mr. Wieder, together with two running mates, ran under the banner of "Experience and Results," while Mr. Schwimmer's team ran under the name "People Together in Kiryas Joel."
Those who supported Mr. Schwimmer said that they wanted a reformer who would push for more affordable housing and more open government, and who would end what they said were hardball tactics and discriminatory practices.
One group of synagogue students, for instance, were huddled near a Winnebago covered by the banner "Voter's Investigation Team;" it was the place for people to report voting irregularities.
"We won it, and they stole it," said Mr. Waldman, who still had the rat-a-tat rhetoric of the campaign on his lips. "They are dividers, and we are the uniters."
Most supporters of Mr. Wieder cited his accomplishments, like a new health center and a sewage treatment plant, and his good relationship with Rabbi Aaron Teitelbaum, the village's religious leader.
"I think his experience was very great," said David Greenfeld, a school manager at the United Talmudical Academy. "He's finished what he promised."
As Mr. Greenfeld spoke with two visitors at the Kiryas Joel shopping center, he was surrounded by more than a dozen young men.Unprompted, the young men brought out campaign brochures with photos of Mr. Wieder with Bill Clinton, Gov. George E. Pataki, Senator Trent Lott and others. Then they began to conduct their own instant day-after exit poll.
"Abe Wieder?" they would ask passers-by.
"Of course," people would reply.
"You see?" one young student said, turning to a visitor. "Abe Wieder!" Then, in a jab at the opposition, he said: "All the big synagogues, all the big businesses is us. They have nothing."

HEADLINE: Demand Is Rising for Members of the Clergy as Fewer Answer the Calling 

BYLINE:  By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Faith Presbyterian Church, a 420-member congregation in a suburban neighborhood of Indianapolis, spent 16 months unsuccessfully seeking a new associate pastor. The pastor, the Rev. Glen Bell, made several calls himself, including one to a promising senior at a seminary 300 miles away.
 "He told me I was the 12th church that had contacted him," said Mr. Bell, who added that seminaries often listed such students on their Web sites. 
 The church gave up this spring and split the job into four part-time positions, to be filled by a retired minister, a pastoral counselor and two lay people. 
For a number of other congregations in the 2.6 million-member Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), searching for a minister has become a daunting prospect. In May, 1,450 congregations were advertising vacancies, for which only 1,277 members of the clergy were available, said Marcia Myers, associate director of churchwide personnel services for the denomination. In January 1994, by contrast, 944 Presbyterian congregations seeking pastors or associate pastors could choose from 1,697 candidates, Ms. Myers said. 
Until recently, most mainline Protestant denominations as well as Jewish Reform and Conservative organizations seemed to be doing fine in attracting new clergy, in contrast to the Roman Catholic Church, which has faced a deepening shortage of priests for many years, as seminary enrollments have plunged and priests have resigned, often to marry. Protestants and Jews had little trouble filling all but the most remote pulpits, and some groups even had more members of the clergy than jobs, as their memberships stagnated. 
But a number of churches and synagogues are finding that filling vacancies takes much longer than it once did, and the pool of candidates has shrunk. Some never find the leaders they seek.
For Protestant denominations, religion officials say, the problem's roots include the attraction of more lucrative careers in what long was a booming economy, a wide variety of choices in religious life for seminary graduates and escalating retirements from a demanding job in which the pay is often modest and the hours are long. 
In addition, the average age of seminarians has risen, so there are fewer single people mobile enough and unencumbered by educational debt to take over smaller, financially strained congregations.
The denominations affected have not grown as many evangelical churches have, and many of those evangelical churches have lately undertaken efforts to train lay people to serve as pastors, rather than relying on traditional seminary graduates.
A part of the problem among mainline Protestants is that diminishing membership within the larger denominations has meant that a growing number of smaller churches, in rural and inner-city areas, wind up with little money to pay a pastor.
One of the closest statistical analyses of the problem within one denomination was published last year by the 5.1 million-member Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. The church, the nation's largest Lutheran body, found that the proportion of small congregations without permanent pastors (those with 175 or fewer baptized members) rose to 39 percent from 27 percent between 1990 and 1999.
During the same period, the overall number of pastors within the church declined.
The Rev. A. Craig Settlage, an official with the church's Division of Ministry, said some rural synods, or jurisdictions, were critically short of newly minted seminary graduates -- or "first-call" pastors -- to serve small congregations. But some metropolitan areas may have a surplus of clergy.
Presbyterian officials say the shortage strikes hardest among churches seeking associate pastors and ministers for young people.
Paradoxically, Ms. Myers said, the denomination did not have a shortage of people who had been ordained as ministers.
"It's a shortage of people who are willing to be pastors in particular kinds of situations," she said.
In California, demand for Presbyterian ministers has begun to outstrip supply, said the Rev. David Tomlinson, a vice president at San Francisco Theological Seminary. In May, the seminary conferred master of divinity degrees on 29 students, 19 of whom will be ordained as ministers.
"Probably every one of those 19 could get three offers today" from churches seeking a pastor or associate pastor, Mr. Tomlinson said.
Five years ago, he said, a graduate might wait months for an offer.
Nationally, the number of students in masters of divinity programs has remained steady, according to the Association of Theological Schools. But some denominational officials say they believe fewer people with those degrees are going into parish ministry.
Teresa Blythe, a 2000 graduate from San Francisco Theological Seminary, calls herself a lay minister who works as a spiritual director with individuals and groups.
"A lot of my friends in my graduating class were choosing not to go into pastor jobs," Ms. Blythe said. "People like myself are taking it outside the church."
That such a course is possible reflects public fascination with spiritual matters, rather than institutional religion, in which lay-led Bible study groups, various spiritually focused seminars and retreats, and an immense number of religiously themed books for the solitary "seeker" are available.
Officials of the two largest branches of Judaism, the Conservative and Reform movements, say they lack enough rabbis to go around. They believe that the strong economy of the 1990's lured young people into other professions. 
The problem also affects Orthodox Jews, at least those synagogues in Orthodox's modern wing, said Rabbi Steven Dworken, executive vice president of the Rabbinical Council of America. The problem has been most felt in smaller communities, Rabbi Dworken said.
"In mainstream Orthodoxy," he said, "we have taught our children and imparted the message all too well that you can be a Jew at home and in the marketplace."
"They went to Wall Street, they went to law school, they went to advertising," he said.
But the other causes the Reform and Conservative officials cite vary somewhat from those among Protestants. Rabbi Jerome Epstein, executive vice president of the United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism, said that among Conservative congregations, the problem was due to more demand for rabbis, "because more and more of our congregations are feeling the need for a second or third rabbi" to serve different groups within the congregations.
As a result, Rabbi Epstein said, 50 to 75 synagogues are without a rabbi or an assistant rabbi this year.
One of those is Aventura-Turnberry Jewish Center, a 1,400-family synagogue up the Florida coast from North Miami Beach. After enrollment in its day school shot up, the synagogue last year sought an assistant rabbi to work with younger families.
"Lo and behold, we found there's not a lot of people out there," Rabbi Barry Konovitch said. "We're not doing the interviewing -- the people who are available, they're interviewing us."
With the Reform movement, leaders of the rabbinical and synagogue organizations became so concerned that they established a task force to examine the issue.
"If you travel around the country," said Robert Heller, an antitrust lawyer who is its chairman, "you hear the same stories over and over: 'We need a new cantor, we need a new rabbi.' "
Among Protestants, some experts say that talk of a clergy shortage should be kept in perspective, particularly compared with the shortage of Catholic priests.
Barbara Wheeler, president of Auburn Theological Seminary in New York, said the bigger cause for concern, among Protestants, was why seminaries had increasingly attracted older, second-career students.
A recent study by Auburn found that the mean age of seminarians was 35, a decade older than men and women entering law school and medical school. Older students can bring professional experience, but they have fewer years to devote to church service. They may also be married and less able to move outside an urban area where a working spouse can find a job.
But amid the trend, the 8.2 million-member United Methodist Church has found a long-existing tool that has helped it get around its clergy shortage.
The number of seminarians annually ordained as Methodist ministers declined throughout the 1990's, said the Rev. Robert Kohler, an official with the denomination's Board of Higher Education and Ministry. But during the same period, Mr. Kohler said, the denomination increased the number of people serving as "local pastors," people who complete special, nonseminary study and are assigned to serve a congregation. In Alabama and West Virginia, local pastors now outnumber ordained clergy.
"If we didn't have that," Mr. Kohler said, "we'd be in crisis."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
AMERICAN AIRLINES ANDFLIGHT ATTENDANTS STILL AT ODDS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 American Airlines, a division of the AMR Corporation, and its flight attendants have failed to reach a labor accord after four days of talks, and federal mediators will consider asking President Bush to intervene to block a strike days before the busy Fourth of July holiday, the carrier said yesterday. The National Mediation Board convened talks in hopes of negotiating a contract before attendants are allowed to walk off their jobs at the carrier on July 1, the height of the summer travel season. 
The board recessed talks until June 20, and said it was awaiting an economic impact study from the Transportation Department. Such a study is required before the board would ask Mr. Bush to intervene and delay a strike up to 60 more days.

HEADLINE: U.S. FIGURES SHOW PRISON POPULATION IS NOW STABILIZING 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 8 

 BODY:
After growing explosively for three decades, the nation's prison population has begun to stabilize, according to new government figures.
 For the first time in years, the overcrowding that has plagued state prisons and local jails alike is beginning to ease, as a result of falling crime rates and a decade of new construction. 
 Through the middle of last year, the number of state prisoners grew by only 1.5 percent, the lowest annual increase in 29 years, according to figures recently compiled by the United States Department of Justice. In the three most populous states, the number of prisoners in California and New York actually fell last year, and the number in Texas grew by only half of 1 percent.
Nine other states -- including New Jersey -- also reported a decline, the largest number of states to do so in two decades. Connecticut's prison population grew 1.4 percent. 
Government officials and other experts in the field say there are several reasons for the slowing growth, but the most important is that the prison system is finally experiencing the benefits of the decline in crime rates that began in the mid-1990's.
Before the crime rates fell, many states had begun toughening their criminal justice systems, imposing longer minimum sentences for a wider spectrum of crimes and ending parole. The average sentence increased by 13 percent during the 90's, and with more prisoners staying behind bars longer, it took several years for the drop in crime to be reflected in the prison population numbers.
"The reason we saw those increasing numbers every year was because of the sentencing reforms undertaken by so many states," said Allen J. Beck, the chief of corrections statistics for the Justice Department, who compiled the new figures. "In the 90's, there was a much greater chance that violent offenders would be incarcerated, and would stay longer. But those reforms had their effect, and now we're finally starting to see the prison population stabilize."
The drop in crime was not directly related to the increased sentencing; a variety of studies have shown no relationship between the length of sentencing in a state and its crime rate. Rather, criminologists say, many of the tough sentences imposed earlier in the decade began to run their course at the same time as the crime rate continued to decline.
During that same period, many states with corrections systems that became overwhelmed by the new prisoners also began experimenting with alternative sentencing -- special drug courts and diversionary programs for drug users that are starting to have an effect on reducing inmate populations. By more closely supervising convicts on parole, states have kept many of them from returning.
"Forty percent of the people walking through our prison doors were parole violators, mostly who had relapsed into drug use," said Martin F. Horn, who was the secretary of corrections in Pennsylvania for six years until earlier this year.
"So we started a system that put them in an intensive treatment program inside prison for six months, then put them back on the street under close supervision, Mr. Horn said. "Now our prison population has been flat for three years, which we hadn't seen since before 1980."
In addition to California, New York and New Jersey, the other states that reported declines in prisoners were Alaska, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Ohio, Rhode Island and South Carolina.
State prisoners represent about 60 percent of all people incarcerated in the United States. The growth in the number of jail inmates -- usually people held for a year or less, representing 32 percent of those incarcerated -- has also been flat in the last two years, which is considered a more direct reflection of the drop in crime.
"Jails are the most immediate beneficiary of the crime decline, because their sentences are shorter," said Alfred Blumstein, a professor of criminology at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, who studies crime statistics. "Typically, at least half the people in jail are awaiting trial, and as the crime rates declined, trials can occur faster."
But the trend has not held true in the federal prison system, which grew by 11 percent last year, mostly due to mandatory drug sentencing and the federal takeover of prisoners from the District of Columbia. Federal prisons remain considerably more crowded, on average, than state prisons or local jails.
One reason for that is the boom in prison and local jail construction during the 1980's and 90's, which doubled the number of state prisons, though it was not matched at the federal level. Between 1990 and 2000, the number of state prisoners nationwide grew by 75 percent, to 1,242,962 from 708,393, corresponding to the rise in drug arrests, more vigilant policing and harsher sentences.
But prison construction in most states has kept pace and often exceeded the increase in prisoners, even though most prisons remain overcrowded. Justice Department figures show that the state prisons were operating at 115 percent of capacity in 1990, and at 109 percent of capacity in 1999, the latest year for which statistics are available.
Similarly, the number of local jail beds almost doubled during the 1990's, to 677,000. In 1990, jails were operating at 104 percent of capacity, but last year, that number dropped to 92 percent. Mr. Beck said that in the year ending last June, more jail beds were added than jail inmates.
Many states continue to make headlines because of overcrowded prisons and jails, mostly in cases where the state has not built new prisons as fast as elsewhere. New Jersey has the most crowded prison system, according to the Justice Department, at 143 percent of its capacity, and Illinois and Wisconsin are only a few percentage points behind. Other states, including Alabama, have allowed local jails to hold their excess prisoners, resulting in lawsuits over jail conditions and court orders to expand state capacity.
But nationally the crowding is diminishing, and experts predict it will become a much less serious problem in the coming decade as the number of prisoners stabilizes and prisons now under construction open. Several states added so many beds that they have an excess of prison capacity, and Texas and Virginia have made a lucrative business out of leasing their spare prison beds to more crowded states.
Ten percent of the inmates in Virginia's prisons are from out of state, and the state expects to receive more than $80 million this year for housing them. Several prisoners from Connecticut and New Mexico who were housed at Virginia's newest "supermax" prisons have filed lawsuits complaining about abusive conditions and racial discrimination at the new buildings, which restrict the movement of prisoners more sharply than in most prisons.
Marc Mauer, deputy director of the Sentencing Project, a nonprofit group that supports prisoners' rights, said he expected that questions regarding treatment of prisoners at new institutions would eventually overtake crowding as the principal concern of advocates.
"Crowding only tells you whether there are enough beds for all the inmates," Mr. Mauer said. "It doesn't tell you how many vocational or treatment programs there are, or what life is like inside the prisons 24 hours a day."
If the prison population continues to stabilize or diminish, it could have a substantial economic benefit to states and localities. State prisoners now cost an average of $23,000 a year to house, so the 65,810 prisoners added between 1998 and 1999 increased the nation's prison expenditures by about $1.5 billion. By contrast, the following year, only 18,558 prisoners were added, a difference of more than $1 billion. 
But prison-building remains popular with many politicians and voters, and new prisons often provide a boost to rural economies. Few people in the field expect building to stop.
"We're a long way from the point where crime is not a major political issue," said James Alan Fox, a professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University. "The political agenda is still heavily weighted towards punishment, and many states are much more willing to spend money on prison construction than on new schools."

HEADLINE: School Board In New Dispute On Test Scores 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The testing director for the New York City Board of Education accused a major testing company yesterday of miscalculating yet another set of scores, this time on a sixth-grade reading test in April 2000.
 Board officials said that because of the alleged error, about 60,000 students were given higher scores than they deserved on the test of 50 multiple-choice questions. But the testing company, CTB/McGraw-Hill, insisted that it had scored the exams correctly and that the sixth graders had simply performed extraordinarily well. 
 Although students in grades three through seven take standardized reading tests, only the sixth-grade scores from 2000 are in dispute. Officials on both sides expressed confidence last night that scores on the 2001 reading test, which will be made public next week, are accurate. But they said it will be impossible to compare this year's sixth-grade scores with last year's. 
The episode stirred echoes of the mistaken scoring of 300,000 reading tests in 1999, which compelled nearly 9,000 students to attend summer school unnecessarily. That incident also undermined the reputation of the schools chancellor, Rudy Crew, who later lost his job.
But while CTB/McGraw-Hill ultimately admitted botching the 1999 scores, the company's president adamantly denied any error on the 2000 exams yesterday. And while Robert Tobias, the board's longtime testing director, said he felt certain that the company had miscalculated, he added that he had not been able to prove it so far.
"It seems to me that the test was judged to be of greater difficulty than it actually was, and that led to the inflation of scores," Mr. Tobias said in an interview last night. "I see lots of evidence that there is something wrong. But I have not found a definitive smoking gun."
Mr. Tobias said that the sixth-grade scores appear to have been miscalculated because half of the questions on the test were assigned a greater level of difficulty than they deserved. As a result, he said, the citywide results were mistakenly inflated. Sixth graders had the city's most impressive gains in reading last year, with the average score improving by 12.4 points, according to the disputed scores.
Part of the problem, Mr. Tobias said, was that only 21 questions on last year's exam had been tested on a national sample of sixth graders to determine their level of difficulty. The other 29 questions were new and had not been tested, he said.
It is standard practice to include questions that have not been tested on a national sample of students, he said, but those questions are usually kept to a minimum and the scorers assign them a level of difficulty based on questions that have been tested on a national sample.
But in this case, Mr. Tobias said, students who answered the new questions correctly apparently got more points than they should have. As a result, the overall scores were high -- so high that Mr. Tobias said he was immediately suspicious.
"We brought it to the testing company's attention, and their research scientists said, 'Yes, it looks a little strange,' " he said. "They did a variety of analyses but assured us that everything was accurate."
David M. Taggart, the company president, said that his staff members had indeed pored over the test data and had found nothing wrong with the scoring process. One possible reason for the "remarkable" scores, he said, was that 12 of the 50 questions had also been used on the 1999 sixth-grade test, raising the possibility that students had seen them before.
"We're saying it looks anomalous," Mr. Taggart said of the performance on the 2000 test. "Does that mean those scores were wrong? No. It means those students had a good year last year in terms of their performance on the test."
Mr. Tobias said he felt certain that the scores of last year's sixth graders had been miscalculated after reviewing the same students' scores on the reading test they took this year, as seventh graders. There was "absolutely no gain" in the students' scale scores, which was highly unusual, he said. As for Mr. Taggart's theory that the students had for some reason performed exceptionally well as sixth graders, Mr. Tobias said, "I totally reject that."
Mr. Tobias had been debating the scores' accuracy with CTB/McGraw-Hill for weeks, but the conflict did not come to a boil until yesterday, after reports in The Daily News and The New York Post. Mr. Taggart and Robert Evanson, president of McGraw-Hill Education, the testing company's parent, met with Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy and his aides at the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn. After hours of tense discussion, Mr. Levy and Mr. Taggart released a carefully worded joint statement acknowledging that the sixth-grade scores in 2000 were "overstated." The statement also said that the scores had immediately raised a red flag, but they said that they did not want to draw conclusions before seeing the 2001 scores.
"While there was some evidence of anomalies in the results last year, we agreed at the time that they were not conclusive," the statement read. "Now, we have determined that the anomaly was real. This means that aggregate performance data reported for sixth-grade reading last year were higher than warranted."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Levy said he was "very disappointed that this happened" but was careful not to attack the testing company.
"There was a judgment exercised that in hindsight I think was wrong," Mr. Levy said of the decision by the testing company and the board to release the sixth-grade scores last spring even though they had concerns about them.
Although Mr. Levy would not say whether he thought the company had erred, he said Bob Tobias is "really the dean of this field, and I rely heavily on his office's judgment."
Mr. Levy also said that the alleged inflation of scores did not significantly affect the number of sixth graders sent to summer school last year, even though that decision was based largely on test scores.

HEADLINE: World Briefing Asia: Vietnam: Russians To Leave Cam Ranh Bay 

BYLINE:  Agence France-Presse 

 BODY:
 The government will not extend Russia's lease on its sole military base in Southeast Asia when it runs out in 2004, the Foreign Ministry announced. Instead, it plans to use the natural harbor and facilities of Cam Ranh Bay for civilian economic development. The base, built by the United States during the Vietnam War, served as a Soviet listening post in the 1980's and as a runway for Soviet nuclear bombers, intelligence officials have said.

HEADLINE: Rival Medicare Drug Plans Are Both Ruled Affordable 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8 

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office provided the first independent estimates today of the cost of new Medicare drug benefits, showing that the proposals of Senate Democrats and House Republicans are both affordable under the budget adopted by Congress earlier this year.
 Members of both parties welcomed the estimates and said they increased the likelihood of legislative action on the issue this year. 
 Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who took over this week as chairman of the Finance Committee, said the new figures showed that "we have the money in our budget to enact a truly comprehensive drug benefit -- one that will guarantee coverage to all beneficiaries."
The Senate Democrats' proposal would cost $318 billion over the next decade, the budget office said. That is just a bit more than the maximum of $300 billion allowed under the spending plan adopted by Congress in May. 
The budget office also said a Republican proposal for Medicare drug benefits passed by the House last year would cost $157 billion in the coming decade, about the same as the amount proposed by President Bush in February.
Senate Republicans tend to favor legislation that would offer drug benefits through a range of competing health plans. The budget office said this approach -- proposed by Senators John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee -- would cost $176 billion over 10 years.
The main factor determining the cost of each proposal is the generosity of benefits, budget analysts said. When Bill Clinton was president, he proposed drug benefits that would have cost $425 billion over 10 years.
Medicare beneficiaries are among the greatest users of prescription drugs, but they are much less likely than working families to have insurance to cover the costs. About one-third of the 40 million elderly and disabled people on Medicare have no insurance for drug expenses, even though drug companies are continually developing costly, effective new medicines to treat the elderly.
Senate Democrats rejoiced at the new cost estimates. They had feared that the budget office, the official scorekeeper for Congress, might put a much higher price on their proposal.
In an interview, Senator Bob Graham of Florida, a principal author of the Democratic proposal, said he was "extremely pleased" with the cost estimate.
Mr. Graham said Democrats hoped to start moving their legislation through the Finance Committee in July. Michael Siegel, a spokesman for Mr. Baucus, said drug benefits were "definitely at the top of his priority list." Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, has said he will use his new power as majority leader to push for action.
House Republicans also expressed satisfaction, saying the new estimates supported their contention that the $300 billion in the budget was more than enough to provide drug benefits.
The budget office estimated the premiums that would be charged under the various proposals: about $53 a month under the Senate Democratic and House Republican plans in 2004, compared with $28 a month under the Clinton plan. 
Premiums would rise in subsequent years. In 2011, the budget office said, beneficiaries would pay a monthly premium of $65.50 under the Clinton plan, $114.70 under the Senate Democratic proposal and $92.50 under the House Republican bill.
Under all the proposals, the government would spend roughly $100 billion over 10 years to help low-income beneficiaries pay premiums and other costs.
Marilyn Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute, put the proposals in perspective. Under all the proposals, she said, drug benefits would be less generous than what workers typically receive, and the cost to participants would be higher.
Drug spending by or for Medicare beneficiaries will total $1.3 trillion in the next decade, and the government would pay only one-third of those costs under even the most generous proposals, the budget office said.
Experts at the Congressional Budget Office said that Medicare coverage of drug costs would increase demand for prescription drugs, leading to larger price increases than would otherwise occur. None of the major proposals call for explicit federal regulation of drug prices. But all envision a role for private companies in trying to manage drug spending under Medicare.
Such companies would try to negotiate price discounts with drug manufacturers and pharmacies and would steer beneficiaries toward lower-cost drugs.
Cost-control techniques in the House Republican bill would be much more effective than those in the Senate Democrats' plan, the budget office said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Nasdaq Up 3% for the Week Despite Conflicting News
Despite conflicting news from technology companies, the Nasdaq composite index ended the week 3 percent higher. The Nasdaq fell 48.90 points, or 2.2 percent, to close at 2,215.10. It closed at 2,149.44 last Friday.
 Elsewhere, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 113.74 points, or 1 percent, to 10,977.00, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 12 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,2964.96. Both indexes were virtually unchanged for the week. Page C3. 

Nasdaq has started a trading system for its Nasdaq Europe subsidiary, with several big investment banks buying shares. C3.

Regulators Criticized on Tire Inquiry
Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has criticized federal regulators for investigating only the tires in a spate of rollovers of Ford Explorers. Mr. Tauzin asked regulators to study the performance of the Explorer as well as that of the Firestone tires. C2.

British Pound Falls After Election
The British pound slipped again to a 15-year low against the dollar, after a landslide electoral victory by the Labor Party amplified talk that Prime Minister Tony Blair might speed the replacement of the pound with the euro. William Hague resigned after leading his Conservative Party to disastrous defeat on an anti-euro platform. C2.

2 Sony Executives Are Disciplined
Sony Pictures has reprimanded and suspended without pay two advertising executives for their part in concocting quotations from a fictitious movie critic to promote four Columbia Pictures movies in advertisements. C4.

Comair and Pilots to Resume Talks
Comair and its striking pilots agreed to return to the bargaining table in hopes of resolving a two-month strike that has shut down the nation's second-largest regional airline. Talks will resume Tuesday with federal mediators, and both sides agreed to try to reach agreement within 72 hours. C3.

American Airlines and its flight attendants did not reach an accord after four days of talks, and federal mediators will consider asking President Bush to intervene to block a strike days before the Fourth of July holiday. C3.

President Nominates Fed Governor
Susan Schmidt Bies, executive vice president of First Tennessee National, was nominated by President Bush to fill one of two openings on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. If confirmed by the Senate, Ms. Bies, 54, would be the only banker on the seven-member Fed board. Ms. Bies is one of at least five Fed appointments Mr. Bush is likely to make in his first term as president. C4.

Procter & Gamble to Settle Lawsuit
Procter & Gamble said it would pay $49 million to shareholders to settle a lawsuit over its March 2000 earnings announcement. On March 7, 2000, Procter & Gamble's shares fell about one-third, wiping out $40 billion in value, after the company said its forecast for third-quarter profit growth was too optimistic and that earnings would fall instead. C3.

Doubts Raised Over Japan's Growth
Japan's economic policy minister, Heizo Takenaka, expressed doubt about whether the country's economic pace reached the government's forecast of 1.2 percent growth for the fiscal year that ended March 31. C2.

Dismissals at The New York Post
The new editor of The New York Post, Col Allan, has fired two of the newspaper's three managing editors and two metropolitan desk editors, in addition to Jack Newfield, one of New York City's most distinctive liberal voices. Mr. Allan said that he wanted to take the newspaper in a new direction. B3.

HEADLINE: Talking With North Korea 

 BODY:
President Bush is right to resume discussions with North Korea on curbing its long-range missiles and addressing a number of other important security issues. The White House denies that its new position reflects any policy change. But it was just three months ago that Mr. Bush announced an indefinite pause in talks with the North on the grounds that Pyongyang could not be trusted to live up to any agreements. 
 After a careful internal review, the White House now seems to recognize that diplomacy is its best option for dealing with North Korea. The place to insist that tough verification requirements must be part of any missile agreement, for example, is at the negotiating table. If North Korea accepts Washington's offer, talks could resume in a few weeks. 
 The administration rightly declares America's goals to be verifiable limits on North Korea's development and export of long-range missiles, international inspections of Pyongyang's nuclear facilities and shifting the North's conventional forces, now facing South Korea, into less threatening positions. To the extent that North Korea is willing to address these legitimate American concerns, Washington is prepared to respond with increased humanitarian aid and an easing of American economic sanctions against Pyongyang. 
The Bush administration's temporary suspension of negotiations with North Korea had frustrated South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, who was pursuing his own efforts at reconciliation on the Korean Peninsula. The suspension also sparked uncertainty in the North about the direction of American policy, adding to the reasons that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, has still not scheduled a visit to Seoul to reciprocate for Kim Dae Jung's historic trip to Pyongyang last June. One benefit of the administration's decision to resume negotiations should be closer coordination between the United States and its South Korean ally. 
Under the best of circumstances, North Korea has been a prickly and unpredictable negotiating partner. It may not be happy about Mr. Bush's public statement of America's negotiating goals. But if Pyongyang is sincere in its expressed desire for better relations with the United States, it should respond positively and constructively to Mr. Bush's offer of renewed talks.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
British Pound Falls Further On Labor Party's Landslide

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 8 

 BODY:
The British pound slipped again to a 15-year low against the dollar today, after a landslide victory by the Labor Party amplified talk that Prime Minister Tony Blair may speed the replacement of the pound with the euro.
 When William Hague resigned today after leading his Conservative Party to disastrous defeat on an anti-euro platform, it reinforced the perception that the outcome of the election had lowered the political hurdles to joining the 12-nation euro currency union. 
 "Hague's departure certainly demonstrates that the 'no' campaign has taken a heavy blow," said Graham Bishop, an independent economic consultant.
The Labor Party victory on Thursday was not a surprise, and speculators had begun pushing the pound down sharply two days before the balloting. But Mr. Hague's resignation set their hammers falling in earnest, and the pound was driven down to $1.3773, lower than at any time since February 1986. It closed in New York at $1.3806. Over all, in this election week, the pound lost 2.6 percent of its value against the dollar, and 2.2 percent against the euro. 
"I think it's got a bit overexcited, this whole euro story," said Michael Lewis, senior economist at Deutsche Bank. Still, he said he believed the pound could sink lower. Some big banks have lowered forecasts for sterling over the next few months, and one, WestLB in Germany, foresees $1.34 to the pound this summer.
But economists said that there was little chance of a quick move to adopt the euro.
Before the election, Mr. Blair said he expected to decide within two years whether to take the most pivotal step, calling a referendum on adopting the euro. Gordon Brown, the finance minister, said on Thursday that the process could take even longer, with two years spent just to assess whether membership in the euro zone would meet the five economic tests Britain has set for entry.
Public debate would follow the assessment, and only after that would a referendum be scheduled. Mr. Bishop, the consultant, said that at the earliest, Mr. Blair might begin making a public case for adopting the euro in September.
Whatever the timing, analysts said, Mr. Blair leads a nation whose attitudes about the euro range from ambiguous to downright hostile. "The real obstacle lies not in the economic tests, but in whether the government can get the assent of the people in a referendum," said Ian Stewart, chief British economist at Merrill Lynch.
Mr. Hague sought to paint the election as a vote for or against British euro membership, saying repeatedly that the ballot was "the last chance to save the pound." His party's resounding defeat suggested that the rallying call did not resonate with voters.
On the other hand, opinion surveys since the euro was introduced in Continental Europe in January 1999, have consistently found that two-thirds of Britons oppose entry, though the same proportion said they thought it was inevitable.
Beyond politics, economic and technical issues underscore the differences between Britain's possible alliance with the euro and the Continent's marriage to it. The core euro-zone countries, especially France and Germany, had their economies and currencies marching in step for years before January 1999, while Britain has kept its own economic rhythms and fell out of the exchange-rate coordination system in 1992.
Qualification for joining the euro depended on straightforward statistical criteria, but Britain's self-readiness tests are much more woolly. "I have to say that the government's tests are so broadly drawn that a lot will depend on the eye of the beholder," said Mr. Stewart at Merrill Lynch. It is not clear whether Mr. Brown's treasury or the government as a whole would do the beholding.
The tests pose five questions:
*Are the British and Continental European economies capable of "sustainable convergence?"
*Can the euro cope flexibly with economic upheaval?
*How would British membership affect investment?
*What would the disappearance of the pound mean for the City, Britain's Wall Street?
*Would euro membership increase British employment?
Beyond those issues, Mr. Brown wants to be assured that the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, whose policies and pronouncements on monetary policy have so far tended to confuse investors, can operate as openly and effectively as the Bank of England, whose autonomy in interest rate policy was enshrined when Mr. Blair first took office in 1997.
Some of the economic gaps between Britain and the rest of Europe are closing. Benchmark interest rates set in Frankfurt and London are now just 0.75 of a percentage point apart, down from four points in 1999. Long-term rates are close together as well, and Britain's inflation is the lowest in Western Europe.
But there remains the thorny matter of negotiating the exchange rate at which Britain would join. Many investors expect the pound to be devalued sharply before entry.
The European Union accounts for half of Britain's foreign trade, so the fates of the pound and euro are already linked. Bloomberg News calculated this week that the two moved up or down in step against the dollar 92 percent of the time this year.
But "the current market rate would lock Britain in forever at an uncompetitive rate," said Michael Klawitter, a strategist at WestLB. When the pound is high, British exports cost too much to sell well overseas, while domestic producers are undercut by cheap imports.
British exporters want a substantial devaluation. "Ten percent off is a good starting point," Mr. Bishop, the consultant, said. "But then the question is: How to manage the rate downwards without provoking a serious sterling crisis?" A rapid movement could ignite inflation, he said, provoking interest rate increases from the Bank of England and widening the rate gap with Europe, just when it should be narrowing.
Such considerations, though, may well pale beside the broader contours of Mr. Blair's second term. "The bottom line is that it's a political decision," said Mr. Stewart at Merrill Lynch. "The government didn't campaign on it, and they really have a mountain to climb."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Drop on Juniper Networks' Outlook

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday as investors shed technology issues after Juniper Networks released a bleak second-quarter forecast, reigniting Wall Street's concerns about weak corporate profits.
 Trading was disrupted yesterday morning when computer software problems forced the New York Stock Exchange to shut down for nearly an hour and a half. But analysts said the disruption contributed little to the selling yesterday. 
 Semiconductor stocks, which rallied sharply on Thursday on investors' hopes that the chip industry was beginning to revive from its slump, lost ground yesterday.
Analysts said the conflicting news from technology companies puzzled investors, who, without any major economic data to consider, were seeking clues about the strength of the economy from the coming preannouncement season.
"There still remains quite a lot of indecision regarding what to do with these stocks," said Brian G. Belski, a market strategist at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 48.90 points, or 2.16 percent, to close at 2,215.10. For the week, however, the Nasdaq was up 3.05 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 113.74 points, or 1.03 percent, to 10,977.00, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 12.00 points, or 0.94 percent, to 1,2964.96. Both indexes were virtually unchanged for the week.
Shares of Juniper Networks, a network equipment company, tumbled $8.50, to $38.02, in late trading after it reduced its second-quarter sales forecast by one-third, to $200 million to $210 million, and said it would cut jobs by 8 to 9 percent. Other network equipment companies dropped as well: Cisco Systems $1.33, to $20.49, and Ciena $5.70, to $56.14.
Intel, the chip maker, fell 49 cents, to $30.67. The company said late Thursday after the stock market closed that its sales in the current quarter would be within the lower end of its previous forecast. Investors had initially taken Intel's new projections as a sign that the chip industry might be reviving, sending its stock up to $33 in after-hours trading.
Among other semiconductor stocks, Xilinx fell $2.96, to $46.41; National Semiconductor dropped $1.91, to $29.13; and Texas Instruments dropped $1.40, to $37.99. But Advanced Micro Devices gained 82 cents, to $31.10.
Trading was suspended on the New York Stock Exchange around 10:10 a.m. after new trading software malfunctioned, exchange officials said. The system came back online around 11:35 a.m. But some stocks were still not trading by midafternoon. 
Exchange officials said that the halt in trading was the first time the Big Board had failed since Oct. 26, 1998.
Even so, analysts said the breakdown had little influence on market activity.
In the bond market yesterday, Treasury prices drifted lower. The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note declined 12/32, to 97 10/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.36 percent from 5.31 percent on Thursday.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 94 28/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.74 percent from 5.72 percent.

HEADLINE: Bush Trip Aimed at Winning Over Europeans 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ and FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8 

 BODY:
President Bush will carry few specific proposals when he embarks on his first major overseas trip on Monday, hoping instead that face-to-face encounters will win over Europeans skeptical of his policies and abilities.
 "The common European perception is of a shallow, arrogant, gun-loving, abortion-hating, Christian fundamentalist Texan buffoon," said a senior administration official. "They read all the press about a hard-line unilateralist. They really believe this stuff about cowboys. We need to get it all on a higher plane." 
 Though Mr. Bush and his aides say they are aware of Europe's disagreements with the administration on a range of issues -- including the death penalty and the environment -- they have been depicting these as problems that could be overcome by the president's charm and personality -- as happened, experts note, with President Ronald Reagan nearly two decades ago. 
Mr. Bush arrived tonight at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., where he will spend the weekend receiving briefings from his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. The briefings are intended to ensure that the president, who has seldom traveled abroad, will be ready to transform himself into a player on the world stage. 
During the five-country trip, which will include a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, Mr. Bush will confront a Europe increasingly aware of -- and prepared to exercise its economic and diplomatic influence on -- matters including missile defense, climate change, the American peacekeeping role in the Balkans and the creation of a European military force to complement NATO. European leaders have made it clear that they are uncomfortable with the American positions on those issues, and with the unilateralism that seems to underlie them.
On a personal level, many European leaders and opinion makers view Mr. Bush as a political and intellectual lightweight who has flubbed basic tests on foreign affairs, and whose position on some social issues like capital punishment is out of sync with that of the rest of the world. The perceptions will only be strengthened by the impending execution of Timothy J. McVeigh -- the first federal execution in the United States in 38 years. It is scheduled for Monday, the day Mr. Bush is to leave for his first stop, Spain.
In an interview aboard Air Force One this week, Mr. Bush said he would seek to reassure the European allies that the United States was not abandoning them by shrinking into an isolationist shell. He also said he would try to allay their doubts about missile defense and impress upon them the correctness of his view. 
"There are some in Europe who worry about America becoming isolationists," Mr. Bush said. "And I'll ease their concerns. We're an internationalist government." 
He looks forward to "making the case," he said, that missile defense is necessary in the post-cold-war era because "we need to use our technologies to be able to develop ways to face down the post-cold-war threats."
The possible development of those technologies took a step forward today when the Pentagon's Ballistic Missile Defense Office announced that the next test of an interceptor "kill vehicle," a major component of the missile defense system, would be conducted in mid- to late July, a year after the last test failed.
Defense Department officials say that more than two dozen options are under consideration for initial deployment of missile defenses, and that no timetable exists for a decision by Mr. Bush.
After Mr. Bush's visit to Spain, which was selected as the first stop in large part because the president speaks Spanish and because the administration sees Madrid as a "center-right government," he will go on to Brussels, where he will address NATO. He will then travel to Goteborg, Sweden, for the United States-European Union summit meeting; fly to Poland, where he will deliver a major address on his vision of the American relationship with Europe; and then end up in Slovenia for his meeting with Mr. Putin. 
Mr. Bush said he would explain to Mr. Putin that the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty was no longer relevant. He will tell him that "we don't need to be bound by a treaty that was signed when both of us viewed each other with hostility, and that we need to think differently."
Stressing the personal nature of the scheduled two-hour meeting with Mr. Putin in the Slovenian capital, Ljubljana, Mr. Bush said, "It's very important for him to hear it from me and for me to hear from him." 
The meeting with Mr. Putin is in fact a late add-on to a long-planned trip that is anchored to the United States-European Union summit meeting, a semiannual event that the White House wants to reduce to once a year because it regards the meetings as unproductive.
The White House did not want to hold the meeting with Mr. Putin until later, perhaps as part of a summit meeting of seven industrialized nations and Russia in Genoa, Italy, in July.
But persistent problems with China, including the American spy plane incident, officials said, made the administration reconsider the extent to which it wanted to keep Russia at arm's length.
Further, in preparatory meetings for the president's trip, European officials made clear that one of the ways of diminishing the doubts in Europe about Mr. Bush was to signal that the administration could manage the relationship with Russia properly. 
Mr. Bush's aides said they had not laid out any major objectives for the meeting with Mr. Putin. "We're not expecting major agreements here," Ms. Rice said in a briefing with reporters. "What we really are doing here is establishing a foundation with these two presidents in their personal relationship that can help us to promote a constructive and realistic relationship with Russia."
Ms. Rice said that "the new security framework" would be the focus of the discussion with Mr. Putin but that other matters would be covered, including Chechnya, press freedom in Russia and Moscow's proliferation of missile technologies. 
Setting a more moderate tone toward Moscow than harsh remarks made by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld just after he assumed office, Ms. Rice said, "The president wants to signal his support for having a Russia that is really a part of Europe, that is a respected partner in international politics." 
As administration officials laid out their game plan for Mr. Bush's journey, they stressed that things were not as bad between Washington and the allies as they might seem.
"This is a relationship under some stress but by no means in crisis," said Richard Haass, the director of policy planning at the State Department. An administration team that went to Europe last month to describe the Bush ideas about missile defense prepared the way for the president's visit and allayed the basic fear that Washington would act unilaterally, Mr. Haass said. 
For his part, Mr. Bush noted in the interview this week that consultations were under way. "One of the things we did on the missile defense issue is we sent high-ranking officials to consult and spend time with -- in various capitals -- on the issues, explaining our position," he said. "There's a lot of give and take. And that's important." 
The White House organized the missile defense briefings after failing to take such a course on the international treaty on global warming, known as the Kyoto Protocol. The sudden announcement that the United States would not abide by the pact contributed to the image in Europe of a high-handed White House. 
At a meeting in Luxembourg on Friday, the European Union's environment ministers set the stage for a standoff on global warming at the summit meeting. The ministers said the European Union would press forward with final negotiations on the Kyoto Protocol so that ratification procedures could get under way. 
But the White House continued to signal this week that Mr. Bush did not plan to change course. 
Despite unanimous support for the pact that is expected to be expressed by the 15 members of the European Union in Sweden, the administration officials said there was no flexibility in their attitude toward the Kyoto proposals. 
They suggested that the administration might work up a set of principles on climate warming but that this would fall far short of any proposal to modify or renegotiate the pact, which requires mandatory emission reductions.
Concerning the death penalty, which is outlawed in European Union nations, it is not on the formal agenda of the summit meeting. But Mr. Bush is still expected to hear much about it during a free-wheeling dinner discussion with European leaders. Ms. Rice, asked by reporters about the awkwardness of Mr. Bush's arriving in Europe when Mr. McVeigh's execution is expected to occur, said the use of the death penalty in the United States was no one else's business. 
"I believe that our allies probably understand that this is a matter for the American government," Ms. Rice said. "It is a matter for America's democracy, not a matter for international negotiation."

HEADLINE: Tony Blair's Centrist Majority 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Tony Blair's resounding re-election victory on Thursday marks him as Britain's most successful politician since Margaret Thatcher. He deserves full credit for leading his Labor Party to its first re-election to a second full term in office. But his task was made easier by the blinkered anti-European stance taken by his Conservative opponents under the leadership of William Hague, who announced yesterday that he would step down as party leader. To regain credibility as a serious contender for national power, the Conservatives will have to move back toward more constructive policies on Europe. 
 Labor built its current success on an earlier move to the center. After taking over party leadership seven years ago, Mr. Blair engineered a shift away from Labor's previous nationalization and spending policies and its old trade union base, and toward the growing suburban middle class. 
 Consciously modeling his political program on Bill Clinton's, Mr. Blair blended fiscal conservatism, cautious social reform and international engagement, including a constructive attitude toward Britain's role in the European Union. By the 1997 elections the Labor Party had attracted the overwhelming majority of the swing votes that decide elections in Britain as they do in the United States.
Over the past four years, Labor has established a credible governing record, especially in economic and fiscal management. Britain has also been Washington's most reliable ally on difficult international issues like Iraq and the Balkans. Meanwhile the Conservatives have championed populist and nationalist causes, such as rejecting foreigners who seek asylum on political or humanitarian grounds. The party also warned that British sovereignty and democracy could be harmed if Mr. Blair holds and wins a referendum on joining the new European currency. 
At times, Britons complained that Mr. Blair and his fellow ministers appeared smug and aloof. Some cabinet changes have already been announced. There is also discontent with the deterioration of public services, particularly the national health service and the recently privatized railroads. But Labor has promised increased spending in both areas and has an almost unassailable parliamentary majority of 167 seats. 
It was only after successive defeats by Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives that Labor turned to more modern policies and leaders. Now it is the Tories who must begin drawing hard lessons from their back-to-back defeats.

HEADLINE: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBAKCS 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 GREENE ON CAPRI: A Memoir, by Shirley Hazzard. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.) With a pervasive wariness and modesty, the novelist recalls the long, often stormy, friendship she and her husband, the Flaubert scholar Francis Steegmuller, struck up with Graham Greene, who is portrayed as a proud but prickly soul who ruthlessly disagreed with anyone who agreed with him. "Hazzard tells of a relationship that was a treasure hunt among nettles," Richard Eder wrote in the Book Review last year. Her "feeling for the landscape is incantatory."

SOME THINGS THAT STAY, by Sarah Willis. (Berkley, $13.) This first novel's feisty narrator is an artist's 15-year-old daughter who is intent on testing life's possibilities (including her ability to fly) as she comes of age in a small town in upstate New York in 1954. She is "an engaging character not because she gains insight but because she's so responsive to the world," Joanna Scott wrote here in 2000.

LIVING TO TELL, by Antonya Nelson. (Scribner, $13.) An entire family -- the Mabies of Wichita, Kan. -- is the protagonist of this wry, obsessively observed novel, which begins with the return of a son from a prison sentence for killing his grandmother while driving drunk. "The story's hard-won, moderately happy ending is a satisfying benediction" upon an ensemble cast "about which the reader has truly come to care," Emily Barton said here last year.

EXPERIENCE: A Memoir, by Martin Amis. (Vintage International, $14.) The novelist crams a lot into his account of growing up in the shadow of his father, Kingsley Amis, including his youthful wanderings, his midlife crisis, his withering assessments of fellow writers and even his elaborate dental work. " 'Experience' is a portmanteau of personal history, ancestor worship and promiscuous opinionizing, and a pinata of literary gossip," John Leonard wrote in these pages last year.

THE END OF THE PEACE PROCESS: Oslo and After, by Edward W. Said. (Vintage, $14.) In a series of angry essays that find fault with all involved in the Middle East power struggle, the author, a professor at Columbia University and an eloquent advocate of the Palestinian cause, views the 1993 Oslo accord as an unpalatably one-sided expression of Zionism. "You don't have to agree with Said to admire him," Ethan Bronner said here last year. His voice is "deep, rich and courageous in what is often a scripted and dishonest international dispute." Yoram Hazony, the author of The Jewish State: The Struggle for Israel's Soul (Basic Books, $18), maintains that some leading intellectuals have been undermining the Jewish purpose and nature of Israel and calls for a new vision that will revitalize the nation's mission. Last year in these pages, Walter Reich said that even if "Hazony's argument is at times overheated," his book "contains much that is valuable and illuminating." Between Memory and Desire: The Middle East in a Troubled Age, by R. Stephen Humpreys (University of California, $17.95), explores the many stubborn issues facing a region whose most serious challenges, he says, lie less in economics than in perceptions, habits and attitudes. In 1999 our reviewer, Max Rodenbeck, called this an "objective yet sympathetic, scholarly yet accessible" work.

THE SLEEP-OVER ARTIST, by Thomas Beller. (Norton, $13.) Less a novel than a set of interwoven stories, this collection follows the evolution of its hapless Holden Caulfieldesque hero from the age of 6, when he's tossing water on people from the windows of high-rises, into his mid-20's, when he's fumbling toward maturity and becoming entangled in romantic relationships. "Beller is particularly skilled" at capturing "the myriad stages of fear, discovery and elation that mark one's first sexual experiences," Katherine Dieckmann wrote here last year.

WHEN MOUNTAINS WALKED, by Kate Wheeler. (Mariner/ Houghton Mifflin, $13.) This first novel unfolds along parallel tracks as it tells of an idealistic young woman struggling to bring health and prosperity to a remote Peruvian valley, and of the woman's grandmother, who traveled to the region many years earlier -- with tragic results. "It's the kind of novel you gulp down, curious to find out what happens next," Susan Bolotin said here in 2000.

LEGACY OF THE DEAD, by Charles Todd. (Bantam, $5.99.) A guilt-ridden detective sent to Scotland to identify the remains of an English aristocrat finds that the person accused of murdering the noblewoman was the fiancee of a soldier he executed during World War I. The result is a "study of postwar Scotland as a land rich in beauty but barren of new life," Marilyn Stasio wrote here last year. Scott Veale

HEADLINE: Customer Service By E-Mail 

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
There is perhaps no easier way to get a person started than to ask about a travel horror story.
 For Jennifer Zimmerman, it was a business trip in October from her hometown, Dallas, to Washington, D.C. At midday Sunday she checked her bags at an American Airlines gate, then watched the thunderstorms roll in. After a succession of cancellations and delays, she drove home early the next morning, frazzled. 
 The next day was barely better. Ms. Zimmerman got a flight, but it arrived after a crucial business meeting had begun. She rushed off the plane in jeans and sandals, looking frantically for her luggage, to no avail. 
An airline employee eventually discovered that Ms. Zimmerman's baggage was still in Dallas and told her there was nothing she could do. 
"I fly 35,000 to 75,000 miles a year on American, and I cut them a lot of slack," Ms. Zimmerman said. "Not this time." She had seen a billboard advertising a Web site called PlanetFeedback.com, which claims to help wronged consumers get responses from companies. The site helped her construct an e-mail complaint to American's chief executive, Donald J. Carty, and sent it on her behalf. A week later she received an e-mail apology from American -- and a $250 travel voucher.
Such happy endings are rare in an era when travel providers -- airlines in particular -- have earned ever lower marks for customer service. The fact that the complaint was resolved through the Web is even more remarkable since, according to travel industry analysts, many travel sites offer poor customer service.
"In situations where something's gone wrong, there are ways to get it taken care of on the Web sites -- usually through e-mail forms -- but they're typically buried," said Henry Harteveldt, an analyst with Forrester Research, a company with headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., that analyzes technology changes for business clients.
But even if customers find the e-mail link on one of the airline sites, for example, they may be wasting their time. Forrester recently found that six of the nine major airline sites didn't respond to e-mail messages within five working days.
Mr. Harteveldt said that consumers will see "major improvements in the next year, or even six months, since every company says it's focusing more on customer service on the Web." For instance, he said, he expects companies to set standards for answering e-mail messages within two to six hours, depending on the level of the complaint. "Of course, if it's an immediate problem, that's probably 1 hour and 59 minutes too long," he said.
One airline Web site where the e-mail link is not buried is United (www.ual.com), which says "contact us" at the top of the home page. Clicking on those words takes you to a page with contact information, including an e-mail link. According to a United spokesman, Chris Brathwaite, e-mail is usually answered within 72 hours, regardless of the subject matter, "but if we have a backlog, it can take up to a week," he said.
Mr. Brathwaite said that the company will address complaints more quickly if a customer is a member of United's frequent-flier program and includes a membership number along with the note. 
The company does not track the percentage of people who send e-mail inquiries rather than calling, according to Mr. Brathwaite, but Mr. Harteveldt, of Forrester, said that over 70 percent of consumers use the telephone to get help with travel problems, while just 15 percent use e-mail (the rest send faxes or write letters).
The beauty of complaining through e-mail, of course, is that you can state your case clearly, in as much detail as you like, without having to contend with a call-center labyrinth, five-minute spans on hold and the misery of repeating the same story to a succession of employees.
Fortunately for the millions who book through them, the major online travel agencies, Expedia and Travelocity, do a better job of handling e-mail inquiries than do many travel providers. On Expedia's Web site, for example, customers are assured that their inquiries will be answered within 24 hours, although the company's marketing director, Suzi LeVine, said that responses come within five hours.
The substance of the responses, though, may disappoint those who are counting on the site to resolve their problems. In many instances, the site will "work with the travel supplier to make sure a situation is remedied," Ms. LeVine said. "But unfortunately, there are some situations where it's clearly the responsibility of the travel supplier, and there's nothing we can do."
In the case of lost luggage, she said, "we can point people to phone numbers, but unfortunately that's the purview of the airline."
The same is true on Travelocity.com. A customer service representative said that in disputes with airlines Travelocity does whatever it can to help, but that the airline will have the final say. 
A new competitor of Travelocity and Expedia, Orbitz.com, says it will do things somewhat differently. The site, which is scheduled to roll out to the public this month, has been operating in a test mode for several months, selling airline tickets, hotel rooms and car rentals. According to Gerry Romanescu, Orbitz's vice president for customer care, the company will coordinate lost-luggage claims and other complaints on a customer's behalf. It will forward a customer's e-mail message to the airline, Mr. Romanescu said, "and if they don't get back to you in the normal amount of time, we'll follow up." The company is also trying to persuade the airlines -- five of which are part-owners of the site -- to allow Orbitz to act on their behalf. One airline, which Mr. Romanescu would not name, has already agreed to pass along its rules about providing discounts and other perks to rankled customers, thereby allowing the site to cut through bureaucracy.
Meanwhile, a growing number of consumers are taking their complaints to online ombudsmen, like PlanetFeedback, or smaller operations like ComplaintDetective.com. According to Pete Blackshaw, PlanetFeedback's chief executive, the site does not yet track the number of travel-related complaints that are ultimately resolved because of his company's intervention, but he believes it is well over 50 percent.
Not surprisingly, the airlines have generated the most complaints within the travel category in the past six months, with roughly 8,500 such e-mail messages. (The site also sends compliments on behalf of customers; airlines garnered 3,000 of those.) Unlike some other complaint sites, PlanetFeedback sends a follow-up e-mail message to a user after three weeks, asking if the user received a response. If not, the site will send an "escalation" e-mail message.
"It's amazing how many companies will ignore a complaint the first time, but respond to the second one," Mr. Blackshaw said.
For those who have tried in vain to get a response, Complaint Detective may be worth considering. Aggrieved customers pay a $25 deposit to the site, explain the issue by e-mail or by telephone, and the company pursues a remedy. If the problem isn't resolved, customers get their deposits back. But if they get a refund or travel voucher, they pay the site about 20 percent of the value of whatever remedy is offered.
"It may take me five calls to customer service to get a nice rep who'll give me the right name, but eventually I'll get it," said Lisa Quinn, the site's president. She added that she's always had good success with the airline complaints.
When asked to divulge her secrets for getting through to the people who actually make the decisions within the airlines or other travel companies, Ms. Quinn hesitated. "Well, I figure there are a lot of people who are e-mailing or calling," she said. "So I always get the fax number."
