HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Beach Towns Evolve by Adding Year-Round Homes

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AN oceanfront block in Manasquan has been bulldozed to make room for an enclave of 26 upscale condominiums, a move that in many ways is a metaphor for the continued evolution of the shore community in southern Monmouth County to a year-round address.
 Until last month the block was crowded with an amusement arcade, shops and timeworn bungalows that hosted generations of college-age students and young adults and was as much a beachfront tradition as salt water taffy. But traditions change. 
 "It was a major nuisance and an eyesore," John L. Winterstella, the mayor of Manasquan, said of the block. Its transformation, he added, is in keeping with Manasquan's changing character "as a year-round, family town." 
The project sits between Brielle Road and East Main Street and overlooks the beach and Atlantic Ocean, separated from them only by the stretch of macadam, instead of a traditional boardwalk, that spans the borough's mile-long shoreline. 
The $13 million development, Surfside Estates, will rise in the next 18 months and consist of seven buildings, each three stories high and each with three or four apartments. The units all will have three bedrooms, 1,800 square feet of space, two-car garages, a front deck and price tags of $650,000 to $700,000, according to Paul R. DeBellis Sr., president of the Franklin Group of West Paterson, the developer.
Surfside Estates is the first sizable condominium in the 1.4-square-mile borough and one of a smattering of developments under way or about to begin at the water's edge. Among the reasons for the slow pace of construction along the beach, real estate professionals say, are the lack and high cost of oceanside land and state regulations, mainly the Coastal Area Facility Review Act, governing growth along the state's 127-mile shoreline.
In February 2000 the state changed its coastal law to align it with its state Development and Redevelopment Plan. The plan encourages growth where highways and utilities are in place and discourages it in less-developed areas. 
To that end the state's Department of Environmental Protection designated shore towns into existing centers and four other types of land-use areas. Each area has been given an allowable density with "the more-dense development allowed in those places, including the barrier islands, where development already exists," said Raymond E. Cantor, assistant commissioner for land-use management and compliance at the department 
The new rules, however, never completely closed what many say is a loophole in the 1973 law. While the law governs some single-family homes within 150 feet of the water, it is silent about developments of 2 units to 24 units. 
In turn, there are those who say the rules are too loose and those, including developers, who say they are too stringent. The opponents include the New Jersey Builders Association, which filed a lawsuit against the Department of Environmental Protection. 
Mr. Cantor said he was confident the rules would be upheld and would result in "better protection of the shoreline."
Meanwhile, development continues. Most of the activity along the oceanfront consists of tearing down modest older homes and replacing them with larger ones. Although there are no exact figures available, Mr. Cantor said the activity "has been substantial for the last decade." 
There are also projects, like Surfside Estates, that recycle parcels. Plans are also advancing to replace an old restaurant on Brielle Road in Manasquan with 12 more condos, said John T. Trengrove, the borough administrator. 
That is also the case in Spring Lake, where the century-old, blocklong Warren Hotel, a remnant of the town's past as a luxury resort, was recently demolished to make way for 10 Victorian-style homes. They will have 4,500 square feet of space, sit on 75-by-150-foot lots and cost from $2.5 million to $2.8 million, said Daniel Matthews, a principal at National Home Developers of Spring Lake, the developer. Construction will start the end of the month, he said, noting that seven houses had been sold. 
Exceptions to small, piecemeal projects can be found in more urban shore towns like Long Branch. There, a redevelopment plan is in place to transform 150 acres of the city's faded Atlantic Ocean coastline into a mix of residential, commercial and entertainment uses. And in Asbury Park redevelopment efforts have been discussed for years for its mile-long oceanfront. But they have been tied up in litigation and complications arising from bankruptcy and so far have not moved forward. 
VACANT parcels outside such redevelopment areas are also gaining new life. Indicative of that are two projects bordering the redevelopment area in Long Branch. One, called Renaissance on the Ocean with 86 residences, is under way on 9.2 acres at the southeast corner of Ocean and Brighton Avenues.
The residences range from condominium apartments to town houses and single-family detached homes with 2,000 to 4,000 square feet. Since sales began three years ago, all but four units have been sold at prices ranging from $300,000 to $1.9 million, according to the developer, Renaissance Estates L.P., made up of a group of investors based in Neptune. 
An empty, weed-choked lot across Ocean Avenue is the site of the second project. It will contain 23 town houses, with 2,700 to 3,400 square feet, covered front and rear porches and prices starting from $400,000. Construction will start in mid-July, said Joseph Forgione, a principal at Sterling Properties of Livingston, the developer. 
Manasquan, founded in 1887, originally was a summer community with rows of little bungalows and a boardwalk. But the borough, like many others along the shore, is evolving into a year-round community. Over the last decade its year-round population increased to 7,000 from 5,300, according to census figures. (During the summer the population at least doubles.) 
Meanwhile, the borough's supply of bungalows is dwindling as developers tear them down and put up large waterside houses. There have been 5 to 10 such teardowns a year for each of the last four years, said Mr. Trengrove, the administrator. 
Such homes sell for about $1.5 million and replace bungalows, often three on a lot, that cost a total of $700,000 to $1 million, said Robert Wood Sr., who runs the Wood Agency, a real estate office in Manasquan.
The Surfside Estates site became available only after the death of its former owner, Irving Kirsch, a large property owner in the borough. Mr. DeBellis, the developer of the condominiums, said his company bought the one and a half acre parcel three years ago for $3.2 million because the chance to redevelop a whole oceanfront block was "absolutely like finding a treasure." Initially, the project planned 36 condominiums, but borough officials thought that was too dense and the number of units was cut to the current 26, said Robert Richardi, a Franklin principal and the project's architect. He said reducing the number also enabled his company to spread the buildings apart and design them so the garages, rather than being visible from the street, will be tucked into an interior courtyard, which pleased local officials. 
The borough also required the company to use certain construction materials to better withstand the high winds and salt water at the shore. 
Mr. De Bellis said meeting all the borough's requirements added 25 percent to the overall cost of the project. But in the three years since it was planned, the real estate market improved, "making it economically worthwhile to move ahead," he added.
Richard F. Martel Jr., the manager of the Spring Lake office of Coldwell Banker, the residential brokerage, said that because of the sluggish national economy, prices for oceanfront housing in towns in and around Manasquan "have not dropped, but they are no longer going through the roof." There also are 20 percent more homes on the market today than a year ago, so they are taking longer to sell, he said. 
Mr. Wood, the realtor, said the average sale price of existing single-family detached beachfront homes in Manasquan is $800,000, up 35 to 40 percent from two years ago.
Mr. DeBellis said there is a pent-up demand for the kind of maintenance-free housing at the water's edge that Surfside Estates will offer. Fifty-one people have put their names on a waiting list, he said.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
A Cautionary Tale Taken From Pulpit to Stage

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
MUSIC has never been a very effective medium for polemics. To have an impact, a polemical argument must be precise and persuasive. Music is powerful but indistinct. Propped up by rabble-rousing music, a political tract tends to sound bombastic.
 Even opera resists preaching, as Verdi understood. His operas are full of disarming choruses expressing the nostalgia of captive people for far-off homelands or stirring calls to battle. But the expressions are generalized. In "Simon Boccanegra," Verdi didn't try to sort out the alliances and grievances of 14th-century Genoa that motivate the factional strife in the hopelessly confused story. Yet the music presents poignantly recognizable human beings coping with loss, regret and disconnection. 
 The Danish composer Poul Ruders seems to have a Verdian understanding of the genre. In his opera "The Handmaid's Tale," which received its premiere last spring at the Royal Danish Opera and has just been released on CD's, he found a grippingly operatic way to tell a story so loaded with polemics that it might have crushed a lesser composer. The opera is an adaptation of a futuristic 1986 best-seller, a cautionary tale by the Canadian novelist Margaret Atwood, written in response to the emergence of the Moral Majority in the United States, the rise of Islamic fundamentalism, the policing of birth rates in Romania and China, and other signs of increasing intolerance.
In the book, a part of the northeastern United States has been taken over in the 21st century by Christian evangelicals aghast at the country's wantonness and alarmed at the widespread pollution and virulent new infections that have depleted the population and rendered a majority of women infertile. They establish a male-controlled totalitarian state, the Republic of Gilead, where women are divided into classes based on their household functions and identified by uniforms. There are Marthas, the efficient housemaids, in drab green; Econowives, the working class, in colored stripes; Wives in blue; and Aunts, like some matronly thought-control force, in brown. Clad in bright red are the Handmaids, named for Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid in Genesis. Their sole function is to bear children for the heads of households, called Commanders, whose wives are barren. Abortion and divorce are capital offenses.
The libretto, written by Paul Bentley in English and translated by Mr. Ruders into Danish for the premiere, retains the framing device of the novel. The opera begins with a prologue set in 2195. At a worldwide video conference, the 12th Symposium on the Republic of Gilead, a newly discovered audio cassette diary will be played. It was left by Offred, a Handmaid in the republic, whose name, like those of all Handmaids, is derived from that of her Commander: she is "of Fred."
To judge from his work, Mr. Ruders was less interested in the politics and symbolism and more taken with the charged dramatic situations and internal struggles of the characters. He clearly saw the potential for opera, with its ensemble technique, to project the different tiers of the story simultaneously.
This riveting, kaleidoscopic score can now be heard in a Dacapo recording, taken from the premiere performances in Copenhagen. Conducted by Michael Schonwandt, it features two mezzo-sopranos, Marianne Rorholm as the Offred of the diary and Hanne Fischer as Offred in the time before. The music is a triumph of stylistic pluralism. Mr. Ruders, 52, has thoroughly modernist credentials, and he writes in a pungent, freely atonal harmonic language. But washes of diatonic consonance often flood his scores, and for a while he was associated with the Minimalists. He is a brilliant practitioner of musical parody, riffing everything from medieval chant to break-dance disco. A highly original ear for harmony and texture, as well as an infectious love of the large gesture, runs through almost every Ruders work.
Surely, "The Handmaid's Tale," his first large-scale opera, represents a summing up. The lavish scoring deftly mingles electronic and standard instruments. In the apt phrase of Stephen Johnson in the program notes, Mr. Ruders is the "Richard Strauss of the computer-age orchestra."
From the opening moments, when sustained soft, misty, strangely astringent orchestral chords hover in the background while bits and pieces of themes in solo instruments struggle to break out, the music is haunting. Though prone to violent shifts of mood that closely follow the situations, the score has a taut linear continuity. But what gives it dramatic richness and rescues the story from Ms. Atwood's weighty symbolism is Mr. Ruders's use of musical parody. The wife of Offred's Commander, a gospel singer named Serena Joy, is depicted in a grotesquely beautiful rendering of "Amazing Grace." Hints of Bach chorales, grimly fractured, keep recurring. In a scene at a private club for the Commanders, Mr. Ruders offers a wicked skewering of 1940's big-band music.
For a work of literature to be a good operatic source, there must be something music can add. Andre Previn might have considered this obstacle before taking on "A Streetcar Named Desire." Even John Harbison's "Great Gatsby," an opera I admire, struggles to achieve a profile that can stand up to Fitzgerald's classic novel.
But Mr. Ruders felt that "The Handmaid's Tale" was begging for operatic treatment. And in providing one, he freed the story from its sermonizing, something even a 1990 film adaptation starring Natasha Richardson could not do. How the opera works on stage, those of us who were not at the premiere can look forward to discovering, for productions of "The Handmaid's Tale," in Mr. Bentley's original English, arrive in London in 2002 and in Minneapolis in 2003.

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
In Belleville, the Priorities Speak Volumes

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
ON the ceiling of the reference room at the Belleville Public Library are three allegorical panels painted in an Italian Renaissance style. Together, they tell the story of a man on a quest for knowledge and wisdom. The middle panel shows the man in mortal battle with a beast.
 "Slaying the dragon of Ignorance," said Cindy LaRue, the head reference librarian. 
 A similar battle is going on in Belleville. 
The Town Council, which finds itself facing a $5 million budget shortfall, is considering cutting the library budget by $146,000, and requiring the library to pick up the $200,000 tab for employees' benefits. That would cut the budget by 54 percent, to the minimum allowed by law.
Belleville's library director, Joan Taub, doesn't think she can keep the library open on such a tight purse. "I almost have to not let myself think about it," said Ms. Taub. 
Ms. Taub recently had a dream in which she was in a library -- -- supposed Belleville's, but it wasn't. She was screaming at someone to get out. "And I never scream in the library," the soft-spoken librarian explained.
Nor does she scream in Town Council meetings, like the one on May 22, in which she was interrupted during a prepared speech and asked to stop.
"I don't think it is appropriate at this time," Mayor William Escot said. "We are all very aware of your opposition to the budget cuts."
Ms. Taub quietly took her seat.
When some residents brought up the library budget that night, the town manager, Tom Banker, brandishing his credentials as a former director of the Newark Public Library, said: "I'd like to see the library funded at high levels. "But you can't have your cake and eat it too."
What he's referring to are the competing desires to put out fires, stop robbers, educate children -- and buy books -- and not raise property taxes. Services on the chopping block include the fire and police departments.
Nobody can explain how Belleville got in such a mess, although three new Town Council members were elected last summer on a tax-cutting platform, and managed to bring the tax rate down by four points. Then Belleville, which is self-insured, swooned under the unexpected burden of 10 catastrophic illnesses. Still, the town is thinking about lowering taxes again -- by one tax point.
Many see the current budget battle as part of the rough-and-tumble politics that dominates this distressed, blue-collar town, which looks like a set out of "The Sopranos" and is in fact used when the fictional mob family needs a funeral home.
"The library is the only oasis in a wasteland," said Irving Berkowitz, who has lived in Belleville his entire 77 years. "Culturally, it's the finest thing in this town." 
Actually, the library -- which was built with an Andrew Carnegie grant in 1910 and renovated for $300,000 in 1992 -- is too fine for the likes of some people. With its Italianate ceilings, faux-marble columns and baby grand piano, it's a bit too much for some. "People felt it shouldn't have been so grand," Ms. Taub said of the renovation.
I wanted to research the history of libraries, so the other day, I went to Belleville instead of using the Internet. Ms. LaRue directed me to a reference I hadn't even thought of it: the encyclopedia. There were pictures of grand, columned libraries throughout history, reminding me that libraries, like churches, are things that can be built only by communities. Libraries, in fact, are churches for books. Recording, remembering, referencing history -- their buildings tell us -- is a sacred task.
In Belleville, a town whose modest housing stock has always attracted immigrants, libraries have another sacred duty: educating the newcomer. Sitting next to me was Del Lagdameo, who came to Belleville from the Philippines last year, and was studying books on dental and medical careers. In the next room, Dawit Tadesse, who came to Belleville five years ago from Ethiopia, was reading about his homeland. The library also provides classes on English as a second language.
The encyclopedia also mentioned that libraries flourish under "strong and stable governments" in times of "economic health" -- two conditions that seem perceptibly lacking in Belleville these days. 
Ms. Taub didn't even want to mention it, but somehow it slipped out. When she invited the Town Council to a breakfast last month, not one person showed up. If you weren't in a library, it could make you scream.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
For Old Union Carbide Headquarters, a Time of Flux

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: DANBURY 

 BODY:
A MILE and quarter down a private two-lane road within a 646-acre tract of unspoiled forest and meadowland alive with deer and wild turkey lies the 2.1-million-square-foot former world headquarters of the Union Carbide Corporation -- Connecticut's largest office building, acknowledged to be among the most architecturally significant, innovative and controversial office structures in the country. 
 Despite its auspicious opening in 1982 as an icon of Fairfield County's crop of corporate campuses, the property has been in flux for most of its life -- and, with the end of Union Carbide earlier this year, it remains in flux. Since 1992 it has been called Corporate Center. Currently it has 451,000 square feet rented and 236,000 square feet available at annual rents of $23 a square foot, plus electricity, according to Leroy Diggs, its facilities manager. 
 From its earliest days, the building was tied to Union Carbide's declining fortunes. Starting in 1986, space was rented to outside tenants, and its fate was also linked to its location in Danbury, a secondary office market. This year, in a merger consummated on Feb. 6 with the transfer of $10.2 billion worth of its stock, debt and equity, Union Carbide became history. It is now a wholly-owned subsidiary of Dow Chemical Company -- its products and stock known by Dow's name and the 200 or so remaining members of a Carbide staff that once numbered over 3,000 now employed by Dow. 
The building, off Old Ridgebury Road, was designed by the architectural firm of Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo and Associates and constructed at a cost of $190 million. It rests in spectacular fashion off the ground on 5,000 columns ranging from 8 to 40 feet tall, accommodating the hilly terrain and avoiding vast amounts of earth- and rock-moving that would have been required for a conventional foundation.
Inside and out, the building wears its age with remarkable grace. The original interior wall coverings, carpeting, furniture and patterned wood floors, and the building's awesome exterior of anodized aluminum and glass, have been maintained in pristine condition. 
Current tenants include Praxair, a supplier of industrial gases, with 135,000 square feet; Honeywell International, with 60,000 square feet; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, with 9,000 square feet; Boehringer Ingelheim, a health-care products company, with 76,000 square feet; NuKem, a uranium trader, with 9,000 square feet; American Express Travel, with 5,000 square feet; and Dow, which occupies Carbide's 288,000 square feet of space. 
Carbide's downward spiral began in 1984 with the deaths or disabilities of more than 6,500 people in Bhopal, India, after a massive gas leak occurred at the company's chemical plant there. Settlement costs totaled $470 million. The next year, Carbide fended off a hostile takeover by the GAF Corporation by divesting itself of several divisions, further weakening its financial structure. 
IN 1986, to avoid seizure, the Danbury building and 100 surrounding acres were sold to Sunbelt Management of Delray Beach, Fla., in a 20-year lease-back arrangement that ends in 2006. Carbide rented out the space that it no longer needed to a variety of companies that moved in, moved out, sometimes came back, sometimes expanded within the building. 
While never fully occupied, the building attracted sufficient tenants to provide a steady stream of income that will now go to Dow. Dow will in turn continue to pay rent to Sunbelt according to the leaseback agreement, and as the city's largest taxpayer, it will take over payments totaling $3,862,056 in real estate and personal property taxes.
Dow would like to sell the 546 undeveloped acres not owned by Sunbelt, according to Garland G. Warren, former manager of real estate services for Union Carbide, who is now performing that function for Dow. But restrictions placed on Dow by the Federal Trade Commission as a result of the merger prevent it from selling any of its properties for two years. In 1989 the same vacant tract was sold by Union Carbide to RP Development Limited Partnership of New York City, but with the real estate recession of the early 90's development never took place, and Carbide bought it back in 1997. 
Dow's headquarters are in Midland, Mich., and it has 50,000 employees in 170 worldwide locations. Jim McIlvenny, chairman of Dow's Danbury site management team, said: "Dow has always coveted an East Coast presence to attract and retain East Coast graduates. We will continue to maintain an East Coast presence, but in a reduced capacity."
While Corporate Center has its admirers, prospective tenants can be put off by its unusual configuration. It is composed of a long four-story rectangle, slightly curved like a centipede about to turn a corner, and its snowflake-shaped office pods sprout from its sides like legs. Lit up at night, it has been compared to a science-fiction starship. 
Incorporated into the building are two four-story parking wings totaling 900,000 square feet and accommodating 2,568 cars. There is no outdoor parking. Centered crosswise between the wings is a vertical 222,000-square-foot core containing five variously styled dining rooms; a marble-floored cafeteria; a conference theater; 10 conference rooms and two board rooms; law and business libraries; a shopping arcade; a medical clinic; dry cleaning, hair cutting and ATM facilities; a reception hall; and a fitness center with dozens of exercise machines, showers and dressing rooms. 
EVERY office has individual temperature controls and natural light from continuous ribbons of windows. Vaulted skylights, reflected light from mirrored ceilings and diffused light from translucent wall panels provide daylight in dining rooms, hallways and service areas. A jogging track runs through a mile of the property, and a helipad is in active use. 
Ten interior roadways take employees and visitors to their appointed parking areas. Employees drive to spaces directly facing the pods, where their offices are 10 feet away, across glass-enclosed pedestrian bridges. They need not set foot outdoors from home to office. "It's a huge building made small," said Ivana Tibbetts, Dow's public information officer for the building, who led a visitor on a recent tour. 
Like some of his colleagues, Ed Tonnessen, an executive vice president at Albert Ashforth Inc., a Stamford, Conn., brokerage company, finds the layout of Corporate Center hard to market. "Some companies don't want to be small fish in a very big pond," he said. "Some large tenants want their own signature on a building, and the need to be close to where the C.E.O. lives is not a need that Danbury satisfies."
But Arthur Delmhorst of Delmhorst & Sheehan Inc. of Stamford and Manhattan, leasing agents for Corporate Center, said that these days tenants and potential tenants seem happy with the space. "Five years ago, when we started leasing, people wanted large blocks of open space -- a big shoe box," Mr. Delmhorst said. "This building was never suited to that. But today people are more interested in private offices."
Rentable spaces range from 4,000 to 100,000 square feet. But "there are not a lot of big tenants floating around the Danbury area," Mr. Delmhorst said. "We thought we'd have bigger companies and more from Manhattan, but most of them have been from Stamford or along Route 7." 
Many brokers in lower Fairfield County consider Danbury unsuitable, in part because of the narrowness of Route 7. "It's an alternative market unto itself," said Dean Shapiro, executive director of Insignia ESG in Stamford. "Technically it's in Fairfield County, but it really operates independently, the reason being its relative inaccessibility to the rest of the county because of Route 7. It can take an hour to get from Danbury to Stamford." Attempts by the state's department of transportation to widen the road are strongly opposed by many residents who fear an increase in traffic and urbanization.
In addition, "from a cachet standpoint, Danbury is low on the scale relative to the rest of the county," Mr. Shapiro said. "But relative to the rest of the county, its housing costs and labor pool are terrific." 
Even though Dow said that it hopes to maintain an East Coast presence, Mr. Tonnessen of Albert Ashforth said that he has "the impression that Dow will disappear as soon as it can."
"When it does there will be more space available," he said, "and that will have a governing effect on the price of office space in Danbury, that is now in the $23 to $25 per square foot range."
Richard Reeves, president of Sunbelt Management, said he was beginning to consider what he would do when Carbide's -- now Dow's -- lease expires in 2006. "We will think about our strategy over the next two years and decide," he said. "It's a long way off."

HEADLINE: Along the Rivers, Routes for Paddlers 

BYLINE:  By CAROLYN BATTISTA 

 BODY:
AT a landing behind a parking lot off Route 3 in Cromwell, about a dozen people eased their canoes and kayaks into the Mattabesset River. Soon they were in a different world from the nearby cars and commerce as they paddled past quiet hillsides looking for birds and making their way toward the big freshwater tidal wetland called Cromwell Meadows.
 On this sunny Saturday morning the Mattabesset, which meets the Connecticut River beyond the Meadows, had risen above its tree-lined banks and resembled a flooded forest. 
 "This is the spring freshet," Michael Lutz said, describing how the melting northern snow had raised the waters of the Connecticut and its tributaries.
Along their route, Mr. Lutz spotted a cormorant darting between the trees, and a fellow paddler, Jim Beck, reported on other river birds. 
"There's a heron that likes to sit by the landing," Mr. Beck said. "Last week I saw a couple of eagles over the Meadows."
The Mattabesset River Canoe/ Kayak Trail, which the two men were following, is scheduled to officially open this summer. The trail continues through the Meadows into the Connecticut, ending at Harbor Park in Middletown.
The trail is one of a growing number of routes in Connecticut that take paddlers down rivers and creeks, into coves, around islands and marshes, past historic sights and close to an impressive variety of birds, animals and plants.
With signs and other materials along the way, these trails help canoeists and kayakers navigate safely, savor the natural world without disturbing it and learn a bit about what they are paddling past. The hope is that the trails will help people enjoy, appreciate and become more protective of the state's waterways.
In recent years at least three such trails have opened: in Cheshire, in Old Lyme and in Essex. Besides the Mattabesset, the other trails scheduled to open this summer are in Deep River and in Norwalk, along with the start of a trail in East Lyme. In the works for next summer are a trail in Old Saybrook and an extensive trail on the Sill and Housatonic rivers stretching from Danbury to Monroe.
"There's an explosion of interest in canoeing and kayaking," said J. H. Torrance Downes, a regional planner who designed several trails. He said paddlers welcomed trails that have informative signs and brochures.
The Quinnipiac River Watershed Association got things going around 1995, with help from the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection and the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven. Members of the association put numbered signs at sites along the riverbank and printed the Quinnipiac River Canoeable Trail Guide, a booklet with entries corresponding to the signs.
"It's an educational trail," said Mary Mushinksy, executive director of the association, "and it's a way of enticing people down to the river."
The trail follows a quiet stretch of water through Cheshire with numbered sites, including an upland forest that buffers the river and a spot where otters like to romp.
In 1998, the Connecticut River Estuary Regional Planning Agency started a trail that became a model for the others. The project got its start when Peter Webster, first selectman of Essex and a longtime kayaker, suggested to Mr. Downes of the river planning agency, that canoe and kayak trails would help people explore and appreciate the lower Connecticut and its tributaries.
Mr. Downes started scouting routes, reading and talking with biologists, historians, fishermen and others who knew the river. In 1998, the river planning agency received a grant from the D.E.P.'s Long Island Sound Fund for the trail in Old Lyme. Since then the Essex, the Deep River, the Mattabesset River and the Norwalk Islands trails have been developed with support from the Long Island Sound Fund, along with help from towns and other sources.
In May, the fund approved $6,184 to establish the Old Saybrook trail and $25,000 for a sign, ramp and floating dock on the East Lyme side of the Niantic River.
The trails aided by the Long Island Sound Fund follow the pattern devised for the Old Lyme trail by Mr. Downes. There are no signs along the way, but there is a big sign with a map at a launch site, and paddlers can carry along a laminated brochure. Each brochure includes a map, illustrations and information about what can be seen. The brochures also include information about tides, currents, safety regulations, approximate paddling times and areas that should not be disturbed, such as the feeding and nesting sites for birds.
Following tidal creeks, the Connecticut River Estuary Canoe/Kayak Trail in Old Lyme includes views of the 500-acre Great Island salt marsh and of Griswold Point, a shifting sand spit. Paddlers checking the brochure learn that off that spit, in 1775, David Bushnell of Old Saybrook launched his submarine, the Turtle. They also learn why salt marshes matter.
The Connecticut River Estuary Canoe/Kayak Trail in Essex meanders through four coves and along the river; its brochure points out where birds feed and where 18th-century shipyards turned out splendid sailing vessels.
This season the Connecticut River Estuary Canoe/Kayak Trail in Deep River will open, with one of its three launch sites at the Town Landing on the river. This trail includes passages into Pratt and Post Coves, both freshwater tidal wetlands. A brochure explains just how the tides of Long Island Sound affect such wetlands; it also notes that ships once delivered ivory for the local factories that produced combs and piano keys at the Town Landing. 
For the Norwalk Islands Canoe/ Kayak Trail, the Southwestern Regional Planning Agency hopes to have its sign ready by early summer, with the brochures following later, said Rich Stoecker, a planner at Southwestern agency. Starting from Calf Pasture Beach, Norwalk, the trail will include two loops in Long Island Sound.
"An interesting aspect of this trail is its access to some of the publicly owned islands and its connection with ground trails on the islands," Mr. Stoecker said.
Paddlers will encounter islands that are wildlife refuges and islands that have public beaches. On Sheffield Island they will see the 19th-century lighthouse maintained as a museum by the Norwalk Seaport Association. (In the summer, for $3, they can stop for a climb to the top.)
Mr. Stoecker said the idea was for people to enjoy the islands and, at the same time, gain a "heightened appreciation for the resources of the Sound and the need for better protection and stewardship."
The town of East Lyme hopes to have its floating dock with ramp in place at Cini Park on the Niantic River by late summer. There will also be a big sign advising paddlers on how to avoid nearby strong currents and areas of large-boat traffic as well as providing information on local history and natural features.
The long-range plans are for a complete trail, on the river's quiet, scenic stretches north of the dock. Next summer, the Old Saybrook trail will open in North and South Coves.
Meanwhile, the Mattabesset River Canoe/Kayak Trail is already showing people a steam that is beautiful and full of life. 
"It's a river that we're trying to take back and draw people to," said Jane Brawerman, director of the Connecticut Riverwatch Program at the Middlesex County Soil and Water Conservation District Inc. The district established the trail with help from volunteers, including members of the Mattabesset River Watershed Association, an advocacy group.
The new Mattabesset brochure notes that the river, though cleaner than it once was, still gets polluted run-off from many sources, including lawns, roads and construction sites. But the brochure also includes drawings of thriving river plants, like wild rice, and describes the Meadows, an important conservation area that is home to many birds and a nursery for anadromous fish.
The Saturday paddlers moved nicely along the Mattabesset, sometimes chatting about the locals (muskrats, snapping turtles), at other times muttering about such topics as lawn pesticides.
"It's part of the mission to get people aware of their environment, so they'll think about what they do on land and how it affects the water," said Mr. Lutz, who is on the board of directors of the Soil and Water Conservation District. 
Other efforts to guide paddlers include two folders (with maps): the Mattabesset River Canoe Guide and the Willimantic River Recreation Guide.
While the organized trails are laid out to be reasonably short, safe and doable -- a few hours of steady paddling, without major difficulties -- each of these folders briefly describes an entire river, noting launch sites and also warning paddlers about areas with rough water or obstacles like dams. The Mattabesset folder covers 12.6 miles, the Willimantic 23 miles.
Something bigger and different, is one the way. The Housatonic Valley Economic Development Partnership is planning a 38-mile trail on the Sill and Housatonic rivers. The trail will start on the Sill in Danbury, follow that north to meet the Housatonic at New Milford, and then continue on the Housatonic to the Stevenson Dam in Monroe. Boat launches are to be placed about every five miles.
The Housatonic River Valley Trail also differs from the others in that it is being developed by the economic development partnership, said Peg Daley, project director for the trail. The idea is to increase tourism as well as the quality of life in the area. The trail will also draw attention to the improved state of the Sill, which once ran in the colors of dyes dumped by Danbury hat makers.
Ms. Daley hopes the trail will be open by next summer. She said the project has the support of the public, a grant from the National Park Service and technical assistance from the King's Mark Resource Conservation and Development Area of the United States Department of Agriculture, but more help was needed.
"The most difficult thing is finding money," she said.
More trails are expected.
"Interest has spread to other groups," said Kate Hughes, coordinator of the Long Island Sound Fund, who added that she had gotten inquiries about starting other trails.

Tidbits for Treks on Water
For the Connecticut River Estuary, the Mattabesset River and the Norwalk Islands trails, the laminated brochures are free. The estuary trail brochures are available at several locations, including area town halls and libraries.
Folders from the Mattabesset River Watershed Association and the Willimantic River Alliance are also free. There is a small fee for materials from the Quinnipiac River Watershed Association.
For information about Connecticut's canoe/kayak trails contact:
Connecticut River Estuary Regional Planning Agency: (860) 388-3497.
The Housatonic Valley River Trail: (203) 426-3830.
Quinnipiac River Watershed Association: (203) 237-2237.
Southwestern Regional Planning Agency: (203) 316-5190.

HEADLINE: Battle Continues Over Mall That Won't Die 

BYLINE:  By LINDA SASLOW 

DATELINE: SYOSSET 

 BODY:
SURPRISES are unlikely at Tuesday's scheduled meeting of the Oyster Bay Town Board, when its seven members are expected to vote down the Mall at Oyster Bay. But even if the developer of the proposed shopping mall loses, the deepest disappointment seems to be reserved for anyone who hopes the vote will end the most bitterly contested development dispute in recent Nassau County history.
 The proposed mall, on a 39-acre Syosset site formerly owned by the Cerro Wire and Cable Company, has been a source of controversy in the Town of Oyster Bay for the last seven years, since the developer, the Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., proposed a 950,000-square-foot shopping center with upscale anchor stores that could include Neiman Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor. 
 Although the developer has downsized the original proposal twice, first to 860,000 square feet and in April to 750,000 square feet, local residents, concerned about the impact of mall traffic, have been unrelenting in their opposition, while supporters have been equally vociferous in touting the economic benefits. 
Some heavyweights have joined the fray. While the Nassau-Suffolk Building Trades Council has endorsed the project, the Nassau County Council of Chambers of Commerce has opposed it. After Simon Properties, owner of five million square feet of Long Island shopping centers including Roosevelt Field, Walt Whitman Mall and the Mall at the Source in Westbury, joined a consortium of civic and business groups to block the project, accusations went as far as to suggest that Joseph Mondello, the Nassau County Republican Party chairman who is also a partner in the law firm that represents Simon Properties, had strong-armed the town supervisor, John Venditto, to oppose the mall.
Last month, the Town Board voted 6 to 1 to adopt the findings of the town's environmental review committee, which concluded that the mall would have a negative impact on the environment that outweighed any possible economic benefits. Interviews with several members indicated that the board's vote on Tuesday will not contradict the acceptance of the environmental report.
"The dominant factor is traffic density and its impact on the environment," Mr. Venditto said. "Having accepted these findings, the board would be hard pressed to approve this project."
But the board's action drew angry criticism from the developer, because the environmental review committee made its evaluation based on its earlier plan of 860,000 square feet, ignoring the revised plan that reduced the size of the mall by more than 100,000 square feet.
"The new proposal had effectively mitigated the concerns raised by a previous report prepared by the town that reviewed issues ranging from traffic to quality of life," said Morton Weber, a Melville lawyer who represents the developer. "It demonstrated a willingness by the developer to compromise and negotiate."
While Mr. Venditto acknowledged the inevitability of a court challenge, he dismissed Mr. Weber's argument.
"For the last four years we've been moving the process along on the basis of an 860,000-square-foot mall," the supervisor said. "Now, at the 11th hour, 59th minute and 59th second, along came the applicant, apparently reacting to adverse environmental findings, changing the application to 750,000 square feet with the assumption that if this doesn't work, they'll continue to scale it down. It's like a jury who has been listening to a trial for many months and as they're ready to vote, along comes the prosecutor with a new piece of evidence and no chance for the defense to respond. My sense of fairness was that we couldn't accept the new proposal at the last minute."
The majority of board members also supported the findings of the environmental review committee.
"This has been one of the most thorough processes in my history of more than 12 years on the board," said Leonard Symons, a Republican. "There has been a huge amount of input both from experts and from the public. Part of good government is being able to listen to all sides and then make an intelligent decision. There has to be some finality to this never-ending story."
Anthony Macagnone, a Democrat, the only board member who voted against accepting the environmental findings and who has publicly supported the Mall at Oyster Bay, said, "I thought the report was ambiguous in its findings. It also contradicted an earlier report that indicated that economic factors outweighed environmental factors."
Bonnie Eisler, another Democratic board member, would not disclose how she will vote this week, but said, "The adoption of the environmental findings is indicative as to how the board is going to vote. It's up to us as the lead agency to decide whether the economic benefits outweigh these environmental issues."
But regardless of the board's vote on Tuesday, the saga seems destined to continue, in court.
"We're not going away," Mr. Weber said. "We are anticipating a no vote from the town and would be shocked if they vote otherwise. But Taubman will continue with this fight to build the mall."
Gary Lewi, a Taubman spokesman, said, "This long-term battle has come to a new and uglier phase, and for those who thought the process had come to an end, it hasn't."
Cerro Wire operated at the site adjacent to the Long Island Expressway, manufacturing electrical conduits and copper rods, from the early 1950's until 1986, when it sold the property to the Tribune Company, the Chicago newspaper publisher, which now also owns Newsday. In 1983, the state Department of Environmental Conservation declared the site a hazardous waste site, but after a cleanup it was removed from the list in 1994.
Proponents of the mall have said it would bring upscale shopping opportunities and thousands of jobs.
"This mall means a lot of jobs for us," said Jack Kennedy, president of the Nassau-Suffolk Building Trades Council. "We anticipate between 3,500 and 4,000 jobs during construction. The developer has made a commitment that all work will be done by union members."
Mr. Lewi said that once built, the mall would provide 2,500 full- or part-time jobs and a $75 million annual payroll.
On the other side are 26 chambers of commerce and civic, education and business groups united as the Cerro Wire Coalition to block the project. 
Howard Avrutine, a Syosset lawyer who represents the Birchwood Civic Association, said the regional group represented 44,000 families in the Town of Oyster Bay who were concerned about land use, traffic and other environmental issues.
"This mall is just the wrong project for this property," he said.
Dave McDonough, president of the Nassau Council of Chambers of Commerce, agreed. 
"This mall would mean too many dollars taken from small businesses," he said. "We're not against growth and development, but against something that would hurt our own constituency."
The board's vote, although clearly not the end of this seven-year debate, will be a turning point.
Mr. Venditto said: "We've been criticized for taking so long, but I'd rather have the process be too open than have anyone feel they didn't get a fair say. Whatever subsequent litigation we face, I want to be comfortable that when any judge reviews this record, he will stand behind our decision."

HEADLINE: Conservationists Are Divided on Cross-Sound Gas Pipeline 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
A PROPOSAL to build a 40-mile-long natural gas pipeline across Long Island Sound has divided conservation groups in New York and Connecticut, not just along state lines but along philosophies. At the heart of the disagreement is whether the project will threaten the environment or improve it.
 On the Connecticut side are the organizations that contend the pipeline will destroy oyster and lobster habitats and fish breeding areas and will endanger delicate wetlands. Many of the groups that oppose the gas pipeline also opposed the proposal for a cross-Sound electrical cable that was rejected by regulators in March, primarily because of environmental issues. 
 "It's very unlikely they could put a gas pipeline across the Sound in a way that would be environmentally acceptable," said Barbara C. Gordon, the executive director of the Connecticut Seafood Council, an industry group. "There are alternatives for utility companies, and there is no need to damage the environment." 
On the other side of the Sound are some environmental advocates who say that growing electricity demands will require new power plants and that gas-fired generators will produce much less air pollution than coal- or oil-fired plants.
"From an energy point of view, we support it," said Neal M. Lewis, the executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network, a grass-roots citizens' group with an office in Massapequa. "What we're calling for in the short term is more gas to replace the oil-burning plants on Long Island."
Some Long Island groups have avoided taking any position on the project yet. "We don't want to see brownouts in Suffolk County and have people saying, 'You dopey environmentalists caused this,' but on the other hand, we don't think they have proved the need for this," said Howard R. Meinke, the president of the North Fork Environmental Council, in Mattituck. 
The pipeline proposal is being put forward by the Islander East Pipeline Company, equally owned by KeySpan and Duke Energy, based in Charlotte, N.C. John P. Sheridan, a spokesman for Duke Energy in Boston, said that the pipeline would run along existing utility and railroad rights of way and across industrial properties.
The new pipe, which would would vary in size from 24 to 30 inches in diameter, would tap into an existing Algonquin gas pipeline in North Branford, Conn, just east of New Haven, and would then run south through Branford into the Sound. From there it would run southward to the Town of Brookhaven, where it would hook into existing pipelines on Long Island Power Authority property in Wading River. The new pipeline would initially transport 250,000 decatherms of gas a day, or enough to heat about 600,000 homes. 
To avoid the most sensitive shellfish areas, Islander East would use a horizontal drilling technique to sink the pipe 30 to 40 feet below the seabed for about 4,000 feet after it leaves Branford. The company plans to meet with officials on the Long Island side to determine what areas it must avoid there.
"We are taking every possible step to reduce the impact on the environment," Mr. Sheridan said.
So far, he added, public comments have been more positive than negative. "People realize there will be a need for natural gas resources in the 2003-2004 time period, and Islander East will come on line just in time to meet that need," Mr. Sheridan said.
State and federal regulatory agencies will have to balance all the arguments when the formal proposal is submitted this summer, after which a 14- to 16-month review period will begin. 
Local officials on both sides of the Sound seem to be waiting for more details on the need for the pipeline and its potential impact before taking an firm position.
For example, Inez Birbiglia, the spokeswoman for the Town of Brookhaven, said that officials there were waiting for an "energy summit" on July 12, with representatives from the Long Island Power Authority, Brookhaven National Laboratory, KeySpan and other groups.
"We want to examine what's good about it, and what's not, and we want to hear about any alternatives," Mrs. Birbiglia said. "We want to hear from the experts before we set a clear direction for the township. We want to be careful about where new energy sources go, but at the same time, we want to be realistic, and do what makes the most economic sense for our residents. Everyone is watching what's happening in California and asking, 'Is that what's in our future?' "
Environmentalists in Connecticut remember one pipeline that had harmful environmental results. In 1996, the Iroquois Pipeline Operating Company paid a $22 million fine for damaging 200 rivers and streams when it constructed a pipeline through New York and Connecticut in 1991 and 1992.
Mrs. Gordon of the Connecticut Seafood Council said while measures to protect the environment have been implemented since then, the Islander East pipeline would still cause significant environmental disruption. She contended that silt from the digging in the Sound could settle over shellfish beds, which would take many years to recover.
"It's very unlikely that they could do this in a way that would be environmentally sound," Mrs. Gordon said. The council will discuss the proposal during its next meeting on June 19, she said. The Islander East pipeline venture is designed to carry gas from fields off Sable Island in Canada into the United States. It is one of six major projects proposed for New England, according to the New England Gas Association, which represents distribution companies serving 2.3 million customers.
Mr. Sheridan of Duke Energy said that the Islander East project would give southern New England and Long Island a direct link to a major energy source. 
"Gas will be flowing north to south, where typically for the last 50 years it has been running in the other direction, north from the Gulf of Mexico," he said. "That's going to make additional supplies of gas available for Connecticut and Long Island distributors."
Thomas M. Kiley, the president of the gas association, said that the entire region would benefit from Islander East. "By adding more pipeline capacity, it makes for a more robust distribution system, which will give customers more choice in terms of suppliers," he said. He noted that in a recent study, the regional electric power distribution agency, ISO New England, concluded by 2005, 10,000 to 11,000 megawatts of additional electricity generating capacity will be needed, and it called for improving the gas distribution pipeline to do it.
Sarah J. Meyland, the executive director and general counsel for the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, in Farmingdale, said that her group had not taken a position on the pipeline, but she noted that it could provide a valuable option.
"Down the line, as fuel cells become more commercially available, we will need a supply of natural gas," Ms. Meyland said. "That's a future technology that could prove to be very valuable for Long Island."
Mr. Kiley said pipelines were generally "environmentally benign" once they were constructed. In fact, in some areas the open spaces above them can be put to good use. "A lot of people use them for recreation activities, such as biking and snowmobiling," he said. "They have proven to be pretty good neighbors in most cases."

HEADLINE: An Uncomfortable Debate 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
ORIGINALLY founded as a parish and named for a Congregational minister, Brookfield is not a place typically associated with shops selling X-rated videos and sexual aids. But town leaders are considering whether to create a business district that would allow such shops, an issue that has everyone from grandmothers to a Roman Catholic priest talking about sexual devices and pornographic films.
 It is an uncomfortable debate that is not confined to Brookfield. Several towns around the state have been forced to consider the creation of such districts. While no one is putting up welcome signs for the sex industry, officials are learning that without zoning regulations, such businesses can almost open up wherever they wish. 
 That's what happened in Brookfield, a town known for furniture stores and its craft center. Last year, the Satin & Silk Sensations shop, with its signs forexotic lingerie and videos, opened on Route 7. The shop is in the town's central business district, next door to a pizzeria that is popular with teenagers and families. It didn't take long for shocked residents to complain to the town.
"It's next to a pizza place where I bring my five-and-a-half-year-old son," said Mary Ann Capron, owner of Merles Barber Shop, which is located just south of the store. "I don't want to walk by there. It's the porno crap that's got to go."
But the town soon discovered that the shop broke no zoning laws. In fact, the laws didn't even bring up the subject. So not wanting similar stores to open up around town, officials decided they had no choice but to consider setting up a zone that would confine the shops to one area of town.
"We are not trying to legislate morality or anything like that," Martin Foncello, the first selectman, said. "But we are trying to restrict, in terms of taste, the type of things you would like to see in the town."
The proposed ordinance, which is not expected to be voted on for months, puts Brookfield on a growing list of communities that are grappling with the presence of adult businesses that have long been associated with urban centers but are now popping up in inner ring suburbs. 
In recent years, municipalities including Burlington, New Milford, Thomaston, Windham and Wallingford have adopted ordinances or amended zoning regulations to include sections on adult-oriented businesses. East Hartford and New London also have them in place.
"I think there were some other towns having some problems and I believe they wanted to get something in place, too, so it didn't catch them blindsided," Kip Brammer, the first selectman of Thomaston, a Litchfield County town of about 7,500 residents, said of its decision to include a section on adult entertainment businesses in its zoning regulations. "You don't want to lose sight of your character and that type of thing but I think they were trying to protect us from businesses overflowing from different things that tend to be from bigger cities."
Kevin Maloney, spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, said it was a quality of life issue.
"They tend to have an impact on the commercial and or residential neighborhoods that they exist in or are located near," he said. "No town wants to be known for having an adult entertainment business. And certainly it's going to attract traffic to that area that other people would prefer would not be there."
So towns put them somewhere else. David Hubbard, director of community planning and economic development for New Milford, said his town created a zone for the sex industry in an industrial area off of Route 7.
"All of the communities are essentially faced with the prospect of either providing a designated zone for whoever may wish to undertake such a business or suddenly facing them any place in town," he said. "For instance, if somebody opened an exotic lingerie store in the middle of the town green, I think that would raise an awful lot of conversation, and so we eliminated that possibility. If someone were to open up an exotic dance club directly next door to a church, it would probably create some conversation. So we just moved to minimize the conversation."
The owner of the Brookfield shop, Nicole Lynn Jones, who listed a New Milford address on her zoning application, and a female sales clerk refused to comment about the issue. According to town records, Ms. Jones applied for a certificate of zoning compliance on July 18, 2000, writing in the application that she intended to sell clothing, fashion and accessories.
But what Ms. Jones referred to as accessories, others called X-rated material. In addition to lingerie and swimwear, the store sells sexual aids and pornographic videos. 
"I wouldn't consider that accessories in a store," said a longtime resident, Mary Lou Moker, a grandmother of 12 who visited the store with a friend under the guise of buying a bridal present. "That would be the last thing on my mind."
"I am not a prude," added Ms. Moker who filed a complaint with the zoning office in September. "But I draw the line to what should be exposed in public and especially when there is a pizza parlor where families go to."
Not everyone is upset by the store, saying it is perfectly legal and wouldn't be open if people weren't shopping there.
"I think they should just leave her alone," Gail C. Apilado, owner of the Village Liquor Shop, said of the store's owner. "She's still open, isn't she? She's making money."
Ms. Moker and other residents have questioned why officials can't cite what they say is a misleading application to shut down the store. But Zoning Commissioner William Schappert said it would be a difficult task to determine whether Ms. Jones intended to deceive zoning officials.
"It's a hot potato from a legal point of view," Mr. Schappert said. "You'd have to get 16 lawyers to figure that out and the Zoning Commission isn't about to do that."
So some residents approached their priest, the Rev. Albert D. Audette Jr., pastor of St. Marguerite Bourgeoys Roman Catholic Church in Brookfield. A widower with four children and 15 grandchildren, Mr. Audette visited the store and was amazed at what he found. While he acknowledged that many businesses sell pornographic magazines, Mr. Audette said that devices such as mechanical sexual aids should not be sold in a store.
"The question is would you have this stuff in your home?" Mr. Audette asked. "Would you give it to your children? And so why do we sell it?"
Mr. Audette, who said he believed such merchandise should be sold strictly through mail order catalogs, called local religious leaders to ask them to protest the store. He expressed hope that they would meet with Mr. Foncello in the coming weeks to discuss the issue.
Meanwhile, Mr. Foncello's office has been flooded with calls from people who noticed the store with its hot pink door and window trim while stuck in traffic. With Sal's Pizza II located next door, residents expressed concern that it would be a teenage magnet. 
Mr. Foncello asked the town attorney, Edward McCreery, to investigate whether such stores could be prohibited and learned that it would be unlawful to ban them. So he and the other two members of the Board of Selectmen have proposed an adult-oriented business establishment ordinance that would regulate similar businesses should they come to town. 
Under the proposal, about 1,500 feet of frontage on the west side of Route 7, north of Production Drive, near the New Milford border and its own such district, would be designated for such businesses.
The ordinance would prevent the businesses from opening within 500 feet of a residential structure or property lines of a school, day-care center, senior center, restaurant or establishments that sell alcoholic beverages other than beer or wine for on-premises consumption.
The businesses would not be allowed to have entertainers or employees who expose certain parts of their bodies.
But at a recent public hearing, residents questioned whether such an ordinance is appropriate. One resident read out loud "giggly words" like breasts and buttocks, and claimed that it looked like the town was trying to entice such businesses into town, Mr. Foncello said.
"We were certainly not encouraging anything," he said. "We are trying to restrict the area that they can operate in, being mindful of everybody's constitutional rights."
The proposal was later sent to a town meeting where residents asked officials to toughen it. Mr. Foncello said the Board of Selectmen is seeking additional input, including whether the proposed zone, which would be sandwiched between a preschool that is under construction and a proposed worship center in New Milford, is a proper location.
Business owners in that area don't think it is. "We don't want it here," said John Ambrosi, a partner in Alpine Cutlery on Route 7. "There's enough crazy people around. Whoever needs to be adult entertained is either a pervert or a nut job."
But Frank Santora, pastor of the Danbury-based Bright Clouds Ministries, which wants to build a community and family life worship center in New Milford on land just north of the proposed zone, saw it as a chance to help people.
"My conviction is that people who turn to those types of entertainment are searching for inner peace or searching for some type of comfort, but they are looking in the wrong place," Mr. Santora said. "I believe that just the presence of godly light and voice in that area would be an alternative for them that can perhaps be a blessing for them."
Mr. Hubbard, the New Milford official, said he doesn't believe these kind of businesses can survive in small towns, pointing out that the only topless bar in New Milford closed down several years ago.
"The reality of this is these types of districts flourish when there are two elements present," he said. "The first element is a larger population so that they have the patronage base. And the second element is anonymity and they tend to go hand in hand.
"What we have up here is a very low density, rural part of the world, which lacks both dense population and anonymity," he added. "If Harry parks his pickup truck in one of these places, his wife, Julie, is going to know in about 32 seconds. There are just no secrets in a small town."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; 
Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. "Coming Soon," the sign says, "Starbucks Coffey."
 Both a play on words and a joking reference to the neighborhood's nascent gentrification, the sign does not seem an accurate prediction -- at least not yet. 
 With a long history as a shipping port and industrial district, the neighborhood, not quite two miles across from the Battery at the tip of Manhattan, is thoroughly urban. But in the evenings it is as quiet as a remote and leafy suburb, a result of its relative inaccessibility and isolation. There are no subway stops in Red Hook, and it is bounded by water on three sides and the elevated Gowanus Expressway on the fourth. 
While other Brooklyn waterfront neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Dumbo have developed an image of youthful urban chic in recent years, Red Hook is still largely the gritty industrial district it has been for decades. Though the faux Starbucks sign is only a joke, neighborhood boosters point to several developments of recent years as increasing the area's attractiveness. 
With the introduction of the MetroCard for buses in 1995, the trip to Red Hook from Manhattan on public transit suddenly became easier, and the cost fell to $1.50 from $3. In addition, a proposed ferry that could begin operating as early as next summer and would circulate through points along the Upper New York Bay, including Red Hook, downtown Manhattan and Staten Island, would make getting to the neighborhood easier still.
Another major development occurred in May 2000, as the city was deciding how to handle household waste after the close of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island this year. When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a plan for garbage disposal that did not include a waste transfer station in Red Hook, it erased a big question mark hanging over the neighborhood's real estate values, said Frank P. Manzione, a real estate agent who does business in Red Hook.
In addition, two years ago, the propeller on the flushing tunnel of the Gowanus Canal, the neighborhood's eastern border, which was notorious for its stagnant, foul-smelling water, was replaced and reactivated, circulating the water for the first time in more than 30 years and eliminating the stench.
Within the last few years, new businesses have opened in the neighborhood, including the Independence Community Bank branch at Lorraine and Columbia Streets, which opened in 1997, and the neighborhood's first restaurant in many years to be open at night, the Liberty Heights Tap Room. The restaurant takes its name from an allusion to the area's proximity to the Statue of Liberty, a name that some feel avoids the negative connotations of Red Hook and may itself help attract new residents.
The neighborhood is divided into two quite different sections by Richards Street, which runs down its center. To the east is the area known as "the Front," or "the Houses," which mainly consists of the largest public housing project in Brooklyn, the Red Hook Houses, 30 red brick buildings that are home to roughly 8,500 people. To the west of Richards Street is "the Back," or "the Point," where turn-of-the-century and Civil War-era brick row houses and frame houses are interspersed among warehouses, industrial buildings and weedy or trash-filled vacant lots.
The neighborhood's main commercial areas are on Columbia and Lorraine Streets near the projects and on Van Brunt Street from Verona to Dikeman Streets. On Van Brunt, one can find the AR bagelry, the Red Hook Coffee Shop and the Red Hook chapter of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
The Dutch gave Red Hook its name in the 17th century for its peninsular shape and its ruddy soil, said John Manbeck, the Brooklyn borough historian. (Another bulge on the Brooklyn shore -- now known as Bay Ridge -- was called Yellow Hook until yellow fever epidemics in the 1790's made the name unsavory, Mr. Manbeck said.)
During the Civil War years, while Park Slope was still farmland, the neighborhood was already a busy commercial district. Forty-five years ago Red Hook reached its greatest population, 22,000. Now it is about half that. "It's a rundown waterfront village," said John McGettrick, co-chairman of the Red Hook Civic Association. "You see shadows and images of a community that once was bustling."
At its height, Red Hook was largely populated by Italian and Irish dock and factory workers and their families. A few institutions hark back to those days, including the local Roman Catholic church, Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary, and the R. M. Amendola Italian-American Grocery, which has stood on Van Brunt Street for 41 years.
Ralph Amendola, 65, and his younger sister, Sue, lifelong residents of Red Hook who run the store, have watched their neighborhood fall from its pre-World War II heyday into a desolate, crime-ridden corner of Brooklyn as the shipping industry moved to New Jersey and blocks were razed for a container port and a sewer line.
"They took a lot of houses down," Mr. Amendola recalled from his seat by the store's window. "The movie house, the Pioneer, they took that down. The grain elevator, that stopped."
WITH no new housing in decades, the availability of buildings is low, and prices depend a great deal on whether a building has been recently renovated. Newly renovated multiple-family buildings sell for $350,000 to $425,000, while others usually go for $250,000 to $350,000, Mr. Manzione said.
The neighborhood has one-family buildings and six-family buildings and everything in between, but the majority are for two or three families and are owner occupied. Few residential buildings are taller than four stories. They are mostly brick, but there are also frame houses and a few rare brownstones. 
Housing prices depend on location as well. Residential buildings can often be found on blocks that also house warehouses or industrial buildings. These usually sell for $100,000 less than comparable houses on the prime all-residential blocks.
The most desirable streets in Red Hook are Coffey Street, especially the block near the waterfront between Ferris and Conover Streets but also the blocks extending inland to Dwight Street; Pioneer Street between Van Brunt and Richards Streets; and Dikeman Street between Conover and Dwight.
Values throughout the neighborhood have been rising in recent years. Five years ago, prices began increasing 2 to 3 percent a year, said Gerard Longo, president of Madison Estates and Properties. Within the past two years, prices have gone up 10 to 12 percent a year.
The increase is partly the result of demand for the area by artists. "They're making their way into Red Hook," said Benny Torres, the sales agent who specializes in Red Hook at Joe Felix Realty in Bushwick. "They need new space because they're priced out of Williamsburg."
Red Hook is only 15 minutes from Manhattan's financial district by the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, but it is not an area with many commuters. "The commute is terrible, especially in the winter, at night, when you're waiting there at Jay Street" for the bus, said Geoff Porter, 30, a freelance writer who lives on Van Brunt Street. "This is a neighborhood for people who work at home."
Parking is not a problem. To many people, it's a necessity. "You need a car out here," Mr. Porter said.
The small but growing artistic community in Red Hook has made its mark at a few spots along lower Van Brunt Street, which is home to the Red Hook Zawia Gallery, an open furniture design studio run by Craig Palmer, 32, and an annual art exhibit put on by the Brooklyn Working Artists Coalition, a nonprofit group. The exhibit, in a two-story warehouse at the Beard Street Pier at the southern end of Van Brunt Street, features works by 200 artists. It runs for six spring weekends and will end next Sunday. 
Two community centers have opened recently. One is the first new building to be constructed in the neighborhood in many years, the Good Shepherd Services Center, an $8 million, 35,000-square-foot building at Conover and Wolcott Streets, which opened last month. The center houses administrative offices, a family counseling program and the South Brooklyn Community Academy, an alternative school for youths who have dropped out of high school.
The other is the Red Hook Community Justice Center, a community court and social service center opened a year ago by the New York State court system. The center offers job counseling and classes to help people get their high school equivalency degrees and has office space for the Legal Aid Society and AmeriCorps.
But the center's existence points to the neighborhood's troubled past. The movement to create the center began after Patrick Daly, a beloved principal at P.S. 15 on Sullivan Street, was killed in a drug-related gunfight one morning in December 1992 as he searched the Houses for a 9-year-old boy who had left school crying after a fight.
That year 7 homicides, 22 rapes, 490 robberies and 359 assaults were reported in the 76th precinct, which encompasses Red Hook, Cobble Hill, Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens. Last year, reports of those crimes were down to 1 homicide, 6 rapes, 61 robbieries and 46 assaults.
Mr. Daly was succeeded by Mary E. Manti, who helped start a chorus and a band at the school. Thirty-one percent of students at P.S. 15 read at or above grade level, a figure slightly below the citywide average. The neighborhood's other elementary school is P.S. 27, on Huntington Street between the Houses and the Gowanus Expressway, where 17 percent of students read at or above grade level.
Children go to middle schools in Community School District 15, which extends from Cobble Hill to Windsor Terrace to Sunset Park. The only middle school in Red Hook is the School for Leadership in the Environment, with 80 students in Grades 6 to 8, which is within P.S. 27. Middle School 142 is just outside Red Hook on Henry Street.
Besides the Beard Street pier, the neighborhood has two other public piers. One is the Red Hook Garden Pier at the southern end of Conover Street, where marigolds and irises bloom next to the Waterfront Museum, which exhibits artifacts from a time when barges plied New York Bay and the Hudson River. It is housed on an antique barge docked at the pier.
The other is the Louis Valentino Jr. Pier, a concrete pier and ramp for canoes and kayaks that opened in 1998 at the cobble-stone paved western end of Coffey Street. It is managed by the Parks Department and named for a firefighter from Red Hook who was killed in 1996 in the line of duty.
On weekends neighbors gather at the pier to walk their dogs, enjoy a magazine or gaze out across the bay and talk. On a recent sunny Saturday, Virginia Santivanez, 29, a film special effects designer, let her dog play in the grass nearby.
The pier offers a view of Staten Island, Jersey City and Governor's Island and what many say is the best view of the Statue of Liberty from land.
Looking to the north, Manhattan can be seen but not heard. That's how Ms. Santivanez likes it. "To me," she said, "this is the most civilized place in New York."

IF YOU BUILD IT . . .: Among the Civil War-era warehouses at the foot of Van Brunt Street are old-looking trolley tracks and overhead power wires. Unlike the warehouses nearby, these are not vestiges of a Brooklyn past. They are the newly built first leg of what the Brooklyn Historic Railway Association hopes within two years will become a $1 fare trolley line that will run 1.6 miles from the Red Hook waterfront to Borough Hall. The line now extends just a quarter mile along the waterfront, and the trolleys are driven only on special occasions. But the association is awaiting government financing that would allow it to extend the tracks a half-mile to the intersection of Coffey and Richards Streets, where trolley tracks that have not been used since 1951 lie buried under three inches of pavement. The group hopes to use these tracks for much of the route to Borough Hall. "The trolleys will help reintegrate Red Hook into downtown Brooklyn," said Bob Diamond, president of the railway association. "They have a nostalgic charm that will help to improve the area."
