HEADLINE: A Pipeline Proposal for the Sound 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
A PROPOSAL to build a 40-mile stretch of natural gas pipeline across Long Island Sound between Connecticut and Long Island has divided conservation groups on both sides of the Sound, not just along state lines, but along philosophies. One side said the pipeline will hurt the environment; the other said it will help.
 On the Connecticut side are the organizations that contend the pipeline should be judged based on the oyster and lobster habitat and fish breeding areas it would destroy and the delicate wetlands it would cross. Many of the groups that oppose it also fought a cross-Sound electric distribution line earlier this year that was rejected by regulators, primarily because of environmental issues. 
 "It's very unlikely they could put a gas pipeline across the Sound in a way that would be environmentally acceptable," said Barbara C. Gordon, executive director of the Connecticut Seafood Council. "There are alternatives for utility companies, and there is no need to damage the environment. These are things that, once you damage them, you don't get the opportunity to bring them back to the quality you had before." 
On the other side of the Sound, some environmental groups say growing electric demands on Long Island will require new power plants, and that natural gas-fired generators produce much less air pollution than coal or oil plants, and there are not the radioactive waste problems of nuclear power.
"From an energy point of view, we support it," said Neal M. Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network. "What we're calling for in the short term is more gas to replace the oil burning plants on Long Island. There are a few plants that can burn either, but if you want them to switch to gas there has to be a better supply of it."
The pipeline would start from the existing Algonquin gas pipeline in North Branford, south through Branford, into Long Island Sound, and end in Wading River, N.Y. The pipe would would vary in size from 24 to 30 inches in diameter and be able to transport 250,000 decatherms of gas a day -- enough to heat about 600,000 homes. The companies behind the proposal, Duke Energy and the Keyspan Corporation, said the pipeline is necessary to help them meet the energy needs of Long Island.
"There are a lot of people in town who are really concerned about this, not only about the impact during construction, but the safety impacts over the long term," said William C. Horne, president of the Branford Land Trust, which owns four properties in the pipeline's path, two with ponds and two with low-lying wetland areas.
Some Long Island-based groups, however, have avoided taking any position on the project yet.
"We don't want to see brownouts in Suffolk County and have people saying, 'You dopey environmentalists caused this,' but on the other hand, we don't think they have proved the need for this," said Howard R. Meinke, president of the North Fork Environmental Council in New York. "The question we want to see answered is, what is the local demand? If this is going to come down to supply power plants that could be built to produce power that would be shipped somewhere else, that's a different story, and the public would be less interested in seeing it built."
John P. Sheridan, a spokesman for Duke Energy, a partner in the Islander East pipeline project along with the Long Island-based Keyspan Corporation, said the company is running the pipe along existing utility and railroad rights of way, and on industrial properties. It has agreed to use a horizontal drilling technique to put the pipe 30 to 40 feet below the seabed for about 4,000 feet after it leaves Branford, Conn., to avoid the most sensitive shellfish areas. The company is meeting with officials on the Long Island side to determine what areas it must avoid there.
"We are taking every possible step to reduce the impact on the environment," Mr. Sheridan said. So far, he said, the public comments have been more positive than negative.
"People realize there will be a need for natural gas resources in the 2003-2004 time period, and Islander East will come on line just in time to meet that need," Mr. Sheridan said.
Joel M. Rinebold, executive director of the Connecticut Siting Council, said state and federal regulatory agencies are going to have to balance all the arguments when the formal proposal is submitted this summer, which will begin a review period estimated at 14 to 16 months.
"It's not a simple on-off, yes-or-no question," Mr. Rinebold said. "It's 'yes' only if it's the best possible corridor, if it is environmentally sound, and due diligence must be applied at each step of the construction process. These projects are large, they're going to be in the ground for many years, so it just makes economic and environmental sense to get it right the first time."
Local officials on both sides of the Sound seem to be waiting for more details on the need for the pipeline, and any potential impact, before taking an firm position. In Brookhaven, where the pipeline will come ashore on Long Island, Inez Birbiglia, a town spokeswoman, said there will be an energy summit on July 12, with representatives from Long Island Power, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Keyspan and other groups.
"We want to examine what's good about it, and what's not, and we want to hear about any alternatives," Mrs. Birbiglia said. "We want to hear from the experts before we set a clear direction for the township.
"We want to be careful about where new energy sources go, but at the same time, we want to be realistic, and do what makes the most economic sense for our residents," she said. "Everyone is watching what's happening in California and asking, 'Is that what's in our future?' "
Islander East is designed to bring gas from fields off Sable Island in Canada down into the United States. It is one of six major projects proposed for New England, according to the New England Gas Association, which represents distribution companies serving 2.3 million customers in the region. Thomas M. Kiley, the association president, said that while it might seem that Islander East is designed to serve Long Island and will only pass through Connecticut, it will provide benefits to the entire region.
"By adding more pipeline capacity, it makes for a more robust distribution system, which will give customers more choice in terms of suppliers," Mr. Kiley said. He noted that in a recent study the regional electric power distribution agency, ISO New England, concluded there will be a need for between 10,000 and 11,000 megawatts of additional generating capacity by 2005, and it called for improving the gas distribution pipeline to do it.
Sarah J. Meyland, executive director and general counsel for the Citizens Campaign for the Environment in Farmingdale, N.Y., said her organization has not taken a position on the pipeline, but has taken no option to oppose it, not only because gas-fired electric plants are more acceptable from an environmental standpoint, but it could open even better options for the future.
Down the line, as fuel cells, which convert natural gas to electricity, become more commercially available, "we will need a supply of natural gas," Ms. Meyland said. "That's a future technology that could prove to be very valuable for Long Island."
Mr. Kiley said pipelines are generally "environmentally benign," once they are constructed, and in fact in some areas provide open space. "A lot of people use them for recreation activities, such as biking and snowmobiling. They have proven to be pretty good neighbors in most cases."
But some environmental organizations in Connecticut recall that the Iroquois Pipeline Operating Company paid a $22 million fine for damaging 200 rivers and streams in a pipeline project that runs through New York and Connecticut.
The Branford Land Trust met with representatives of Islander East recently and voted to oppose the project, though it has agreed to allow environmental, cultural and social surveys on its properties.
"We actually think we're going to be in a stronger position if they know what's on the property than if they're just flying blind," Mr. Horne said.
Mrs. Gordon of the Connecticut Seafood Council said that while the companies have adopted some measures to protect the environment, the disruption would still be significant. For instance, silt from digging a ditch across Long Island Sound could settle over shellfish beds, which would take many years to recover.
"It's very unlikely that they could do this in a way that would be environmentally sound," Mrs. Gordon said.
Her organization will discuss the proposal during its next meeting at 6 p.m. June 19 at the Past Time Club in East Norwalk, though she said the council will probably not take an official position at that time.
Some of the environmental groups have accused Duke of coming in with the pipeline proposal during a period when an energy shortage in California has caused rolling blackouts, and there is worry about a similar situation in the Northeast this summer.
"I think that is on a lot of people's minds," Mr. Sheridan said. But the company is responding to the demand for natural gas, not seeking to take advantage of any fears about energy shortage, he said.

HEADLINE: A Last Best Chance To Revive Camden 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
THE crowd erupts when one of the Camden Riversharks hits a home run, the ball sailing over the green wall, heading for the Benjamin Franklin Bridge looming majestically beyond the outfield. In the month since its opening, Campbell's Field, the new minor league baseball stadium on the banks of the Delaware River, has become a hot destination for mostly white, mostly suburban families looking for a fun night out and a home team worth cheering about.
 It has been a long time since there was anything to root for in Camden, a city that decades ago ran out of disparaging adjectives to describe its squalor. And the notion of heading into the heart of the city for a family outing has been unheard of until recently. 
 To be sure, school-age children may take class trips to the New Jersey State Aquarium and the adjacent Children's Garden, or teenagers might catch a concert at the Tweeter Center, but as soon as the activity is over, visitors flee the city. But now, with the old-fashioned-style brick-and-green stadium joining the aquarium and the concert arena as the third anchor along Camden's re-emerging waterfront -- and with ambitious plans to fill in the spaces between the three major sites -- an unfamiliar sense of optimism is in the air here. 
"I honestly believe that this is and may be the last chance in our lifetime to turn this city around," said Paul Drayton Jr., chief executive of the Delaware River Port Authority. "There are a tremendous number of resources coming to bear on this city. It's the first time we've seen it and the first time it's happening in a coordinated fashion."
With visions of Baltimore's Inner Harbor dancing in its head, the Camden Waterfront Marketing Bureau predicted that in the next five years, visitors to Camden's waterfront would jump from the current level of just over one million to five million annually. If the Philadelphia side of the river can get its plans in order, the projection jumps to 10 to 12 million people visiting both sides of the river each year.
While a proposed $250 million entertainment complex at Philadelphia's Penn's Landing is encountering a number of delays, development along the Camden side of the river continues to buzz along -- to the surprise of many.
After years of wrangling with Bayonne and to a lesser extent Jersey City, Camden won out in its bid be the berth of the much decorated battleship New Jersey, which will open as a fully refurbished museum on Labor Day at its site just outside the Tweeter Center. Next spring, it will be joined by the Moshulu, the floating restaurant that chose to cross the river to Camden after a disastrous pier collapse forced the Philadelphia institution to shut down last year.
To make the trip across the Delaware less cumbersome, pylons are being installed for an aerial tram system that will carry visitors between Philadelphia and Camden by the spring of 2003. A public-private venture to double the size of the aquarium, then adding a restaurant and IMAX theater next to it got closer to reality when the aquarium expansion was included in the state's proposed revitalization package for Camden. Moreover, additional private funds have been raised to convert one of the old RCA plants into luxury waterfront apartments. 
The level of proposed public and private spending now focused on Camden is unprecedented in the city's history, leading those who have long been involved in shaping a new vision for New Jersey's poorest city to believe that for the first time, they are seeing a light at the end of the tunnel.
"This is a good time for Camden," said Jane Kenny, New Jersey's Commissioner of Community Affairs, whose department was given oversight authority over Camden's finances last May and has been instrumental in putting together a proposed $150 million in state aid. "Many people have been paying attention to Camden and right now all systems are go."
Camden is one of only two cities in New Jersey currently under state supervision; the other is East Orange. And while East Orange has turned its $9 million deficit in 1999 into an anticipated $4 million surplus this year, Camden continues to fall short in covering basic city services and balancing its budget. In addition to the $70 million in comprehensive aid New Jersey contributed to the city's $112 million budget this year, the state provided another $13.5 million to close the ever-widening budget gap.
The last four administrations have floated various proposals to save Camden, the latest being the recently announced Camden Rehabilitation and Recovery Act.The proposed legislation will get its first public airing tomorrow when the NJ Senate Economic Growth, Agricultural and Tourism Committee holds a hearing on the rescue package.. 
Under the terms of the proposed legislation, the state would issue a $150 million bond to provide Camden with funds for neighborhood revitalization, job training, new streetscaping and signs, more police and fire service, support for the city's colleges and hospitals and expansion of the aquarium. The colleges and hospitals would have to match the state's contribution, adding another $24 million to the pot.
The package also called for about $5 million in residential tax and rebates and commercial tax incentives, and about $10 million to $15 million in matching private investment at the waterfront. On top of that, Camden County has agreed to kick in $50 million to repair the city's outdated sewer system and take over management of the parks and the 911 system.
To help coordinate the city's recovery and turn the old patterns around, the state would install a chief operating officer here who for the next five years would act as a city manager -- having full power to make appointments, approve expenditures and veto decisions made by city council, the mayor and all city boards. The port authority was named as the agency in control of the funds. 
"In the last 12 years, every management study has shown that there are problems in the city's government," said State Senator Wayne Bryant, the Camden Democrat who drafted the proposed revitalization legislation. "All we've been doing until now is plugging holes. It's time for the state to take a bold approach."
Yet Senator Bryant has become the target of city officials who see the legislation as a wholesale takeover of Camden. Indeed, the newly elected mayor, Gwendolyn Faison, stole the spotlight from Acting Governor DiFrancesco at a news conference two weeks ago by following the announcement of his proposal with a public plea to "please don't take the ability away from me that I can't even change a light bulb," and the promise that "at no price will I sacrifice my democracy."
An inevitable battle between the state and city may result in the entire proposal being tabled. But while the legislation wends its way through various committees, people in Camden are encouraged by what they see going on right now. Throughout the city, words like "momentum" and "renaissance," and phrases like "something magical," or at least "cautious optimism" are being used to describe Camden.
This is an enormous change for a city in which one out of seven houses is abandoned, the county prosecutor's office can identify 150 drug corners, and the former mayor, Milton Milan, became the latest city official to be convicted on corruption charges last December.
"I believe there's a positive spirit that's going through our city," said the Rev. J. A. Jones, who is currently trying to raise $2 million to build a new church for the congregants of First Nazarene Baptist Church. "People are starting to feel hope." 
When the 1,200 congregants -- more than half of whom now live outside of Camden -- had to decide where to build their new church, Reverend Jones said, "We felt the moving van out of the city was not the answer."
In the meantime, several blocks away, in the Parkside section of town, red iron beams pierce the sky, while rows of cement blocks begin to form the walls of the new Boys and Girls Club being built across the street from Camden High School. And while the high school suffers a dropout rate of more than 50 percent, the building going up across the street represents a chance for the city's youth. 
"The city's deterioration is like rust," said Lewis Katz, the owner of the New Jersey Nets, who grew up in the neighborhood where he is spearheading the building of the Boys and Girls Club. "It never slept. And 50 years of rusting has left it in pretty sad shape. Camden needs hope, it needs the sense that it can be done. And things are being done, one project at a time."
The 10-square-mile riverfront city was not always in such desperate straits. At the turn of the century, Camden was a bustling metropolis, serving as home to Campbell Soup and the Victor Talking Machine Company, later known as RCA Victor. With active ferry service along the river and a web of railroads converging in the city, Camden was a hub of transportation and commerce, thus earning it the title of "the biggest little city in the world." But with the advent of the automobile, the building of the Ben Franklin Bridge, and a sharp decline in ferry and rail service, the city began to lose jobs and population.
While other urban areas were hurt by white flight and the disappearance of a manufacturing base, Camden, which never had much of a middle class, took its losses particularly hard. Now, with 46 percent of the population living at or below the poverty line, Camden ranks as the nation's poorest city of more than 20,000 residents. Homes in the largely deteriorating neighborhoods cost an average of $30,000, with just 37 percent being owner-occupied.
In a city where the aggregate income of $582 million for its 79,904 residents is less than what some individuals in New Jersey earn, the concept of close to $1 billion in public and private funds being spent here over the next five years is nearly unfathomable.
In addition to the $200 million of state and county aid in the economic recovery package, another $437 million has been earmarked to build or renovate public schools, stemming from the 1998 Abbott v. Burke Supreme Court decision calling for equitable programs for disadvantaged school districts. Westfield Acres' land has been cleared for a new $100 million affordable-housing development, largely financed by federal and state dollars. The tram will cost the port authority $26 million. The baseball stadium carried a $24 million price tag, and the restoration of the New Jersey will cost $22 million. 
Then there is the $615 million Trenton-to-Camden light rail line, which, with four stops in downtown Camden, not only provides financial advantages to the city but also much-needed access to Philadelphia and Trenton.
"Ever since they shut down the Pennsylvania line in 1952, it's like the lights went out in Camden," said Tom Corcoran, executive director of Cooper's Ferry Development Association, which has been largely responsible for the Camden waterfront development. "There's been a sense of isolation. One by one, the lights are starting to come back on, connecting us back again to the larger economy of the region."
But conventional wisdom says that if Camden is ever to succeed on its own, it will have to attract private investment. And while the city's rating has been so low it has not been able to go to the bond market for the last 20 years, some investors are starting to see opportunity. While ventures here are still considered quite risky, developers like Stephen Shilling and Carl Dranoff are willing to take a chance.
When Mr. Shilling first got the idea for a minor league baseball stadium in Camden a few years ago, he commissioned a feasibility study to determine its viability. The results he got back were so positive that he ordered a second study. The conclusions were the same: Philadelphia was an underentertained market and the only major city with just one baseball team. Minor league baseball had proven successful in Trenton and Wilmington, Del., and rather than cutting into those markets, a Camden stadium would draw from the four million people living in the greater Philadelphia area.
Armed with an ambitious master plan for Camden's waterfront and the fact that the other waterfront sites experience almost no crime, Mr. Shilling's Quaker Group was able to raise the money needed to build the new ballpark and install his team, the Camden Riversharks. Helping to make the deal work was selling the stadium's naming rights for just under $3 million to Campbell Soup Company, which has been based in Camden since 1869 and had a food-processing plant on the site of the stadium until the early 1990's.
"If this was somewhere else, we wouldn't have done it," said Jerry Buckley, Campbell's vice president of public affairs. "But it's a natural for us in Camden. Our employees are excited, and we think the stadium is a very good development for the area."
While the stadium cost more and took longer to complete than planned -- the front gates were still being welded into place three hours before the opening game -- Mr. Shilling says he is willing to take a chance in Camden once again.
"There were a lot of frustrations dealing with various government agencies along the way," said Mr. Shilling, who would like to build another office tower near the waterfront. "I can't say they exactly opened their arms and said, 'Come on in.' But I'm on a roll now, and hopefully I won't have to spend a year convincing people again."
Likewise Mr. Dranoff, a Philadelphia developer who has made a name for himself turning dilapidated factory buildings into desirable housing, got wind of Camden's potential a couple of years ago, during a groundbreaking for one of his Philadelphia projects. He was approached by Mr. Corcoran, who asked him to come over and check out Camden. Mr. Corcoran showed him the Nipper Building, named for the four stained-glass tower windows depicting the RCA mascot terrier, Nipper. After two months, and some due diligence, Mr. Dranoff concluded that "Camden's revival was about to happen big time."
He struck a deal that allowed him to buy the 520,000-square-foot building for $1, after the port authority spends $6 million in remediation now underway, then invest $50 million to turn the 92-year-old building into 349 waterfront lofts. Mr. Dranoff also has first option on two other historical buildings near the waterfront, which, if he pursued them, would add another 175 apartment units, creating what he called "a critical mass" of market rate housing on the waterfront.
"I've been in this business 20 years, and every time I go into a new area people are skeptical," said Mr. Dranoff. "In my business I always have to be ahead of the curve -- the out-in-front guy finding the hot new neighborhood before the revival begins."
Like Hoboken and Jersey City, which benefited from the overpriced, overcrowded New York City housing market, Camden may be able to do the same, with Philadelphia's residential market becoming more competitive than it has been in many years. Indeed, Mr. Dranoff said he had heard of "others nosing around" for investment opportunities.
"People have said, 'You woke us up,' " Mr. Dranoff said. "They're looking around at those neighborhoods adjoining the waterfront, looking to get in before it gets too expensive. Mr. Dranoff hopes to begin renting apartments in the Nipper building, which he is renaming the Victor building, by next summer.
One area likely to enjoy the spillover effect is Cooper's Grant, the Victorian-era neighborhood between Rutgers University's Camden campus and the waterfront. Rutgers has already purchased several buildings along Cooper Street, which the university plans to convert to executive offices and more dorm space. Down the street, Rowan University and Camden County College are planning expansions of their downtown campuses as well, using funds from the state's economic revitalization package.
Currently, only 500 of the Camden Rutgers 5,000 students live on campus. And though admissions are up at the Camden campus, the provost, Roger Dennis, said the image of Camden as a dangerous, drug-ridden city was the biggest sticking point in attracting students.
"If you have an 18-year-old kid whose vision of college is Princeton, or some small town in Vermont, then we have some selling to do," said Mr. Dennis, who has lived through many other periods of promise in his 20 years in Camden -- but thinks this time it's different.
"There have been other grand plans that were really exciting but didn't come off," said Mr. Dennis. "I guess I'm a romantic, but this time it feels real. This is a once-in-a-generation chance for Camden to have some fundamental change and I'm very hopeful it will happen."

HEADLINE: East New York: a Neighborhood Reborn 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
FOUR stops after the No. 3 IRT line rises out of its tunnel in the far reaches of Brooklyn, its elevated tracks enter East New York, looming above what was, less than a decade ago, a six-block stretch of weed-choked grassland.
 This was no natural habitat. That swath, criss-crossed by a street grid, was pockmarked in those days by the rusted hulks of junked cars, torched mattresses, tire mounds and the scattered remains of hollow-eyed abandoned buildings. 
 These days, most of that stretch below the IRT tracks -- along with dozens of similar sites throughout the neighborhood -- is lined by newly constructed, privately owned, pastel-shaded row houses set off by wrought-iron gates, some bearing ornamental sculptures. Sprinkled like confetti throughout the 5.6-square-mile community are hundreds of rehabilitated homes. 
The main commercial strip, Pennsylvania Avenue, is now dotted by chain stores. A 640,000-square-foot mall is planned -- with 88 percent of it already leased -- for 50 acres at East New York's southern end. And 2,300 homes are to be built on another 180 acres surrounding the mall.
Back in the late 80's and early 90's, most New Yorkers thought of East New York, when they had to, as some sort of frontier town -- out there at the end of Brooklyn, but not in Queens; out of sight but not quite far enough out of mind. Newspaper stories, citing the morbid statistics, dubbed it the "murder capital of New York City."
For the last 10 years, E. Perry Winston has walked the streets of East New York. As the senior architect at the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development, Mr. Winston has seen -- indeed, has helped promote -- a significant transformation.
"It's nice to walk down part of Snediker Avenue where 10 buildings have been rehabbed," Mr. Winston said. "Snediker, by the way, is now repaved."
"Moving further down the street there's a row of Nehemiah homes, privately owned attached houses built by East Brooklyn Congregations," he said. "Then there's brand new multiple-family rental housing built by Genesis Homes, another not-for-profit.
"A block away on Williams Avenue there's a row of rehabbed multifamily buildings done by East New York Urban Youth Corps, also rental. And then near the Williams Avenue apartments, there's a community garden, sponsored by the East New York Urban Youth Corps."
All of that has sprouted in a core of East New York "that the local police precinct used to call the 'Dead Zone,' " Mr. Winston said. "This was the most extreme area of devastation in the community, and to drive down that street now shows how far East New York has come."
Daunting problems persist: desolate lots still blemish the community; ramshackle buildings remain; there is a dearth of on-the-block retail activity; drug deals still go down. But the shift is undeniable.
Despite the demolition of dozens of dilapidated buildings over the last 10 years, the overall number of homes in East New York has increased. Mortgage loans and home-improvement loans have doubled, both in number and in their total dollar value.
In 1991, according to the New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, a triennial study conducted for the city by the Census Bureau, there were 41,800 housing units in what the bureau calls the subborough area of East New York. By 1999, there were 44,600 units -- an increase of 2,800.
Citing statistics recorded under the Federal Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, Glynis Daniels, associate director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law, said, "There are clear signs of improvement in the community as far as investments in housing and the value of housing." The mortgage disclosure act, designed as a barrier against redlining (refusing to make loans to particular racial or ethnic groups), requires most banks and large lenders to report mortgage data to the federal government.
Between 1996 and 1999, Ms. Daniels said, "There was a significant increase in the amount of mortgage lending activity in East New York, both in purchases and especially in home refinance and improvement loans."
In 1996, 511 home-purchase loans were originated in the area; during 1999 there were 650. And, again comparing those years, the total dollar amount of home-purchase loans increased from $66 million to $109.5 million. "There was a bigger increase in the dollar amount than in the number of purchases," Ms. Daniels pointed out. "That could indicate that values are going up, but also that people are rolling in some money for home improvement with their purchase loans, borrowing more than the purchase price to make improvements."
In the refinancing and home-improvement category, 515 loans totaling $40,558,000 were originated in 1996, compared with 1,093 loans totaling $89,337,000 in 1999. "That's significant, a doubling in the number of loans and a doubling in the amount," Ms. Daniels said.
Jaral Chamble bought his first home six months ago in East New York, just a few blocks from where he grew up. "I was raised on Schenck Avenue, across from the projects," said Mr. Chamble, who is 29 and sells cars in Teaneck, N.J. "I lived in a six-story apartment building -- drug-infested, urine smell in the hallways; a lot of gunshots at night, robberies."
It was on Dec. 20 that Mr. Chamble and his wife, Danielle, closed on the two-story, three-bedroom row house on Williams Avenue, built with city subsidies by the Nehemiah Homes project of East Brooklyn Congregations. "Our Christmas present," Mr. Chamble called it -- and that coming only one month after the birth of their daughter, Deja Janelle. 
The Chambles paid $110,000 for the house, making a down payment of $5,000 and another payment of $5,000 for closing costs, on a New York State-backed mortgage that started at 4 percent interest and will rise to 7 percent after four years.
"We weren't too sure about being able to afford a house," Mr. Chamble said, "so we had an apartment on Belmont Avenue for two years." The rent was $568 a month. The current monthly mortgage payment is $588.
Ron Waters, the general manager of the Nehemiah Homes Development Fund, pointed out that the interest rate for most homes in the program is currently about 7 percent, but that occasionally -- as in the case of the Chambles -- the state offers special mortgages at 4 to 4.5 percent for the first four years, with a jump to about 7 percent after four years.
Mr. Waters has an unusually decorated wall in his office. "I made it a goal of mine that when we have our house closings, as we hand people the keys to their new, first-time home of their own, we take a Polaroid shot of them," he said. "We have about 400 of those shots on the wall."
Mr. Chamble, asked what it meant to own his own home, unhesitatingly reeled off his list: "Pleasure, pride, a sense of accomplishment, hope, a step up, space, no more clutter, a sense of safety and security."
In the last five years, the community has "become much more peaceful; not as much gunfire," he said. "Now I'm proud to say I live in East New York."
In 1993, according to Inspector James Secreto, the commander of the 75th Precinct, there were 126 homicides in East New York -- the still-standing record for any precinct in the city. So far this year there have been 10.
According to the Housing and Vacancy Survey, in 1991 the median income for the community was $17,000; in 1999 it was $24,000. In 1991, according to the New York City Department of Finance, there were 27.8 million square feet of vacant land in East New York; by 1999 that had been reduced by 26 percent, to 20.7 million square feet.
Property values have risen significantly -- though not quite as much as Virginia Daniels hopes.
For 28 years, Ms. Daniels (no relation to Glynis Daniels at the N.Y.U. real estate center) has lived in the high-ceilinged, four-bedroom house at the corner of Newport Street and Alabama Avenue -- its porch cheerily decorated with potted, though sometimes plastic, plants.
"This was a shell, gutted, when I moved in," said Ms. Daniels, who is 55 and works for the federal government. "The steps were really busted up; you couldn't get to the second floor. We had to replace the walls."
"The house is 100 years old, but it's solid; layers of brick," she continued. "Quality was built in in those days."
Ms. Daniels said she is still fixing up the place, with even greater impetus now that the community's prospects have brightened. "Ten years ago, I was the only one on the block," she said. "Now there are neighbors with jobs trying to pay that mortgage. It feels like a real neighborhood now."
Asked what she believes she could get if she sold her house, Ms. Daniels said, "$400,000."
That may be a stretch. According to the Housing and Vacancy Survey, the median price for a single-family home in East New York was $140,000 in 1991, and by 1999 it had risen to $165,000.
The trend has continued, said Gerard Longo who, as president of Madison Estates and Properties in nearby Marine Park, has brokered about 300 deals in East New York over the last four years -- many for first-time buyers, others for investors seeking to buy, fix and flip properties.
"For example, there is a two-family on an 18-by-100-foot lot on Eldert Lane," Mr. Longo said. "It sold for $131,000 in 1996 and recently sold for $177,000."
Mr. Longo also cited a one-family, three-bedroom attached brick home on Milford Street that sold for $77,500 in 1996. "It sold again at the beginning of April for $172,000," he said.
"Keep in mind," Mr. Longo said, "that a great many homes in this community were built in the 1920's, 1930's, and it's not uncommon to see houses from 1915, 1910. So what we are seeing is a lot of people renovating, taking pride of ownership. And we also have a lot of speculators buying and selling flip properties."
THERE was a two-family frame house on an 18-by-100-foot lot on Decatur Street, built in 1915, that sold in June 1998 for $64,000, Mr. Longo said. Three months and considerable renovation later, it sold for $99,000. And two years after that, it sold again for $224,000.
"The community has turned around," Mr. Longo said. "You see houses being better maintained, people painting, gardening. It's turned from what might have been called a lower-income area to a middle-income area. The $200,000 range, that's middle income." 
It seems a good sign that the memorial mural on the brick wall at the corner of Newport Street and Williams Avenue -- "Memories of Yvette: I shall not listen when they say life is sad and brief" -- is peeling.
There was a time when too many murals, usually eulogizing a teenager from the neighborhood, were all too freshly painted. "You don't see many new ones," said Mr. Chamble, the new homeowner who grew up in the neighborhood.
In the eyes of the Rev. Johnny Ray Youngblood, pastor of St. Paul Community Baptist Church and co-chairman of the Nehemiah program: "The community became a cemetery. For those of us who believe in the resurrection, the best place to start a resurrection is a cemetery."
It wasn't always so.
From the 1920's through the early 1960's, East New York was primarily a community of blue-collar Irish, Italians and Jews -- lured there by its moderately priced row houses and low-rise apartment buildings, its walk-ups over storefronts and its bustling shopping districts along Pitkin and Livonia Avenues. Fortunoff's got its start in a small shop on Livonia in 1922. A young John Gotti found company among the men playing cards and sipping espresso at a "social club" run by Carmine Fatico, a capo in the Gambino crime family.
"Pitkin Avenue was an important shopping street for working-class people from all over Brooklyn who weren't going to Macy's," said Jerilyn Perine, the city's commissioner of housing preservation and development, who grew up in Flatbush and has taken a keen interest in East New York. "This was traditionally a community for people to buy their first home, then maybe move out to Long Island. There's so many stories when you talk to people from out there -- the house that their grandmother first bought."
But white flight took its toll from the late 60's through the 1970's, and the community -- particularly vulnerable because of its aging, low-rise housing stock -- became a target for racial steering and redlining. With less affluent minority householders moving in, mostly as renters, the community's population climbed by 4.1 percent during the 1980's, even though the total number of housing units dropped by 2.7 percent.
"You had deterioration going on; people moving in because of lower rent, but living in more crowded conditions," said Mr. Winston, the architect from Pratt Institute. "People were living doubled-up next to vacant buildings" -- most of which had gone into foreclosure and been taken over by the city.
The small buildings of East New York would also fall victim to economies of scale. Although Mayor Edward I. Koch had pushed through a $10 billion citywide housing revival program, Mr. Winston pointed out, "Smaller buildings hadn't yet found a place in the program; it was more economical to rehab larger buildings containing 15, 20 or more units with one roof, one boiler, one set of stairs, than the 3- to 5-unit buildings."
In the mid-80's, a community activist group called Acorn began organizing residents to pressure city officials into rehabilitating smaller city-held buildings. It sent squatters into vacant buildings in East New York. The squatters were arrested for trespassing. But, acting on a motion by the Brooklyn district attorney at the time, Elizabeth Holtzman, a judge dismissed the charges. At about the same time, East Brooklyn Congregations was starting its Nehemiah program.
And out of that ferment, the city would slowly refocus its housing efforts, turning toward programs in partnership with nonprofit groups that stressed, particularly, private homeownership.
Since 1987 -- primarily by selling city-owned property for $1 per lot, but also by underwriting low- or even no-interest loans and relocating tenants while their buildings were being rehabbed -- the Department of Housing Preservation and Development has helped create 2,216 owner-occupied homes in East New York. Of those, 516 are rehabs; the rest are newly constructed. It has also either helped renovate or build 2,870 rental units. Current plans call for the creation of another 3,087 units for private ownership over the next four years -- 2,300 of them adjoining the new Gateway shopping mall, near the Belt Parkway -- and 276 rental units.
Since 1987, the city has spent approximately $140 million to help revive housing in East New York, with another $63 million allocated for further development.
"When we first came, 85 percent of the street corners in East New York had no signs," Pastor Youngblood said. "Ambulances, the police and, of course, visitors could hardly find their way." Organizing residents to perform the required street survey, the Nehemiah program successfully lobbied the office of the Brooklyn borough president, Howard Golden, to pay for 32,000 new street signs.
Nehemiah has since become, by far, the most productive of the nonprofit groups in East New York -- erecting 1,539 prefabricated, 18-by-37-foot, two-story, two- or three-bedroom homes throughout the community -- most on contiguous lots, but many as in-fill construction. It helped create a company to manufacture the prefabricated homes, the Capsys Corporation at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, which now employs about 50 people and sells to other housing groups.
"We've raised a phoenix out of the ashes because we were given 150 vacant acres to build on by the city," Pastor Youngblood said.
The more tempestuous activities of Acorn evolved into the founding of the Mutual Housing Association of New York, for which Mr. Winston at Pratt would provide architectural plans as well as construction oversight for the rehabilitation of 75 buildings containing a total of 237 units. Since then, Mr. Winston has been working with community groups on such needs as social services, schools, neighborhood patrols, recreation, community gardens, a farmers market on New Lots Avenue and, particularly, local retail.
The new and rehabilitated city-supported housing, Mr. Winston said, inspired its neighbors to renovate. "They no longer had a fire hazard next door," he said, "so they saw that it was worth their while to spend money on their own house." That attracted newcomers to the neighborhood; and that has increased demand for local shops and services.
EAST NEW YORK'S central shopping district -- Pennsylvania Avenue, from Linden Boulevard to Flatlands Avenue, with the towers of the 6,000-unit, 42-building Starrett City middle-income rental complex looming to its south -- has, in recent years, become home to chain stores like Modell's, H&R Block, Rite Aid, C-Town and Strauss Discount Auto.
"We're busy, near the Belt Parkway," said Randall Bailey, manager of the Strauss store, which opened in 1997. "The company always does market research before they open, and they saw the possibility for growth in this area. It's not so bad like before; people feel more comfortable coming out to do business."
But the little mom-and-pop stores on local streets remain, to a large extent, shuttered. A 1996 study by Pratt graduate planning students showed that only 50 percent of the money spent on produce by neighborhood residents was being captured by local food stores. "If you want to get a carton of milk, you don't want to deal with what we call destination shopping," said Mr. Winston, who sees an opportunity in the problem.
"A lot of these commercial strips were three-story, mixed-used buildings; two or three apartments above a storefront," he said. "Even if you fix up one storefront, but have two vacant stores next to you, you don't have a good retail environment."
"It would require somebody going in and doing several of these storefronts at once," Mr. Winston said. "It might be government; it might be enlightened private capital, but somebody's got to put the foot forward." 
The city sees ongoing opportunity in East New York, Commissioner Perine said.
Adjoining the new Gateway shopping mall, just northeast of Starrett City, what Ms. Perine sees as "essentially a new town" will rise off the drawing boards over the next four years. Called Gateway Estates, its 2,300 units -- 600 to be developed by Nehemiah, the rest by the Starrett Corporation for market-rate sales -- will be a mix of attached and semiattached homes, with an occasional multifamily building, interlaced by 40 acres of parkland. Construction of a new exit off the Belt Parkway is already under way.
Asked about the city's continuing commitment to the community, Commissioner Perine said, "There's a big constituency to see this development through, more work that we're committed to seeing done."
Looking back at how, as young girl, "it was a big deal to go out to Pitkin Avenue, this bustling shopping street you had to elbow your way down," the commissioner recalled an annual pilgrimage to her mother's favorite fabric store. "You'd pick out the material for your next year's good dress," she said.
"I hope we'll have that again," she said. "Ten years from now, I think you'll see an even more dramatic expansion and rebirth of East New York, based on the seeds that have been planted."

HEADLINE: In East Camden, Scars of Urban Strife Fade 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
THE most striking thing about East Camden is what's missing. The burned-out buildings and grafitti-ridden storefronts that fill the city's other neighborhoods are scarce on the blocks around Woodrow Wilson High School and Dudley Park. In their place are houses with flower-filled planters, painted front doors and debris-free porches, the kinds of touches that people living in neighboring suburbs take for granted but that are an anomaly in the state's poorest city. While developers and city planners are busy trying to figure out how the success of Camden's waterfront may spill over to the depressed inner city, this neighborhood has worked to bring itself back, largely because of the efforts of the St. Joseph's Carpenter Society. 
 In 1985, when the Carpenter Society began rehabilitating houses along the blighted blocks of 28th Street adjacent to St. Joseph's Pro Cathedral, the idea was to raise money and bring in volunteers to fix up the houses, then sell them for the cost of materials, minus what was raised. With houses selling for $5,000 to $10,000, more people were able to buy, but increasingly lower-priced housing was coming onto the market. In the meantime, inexperienced buyers not only didn't know how to take care of the homes, they had no sense of having any equity worth protecting. 
 "We were looking at it from a charity point of view," said Sean Closkey, executive director of St. Joseph's Carpenter Society. "What would be the kindest thing we could do? Give these people a home. Our good intentions were having terrible consequences."
Under Mr. Closkey's leadership, the building program shifted to a market-driven model, with housing prices rising as more homes in the area were rehabilitated and the neighborhood improved. So far, the Carpenter Society has finished 250 houses in East Camden, with rehabilitated houses now selling for $45,000 to $69,000. The Society traded in its volunteers for paid workers, Mr. Closkey said, pumping $2 million in construction activity into the neighborhood.
The homes go to the highest bidder, but buyers are required to complete the 12-week Homeowner Academy, a course in financial management financed by Campbell's Soup. An optional 10-week course in home maintenance is also offered. 
Rather than the city's average of one in seven homes being abandoned, this neighborhood has one in 40, and most of those are buildings the Carpenter Society is trying to acquire. Of the 250 homes sold, only two have gone into default. And while housing values elsewhere in the city have dropped by 35 percent in the last five years, here they have risen by the same percentage.
Moreover, while this has taken place, the Carpenter Society has gone from a small charity group to one of the city's most well-capitalized and influential nonprofit organizations. When the federal and state government kicked in $78 million to build 200 new affordable houses to replace the Westfield Acres projects, the Carpenter Society bought its place at the negotiating table with $17.8 million in leveraged grant money. Working with Camden Churches Organized for People, the Carpenter Society fought against a notorious crack corner and won. The Society took over the site on Mickle Street six years ago and it has remained drug-free since.
"That caused a fundamental shift in the way people viewed their neighborhood," said Mr. Closkey. "This is a community that's coming back through thoughtful reinvestment, not only in its properties but in its people."

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
Putting Their Chips Down On an Arena for Newark

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
Arena politics makes strange bedfellows. How else to explain the alliance between State Senator William Gormley, the powerful Republican from Atlantic County, and State Senator Sharpe Jame -- who also happens to be the mayor of Newark.
 Last week, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco unveiled an arrangement worked to pay for a downtown arena that seemed to please more of the parties involved than anything previously proffered. 
 The basic contributors to the $355 million arena for the Devils hockey team and the Nets basketball team are the teams' owner, YankeeNets ($115 million), the city of Newark and Essex County ($50 million from undetermined sources), fans and local shoppers ($190 million in tickets as well as other fees and sales tax revenue) and motorists ($30 million from the State Transportation Trust Fund, financed by gasoline tax).
The proposal also incorporates a piece of pending legislation sponsored by the two senators -- from different parties at different ends of the state -- with few apparent ties except the desire to show they can reach across the aisle to get something done.
The bill could help generate economic activity -- new hotel rooms, shops, restaurants -- that would contribute the $190 million in sales taxes and various fees by encouraging companies with casinos in Atlantic City to invest in other areas.
The proposed measure, which was approved by the Senate in March and is now before the Assembly, requires that casinos invest $20 million in entertainment, retail or housing projects in urban areas outside Atlantic City to qualify for tax breaks on casino expansion plans.
For now, casino operators say they are open to the idea. Joe Cole, a spokesman for Aztar Corporation in Phoenix, which owns the Tropicana, said his company was considering investing in a mixed-used development incorporating the former Hahne's Department Store.
"It's an opportunity for us to leverage our investment in Atlantic City," Mr. Cole said. 
A spokesman for Park Place Entertainment Corporation of Las Vegas, which owns Bally's Park Place in Atlantic City, said it had had preliminary discussions about a 350-room hotel across from a new arena.
For Mayor James, the motivation to push for an arena in Newark seems as clear as a backboard. Mr. James is also up for re-election as mayor in May 2002, as well as for his first full term as senator this year, and reaching an agreement on an arena could boost his popularity.
"For too long we've been the butt of every joke," Mr. James said last week with quiet resentment after Mr. DiFrancesco made public his plan on financing a new arena here.
For Mr. Gormley -- who plans to run for the United States Senate seat now occupied by Robert G. Torricelli, the motivation to be co-sponsor of a bill that benefits areas outside his district is fairly obvious.
While Mr. Gormley, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has been in the spotlight recently for leading committee hearings on racial profiling this spring, experts say he still needs to become more well known outside South Jersey.
"This is what South Jersey politicians are always up against: improving their name recognition up in North Jersey," said David Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University.
John Weingart, associate director of the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers University, said that in addition to spotlighting Mr. Gormley as a bipartisan legislator, the bill being co-sponsored by Mr. James could help soften his image among voters who question the value of legalized gambling. 
"I think for Gormley, he is so clearly identified with issues involving Atlantic City and Atlantic County, and it allows him to show that he is involved with other parts of the state and made contributions to the state," Mr. Weingart said. "And for people who are not comfortable with casino gambling, it could be a tangible benefit that could be seen outside of Atlantic City.".
As for Mr. James, Mr. Weingart said co-sponsorship of a high-profile bill associated primarily with the economic development of Newark could deflect criticism for holding two major offices -- senator and mayor of the state's largest city. 
"He gets the benefits of the funds from Atlantic City, and he also gets what would appear to be a tangible benefit of being a dual office holder," Mr. Weingart said.
State Senator Richard J. Codey, the Senate minority leader, had more than a little sarcasm in his voice when he said of Mr. Gormley: "I would say that his motives are altruistic, that he's doing it for the benefit of the city of Newark and its not for his Senate run."
Even a likely Republican rival to Mr. Gormley for the Senate nomination next year, Essex County Executive James Treffinger, said, "I take my hat off to him."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Tropicana is considering a mixed-used development incorporating the former Hahne's Department Store in Newark, right. (Jim Simpson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Premier Jazz Players at Home Here

BYLINE:  By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
MUCH of New Jersey is a bedroom community for New York City, and some of those bedrooms are in the homes of talented musicians from the world of jazz, a close-knit community where everybody knows everyone else and artists and audiences alike feed off each other's love of the music.
 "Everybody has to live someplace, and every musician is a 'local artist' to some group of people," said Rio Clemente, a master of jazz piano who was born in Morristown and now calls Randolph home. "That does not mean the person was not talented enough to escape from his hometown to make it in the big city." 
 On the contrary, many of the versatile musicians who top almost any critic's list of the best jazz players in the world made a conscious decision to live in the Garden State, creating a gold mine of talent in many small New Jersey towns. 
"South Orange is small, about 16,000 people, but a lot of artists of all types, including musicians, live in and around here," said Judy Wukitsch, assistant director for recreation and cultural affairs for the village. "We started doing a free summer concert series, and it sort of grew to be dominated by jazz. Then we do our Giants of Jazz Concert every fall, and we do a small indoor jazz series in the spring and fall.
"We can attract a dozen well-known jazz players, many of them local," Ms. Wukitsch said. "Our audience values South Orange as a place they can come to for good jazz. John Lee, a prominent bass player and member of the Dizzy Gillespie Alumni All-Stars who lives here, brings in other people. In fact, he has gotten other musicians to move here."
Montclair, Maplewood and other northern New Jersey communities also stage regular jazz concerts.
The largest and oldest jazz festival in the state will be held at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison June 23 and 24. The outdoor Jazzfest 2001, which lends itself to picnic lunches and is popular with families, is sponsored by The New Jersey Jazz Society and Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company.
Among the prominent jazz players who will be featured at Jazzfest 2001 are Mr. Clemente; the Dizzy Gillespie Alumni All-Stars, which is led by John Faddis and includes Mr. Lee and Slide Hampton as well as other well-known artists; Bucky Pizzarelli; Warren Vache; Bill Charlap; Winard Harper; Kenny Davern; Russell Malone; and Earl May, all New Jersey residents. 
Some of the attractions of New Jersey for musicians are the same things that make the state attractive to people from all walks of life, including the proximity to Newark International Airport, which is important to world-traveling jazz players.
"It's comfortable, not as crowded as New York City, and more economical," said Mr. Malone, a guitarist who moved to Jersey City from Georgia. "I never wanted to be a big fish in a little pond like I could have been in Georgia. Here, there is no room for coasting because there are always up-and-coming musicians who are out to take your place. There is always something going on; always other musicians to listen to and learn from."
Although the jazz scene is good in the metropolitan area compared with most of the rest of the country, it is not as good as the musicians would like. The same handful of clubs, including the Crossroads in Garwood, the Cornerstone in Metuchen and Shanghai Jazz Restaurant in Madison were mentioned as the places where New Jersey jazz fans gather. Mr. Clemente also plays in the unusual setting of a Randolph supermarket at lunchtime four days a week.
"There are a lot of talented people here but not enough places to play, even in New York City," said Mr. Davern, a clarinet player, who said he moved to Manasquan because of the beauty of the area after playing a series of gigs on a ferry boat in nearby Brielle. "Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan used to be filled with clubs when I was growing up in the 1940's and 1950's." 
The existence of those clubs can also be credited with the development of some of the musical talent in the suburbs.
"Today's jazz grew out of what happened in the 40's and 50's," said Bill Steinberg, president of the New Jersey Jazz Society. "People playing today were inspired by those musicians. They heard them play in person, the way someone living in the Midwest could not have done."

JAZZFEST 2001
Fairleigh Dickinson University,
Madison.

All day June 23 and 24.

(973) 543-2829 for tickets
www.njjs.org for schedule.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE; 
Friends of a Celebrated Garden Don't View a Pathway as Progress

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
The city's first community garden may be sheared in half by the march of urban renewal.
 Named for the East Village resident who founded it in the early 1970's, Liz Christy's Bowery-Houston Garden blooms along the southern edge of a mostly abandoned block. The city, which owns the block, is seeking to build a complex of apartments, stores and community facilities there, and the developers want to construct a pedestrian pathway through the garden. 
 The garden is at Houston Street and the Bowery. The plan calls for extending Extra Place, a tiny alley that runs parallel to the Bowery, through the middle of the garden to connect First and Houston Streets. The idea is to aid access to the new complex.
"In no way would the park be diminished," said Fred Harris, vice president of development at AvalonBay Communities, a partner in the project. "Any space consumed by the walkway would be given back."
But the gardeners are vehemently opposed, saying the pathway, planned to be 22 feet wide, would be disruptive. "Cutting it in half would destroy the spirit of the garden," said Donald A. Loggins, who has volunteered at the site from the start. 
The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which is overseeing the project, seems sympathetic. Calling the path "an oversight" in a $230 million renewal project, Christopher J. Allred, a spokesman, said, "It's our intention to preserve the garden."
The Bowery-Houston garden was started by Ms. Christy and a loose group of activists, known as the Green Guerrillas, who would lob "seed grenades" into vacant lots to spawn green spaces.
In 1973, the group took over the site, which was then strewn with rubble, laid down topsoil and began planting. The following year, the city agreed to rent the space to the gardeners for $1 a month, and the city's first community garden was created.
Today, the garden is home to a small pond, seven red-eared turtles, hundreds of migrating birds and 2,000 plant varieties, from white bamboo to white strawberries.
Last Tuesday, the developers and city officials met with the gardeners after touring the site. No alternatives to the path were proposed, but officials said they would explore ways to keep the garden intact, including selling the plot to the Parks Department. DENNY LEE

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ms. Christy at her garden. Chart: "BIOGRAPHY: FLOWER POWER"Elizabeth A. Christy, a distant cousin of Frederick Law Olmsted, loved gardens.A sprightly figure often seen chain-smoking, she darted around the city in a green Datsun with a back seat full of plants. She was a co-founder of the Green Guerrillas, an environmental group that still nurtures the city's community gardens. Ms. Christy was involved in the protests at Columbia University against the Vietnam War, worked in advertising and taught arts to children. She was also a landscape painter. But gardening was her first love. Besides starting the city's first community garden, she was the host of "Grow Your Own," a gardening show on WBAI radio in the 70's. She also wrote numerous articles for gardening publications. In 1985, at age 39, she died of lung cancer. The next year, the Bowery-Houston garden was renamed in her honor.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
SLOW GROWTH IN 90'S

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
 Despite a low unemployment rate and an increase in new jobs, New Jersey ranked near the bottom among states in terms of economic growth during most of the 1990's, according to a report released by the federal Department of Commerce last week. 
New Jersey ranked 42nd in growth in the gross state product, which is a measure of the market value of goods and services produced by labor and property, increasing by 2.9 percent from 1992, when recovery from the 1990-1991 recession first began, to 1999. The national average was 4.0 percent, with the fastest-growing states in the West. New Jersey's slowest growth areas were in construction and manufacturing. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Living In Denial, Comfortably, In a Big Home

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
YOU would think that between the economic slowdown and the high cost of heating, people would become nervous and build smaller homes. But that is not the experience of Lee Baum, a Memphis builder. He is building or preparing to build five McMansions, including one for a doctor who is putting the home around the corner from his present big house so that his children and grandchildren will have a place to stay when they visit.
 Now that is consumer confidence. This slowdown has the potential for considerable longevity and considerable damage. The two precipitators, a stock market sell-off and a collapse in capital spending, are not easy to reverse. But the consumer keeps his finger in the dike, and nowhere is this resistance to hard times -- "denial" some would call it -- more noticeable than in America's love affair with big homes. 
 "People's sense of personal space has increased tremendously in recent decades, and even in these difficult months they are expressing that preference," said Richard T. Curtin, director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan. "Children are no longer expected to share a room, and each spouse counts on having private space -- a study, a den, a sewing room. They get different names, but they are dedicated to the use of one spouse."
The average size of newly constructed homes reached 2,305 square feet at the end of March, up from 2,265 last year, according to the National Association of Home Builders. Construction of the newest dwellings began last fall, during some of the scariest days of the slowdown. Frightened families could have canceled or postponed construction, or scaled back the size of their homes -- to three bedrooms, for example, instead of four or five. They could have shrunk the kitchens.
The average home has grown steadily in size for more than 30 years; it is 53 percent larger today than in 1970, although the average family is 15 percent smaller. The only setbacks came in the recessions that hit the economy in the mid-70's, early 80's and early 90's. Homes will probably shrink again if the current slowdown turns into a recession.
Or, the Americans yearning for bigger homes could help to keep the slowdown from going that extra, terrible step. That may be overstating the economic power of the $500,000 to $1 million homes that Mr. Baum and his counterparts are building in so many cities and suburbs. But five years of considerable prosperity and easy credit have honed self-indulgence. The big-home phenomenon is a prime example. And giving up self-indulgence is not coming easily, despite the prods from layoffs, buyouts, falling profits, a weaker stock market, under-water options and shrinking raises as well as bonuses.
This is not a nation reefing sails for hard times -- and that may be a blessing, a Keynesian stimulus of sorts from an unexpected quarter: the consumer. Not all consumers, however. Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center, said that Pew's polls had found that people with incomes above $100,000 a year were more confident about their earning power in January 2001 than they had been in September 1999, while "satisfaction with earning power" plummeted among people with less income.
High earners, in sum, are sustaining home construction, an important leg of the economy, and their preference for McMansions, the giant-home phenomenon that first appeared in the late 1990's, keeps pushing up the size of the average home. Mr. Baum's customers include these high earners: the doctor, a lawyer, a plant manager, a scrap dealer, an executive of an ice-cream company. The homes that Mr. Baum is building for them or preparing to build -- 5,000 square feet and up -- feature 6 bedrooms, 5 1/2 baths, a playroom, a theater room. "These are well-established people with good jobs," he said. "They don't have a problem."
ECONOMISTS see logic in the big-home craze. Falling interest rates make financing cheaper. Baby boomers are still buying or building homes. Tax cuts in 1997 added an incentive. And despite the slowdown, the prices of big homes -- all homes, for that matter -- keep rising. Many experts, in fact, argue that home prices are likely to hold their own during a recession, or at least not slip much. That makes homes seem an attractive alternative investment for wealthy people who have pulled money from the stock market.
Still, logic may fail. Nicolas P. Retsinas, director of Harvard's Joint Center on Housing Studies, is uneasy. "We spend a fair amount of time trying to understand the remarkable resiliency of the housing sector at a time of economic sputtering," he said. "It is almost as if people, in building a big home, are resisting mortality."

HEADLINE: CITYPEOPLE; 
The Last Bohemian

BYLINE:  By PETER EDIDIN 

 BODY:
LUFTMENSCH. Superfluous man. Flaneur. Beatnik. Bohemian. For a century, New York been a magnet for such economically marginal figures, whose role it was to stroll, read, reflect, write and, especially, critique the way the rest of the world lived. They have been a staple of urban life at least since the mid-19th century, when the Parisian Henri Murger wrote his novel "Bohemians of the Latin Quarter," which in Puccini's hands became the opera "La Boheme." 
 Lionel Abel exemplified this type; he lived most of his 90 years at an economic and intellectual distance from the mainstream. He died April 19 in New York, the city he had helped establish as the world's capital of art, ideas and argument. 
 Mr. Abel was 57 before he took his first regular job, an English professorship at the State University of New York in Buffalo. "You know what the first thing he bought was?" said Leslie Fiedler, the literary scholar who arranged the hiring in 1967. "Some false teeth. He had needed them for some time."
The sociologist Daniel Bell has placed Mr. Abel among the founding New York Jewish intellectuals of the 20's and 30's. He was one of the last survivors; only the novelist Saul Bellow and the Partisan Review editor William Phillips are left. But Mr. Abel was possibly the rarest bird among them, though others would achieve far greater prominence as academics, political activists, editors and writers. He was a self-educated and largely self-invented polymath, and he came to the city at a time when it was still hospitable to people who lacked money but had ideas, a compulsion to share them and the ability to stay up all night talking. 
Mr. Abel, born Lionel Abelson, was raised in Niagara Falls, N.Y., the son of a rabbi. He was brilliant, said his younger brother, Raziel Abelson, a retired philosophy professor at City College in New York, and finished high school at 13 1/2. He also spent a lot of time shooting pool with people who wound up their evenings at a local brothel, and this, with his indifference to Hebrew, brought conflict with his father. Lionel Abelson left home at 15 and shortened his name, literally erasing his filial status.
After being tossed out of the University of North Carolina for publishing a magazine the administrators found scandalous, he made for New York, arriving in 1929. 
In Washington Square Park he met the glamorous actor Lionel Stander, who took Mr. Abel on a tour of Greenwich Village. They found the poet Maxwell Bodenheim, who told Mr. Abel to move to Isle of Capri. Joe Gould, a man said to have written a great history of modern times, although he had in fact written nothing, warned: "Don't run after Joe Gould. Find out what Joe Gould runs after, and then run after that. But I'm not gonna tell you what it is." 
There were others, all talkers, whatever else they were, and it was enchanting. A year later, Mr. Abel had rented his own place on Charles Street. 
"He and his friends used to go around, cadge money from acquaintances, do odd jobs, live from hand to mouth," Mr. Abelson said of his brother. But there were cheap bars and all-night cafes packed with people talking politics and art -- Hubert's on Grove Street, Romany Marie's on Fourth Street, the Jumble Shop on Eighth Street. Prohibition beer was 25 cents a glass.
"He was like Socrates, always wandering around Greenwich Village, looking for people to have conversations with," Mr. Abelson said. "He talked from day to night."
Mr. Abel became so well known that when Raziel Abelson came to town in the late 1930's and walked into a Village bar asking if anyone knew where Lionel lived, "half the bar stood up and told me." 
Mr. Abel also became a writer and reviewer for the best intellectual journals, as well as a French translator, a playwright who helped establish Off Broadway theater and the author of a standard text on theatrical tragedy. He came to know virtually everyone of distinction in artistic and intellectual life -- novelists, poets, painters, philosophers, art critics.
In Joseph Dorman's 1997 documentary, "Arguing the World," Mr. Abel emerges as a mocking and somewhat arrogant figure. Mr. Abel always liked a good fight -- literally, on occasion: once he was knocked down a flight of stairs by the art critic Clement Greenberg.
As a young man of the left, he attacked those on the right. As he grew older, he moved increasingly rightward and the left became his target.
In 1963, Mr. Abel set off an enormous storm by mounting an attack in Partisan Review on "Eichmann in Jerusalem," Hannah Arendt's book about the trial of the Nazi official responsible for directing the mass murder of European Jewry. He stated that Ms. Arendt's scholarship was dishonest and that underlying her views was an ugly sympathy for the Nazis and a dislike for Jews that was based on finding that "Eichmann is aesthetically palatable while his victims are aesthetically repulsive."
After Mr. Abel's stint in academia, where, Mr. Fiedler said, "He was best for those students who liked to be despised a little by those who taught them," he returned to New York. In his eyes the city had grown dirtier, more expensive, more dangerous and less accommodating to free expression and the life of the mind. Many of those he respected had died or moved away.
But the city's human resources remained unmatched, as he made clear in the closing chapter of his memoir, "The Intellectual Follies." It consists of a letter urging a young man living in California to return to New York. "To what am I asking you to come back?" he wrote. To "the handful of people still in New York who cannot be duplicated in any other of the nation's cities." Come to New York, he insisted, and "prove yourself, and prove likewise that you are worthy to replace some one or other of the interesting and illustrious persons who made this city what it was at its best, and, such is my hope may again be."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lionel Abel, who died in April, epitomized a city that valued ideas over money. (Jim Tuttle)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Behind The New Gleam In Steel

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
FOR years, steel was not a compelling investment, and for a good reason: the companies did not earn much money. 
 Since 1997 alone, 18 American steel makers have filed for bankruptcy; five have shut down completely. But so far this year, steel stocks have been on a tear. Through Friday, the Standard & Poor's steel index is up by more than 30 percent. 
 Last week, the Bush administration took the first steps toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel. Michelle Appelbaum, a managing director and steel analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, talked last week about the industry's prospects. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. This is the first time since the early 1980's that stiff barriers on steel imports have been considered. Is the current situation different from 20 years ago?

A. There are a number of differences.
The antidumping suit back in 1981 was filed by Bethlehem Steel, and was not supported by the industry or the Reagan administration. They did it alone. 
Bethlehem won the case, and Reagan's people negotiated what was essentially a quota program. But it was not enforced until the summer of 1986, after LTV filed for Chapter 11. 
Over the last 20 years, there has been a massive downsizing in the industry. Output has shrunk by a third. There are only one-fifth as many workers now as then. 
The biggest difference is that the Bush administration is bringing this action. They are not only going to give some breathing room to the industry, but are showing some interest in negotiating global rationalization in steel-making capacity. That is a sea change.

Q. Is it likely that the administration can prove that foreign companies are dumping steel -- selling it at below domestic market prices?

A. As defined, dumping is very easy to prove. And foreign steel companies use the United States as a pressure valve when their own market drops.
But it cuts both ways. In 1991, steel exports from the United States quintupled. Our economy was slow and foreign economies were doing well. I don't know if that steel was dumped, but because steel is such a high-fixed-cost industry, the incremental production costs of those tons was almost nothing. And you can see where the industry would be inclined to never cut production and ship it out of the home market. The economics of the business are so persuasively supportive of dumping that it is going to happen. 

Q. Is there a need to reduce global capacity?

A. Global capacity has shrunk nominally. There have been some capacity increases outside of Japan, Europe and the United States.
You have to look at the fact that the fundamentals of this business are such that steel either needs to be a state-owned monopoly or there needs to be state intervention into the global management of the business. The best solution is to have fair trade enforced across all nations, and for the global industry to address the capacity issue in much the same manner the aluminum industry did in 1994. 
The aluminum agreement, which Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill was deeply involved in, has made it a very efficient industry, one with no national walls. 
There are more nationalistic barriers with steel, and you would need to have buy-ins with unions and governments. But there is no question steel consumers would support it.

Q. Do you expect steel consumers to fight import quotas when the administration presents its case?

A. Historically, automobile and consumer-goods companies have been noticeably quiet on these protection issues. There are a couple of reasons for that. First, they don't use much foreign steel. Second, they buy on long-term contracts.

Q. If conditions in the industry are so bad, why have the stocks done so well this year?

A. The stocks have done very well, but it is not based on the fundamentals. Money has been coming out of technology and into other sectors. It's like pouring buckets into thimbles. Steel is a very small sector. The combined market capitalization of the 12 steel companies I cover is about $10 billion. They are cheap.

Q. Which steel companies are you particularly enthusiastic about?

A. I am recommending the entire list.
One of my favorites is U.S. Steel. Financially, it is the healthiest company in the group. and they just bought an operation in Eastern Europe that is very profitable and they paid very little money for. And a couple of weeks ago, the parent company said it might split off U.S. Steel from Marathon Oil. It is the easiest stock to own in the group.
National Steel is another good stock. It has the most operating leverage in the industry. And Nucor is a great company.
