HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK NEWSPAPERS; 
Little Scandal, But Lots Of News Of Commerce

BYLINE:  By JIM O'GRADY

 BODY:
Queens Business Today, a new weekly newspaper, is short on scandal and long on profiles of bank managers squeezed between reams of advertisements for local businesses. To some, it may be the city's least dynamic read. But its existence is intriguing. Has Queens become such a commercial center that it needs its own business newspaper? 
 Victoria Schneps thinks so. Ms. Schneps owns the Queens Courier, a media company that includes a chain of five local newspapers, a health magazine and a weekly cable television show about Queens. 
 Ms. Schneps said she noticed recently that there were 45,000 businesses, most small, in the borough. Thinking like a businesswoman, she pictured their owners as readers and customers for her advertisers, who fill about 70 percent of the paper's space. She began publication last month with the goal of becoming what she described as "the Crain's New York of Queens," referring to the business newspaper published in Manhattan. Unlike Crain's, Queens Business Today is free.
Does this mean Queens is coming of age as an economic powerhouse? Maybe.
Marie Nahikian, director of the Queens Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit business advocacy group, said Queens has had a 5 percent increase in jobs, income and wages over the last five years, the highest in the city. She added that the borough's 4 percent unemployment rate is its lowest in 15 years.
But some manufacturers are being driven out by rising rents, she said, which may lead to job losses.
Lucy Nunziata of the Queens Chamber of Commerce named a number of thriving commercial strips, like Steinway Street in Astoria and Woodhaven Boulevard in Ozone Park. But Igor Tomic, a professor of economics at St. John's University, pointed to Union Turnpike, a long commercial avenue that struggles to draw customers from the surrounding area. 
Mr. Tomic said merchants on the turnpike near St. John's might benefit from reading a local business newspaper. Few stores there cater to students, he pointed out, even though 2,000 students have been living a block away in new dorms for the past two years.
But is the Queens economy strong enough to float a weekly business newspaper? Peter Constantine, of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state economic agency, thinks so. "You have papers in Queens that cover two square blocks," he said. "There is definitely enough economic activity to warrant a newspaper." JIM O'GRADY

CORRECTION-DATE: June 24, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on June 10 about a new newspaper, Queens Business Today, misstated its frequency. It is month ly, not weekly.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
Tales of Greed in Post-Soviet Russia

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
MARKETS have short memories, and the mourning of the latest boom-gone-bust is usually brief. In the nearly three years since Russia defaulted on its debt, investors have moved on -- first to the dot-com frenzy in the United States and then to its fizzle. Russia's derring-do tales of billions made and lost, of gun-toting tycoons and panic spreading across the globe have long since slipped from the headlines.
 Yet for much of the 1990's, the buzz surrounding emerging markets was intense, reflecting the fact that history was at a turning point: Russia was being sold off -- a former Communist superpower up for grabs in a way that would have once been inconceivable, especially considering that the country was a lumbering monster dripping with oil, diamonds, foreign money and, last but not least, nuclear weapons. 
 For a peek at what went wrong, it is worth dissecting the interplay among investment opportunities, investors themselves and the framework in which they operated.
In Matthew Brzezinski's "Casino Moscow" (The Free Press, $25), a fast-paced narrative of Russia's dalliance with bare-knuckles capitalism, a range of players stand accused: Boris N. Yeltsin's weak government, the Russian oligarchs who became billionaires on the ruins of Communism, the American and other foreign investors who flocked to Moscow for a slice of the action, and even the Clinton administration and other outside powers for what the writer describes as myopia toward corruption on a huge scale.
The conclusion from this travelogue-cum-primer, due in bookstores in July, is that all share responsibility for the mammoth collapse, but that Russia's own share was the biggest and that President Yeltsin was the biggest culprit of all. Those conclusions emerge late in the book, which may disappoint those who seek a detailed dissection of the era but will entertain readers looking for an anecdotal counterpoint to the ponderous legacy of debt negotiations and political analysis.
The truth, the writer argues, is that no one lost Russia but the Russians. During the 1990's, the West offered Russia the same assistance package received by Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, Mr. Brzezinski says. But unlike those prospering countries, which have been rewarded with NATO membership, or the thriving Baltic states, which seek admission to the European Union, Russia's post-Communist leaders never wanted to join the Western family of nations.
Russia's freewheeling and corrupt business elite, the West itself and Western financiers all come in for a share of the criticism. Russian businessmen had been only too happy to take the West's money but were not interested in adopting the openness that is essential to join the global business community in earnest. That Wall Street fell for the hundred-billion-dollar trick is a testament to the blinding power of greed.
Given Russia's imperial history, its wounded pride and the ramshackle institutions that collapsed once the central support of the Soviet state fell away, the events of the 1990's perhaps should not have been so surprising. After all, on a much smaller scale in eastern Germany, a post-Communist failure to absorb capitalist pressures had already become clear. 
But readers interested in the details of what went wrong, or a behind-the-scenes saga, would be ill-advised to look for it here. Mr. Brzezinski, a former freelance contributor to The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal who went on to join The Journal's staff in Moscow, offers a far more a personal odyssey.
If Mr. Brzezinski's name seems familiar, the reason is that his uncle is Zbigniew, President Jimmy Carter's ferociously anti-Soviet national security adviser, and a scion of a Polish family that implanted a vigorous mistrust of Russia in the author. (The reader learns of this relationship early in the book, finding out that the writer has a Polish eagle tattooed on his chest -- arguably one of those tidbits of information that some might regard as gratuitous.)
What this book does offer, though, is a flavor of the times. Like many memoirs written by journalists when their time is up on a big story, the book is filled with anecdotes -- the personal stories accrued but never published in those impersonal dispatches from the front. But the anecdotes should transcend after-dinner brandy-and-cigars conversation. Some of Mr. Brzezinski's stories originated in conversations at dinner tables in Moscow's upmarket restaurants.
For all that, "Casino Moscow" offers rich pickings -- from the writer's terrifying ordeal at the hands of thieves in Ukraine to a chilling portrait of a Chechen gangster in a Moscow hotel. The gangster bemoans the fact that he needs so many bodyguards -- it seems that they are always bumping into things and getting in the way. Some of the writer's most telling yarns come from his trips outside Moscow, to oil fields of Russia's far east or to the rusting Soviet fleet in Sevastopol.
The story is not told exclusively from a journalist's viewpoint. Early on, Mr. Brzezinski introduces Roberta, his partner, who worked for the World Bank and later for a private investment company itself drawn to the opportunities presented by post-Communist Russia. That provides some entree to the platinum-card world of investment-bank living that contrasts garishly with the cruel deprivations of ordinary Russians outside Moscow, bartering their goods for survival in the dislocations of the national economy.
The bookends of this story are provided by the rise and fall of the political influence of Russia's business czars, the so-called oligarchs, who dominated much of the time that Mr. Brzezinski spent in Ukraine and Russia from 1996 to 1998. Their demise, as Vladimir V. Putin succeeded Mr. Yeltsin, is told in a brief footnote after Mr. Brzezinski's departure.
There is, perhaps, an air of abruptness to the ending of the era or at least to the ending of the expatriate heyday in Moscow, when, as the writer says, more foreigners lived in Moscow than at any other time in its history.
Mr. Brzezinski does not try to offer a road map to the future of Russia -- probably a wise choice, because forecasts would almost certainly founder on Russia's unpredictability. That is arguably the most somber message to emerge from the book.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Richard P. Howard; 
T. Rowe Price Capital Appreciation Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
RICHARD P. HOWARD is a risk-averse technophobe, and while his fears might have been a handicap when dot-coms were flying high, they have given him an edge this year.
 "I really don't understand electricity, let alone the Internet," said Mr. Howard, who runs the $1.2 billion T. Rowe Price Capital Appreciation fund. "And when I used my value lens on those securities, they just didn't make any sense at all. You get lots of people screaming at you to swing, but you don't have to swing." 
 Mr. Howard says he worries as much about risk as about reward -- the fund is intended not to lose principal in down markets. The last year has given him plenty of opportunities to test that design.
The fund returned 28.3 percent during the 12 months ended Thursday, compared with 0.04 percent for its peers in the domestic hybrid group and a 12.2 percent loss for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Over the last three years through Thursday, it returned 13.2 percent a year, on average, compared with 5.0 percent for its group and 6.0 percent for the S.& P. 
Mr. Howard, 54, likes to keep at least 65 percent of the fund in United States value stocks and the remainder in convertible securities and bonds. The investment pickings are now slim, he says, so stocks are at 55 percent, convertible securities at 22 percent and bonds at 8 percent. Cash is at 15 percent, compared with only 7.8 percent on June 30 of last year; he has raised the total after a series of market shocks. 
"We've had a boom in the stock market," he said of the bull market of the 1990's. "And I think that we have the risk of a bust in the future."
To reduce risk, he concentrates on value stocks. The price-to-earnings multiple for the portfolio, based on 2001 earnings, averages 12, compared with 22 for the S.& P. 500. The fund's price-to-book ratio is 1.8, versus 4.7 for the index.
"We look for companies that have problems that cause their stock price to fall significantly" -- 5 percent to 50 percent, depending on the company, he said. He uses research to help determine if the price can rebound. 
"We want to understand the business approach," he said, "and how management will overcome the problem that they very well may have inflicted on themselves."
Mr. Howard closely reviews changes in a company's balance sheet over the last quarter and year. "Companies that work off inventory or take high depreciation charges mask improvements in income statements that you can see on balance sheets," he said. 
The energy sector accounts for the biggest chunk of the portfolio, at 15 percent of total assets. "I'm more optimistic than the stock market in terms of energy prices rising," he said, "and the earnings power of companies that can meet the demand."
His bet on energy carries over to bonds, which he is using to build a stake in distressed California utilities. Usually, his bond holdings are plain-vanilla corporate or government agency issues maturing in three to five years, he said. But today, more than 50 percent of the bond portion is made up of Tennessee Valley Authority bonds. Because the bonds do not mature until 2036 and 2045, prices will shoot up if interest rates fall sharply, he said, but a "put feature" on each bond gives him one chance to sell at par if rates rise.
He looks for similar protection in convertible securities -- preferred stocks or bonds that can be converted to common shares at a set price and time. "If stock prices fall, I don't lose much because the converts have a lot of bond value," he said. "If stock prices go up, the converts go up a little, too."
He does not sell often. The fund's turnover averaged a measly 32.4 percent in 2000, compared with 115 percent for all stock funds.
Mr. Howard says he has been buying more shares of USX-Marathon Group, which along with USX-U.S. Steel is part of the USX holding company. The oil and steel units will be formally split by year-end, he said, which should lead to an increase in the value of the oil company. It now trades at $31.97; he first bought it at $23.50 in May 2000. 
The company "has fairly leveraged exposure to the production of natural gas in the U.S. and oil and gas worldwide," he said. 
"You also get a fairly significant amount of refining capacity," he added, "so that if the economy improves, the company should be a major beneficiary." It is also a potential acquisition target, he said.
Another favorite is Fortune Brands, the consumer products company based in Lincolnshire, Ill. Its home improvement and office products units have been hurt by the economic slowdown, he said, while its golf business, which includes Titleist, has been battered by competition, mostly from Nike. Over all, Fortune Brands sells for 14 times 2001 earnings, just over half the market multiple. While it has an unusual mix of businesses, he said, "you don't get to buy a company so cheap without doing something a little offbeat," he said.
The company's spirits business, which includes Jim Beam bourbon, Gilbey's gin and DeKuyper cordials, is growing moderately but consistently, he added. "I think people will be drinking Jim Beam 50 years from now, and I'm pretty sure people won't be using Cisco products that long," he said.
He bought shares in April 2000 at $27.50; they now trade at $35.18.
On May 23, Mr. Howard bought more convertible securities of the Teck Corporation, a mining company based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The convertibles, with a 3.75 percent coupon due July 2006, have a yield to maturity of about 8 percent. Teck mines gold, silver and other metals; it is scheduled to open a big copper mine in Peru this summer, he said. It also operates a lead and zinc smelter in British Columbia, powered by its own hydroelectric dam. Management will shut down the smelter from August through September and sell the electricity to California. "They're going to make a pile of money," Mr. Howard said.
He bought the convertibles at $820; they traded at $825 as of Thursday.

HEADLINE: China Viewed Narrowly 

 BODY:
Though the Bush administration has yet to articulate a fully formed China policy, there are unsettling indications that it may be inclined to see China primarily as an emerging military threat. The United States cannot ignore the possibility that China will grow into a global military power in the decades ahead, but Washington's handling of Beijing ought not to exaggerate the threat. 
 China's armed forces are large but poorly trained and equipped. They have begun modernizing, but pose no real military threat to the United States and will not for many years to come. Some Chinese military leaders speak wishfully of making inroads on America's long uncontested naval dominance of the Western Pacific. Yet Beijing's modest naval forces lack the means for any serious challenge. The more complex problem is finding ways to encourage China to use its growing regional power in peaceful and constructive directions. 
 Fashioning a realistic China policy will require a balanced approach to trade, diplomacy and geopolitics. Military concerns are part of the mix but should not be allowed to drive the larger relationship. President Bush must not let Pentagon concerns about China distort his approach to Beijing. Unfortunately, at this point the administration still lacks an authoritative voice on China in its highest policy-making councils to keep these issues in perspective.
China has been steadily increasing its military budget for most of the past decade. It now spends about $40 billion a year, roughly the same as Japan and less than 15 percent of what Washington spends. Most of China's increased spending has been used to improve the living standards of its soldiers, not to acquire advanced weaponry. China has no real capacity to produce modern weapons on its own and must buy what it needs from Russia and other foreign suppliers. It has obtained some late-model destroyers and jet fighters, but lacks the aircraft carriers and in-flight refueling tankers it would need to deliver substantial forces beyond its borders. 
With two and a half million active-duty troops, China has the world's largest standing army. But it is primarily a land power. Any potential Chinese military challenge would come at sea, where the United States Navy, with its dominance in advanced destroyers, aircraft carriers and nuclear submarines, would have a decided advantage.
It is not Mr. Bush's fault that the April collision of an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet brought early attention to military aspects of the relationship. Beijing's bellicose handling of that incident aroused nationalist emotions on both sides of the Pacific. But in the weeks since the plane crew's release, the administration has done little to get the relationship back on course. 
In his speech on missile defenses last month, Mr. Bush spoke of reaching out to both Russia and China. Yet while he elaborated on his desire to build a constructive new relationship with Russia, he held out no such prospects to China. Washington reinforced this message when the high-level emissaries it sent to consult with Asian leaders on American missile defense plans conspicuously omitted Beijing from their itinerary. A lower-level delegation visited Beijing. China has legitimate concerns that its relatively small nuclear missile force could be blunted by an American shield. Then came word that a major Pentagon review of America's global military strategy would recommend a major shift of planning and resources to the Pacific to counter rising Chinese military power. Meanwhile, Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld has sharply curtailed contacts between American and Chinese military officials, depriving both countries of a useful tool for better mutual understanding.
There is no question that China has become more assertive in its pursuit of regional goals like unification with Taiwan and control of offshore waters and mineral rights in the South China Sea. In addition, Beijing is now less concerned about aligning itself with Washington than it was during the cold-war era, when both nations worried about containing Soviet ambitions in Asia. This newly nationalist tone has led to occasional frictions with the United States and will again. But the problems can be more easily overcome if Washington continues the policy of active engagement with China on economic and arms control issues pursued by the past six administrations. If Mr. Bush hopes to build the "productive relationship" that he spoke of after the 24 American crew members were returned in April, he will have to keep military issues from disproportionately influencing dealings with Beijing.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Arafat Is the Leader, But Who's In Charge?

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
ISRAEL'S prime minister, Ariel Sharon, makes it sound simple: If Yasir Arafat wants peace, he must halt the suicide bombings and other acts of terror and he must do it by arresting the several dozen Islamic militants on a list Israel has handed him.
 But, as always in the long Israeli-Palestinian struggle, the reality is much murkier. 
 As American and European envoys struggled feverishly last week to hold together an exceedingly shaky, bullet-punctuated cease-fire, Israeli officials publicly focused their ire on Mr. Arafat as a kind of supreme puppet-master. They did it to such an extent that it spurred speculation they had run out of patience and might somehow try to oust him. 
"It has been proven categorically that Arafat controls what goes on in the field," said Maj. Gen. Amos Malka, the chief of military intelligence. Reuven Rivlin, the communications minister whose thinking is close to Mr. Sharon's, added bluntly: "Arafat is the brunt of the problem."
But others, including some in Shin Bet, Israel's domestic intelligence service, paint a more complex picture of political infighting among the Palestinians . In the end, these analysts say, Mr. Arafat and the Islamic fundamentalists in Hamas and Islamic Jihad have starkly opposing, irreconcilable goals: Mr. Arafat, having achieved international recognition as the Palestinians' leader on the basis of the Oslo peace accords, wants to salvage what he can from the faltering agreement; the Islamicists want to wreck it.
"The basic relationship is one of rivalry," said Rashid Khalidi, a University of Chicago professor. "It's a competition for power and support, for who can appeal to the vast Palestinian middle. These are people who are not in the same ballpark as far as their objectives. They're like oil and water, it's a basic polarity."
At the moment, the Islamic forces are in the ascendancy, for several reasons. The eight-month-old second intifada, in which more than 484 Arabs and 108 Israelis have died, is directed not only at the Israelis and the frustrated hopes raised by the Oslo accords, but also, to a large extent, at Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority. Many in the West Bank and Gaza Strip see the authority as corrupt, high handed and dominated by cronies Mr. Arafat brought back with him from exile in Tunis.
Palestinian anger and bitterness has been fed by the draconian measures with which Israel has tried to suppress the uprising, including the use of snipers and targeted assassinations. A virtual state of siege has crippled what little is left of the Palestinian economy. Palestinian stone throwing demonstrations have turned into low-level guerrilla warfare, with roadside ambushes and bombs; Israel has responded with tanks, helicopter gunships and even an F-16 air raid. 
Feelings have now hardened on both sides: After Hamas conducted a suicide bombing of a Tel Aviv nightclub, killing 20 teenage Russian immigrants, there were cries for "blood" and "war" even from Israelis who had voted for the dovish parties of the left. Many had come to doubt that Mr. Arafat ever intended to make a real peace. And a recent poll by the Palestinian Center for Public Opinion showed that 75 percent of Palestinians supported armed revolt, including suicide bombings, and 80 percent thought Israel was not serious about seeking a halt to the violence. Similar polls showed drops in Mr. Arafat's already low approval rating.
With his people feeling that way, it appears politically impossible for Mr. Arafat to arrest the militants; he would be seen as a lackey doing Israel's work.
It was not always so. Dr. Khaladi, the descendant of a distinguished family of Jerusalem intellectuals who has long studied the Palestinian movement, noted that during the first years of the Oslo agreement, Hamas tried hard to disrupt the peace process but in the prevailing optimism found little support and abandoned the effort. After a resumed wave of bombing in early 1996, Mr. Arafat's security services began hounding the Islamic forces and continued until last summer, when about 300 Hamas and Jihad members were in jail. Human rights groups say about 20 Islamic fundamentalists died under torture in Palestinian prisons. 
But when the intifada started last fall, the 300 prisoners were released. It is members of this group that Israel is now demanding be re-arrested. 
The current public mood is one of frustration and rage, however, and when Mr. Arafat's police tried to arrest a militant in Gaza's Jabaliya refugee camp two months ago, they were met with an open revolt.
One of the more curious aspects of the tit-for-tat violence is that Israel's response has largely been directed at the Palestinian Authority's security units, rather than at the Islamicists themselves. It has hit, for example, the headquarters of a police force in Nablus much disliked for reining in demonstrations. The two heads of Mr. Arafat's preventive security forces who had been most effective in cracking down on militants in the past, Mohammed Dahlan in Gaza and Jibril Rajoub in the West Bank, are said to fear they are targets of assassination after having come under Israeli gunfire.
On the other hand, both Israelis and Palestinians are looking over their shoulders at the court of international opinion. Mr. Sharon declared his cease-fire late last month after his F-16 attack was followed by urgent calls from the United States to reduce the violence. Mr. Arafat's cease-fire declaration was virtually dictated to him after the Tel Aviv bombing by Terje Rod-Larsen, the United Nations envoy, and the German foreign minister, Joschka Fisher. But the Palestinians are less a tight command structure than a hodgepodge of forces. And even though the level of violence did fall markedly during the week, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the Hamas spiritual leader, immediately announced: "The resistance will continue. Whatever agreements Arafat makes are not binding on us." Islamic Jihad added: "The martyrdom seekers will continue their missions."
The Israeli army has let it be known that it is readying a massive response, or as Defense Minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezar put it, "fingers are ready on the trigger." The leading newspaper Ha'aretz reported last week that the bombing had interrupted plans for a large operation to "stamp out terror" by invading the Palestinian-controlled areas to remove "suspects and heads of hostile extremist organizations," destroy some Palestinian Authority buildings and seize weapons.
All of which leaves the initiative in the hands of the next, inevitable, suicide bomber.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
A Case of Radical Surgery on Failing Schools

BYLINE:  By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
Inner-city schools have grown dramatically worse in the four decades since the economist Milton Friedman first argued for permitting children to transfer from failing public schools to successful private schools, taking public dollars with them. Critics protested that a voucher plan would bleed dollars from an under-funded system. But the Friedmanites have continued to argue for permitting children to escape failing schools while they are young enough to be saved, leaving the schools that failed them to shape up or close.
 The argument for preserving the public-school monopoly carried weight in the minority community when inner-city schools were frayed at the edges but still meeting the needs of their students. But the argument has lost public support in educational dead zones where graduation rates sometimes linger in the single digits. This loss of confidence is vividly evident in Pennsylvania, where Gov. Tom Ridge has advocated using vouchers in a number of troubled districts. As a form of compromise, the Legislature passed a law ceding the state sweeping new powers to take over and refashion entire districts where more than half of the children fail state math and reading tests. 
 The law could eventually be used against a dozen districts, including Philadelphia, one of the largest urban systems in the country. But the initiative was primarily aimed at the neighboring city of Chester, an educational eyesore of 20 years' standing that is widely recognized as one of the country's worst. The district has performed so poorly for so long that the state has considered actually dissolving it and dispersing its children into surrounding districts.
The state-appointed panel that runs the Chester Upland school district has taken the unusual step of hiring three for-profit companies -- Edison, Mosaica and LearnNow -- to run not just a few schools, but the entire district, with the exception of three existing charter schools. The privatizers have generated a mix of hope and suspicion among residents who are accustomed to failure and false promises. In addition, the politics of failure that have dominated the city for decades have already thrown the privatizers some nasty curve balls.
For the past several school years, the Chester Upland district has been the lowest-performing school district in the state. The most recent statistics show that nearly 70 percent of the city's children failed math and reading tests, but in some neighborhoods the failure rate is substantially higher. The dropout rate is more than four times that of the state. Only about 40 percent of Chester High School's students go on to college -- the lowest figure in the county. Nearby districts like Rose Tree Media, Wallingford-Swarthmore and Marple Newtown have college rates between 80 and 90 percent. 
As a Republican governor with both houses of the State Legislature in Republican control, Governor Ridge came to office counting on a full range of methods to use in school reform, up to and including vouchers. His first voucher proposal failed, as did his second and third. Members of the Ridge camp were stoic at first. But as the years rolled on, they began to criticize fellow Republicans who refused to extend their free-market philosophies to the education field. As one state official said earlier this month, "The unpleasant secret is that some in our party oppose vouchers because they don't want poor children from the inner city coming into their neighborhoods to go to school." 
Edison and LearnNow decided to merge after the Chester deal was struck. They and Mosaica are hoping to boost their business fortunes by succeeding where the public system has failed.
The privatizers typically interview the teachers at the schools they take over, keeping those who fit their profiles and encouraging the others to move on. Edison, Mosaica and LearnNow naturally assumed that the Chester project would work this way as well. The companies say they had already committed to Chester when they were told they would have to hire the union teachers who already worked in the schools. 
It is unclear how much flexibility the teachers' union will provide. But one privatizer said that the task of evaluating the teachers and getting rid of the unsuitable ones would probably result in "a house-to-house fight."
The state plans to hold the companies to strict performance targets, and has warned them that failing to meet those targets is a fireable offense. But with the takeover scheduled to begin in September, the companies are just beginning to comprehend a school district budget that has historically been the main source of patronage in the city. As one manager said: "We still do not know where the bottom is. . . . There are leeches all over Chester's schools. When you pull back the patient's clothes, you see that those leeches have burrowed deeply into the body."
The privatizers are eager to show Wall Street that they can make money by improving Chester's spectacularly dismal schools. But they have already seen that this is no walk in the park. In addition, if Chester thwarts them, a Legislature that has rejected the voucher route may well be inclined to reconsider.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Week of Puzzles but Few Answers

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Uncertainty was the theme on Wall Street last week. With a paucity of economic news and major company announcements, investors had few tea leaves to read. 
 The biggest news came from the technology bellwether Intel, which said sales this quarter would be within expectations, though on the low end. National Semiconductor also issued an earnings warning, saying it would post a bigger-than-expected loss, but predicted that results would soon turn around. The two reports touched off a rally in technology stocks, with investors interpreting them as signs that the worst was over. 
 Among the three major indexes, the technology-heavy Nasdaq fared best, rising to 2,215.10, up 65.66 points, or 3.1 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also ended higher, at 1,264.96, up 4.29 points, or 0.3 percent. Only the Dow industrials slipped, weakened by a big jury award against Philip Morris. It finished at 10,977.00, off 13.41 points, or 0.1 percent. 
 Bonds rallied early in the week on comments by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that inflation was not a threat. But jitters about the economy caused a sell-off at week's end. The yield on the 10-year Treasury remained unchanged from the previous week, at 5.36 percent. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: MY FIRST JOB; 
Empire-Building On a Paper Route

BYLINE:  By ROBERT ROSS; Written with Judy Tong.; Robert Ross, who is 82 and lives in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla., made his fortune in the 1970's by trading commodities like grain and petroleum with the Soviet Union. He founded the Ross University School of Medicine on Dominica in the Caribbean and the Ross University School of Veterinary Medicine on St. Kitts. He sold the schools this year for $135 million. The chief buyer was Leeds Weld & Company, a private equity firm in New York.

 BODY:
WHEN you grow up in harsh economic times, as I did during the Depression, there may be a special incentive to get ahead. My father died when I was 8. 
I lived with my mother and my four sisters in Detroit. I was the baby. As we grew older, my sisters and I all contributed to the upkeep of the house. 
 I was always ambitious. At 13, I had a paper route that included some large apartment buildings. I got up at 4 a.m. to deliver 200 copies of The Detroit Free Press, the morning paper. But I wasn't satisfied with a small paper route. I wanted a huge paper route. So after school I delivered 200 copies of the afternoon paper, The Detroit News, to the same apartment buildings. I rarely missed a day. 
 Because I had built one of the biggest routes in Detroit, I won a prize from The News in 1933 to go to the Polo Grounds in New York to watch the Giants play the Washington Senators in the World Series. I was 15 and I was earning $100 a week.
 Entrepreneurship is something you are born with. I had it. What is an entrepreneur? One who takes great risks. In many cases you are not successful, but you have to be tenacious. If you are not, and don't follow through, you'll be a failure.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 17, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of a production error, the My First Job article last Sunday, in which Robert Ross, the founder of the Ross University School of Medicine on Dominica, described his boyhood work delivering newspapers, carried an erroneous credit for the writer who worked with him on the article. She was Jenny Holland, not Judy Tong.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
It's Not Just the Job; It's the Hours on the Job

 BODY:
So you think you have a long workweek? Don't let the average worker from South Korea hear you complain, or people in Turkey or Argentina, for that matter.
 On average, South Koreans put in 55.1 hours a week, which is more than workers from 31 other countries surveyed by Roper Starch Worldwide in New York. 
The survey, whose results were released last week, questioned 1,000 workers in each country. 
 Just behind the Koreans in hours worked were the Turks, at 54.1 a week, followed by the Argentines, at 53.5, and the Taiwanese, 53.4.
Workers in the United States, where economic growth has slowed, and in China put in the same amount of time on the job -- 42.4 hours, below the global average of 44.6.
Who works the least amount of hours each week? According to the study, it is the French, who average 40.3 hours and the Italians, at 40.5. 
France cut its workweek to 35 hours from 39 hours about a year ago to tackle high unemployment levels and bolster the economy. In other industrialized countries, "we're beginning to see greater emphasis on balancing work and leisure," said Tom Miller, group senior vice president of Roper.

HEADLINE: A Holy Place in China Fights for Its Life, Body and Soul 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: YUBENG, China 

 BODY:
The 133 residents of this remote mountain hamlet know they live almost in paradise. 
 In the spring the old-growth forest, one of China's last bits of raw nature, twinkles with the pink rhododendrons that grow in astounding profusion -- one of many reasons why biologists call the area a "hot spot" of biodiversity. 
 In the fall, flaming maples and oaks illuminate the spruce, fir and pine. Bears, monkeys and the occasional snow leopard roam these mountains; golden eagles cruise the valleys while giant squadrons of green parakeets hunt for pine nuts. 
The villagers, ethnic Tibetans in a stronghold of traditional culture, take spiritual as well as aesthetic comfort from the landscape. Commanding the valley and protecting the village is 22,107-foot Kawagebo, the second-holiest mountain in Tibetan Buddhism, which tens of thousands of pilgrims circle each year. 
The hillsides abound with sacred forests, a sacred waterfall and other holy sites that are marked by gaily flapping prayer flags -- places where the faithful can deposit their worries or seek good fortune. 
"My spirit and soul are here," said Aqianbu, a 30-year-old Yubeng man, as he watched horses placidly grazing in the village meadow, against the unreal backdrop of glacier-draped pinnacles. "We worship the nature around us." 
But if this is almost paradise, that "almost" contains a world of sorrows the people of Yubeng could do without. 
Mr. Aqianbu matter-of-factly gave an example. He, his younger brother and the wife they share, in the polyandrous triangle common to the region, have watched three of their four babies die -- a result of the near-total lack of modern medicine, the poor sanitation and nutrition and, ultimately, the poverty and isolation of a village that is an arduous six-hour hike from the nearest dirt road. 
They are proud of their surviving daughter, but they are not happy that to attend school beyond the third grade she must make that same hike over a high mountain pass, then stay at school for two weeks at a time, paying dormitory fees that are a terrible strain. 
Today, the Yunnan provincial government is aggressively promoting tourism and other development, in part to replace the huge revenues lost when logging -- the former mainstay of counties surrounding Yubeng wherever roads had made it feasible -- was banned in 1998 to protect watersheds. 
Now the people of the region, especially in more pristine places like Yubeng, are facing a challenge that many other parts of China have already failed: finding a way to prosper, while preserving their unique environment. 
To solve this problem, the people of Yubeng are engaged in an unusual dialogue about their future -- part of a collaboration between the Yunnan government and the United States-based Nature Conservancy, one of the largest private international conservation groups. 
"The goal of the Nature Conservancy is to protect biodiversity," said Rose Niu, a 39-year-old member of Yunnan's Naxi minority group who has a master's degree in resource management and directs the conservancy's China project. 
"But here, it's very clear that you can't protect nature unless you work together with local communities and preserve the culture too," she said. "We especially need to promote the traditions calling for harmony with nature." 
In this ethnic Tibetan zone of northwest Yunnan, some families and temples keep discreet pictures of the Dalai Lama and the exiled leader is revered, but the political atmosphere is less tense than in parts of Tibet proper. And the Yunnan government has supported the rebuilding of temples and the controlled promotion of Tibetan culture, if nothing else as a way to draw tourists.
Ms. Niu is not Tibetan, but from the ancient Naxi town of Lijiang, a World Heritage Site to the south, which the conservancy is also working to preserve. 
Lijiang's old quarter, she noted, remains quaint but is already overrun with tourists and now has crime and prostitution. 
"In China I don't know of any place that is a good example of eco-tourism," said Ms. Niu. Especially since the logging ban, many counties in northern Yunnan are desperate for quick money, she said, but she hopes the region can pursue "a long-term, sustainable kind of tourism."
Two refugees from Washington politics are also living in Yunnan and advising the project on behalf of the Nature Conservancy. Ed Norton, a lawyer, was a leading environmental advocate and his wife, Ann McBride, was president of Common Cause, the campaign-reform lobby, before the two became entranced by the possibilities and moved here in 1999. 
Their endeavor is called the Yunnan Great Rivers Project, reflecting yet another spectacular trait of the West Virginia-size region it covers. The upper reaches of four of Asia's mightiest rivers -- the Yangtze, the Mekong, the Salween and the Irrawaddy -- flow in parallel within a band of 55 miles, separated by high mountain ridges, 
The drastic elevation changes, the rainy summers and the region's latitude -- at the transition from temperate to subtropical -- fostered an explosion in biodiversity: northern Yunnan is home to 10,000 plant species, including 162 species of rhododendron and 120 species of primrose.
The region is a prime source for Asian medical herbs and for matsutake and morel mushrooms, which are picked by villagers for export, offering badly needed cash income to supplement their subsistence farming and possibilities for sustainable enterprises in the future. 
"It's unbelievable," said Bob Mosely, a botanist from Idaho who is helping with research and strategy in the Yubeng area, part of the range known in Chinese as Meili Snow Mountain. "You turn a corner, and you see three or four different species of plants."
Mr. Mosely is working with local experts to map the "sacred geography" of the area, the zones that are largely protected from cutting and hunting already because of animist beliefs, as an aid to demarcating future reserves. 
The cutting of trees for home heating and cooking, as well as home construction, is a growing threat to the region's forests and must be confronted soon, said Mr. Norton, who also noted that longtime supposed nature reserves were inhabited and heavily exploited. 
The local government is experimenting with biogas, using animal and human waste to create cooking fuel, and in Yubeng there is talk of expanding the current mini-hydro plant, which now generates just enough electricity to light a few 15-watt bulbs in each home. 
"We have to find a way to hook the villagers into the stream of benefits," Mr. Norton said as he hiked the rugged trail to Yubeng. "How can they, and not outsiders, capture most of the revenue?" 
Still-remote places like Yubeng are ideally situated for small-scale eco-tourism, Ms. McBride said, attracting visitors who want to hike and explore both nature and Tibetan culture. "Villagers need to gain the skills to guide visitors and teach them about the environment and the religion," she said. 
Even before the current aid project started, Mr. Aqianbu, the village man, had a similar vision, borrowing money from relatives two years ago to build a small trekker's lodge. But so far, he says, he barely gets by -- unable to save enough to pour cement on the dirt floor or even to build the latrine that is essential if a surge in visitors is not to pollute the sacred land. 
"I have many dreams but I don't have the means to realize them," Mr. Aqianbu said, explaining why he and fellow residents of Yubeng desperately want the road that has been proposed in regional plans, but that some experts say may never be economically feasible. 
Life in Yubeng is not so bad for the people, said Amu, 41, one of two appointed village chiefs, "but it's hard for the cattle, which can't find enough grass to eat." 
"I would never leave this place," he said. "I love the environment, and Kawagebo peak protects us." 
Mr. Amu noted, however, that Yubeng and neighboring villages had already clashed over rights to collect wood and mushrooms, that the valuable mushrooms were getting harder to find and that bears and deer stole a good share of the corn crop. 
Mr. Amu declined to count how many children have died in Yubeng, only saying "there have been many." When people get sick, he said, they usually "let it go the natural way," though in some cases -- if they can borrow enough from fellow villagers to pay the high fees -- relatives may carry patients to the hospital in the county seat of Deqin, a dawn-to-darkness ordeal over two high ridges. 
"Of course, all of us are looking forward to a better life," he said. "We need a road most of all, and we need a bigger hydropower station to give us steady electricity for cooking."
"We see tourism as our best hope," Mr. Amu said. "We welcome more tourists here, but those that bring destruction will not be allowed."

HEADLINE: As Biotech Crops Multiply, Consumers Get Little Choice 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 9 

 BODY:
Despite persistent concerns about genetically modified crops, they are spreading so rapidly that it has become almost impossible for consumers to avoid them, agriculture experts say.
 More than 100 million acres of the world's most fertile farmland were planted with genetically modified crops last year, about 25 times as much as just four years earlier. Wind-blown pollen, commingled seeds and black-market plantings have further extended these products of biotechnology into the far corners of the global food supply -- perhaps irreversibly, according to food experts. 
 "The genie is already out of the bottle," said Neil E. Harl, a professor of agriculture and economics at Iowa State University, speaking of genetically modified organisms, or G.M.O.'s. "If the policy tomorrow was that we were going to eradicate G.M.O.'s, this would be a very long process. It would take years if not decades to do that." 
Most of the biotech fields are soybeans and corn planted in North and South America, the biggest food exporters. But biotech crops -- genetically altered to do things like release their own insecticide or withstand the spraying of weed-killing chemicals -- are being shipped or experimented with in many other countries, including China, India, Australia and South Africa. 
They are even turning up where people least expect them: in countries where they are banned but a black market has developed; in food supplies where they are forbidden or shunned, like organic products; even in fields that farmers believe are completely free of genetically modified crops. 
The rapid adoption and proliferation means that even as scientists and others debate the safety of altering foods' genetic codes to produce cheaper and bigger supplies, a large share of the world's population has little or no choice but to consume genetically modified crops. 
One indication came last year when Starlink, a variety of genetically modified corn not approved for human consumption, accidentally entered the global food supply, leading to extensive food recalls in the United States and Japan over fears it could cause allergic reactions. 
Starlink has not been shown to be harmful; indeed, there is little evidence that biotech foods are dangerous to humans. But the episode showed that seeds planted on less than 1 percent of America's corn acreage could easily spread from farm to farm, contaminate the nation's grain handling system and seep into global food supplies.
Seed companies, farmers, processors and food makers have spent more than $1 billion in the last six months trying to eradicate Starlink. But most experts agree that will take years. 
In the meantime, experts say the spread of biotech crops creates an entirely new set of trade, regulatory and legal problems: 
* Large countries with policies limiting the use of genetically modified crops may soon have to change course, because they will not be able to get enough nonbiotech crops to meet their import needs. 
* Regulators are under pressure to develop new standards to determine what is and is not genetically modified -- a situation complicated, as the Starlink episode demonstrated, by the commingling and cross-pollination of different crops. 
* Big food and agriculture companies are facing legal and public relations challenges, because some farmers and consumers believe their products have been contaminated.
Gene-altered crops are already ubiquitous in the United States, where the Food and Drug Administration has deemed them "entirely safe." But Europe and parts of Asia remain wary of the crops, and there have been moves in those regions to halt or slow their import. 
Skeptics say that tampering with nature could inadvertently alter species, harm wildlife and give rise to new problems, like herbicide-resistant "superweeds." They also worry about the long-term health consequences of eating foods that are armed with insecticides and foreign genes. And the critics suspect that the industry has intentionally flooded the world market with genetically altered seeds to pre-emptively settle the question of whether or not to adopt biotechnology 
Opponents expected Starlink to be a turning point in the fight against genetically altered crops. But while the episode helped stall the advance of genetically modified wheat, potatoes and sugar, it seems to have served as proof, over all, of biotech's inexorable spread. Most food makers in the United States continue to use biotech crops, insisting they are safe and far too pervasive to avoid; meanwhile, relatively few American consumers seem to care. 
Perhaps more important, the bulk of American grain sold for domestic and international use goes into animal feed, and thus far few farmers or big companies have opposed feeding biotech grain to livestock. 
Indeed, biotech industry officials believe the game is nearly won. The United States, Brazil and Argentina account for about 90 percent of the world's corn and soybean exports. Bulk shipments from the United States and Argentina are predominantly biotech. And Brazil is widely believed to have a black market in biotech soybeans. 
If Brazil legalizes biotech production, Europe and Asia -- the world's two biggest purchasers of soy -- would have almost nowhere to turn for adequate supplies of nonbiotech soybeans. Environmentalists in Brazil have protested biotechnology, and though the government there is split, industry officials in the United States say that Brazil is leaning toward allowing the use of genetically modified seeds.
"We are very hopeful that last domino will fall," said Bob Callanan, a spokesman for the American Soybean Association, a trade group that supports the use of gene-altered crops. "That's why the environmentalists are putting up a stink down there in Brazil. They know if that goes, it's all gone." 
That would be a huge victory for biotechnology companies. Monsanto, Aventis, Syngenta and others have spent billions of dollars to create the crops, and some independent groups, including the United Nations, promote them as one answer to world health and hunger problems.
Andrew Cash, an analyst who follows the biotechnology industry at UBS Warburg, says that Europe already has little choice but to accept the crops, largely because Monsanto's Roundup Ready Soybeans, the primary biotech variety, are so widespread. 
"Europe is learning its first lesson in the 'beggars can't be choosers' world of agricultural reality -- it's G.M.O. beans or no beans," Mr. Cash wrote last January. 
Food companies are already having a hard time obtaining nongenetically modified crops. Grain handlers like Archer Daniels Midland and Cargill are charging extra to segregate and test crops to certify that they are nonbiotech. 
And that is becoming harder to do. Some agriculture experts say that cross-pollination of biotech corn and seed corn, as well as poor and imperfect grain-handling practices, have thoroughly scrambled crops in a global food chain that for decades shipped bulk supplies of largely undifferentiated products. 
Food makers around the world are finding traces of gene-altered crops in foods that were not supposed to be made with them; Midwestern farmers are complaining that wind is blowing pollen from gene-altered crops into neighboring fields planted with conventional corn. 
Even organic crops labeled "G.M. Free" are testing positive for genetic modification. Organic growers are now considering a class-action lawsuit against the biotech industry that would seek damages for the contamination.
"We have found traces in corn that has been grown organically for 10 to 15 years," said Arran Stephens, president of Nature's Path Foods, an organic producer of breads and cereals based in Delta, British Columbia. "There's no wall high enough to keep that stuff contained."
Some critics of biotechnology see a sinister plot at work, with the industry ignoring the implications of widespread pollen flow and perhaps even encouraging a black market in biotech crops. 
"They're hoping there's enough contamination so that it's a fait accompli," said Jeremy Rifkin, a longtime critic of biotechnology.
"But the liability will kill them," he said. "We're going to see lawsuits across the Farm Belt as conventional farmers and organic farmers find their product is contaminated." 
The world's biggest biotech seed companies acknowledge that some pollen may go astray. And they acknowledge that they cannot guarantee that even the conventional seed they sell is 100 percent free of genetic modification.
Agriculture, they say, is prone to mishaps. 
"By and large, where there are crops grown, and where G.M. materials are approved, the issue is with us," said Dean Oestreich, a vice president at Pioneer Hi-Bred, the world's largest seed company. "Our basic seed stocks are pure. But there's always adventitious presence, which means small amounts of unintentional presence through pollen flow and physical mixing." 
Because of all this commingling, the companies are calling on regulators in many countries to relax tolerance standards for crops, to avoid trade, labeling and legal problems.
Zero tolerance, said Jeanne Romero-Severson, a professor of agriculture at Purdue University, is simply not realistic.
"If your standard is 100 percent pure," she said, "you better stop eating right now."

HEADLINE: Jitters Over the Economy Guarantee a Long Run for the Budget Late Show 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 9 

 BODY:
Most years the battle over the state budget is long and ugly, but when Gov. George E. Pataki raised the possibility of a three-month emergency spending bill earlier this week, he signaled that the impasse this year is worse than most.
 Such a bill would have probably put off action on a new spending plan until September, later than any budget has ever been passed. The Democrats who control the Assembly rejected the idea immediately. 
 On the surface, this year's impasse seems to be about partisan politics. The governor, a Republican, accuses the Assembly Democrats of proposing irresponsible spending increases. The Democrats accuse the governor of trying to horde money to spend on popular programs during the election year. For the 17th year in a row, the Legislature missed the April 1 deadline and no progress had been made since then. 
Behind the political barbs flying between Mr. Pataki and the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, there is genuine disagreement about the economy's future health. The main reason this budget may well not be passed until September is that it may take that long to see if the economy, and thus tax revenues, will rebound in the second half of the year.
"This whole budget debate is coming down to a single question: tolerance for risk," said Abraham M. Lackman, the budget director for the Republican Senate majority. "The governor has a low tolerance. Shelly Silver has a higher tolerance."
All sides agree that for the past eight years, the country and state have seen phenomenal economic growth and soaring tax revenues, much of it flowing from the millions made on Wall Street. Everyone also agrees the national economy hit a slowdown in late 2000 and has been sinking ever since. 
What the economists advising the governor and legislative leaders disagree on is, what happens next. Some economists predict the economy will rebound quickly in the second and third quarters, bouncing like a superball in the shape of a "V." Others predict a slower, longer recovery, shaped like a "U." Then there are economists who think the economy will bottom out and stay there, like an "L." Both Mr. Silver's advisers and Mr. Pataki's analysts are among the optimists. Both camps assume that there will be a V-shaped recovery this year, and that the national economy will grow about 2 percent. But they disagree on what that means for state tax revenues, which make up about half of the budget.
Republicans who control the Senate were initially more optimistic than the governor, proposing spending of at least $1 billion more than the governor. But the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has recently said his conference may have to reduce its revenue estimate, bringing it closer to the governor's position in light of the faltering economy. 
The governor's aides point out that taxes on Wall Street profits and bonuses make up a much greater part of the state's revenues than they used to, accounting for at least a quarter of income taxes. They also note that the Nasdaq is down 60 percent from last year, which they say will take perhaps as much as $2 billion out of capital gains revenue.
They also worry that the deflating market will severely crimp the bonuses Wall Street executives get this year. Lower corporate taxes are also expected, since it is widely acknowledged that the manufacturing sector is in recession. To make matters worse, the Pataki administration has $1.8 billion in tax cuts passed in previous years that take effect this year.
The governor's aides calculate that if capital gains drop 10 to 15 percent and bonuses are down by 10 percent, the state's revenues will not grow beyond the $42 billion collected in the last fiscal year, even if the economy does grow by 2 percent. 
"To me, flat's starting to look good," one senior Pataki economist said. "It seems to us it's very conceivable that a flat revenue forecast for the year makes sense." 
The Democratic analysts, who do not believe tax revenues linked to Wall Street will be as depressed as Republicans do, are more optimistic. They project state revenues will grow by about 3.9 percent, or $1.4 billion, even if the economy lumbers along at about 2 percent. Not that that would be good, they say. It would still be far below the 10 percent growth in revenues last year.
The Democrats' analysts point out that the governor has underestimated personal income taxes every year for seven years. This spring, they say, at least $1.9 billion more came in than the governor predicted. Most of that flowed from bonuses paid to Wall Street executives.
The Assembly's economists are predicting that much of that $1.9 billion will come in again next year. The governor's aides regard it as a one-time windfall because the stock market has cooled off. Therein lies the rub. No one will know for sure who is right until next February. 
But there will be some earlier signs. In July and September, people who do not make most of their income from salaries, like entrepreneurs and venture capitalists, have to give the state an estimate of what their annual taxes will be. In the past five years, revenues from people who pay estimated taxes have risen 14 to 18 percent every year.
The question is how much they will rise this year. Both sides are waiting for those signals.
One problem for forecasters is guessing how much capital gains there will be. Last year, state residents reported about $60 billion, which meant about $4 billion in income taxes for the state. But it is hard to know in this year's bear market when the stocks being sold off today were bought. If they were bought in the past nine months, there would be few profits and thus little in income tax collected. But if they are stocks that have been held for more than five years, investors unloading them still may profit handsomely and would have to pay tax. 
The governor cannot afford to roll the dice. If his budget office's prediction of flat revenue growth is right, he will have to use some reserves just to finance the 3.2 percent increase in state spending he proposed in January. That would leave him about $3.2 billion in reserves going into the election year, his aides maintain, which fiscal conservatives argue is the very least a state the size of New York should have on hand.
The Assembly Democrats, on the other hand, are willing to bet state revenues will rise somewhat despite the slowdown. They have proposed spending $1.9 billion more in state revenues than the governor did, most of it for education. They like to point out that that amount is already in the bank in the form of a surplus because the governor underestimated revenues last year. 
"If you take this $1.9 billion in the bank, there is enough here to compromise," said Dean Fuleihan, the secretary of the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee.

HEADLINE: Europeans' Rallying Cry: One Share, One Vote! 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
HENRI LACHMANN had a grand vision. By merging his company, Schneider Electric S.A., which makes electrical equipment for factories and power plants, with Legrand S.A., a maker of consumer products like plugs and dimmers, he would create a French mini-version of General Electric, with $11 billion in revenue.
 So earlier this year, Mr. Lachmann reached an agreement with the Decoster and Verspieren families, whose forebears acquired Legrand in 1944 and built it into a major supplier of electrical products, to acquire it for $7 billion in Schneider stock. 
 While the families own only 40 percent of Legrand's shares, they were vital to Mr. Lachmann's ambitions. Under a two-tier stock structure, they control 56 percent of the voting rights. So Mr. Lachmann agreed to pay the families 43.5 percent more for their shares than minority shareholders would pocket for their nonvoting ones. 
Until, that is, the French association for the defense of minority shareholders got wind of it. Backed by investment funds that own Legrand's nonvoting stock, the association, known by the French acronym ADAM, sued to block the deal -- and won. The struggle ended last month, when a court in Paris voided the takeover because it put a higher value on voting than nonvoting stock. The ruling forced Mr. Lachmann and the families that control Legrand to put forth a revised offer on Thursday that was more equitable to the owners of nonvoting shares.
A few years ago, the case might not have even made it into the courts. But these days activist shareholders appear to be all over Europe, where attitudes toward owning stock and exercising the rights of ownership are changing significantly. Mr. Lachmann's rude awakening illustrates how companies across the Continent are being pushed to adjust.
In Switzerland, the families controlling the Roche pharmaceutical group are under assault; in Sweden, the family that runs most of the country's industrial companies is cautiously watching an activist fund manager who recently doubled his stake in the the family's publicly traded investment company; in Italy, investors who took over the national phone company, Telecom Italia, are being challenged in court; and in Ireland, shareholders attending the annual meeting of the Jefferson Smurfit Group, a paper and packaging company with four Smurfit family members on its five-person executive board, chanted "Resign!" at the chief executive, Michael W. J. Smurfit.
"Society has undergone broad changes in this respect," said Walter Knabenhans, chief executive of Bank Julius Baer, one of a small circle of Swiss private banks with asset-management businesses that let them benefit from the new investor mind-set. "It is reflective of changed values at the shareholder level."
Encouraged by fund managers from the United States and Britain, European shareholders are catching the reform fever that took hold among American investors in the 1980's. Now, as then, corporate earnings growth is sluggish -- and so are stock prices. But the executives in charge remain entrenched, resistant to being held to account. Instead of paying greenmail or adopting poison pills to discourage corporate raiders -- as American executives did -- Europeans have so far relied more often on equity structures that give effective control of companies to small groups of insiders. The insiders own a relatively small number of shares, but their shares have extraordinary voting rights.
The surging number of shareholders in Europe, however, is changing this picture. In Germany, more than 12 million people, or 14 percent of the population, owned shares at the end of last year -- 50 percent more than a year earlier and double the 1997 total. That still trails the United States, where about half of all adults own stock, but as more Europeans have jumped into the market, the media have covered financial news more aggressively, giving investors a useful weapon and helping to spread American-style activism.
In Germany, change is expected to accelerate next year, when the government abolishes the 50 percent capital gains tax on share sales. That will free banks to sell the immense industrial holdings that some of them began accumulating before World War II -- thus making millions of shares of stock available to investors just as the country is encouraging individuals to save for their retirements rather than count on government pensions. And for years now here in France, big corporations, in part heeding shareholder demands for more focused investment, have been surrendering the cross shareholdings that historically tied together this country's system.
Last week, European leaders agreed on a law that will make it easier to carry out hostile takeover bids and more difficult for companies to defend themselves by selling shares to friendly shareholders, probably increasing the pace and likelihood of cross-border deals. Though it must still be enacted and would not take full effect until 2006, the agreement represents a turning point for European corporations: It enshrines the principle that shareholders rather than executives have the final say on hostile bids.
EVEN amid such pressure, shareholder rights in Europe are not yet anything like what they are in the United States. In much of Europe, multitiered share structures -- which either give extraordinary voting rights to a special class of shares or deny voting rights to most shareholders in exchange for a larger dividend -- continue to let small groups of investors, often families, control companies and insulate executives from the results of their poor performance.
(Multitiered share structures are not unheard-of in the United States, of course. Some formerly family-owned media companies, including The New York Times Company, use them to preserve journalistic independence.)
In the Old World, many companies consider it too chancy to surrender control to shareholders. Privileged families and financial institutions like banks and insurers have traditionally seen themselves as guarantors of long-term prosperity, a kind of financial aristocracy.
But fund managers and others, including some European bankers, say the changes of the last few years will accelerate as companies compete for capital.
No one may be more familiar with those changes than Roberto Colaninno. He took advantage of Europe's new access to the global capital market in 1999 to raise the $60 billion he needed for his company -- Olivetti, a former typewriter maker -- to buy the much larger Telecom Italia.
But earlier this year, when Mr. Colaninno tried to restructure the financing of Telecom Italia, activist investors blocked his proposed $10 billion share conversion and buyback plan because, they said, it would have primarily benefited Olivetti, of which he owns 30 percent.
ELSEWHERE, a group of rebel shareholders led by the French investor Romain Zaleski recently overturned a plan by the Mediobanca investment bank to have Montedison, a chemicals-to-power conglomerate, pay the Falck family the equivalent of 13 euros a share for its 20 percent stake in Falck S.p.A., an energy utility, after all other shareholders had agreed to tender their shares for 9 euros each.
Mr. Zaleski, a former French bureaucrat turned activist investor, and his allies asserted that the terms were too sweet for the Falck family and Mediobanca, which has historically used informal shareholder pacts to control Italian companies.
Not long ago, such shareholder rebellions were "looked upon as unsocial, wrong or damaging to society," said Kurt Schiltknecht, an investment banker at BZ Bank in Zurich, whose chairman, Martin Ebner, is a leader among European activist shareholders. Activists are no longer dismissed as misfits, he said.
"When we first started, there was enormous resistance," Mr. Schiltknecht added, "but in the meantime, the size of boards is being reduced, members are chosen for their competence, and they have accepted the idea of shareholder value."
The economic logic behind the change is simple. As European companies take on global competitors, the founders' families and banks can no longer finance them. So the companies are turning to capital markets, where individual and institutional investors demand performance and accountability -- and a say in how companies are run. If they are not satisfied, they can easily move their capital elsewhere -- potentially puncturing the stock price of uncooperative companies.
"In the post-cold-war period, debt and equity funding had to make itself acceptable to an international forum," said Guy Jubb, an expert on corporate governance at Standard Life Investments in Edinburgh. "It is the large companies that are setting the pace. Over time, it trickled down to other tiers of business."
The new mind-set is hardly universal. Many European executives assert that tight control by a small group of investors, often a family, frees management from the threat of hostile takeover and assures the tranquillity needed for long-term investments. And they are willing to resist the pressure to change.
Roche, for example, won a protracted battle with Mr. Ebner over its two-tiered share structure, which lets the Hoffmann and Oeri families, descendants of Roche's founder, control 50.1 percent of the votes while owning fewer than 10 percent of the shares.
Franz Humer, Roche's chairman, defends the structure. "One big advantage of family-controlled companies is the fact that the majority shareholder is interested in the long-term success of the company," he said. In the drug industry, he added, "where you need 8 to 10 years to develop a new compound, this long-term perspective is vital."
Mr. Ebner, however, argued that Roche's structure served merely to insulate the company's managers from the consequences of poor performance. Over the last eight years, Roche's stock has risen an average 15.5 percent annually -- less than both the Swiss industry drug makers index, which has advanced an average of 20 percent a year, and Switzerland's biggest pharmaceutical company, Novartis (and its predecessor companies, Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy), which gained 23.5 percent a year.
Moreover, Roche's numbers have worsened. In the last five years, the annual gain of its stock has slipped to 6.5 percent, half that of the industry index. In the last six months, Roche shares have declined 23.7 percent.
Unable to win a seat on the board or otherwise persuade the company to improve its performance, Mr. Ebner sold his remaining Roche stake, which had one-fifth of the voting rights, for $2.8 billion last month. But he may yet force change at Roche, because he sold the stock to Novartis, prompting speculation of a takeover by the larger company. Novartis's chairman, Daniel Vasella, dismisses the idea that traditional European corporate structures are desirable. "Even if you have family behind you," he said in an interview, "I don't think it's any proof that where you're going will bring long-term success."
MR. EBNER'S experience at Roche shows how resistant some companies are to surrendering share structures that give control to small insider groups. So, too, does the experience of Rene Braginsky this year at Sulzer A.G., a Swiss machinery maker.
Mr. Braginsky, 51, is a former banker who has become something once unthinkable in Switzerland: a corporate raider. In April, he made a $2.3 billion hostile bid for Sulzer. He was not battling a family, but rather entrenched managers who shielded themselves by capping the voting rights of all investors at 5 percent, regardless of how much stock they owned. That defense succeeded in fending off Mr. Braginsky, though the board accepted some of his demands and agreed to consider the "one share, one vote" idea next year.
Such setbacks have not discouraged the reformers. Mr. Braginsky is preparing for a wholesale consolidation in Germany next year, once the elimination of capital gains taxes on the sale of cross-shareholdings makes it easier for banks to sell their significant stakes in their corporate borrowers. Deutsche Bank alone owns $16 billion in stock. 
"The puzzle in Germany will be rearranged," Mr. Braginsky said. To make the most of the change, his investment company, Incentive Capital, enlisted as board chairman Karl Otto Pohl, once head of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank.
German bankers say the change will push the 30 blue-chip companies on the benchmark DAX index to buy other companies or risk being bought themselves. Those blue chips, including DaimlerChrsyler, the Bayer chemical group and the ThyssenKrupp steelworks, have long been largely owned or controlled by financial institutions.
Such structural change -- as well as the influence of the United States and Britain, which supply growing amounts of capital and the bankers to invest it -- are even pushing some of Europe's own institutional investors to beat the drum for better treatment by companies that they ostensibly own. For instance, First Eagle SoGen Funds, an asset-management arm of the French bank Societe Generale, ran full-page advertisements in French papers attacking Schneider for offering different premiums to ordinary and preferred shareholders in its bid for Legrand.
But other funds still prefer to let shareholder organizations carry the flag. One of the best-known groups is ADAM, the Association of Minority Shareholders in France, which asked an appeals court to overturn a decision by regulators to allow Schneider's offer. ADAM is run by Colette Neuville, an economist and lawyer who became a shareholder activist a decade ago when her stockbroker went broke; she operates out of a narrow pair of rooms in the shadow of the cathedral in Chartres, an hour southwest of here.
The group would not say how many members it has, but it has emerged in recent years as a challenger to giants of French business, tackling in court suits companies like Vivendi and industrialists like Francois Pinault, who owns the Pinault-Printemps-Redoute retail chain.
THE latest battle to pry open Europe's closed corporations may be the most difficult yet. After selling his 20 percent stake in Roche last month, Mr. Ebner doubled his stake in Investor A.B. of Sweden, to 7.7 percent of its capital and 10.2 percent of its voting rights.
Investor, a large Swedish holding company much like Berkshire Hathaway in the United States, is controlled by the Wallenberg family. Among Investor's holdings are large stakes in Electrolux A.B., the home-appliance maker; AstraZeneca P.L.C., whose products include the ulcer treatment Prilosec and the local anesthetic Xylocaine; and Ericsson, maker of network equipment for mobile-phone services.
Even before Mr. Ebner raised his stake, Investor had come under fire for its two classes of shares. At Ericsson, for example, a two-tiered share structure gives the Wallenbergs almost 39 percent of the voting rights, even though they own only about 7 percent of the company's stock. All Ericsson shares are traded publicly and enjoy voting rights, but some have more votes than others.
Mr. Ebner recently met Investor's chairman, Percy Barnevik, but as is his custom, he declined to discuss what they talked about. However, Mr. Ebner's associates have suggested that Investor, whose shares trade for 25 percent less than the market value of all of the stock it owns, should consider measures like buying back shares and then canceling them, or splitting the group into smaller investment companies.
Mr. Barnevik, who as the longtime chairman of the Swiss-Swedish conglomerate ABB was known for backing the rights of shareholders, dismissed such radical changes in favor of pressing the companies that Investor controls to improve their performance. He believes that this will increase the value of Investor's shares. "I don't want to confuse the issue and dilute the company efforts by having a multitude of parallel goals," he said.
That may sound like old-school thinking, the kind that activist shareholders are trying to exorcise. But Mr. Barnevik says it works. Over the last 20 years, he said, Investor achieved an average annual return to shareholders of 27 percent, almost twice that of the OM Stockholm Exchange cumulative index.
Some experts believe that it is a matter of time before Mr. Ebner seeks a seat on the Investor board. Mr. Schiltknecht described Mr. Ebner as first seeking change through confidential discussions, and only then applying pressure through the media. "Executives pay more attention to newspapers than to investors," he said. "Vanity is a general phenomenon."
While investor activism is shifting the center of gravity toward American-style capitalism and its emphasis on shareholder value, the tug of European-style family capitalism lingers. "It probably goes back really to how European societies developed after the French Revolution, with a stronger preparedness to accept the concept of a certain shared interest," said Mr. Knabenhans, the Bank Julius Baer banker. Europeans may pay lip service to American-style capitalism, he added, "but when push comes to shove, the underlying reluctance is still rather strong."
STILL, the drift toward more responsive corporate governance, under American influence, has already brought change.
In Switzerland, where boards were once packed with 16 to 20 members, the average is now about 8 to 12, said Dr. Vasella, the Novartis chairman. Mr. Schiltknecht added that the practice of apportioning board seats on political, social or even religious grounds -- until recently, for instance, members of the Credit Suisse board could not be Catholic -- has yielded increasingly to competence as the sole criterion.
Mr. Schiltknecht quoted his boss: "As Mr. Ebner always says, 'No idea is as strong as an idea whose time has come.' "
