The events shake confidence in British finance and regulation. 1992The Cadbury Committee in Britain, formed to address concerns raised by big business failures, issues a report calling for the appointment of more outside directors. It also says board members should be held responsible for fraud or mismanagement. 1994The European Union adopts a common currency. This allows the creation of a Continent-wide corporate bond market that lets companies raise capital without borrowing from banks, which traditionally took large equity stakes in corporations. 1995The Greenbury Committee in Britain issues a report on executive pay that calls for greater disclosure of directors' pay, bonuses and stock options. It urges companies to rein in runaway executive compensation. The Vienot Report in France calls for more independent directors and the creation of audit, remuneration and appointment subcommittees by corporate boards. France's 40 largest corporations quickly adopt the suggestions. 1997The Peeters Report in the Netherlandsand the Stock Exchange Report in Belgium outline codes of good corporate governance for publicly traded companies based in each country. 1998The Hempel Committee in Britain issues the Combined Code, which calls on companies to better inform shareholders of risks, give outside directors more oversight authority and tie executive compensation to performance. 1999The Turnbull Report in Britain recommends that every publicly traded company have an embedded control system to monitor important threats to the company, and to hold directors and managers more strictly accountable for managing those risks. HEADLINE: Investing; 
Can Kraft Lay Enough Golden Eggs?

BYLINE:  By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
KRAFT is America's biggest food company by almost any measure. Its brands, including Maxwell House coffee, Oreo cookies, Jell-O pudding, Velveeta, Philadelphia cream cheese, Kool-Aid and Oscar Mayer hot dogs, are consumed in most American homes, and it dwarfs its domestic competitors. 
 But whether Kraft shares are a good deal for investors is likely to hinge on whether its earnings can be expected to increase faster than a typical food company's. 
 Philip Morris, the corporate parent of Kraft Foods, is selling 16 percent of its subsidiary this week, in what is likely to be the second-largest initial offering by an American company. The 280 million shares are expected to be priced from $27 to $30 a share. At $30, Kraft, based in Northfield, Ill., would raise $8.4 billion. (The largest initial offering was AT&T Wireless in April 2000, at $10.6 billion.) At this price range, Kraft would have a market capitalization of more than $50 billion -- more than three times the size of Sara Lee, the second-largest domestic food company. 
People who believe that Kraft's shares will rise appreciably are convinced that the company can increase its earnings at a faster pace than its peers. They argue that Kraft has an advantage derived from economies of scale. And they say Kraft's earnings will be bolstered by improvements in its balance sheet and by acquisitions. 
"We think this belongs in the company of elite consumer-goods companies," says Timothy M. Ghriskey, senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation in New York. 
Investors like Mr. Ghriskey, who put Kraft in the company of consumer giants like Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive, are inclined to look at the midpoint of the price range, $28.50 a share, as a good deal. But those who place Kraft among food companies like Heinz, General Mills and Campbell consider this price rather rich.
A RESEARCH report on April 24 by Goldman, Sachs, which is not involved in the deal, compared Kraft with other food companies. According to Goldman's analysis, even the midpoint price would be high. Romitha S. Mally, the author of the report, told investors on April 27 that a fair price for Kraft's initial offering would be $25 a share. The Goldman report said that the stock should be priced at nine times estimated 2001 Ebitda -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- and that it would be a good buy at up to $28 a share. 
At issue is how investors look at the company's ability to generate cash and to grow. At $28.50 a share, Kraft would be valued at about 10 times estimated cash flow for 2001, measured as Ebitda, analysts said. At 10 times Ebitda, Kraft's results would be in line with the average of other food companies.
Elite consumer-goods companies trade at 12 to 14 times Ebitda, Mr. Ghriskey said. Kraft's earnings will increase 15 percent a year on a cash basis, he said, if it can meet its goals, including a 3 percent to 4 percent increase in sales volume, improvements in its product mix and paying off its $18.4 billion in debt. 
"Those are aggressive numbers," he said, "but if they are able to achieve them, that puts them in that elite category." 
Terry Bivens, an analyst at Bear Stearns, which is not part of the deal, said that at $28.50, Kraft's value is in line with the average food company. But its prospects are "better than the average food company," Mr. Bivens said, noting that Kraft had seven brands that each had more than $1 billion in sales last year. 
Mr. Bivens said he thought that Credit Suisse First Boston and Salomon Smith Barney, the investment banks charged with managing the initial offering, would price the shares "attractively." 
"From an investor's point of view," he said, "anything under $30 is a buy."
Goldman said there were several reasons that Kraft should be priced at $28 or less. First, it discounts Kraft's value by 5 to 10 percent because Philip Morris will remain the majority stockholder and will retain control. Second, Goldman said, shareholders are exposed to liabilities resulting from tobacco litigation involving Philip Morris. And third, Goldman is giving Kraft's offering a 15 percent discount to reflect the number of shares that have to be sold.
Merrill Lynch, which is not involved directly in the deal, also takes a cautionary view. "This, in my opinion, is a food company," says Leonard Teitelbaum, a managing director at Merrill. Cost savings from Philip Morris's acquisition of Nabisco almost a year ago could help Kraft's earnings for a couple of years, he said. After that, he expects Kraft's cash flow, or Ebitda, to increase at 8 percent a year.
At $27 to $30 a share, Mr. Teitelbaum said, the deal is a "a little high for my comfort zone." 
Philip Morris is spinning off Kraft largely to realize the full value of a business that, as part of a conglomerate, cannot be valued against its peers. In the end, Philip Morris will still own about 84 percent of Kraft as well as common stock with 97.7 percent of the company's voting rights.
Because Philip Morris shareholders already so much of Kraft, many of them will not think that they must buy shares in it, analysts say.
HIGH valuations of Kraft assume that the company will not only grow within existing product categories but will also expand into new categories and overseas, said Mr. Ghriskey at Dreyfus. Founded in 1914, Kraft was acquired by Philip Morris in 1988. It earned $2 billion last year, up 14 percent from a year earlier, and is still absorbing Nabisco's operations. 
Although strong in the United States, Kraft has a relatively weak international business. In fact, Goldman analyzes Kraft as effectively two companies -- Kraft North America and Kraft Foods International. And the management arrangement is unusual: each unit is run by a chief executive who reports to Geoffrey C. Bible, the Philip Morris chairman. Betsy Holden heads the North American unit and Roger Deromedi heads the international group. 
Overseas, Kraft is struggling. While operating profit overseas increased by almost 17 percent last year, Goldman is not convinced that this growth is sustainable. Kraft may use the proceeds from the stock offering to strengthen its international presence through acquisitions, but Goldman questions whether a merger target would want to be a large shareholder in a company that continues to be controlled by Philip Morris, with its tobacco legacy. 
Still, many investors point to Kraft's strength in the United States and have faith that it can continue to increase earnings at double-digit rates. 
"They have an elite management group that's been successful in a very difficult industry," said Art Cecil, investment analyst at T. Rowe Price Associates.

HEADLINE: The Decade Nobody Knows 

BYLINE:  By George Packer; George Packer is the author, most recently, of "Blood of the Liberals."

 BODY:
 THE SEVENTIES
The Great Shift in American Culture,
Society, and Politics.
By Bruce J. Schulman.
Illustrated. 334 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $26.
 Until recently, no one has quite known what to do with the 1970's. The years between Woodstock and Reagan seemed to dribble out in a long and tacky anticlimax that never announced any overarching theme. "Try to retrieve the 70's and memories crumble in one's hands, nothing keeps its shape," Irving Howe wrote in his autobiography, "Margin of Hope." "The decade itself lacks a distinctive historical flavor." Nixon's transcripts, Ford's golf shots, Carter's crazed rabbit, Jonathan Livingston Seagull, Richard Pryor, Squeaky Fromme, the Captain and Tennille, stretch-waist baseball uniforms, Rolfing: if all of this had any flavor, it was the taste of the absurd. Children of the 1970's, having inherited a reflexive cynicism toward authority without a cause greater than recycling or a sacrifice more painful than gas lines, learned early on to feel envy, shame and resentment. The last thing anyone growing up in the 70's imagined was that a great historical transformation was occurring.
But 70's teenagers became academics and journalists, and inevitably a small historical literature of the decade has begun to accumulate. It turns out that the 70's gave birth to the America in which we now live.
Anyone attempting a historical explanation is confronted with this paradox: the 1970's carried the revolutions and experiments of the 60's to their reductio ad absurdum, from the Symbionese Liberation Army and EST to the Ramones and Jonestown -- and somehow it all culminated in 1980 with the election of the most conservative president in over half a century. Did Ronald Reagan represent a reaction against the decade, or its fulfillment?
In "The Seventies: The Great Shift in American Culture, Society, and Politics," Bruce J. Schulman essentially answers: both. The "great shift" is away from the public-spirited universalism that gave America the New Deal and the civil rights movement, and toward the sovereignty of the free market and private life. In other words, the 1980's began in the 1970's.
A similar argument appeared last year in "How We Got Here," by the journalist and current Bush speechwriter David Frum. But as a conservative Frum placed the emphasis on the decline of traditional moral values. What Schulman shows is how that decline went hand in hand with the freewheeling private enterprise that has remade American life in the past two decades. In this sense the change transcends the division between left and right: "This implosion of American public life and attempt to reconstruct the nation as a congeries of separate private refuges revealed itself across the traditional political spectrum and among all demographic groups." It was as much geographical as philosophical -- a movement of the nation's center of gravity away from the older consensus of the northeastern establishment, southward and westward to the Sun Belt, that freedom-seeking sprawl of subdivisions from Fort Lauderdale to Anaheim.
When Schulman, a historian at Boston University whose first book was "From Cotton Belt to Sunbelt," speaks of the "southernization" of American life, he isn't talking about Jim Crow and the blues. He means their milder reincarnations in the antiwelfare, Lynyrd Skynyrd-listening South that sloughed off its regional shame around the time Richard Nixon became president. Southernization was an attitude that spread north -- suspicion of government, antielitism, racial resentment, a highly personal religiosity.
If any one person can be said to have invented the 70's, it was Kevin Phillips. His 1969 book "The Emerging Republican Majority," which came out of his work on the Nixon campaign and explained how to effect a realignment of the parties, coined the term "Sun Belt" and described a new kind of American who would replace the core Democratic voters, the older northern urban ethnics: "The persons most drawn to the new sun culture are the pleasure-seekers, the bored, the ambitious, the space-age technicians and the retired -- a super-slice of the rootless, socially mobile group known as the American middle class." 
This thinking was more visionary than Nixon's appeal to "the silent majority" that had brought him to power in 1968. Those middle Americans were defined by opposition to student protesters and black militants, but they represented an older set of values: patriotism and duty and self-restraint. The new Americans of the Sun Belt, Schulman explains, would make their peace with all the things that had scandalized the heartland in the 60's. The counterculture would become the mainstream. But this didn't mean the triumph of utopian idealism, the "beloved community" of civil rights workers and antiwar demonstrators. By the end of the 70's, the self-liberations that had originated in the 60's were merely "lifestyle choices," and they easily fused with the Sun Belt spirit of individualism.
The cultural part of the 60's revolution turned out to be continuous with the economic part of the Reagan revolution. What joins them is the apotheosis of the free individual. The very things that began with liberal universalist dreams of common humanity ended up in fragmentation and skepticism. Watergate, for example: at the time it appeared to be a great triumph for the antiestablishment left, a boon to reform Democrats in Congress, proof that the institutions of government worked. But it's now clear, as Schulman argues, that the "the ultimate lesson of Watergate remained 'you can't trust the government,' " and that it therefore "gave a boost to conservatism and conservative Republican politicians." Similarly, the tax revolt, which most Americans would date to 1978 with California's Proposition 13, turns out to have begun in the early 70's with an anticorporate, populist campaign for equity, not mindless cutting. And the brotherhood dreams of the early civil rights movement crumbled into "diversity." 
The decade's odd figure out was Jimmy Carter. Victim of inflation and a crisis of confidence he himself diagnosed, he proposed a cure -- equal parts Baptist moralism and engineering expertise -- that was hopelessly out of sync with the times. Calling the energy crisis "the moral equivalent of war" was exactly the wrong appeal to make to an age far more inclined toward private self-fulfillment than collective self-sacrifice. Schulman's account of the Carter years is particularly illuminating in a book of shrewd historical analysis and clear anecdotal prose. 
When he turns to popular culture, his historian's judgment is less sure. To claim that Jackie Kennedy's decision to marry Aristotle Onassis "signaled the end of the optimistic, liberal 1960's" or that " 'The Jeffersons' marked the crest of the civil rights movement, the summit of its material achievements and the beginning of the end of the integrationist ideal" is a kind of reductio ad absurdum itself. Sometimes trash is just trash. And in yoking together so many characters and events and trends, from the New Age to the New Right, under the single heading "privatism" leads Schulman into a kind of zeitgeist determinism, blurring important distinctions and forcing unlikely connections, with feminists labeled as entrepreneurs and Francis Ford Coppola shoehorned in with Evel Knievel as 70's rebels.
But his central argument is utterly persuasive. On or about November 1968, American character changed. In the case of most Americans of Schulman's generation, much has been given and little asked, and it's easy to think that nothing short of "the moral equivalent of war" will snap us out of our separate commercial trances.

HEADLINE: New Milford Shows Off for the Cameras 

BYLINE:  By DAVID PARKER 

 BODY:
FOR nearly two weeks, downtown New Milford has seen life turned upside down by a heavily equipped 100-member occupying force.
 Most residents, despite the disruption, seemed to get a kick out of this development, as Columbia Pictures had converted downtown Bank Street into a Hollywood back lot for the filming of "Deeds," a feature starring Adam Sandler, Winona Ryder and Peter Gallagher, who all came to town. 
 Spectators from throughout the region gathered for a glimpse of the action as shooting began May 30. More than 300 locals, culled from several thousand who had answered a casting call, were waiting for their turn on camera as extras, or "background," in a crowd scene to be shot at the old Candlewood Farms airport. Downtown merchants sold the filmmakers everything from coffee and bagels to lumber. 
"It's very positive for the town," Mayor Arthur Peitler said.
It's not just the hundreds of thousands of dollars the production and its crew spend locally, he said, or the "ripple" effect of that spending in the local economy. The mayor spoke of "Deeds" giving the town a "good self image."
"They were saying what a nice place it must be to live and how accommodating the people here are," he said of the movie's crew, noting that one of the Columbia people asked him, 'How do you get all your drivers to stop and let people cross the street?' "
Bank Street was closed to traffic on the first day of filming. Camera booms, klieg lights, reflectors, sound equipment and other gear trucked in from New York were in place. Production assistants kept moving the crowd back beyond various sight lines as camera angles and street locales changed, telling them to keep quiet while the cameras rolled.
Even while being pushed about and hushed, people seemed to love it all. 
The film's crew and cast had already made their presence felt at the Bank Street Coffee House. "A lot of folks with headsets have been in here buying stuff," A.J. Farrell, who was working the counter, said. "The crew are great. They tell you all sorts of stuff about California and what it's like working with different stars."
Columbia had given Bank Street a major makeover. Trees in planters lined the formerly treeless street, stores were renamed for the duration, though all but one remained open for business. Slone Pharmacy bore a feed and grain store sign and had hay bales along its sidewalk. The weekly New Milford Times had become The Mandrake Falls Gazette. An instant park, with Civil War monument, materialized in a parking lot next to the Bistro. That restaurant was now Deeds Pizza, its interior made over as a pizzeria.
"Deeds" is a remake of the 1936 classic "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," directed by Frank Capra and starring Gary Cooper and Jean Arthur. In this new version, Longfellow Deeds, a pizzeria owner and poet in Mandrake Falls, N. H., unexpectedly inherits $40 billion from the founder of a New York media conglomerate. Ms. Ryder plays the television tabloid reporter sent out to get his "real" story. Steven Brill is the director. The movie is scheduled for release sometime next year.
"Deeds" is the biggest film project to come to Connecticut since the 1997 production of "Amistad," according to Guy Ortoleva, director of the Connecticut Film Commission. It's the biggest yet in New Milford, but far from the first, according to Frank Weller, chairman of the New Milford Film Commission.
During the commission's first three years, he said, 12 projects have worked here, including small, low-budget independent films, commercials, the History Channel and most recently an MTV "reality" series that filmed at a local quarry. 
Japanese filmmakers liked the locale photos the commission gave them, "so flew all the way here and decided to film some episodes for a feature they were making," Mr. Weller said. "They did a car chase on one of our scenic roads and we loaned them a bank to rob."
The all-volunteer commission, backed by the town with a $12,500 budget, maintains a Web site of potential filming locales plus rosters of local talent and services. It networks, attends workshops and conventions and, "once a project decides to shoot here, we do everything we can to make things go smoothly for them," Mr. Weller said.
One of the region's lures for filmmakers, along with proximity to New York, is the large pool of actors, technicians, sound and camera people who live here, Mr. Weller said. Their availability helps keep costs below what they'd be if Columbia had to bring in everyone it needed from California or New York, he explained.
Harvey Hubbell, a community liaison for the movie industry and working for Columbia on "Deeds," is an example. Mr. Hubbell, who lives in Litchfield, said he often had to travel many hours to work on a production. "It's great for me to have a job on a project of this caliber 20 minutes from my house," he said. "I hear the New York guys complaining about their two-hour commute. Usually that's me."
Todd Corrigan of New Milford said he was happy for this hometown opportunity. Mr. Corrigan had been working as a volunteer production assistant, helping with crowd control and whatever else is required. A student in film courses at Emerson College, he said it was not a glamorous job, "but you get to talk to the right people and learn the kind of things you want to know."
At a local teen center serving as a "holding area" for extras during early shooting days, Screen Actors Guild members waited for their call to the set. Denis Lybe of Brookfield, dressed as a Mandrake Falls policeman, said that while he now earns his living as a courier, his passion as a 30-year union member remains work on a film set. The chance for two or three days' action on a major film so near home was wonderful, he said.
John Campbell, a college student from Trumbull, was ready for a brief appearance as a child on a bicycle pedaling down Bank Street.
Most New Milford residents "think it's fun and exciting to see a Hollywood movie being filmed here," said Art Cummings, editor of the weekly Greater New Milford Spectrum and a lifetime resident. "It's really festive out there today, and there's probably some long-term image building involved." 
But Mr. Cumming cautioned that some merchants and residents were growing unhappy about disruption of business and traffic and the crunch on parking space, especially as publicity drew more and more people downtown. The filming is scheduled to stop this week.
"On balance, it's a good experience for the town," he concluded. "But I don't know that you'd want to try doing it every week."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Government By Wish List

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHEN President Bush signed into law the tax cut he had championed since the start of the race for the White House a year and a half ago, it marked a political victory of the first order.
 But the significance of the formal signing ceremony in the East Room of the White House last Thursday extends well beyond scorekeeping or the details of the rate reductions. This bill is also a blueprint for governing -- one that, by giving taxpayers first dibs on a big chunk of the projected federal budget surplus, leaves all other claimants to fight over the what money remains. 
 "Taxes are what we pay for a civilized society," Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. once said. And tax policy, historically, has been a reliable guide to what Congress and the president think a civilized society should look like. At its best, that vision represents a balancing of the books between the nation's hopes and its means. In this case, though, support for the tax cut may represent less a consensus that the size and role of government should shrink than a gamble that the country can have it both ways. 
This bill became law largely because politicians -- at a time when power is almost perfectly split between Democrats and Republicans -- could credibly argue that there would be enough money for tax cuts and for a long list of popular and expensive government-expanding initiatives.
Nearly all Republicans and many Democrats were eager to offer the voter tax cuts, and to do the faltering economy a favor in the process. But with the anticipated surplus so large, they could simultaneously promise increased federal spending on education, the creation of a prescription drug benefit for the elderly, more subsidies for farmers and military modernization.
This was the politics of prosperity at work -- even though prosperity, or at least the supercharged version of it that the nation was accustomed to, has taken a holiday. At a time when the economy appears to be generating more revenue than the government knows what to do with, fiscal policy, and by extension ideological clashes over the size and role of government, need not lead to either-or propositions. It can be win-win: tax cuts and a bigger, activist government.
Unless, of course, the anticipated surplus turns out to be illusory. In that case, the nation may have just committed itself to a decade-long course of tax cutting without a serious debate over the consequences. If this proves true, Washington may one day look back and ask why it accepted rosy budgetary projections and did not confront its responsibility to debate and set priorities.
Any such regret would be most profound among liberals, many of whom feel that Mr. Bush fooled moderates in both parties by deliberately playing down the bite that the tax cut would take out of government.
"There was a conscious effort to deal with priorities sequentially rather than together," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office and a critic of Mr. Bush's tax plan. "Had there been a full discussion of the amount that the administration would like to spend on defense, and would like to devote to education over the next decade, and a more realistic estimate of the costs of providing prescription drug coverage for the elderly, then inevitably the tax bill would have been much smaller."
The result, Mr. Reischauer said, was "a procedural triumph for those who would like government to be small."
Indeed, there was no hand-wringing about missed opportunities at the White House. To conservatives who want to check the growth of the government, and who see the solutions to social problems coming from an unfettered economy and private charities, pitting school spending against prescription drug benefits or military procurement would be a welcome development.
"This bill is more than just tax relief," Mr. Bush told a cheering crowd in Florida a few days before signing the legislation. "It is more than just preventing Washington from growing the size of government. This bill reflects a philosophy that says we trust the American people more than we trust government." 
Anyway, there is enough money for prudent investments in the future even after the tax cut, the White House says. And the administration points out that there is no firm evidence that the budget surplus is being diminished by the softer economy.
SUCH optimism, however, is not fully shared at the Pentagon, where officials are suddenly confronting the likelihood that the government may not be able to afford to upgrade the military the way Mr. Bush promised -- even if the surplus is as large as projected. And the difficult budget arithmetic will apply to nearly every function of government starting this summer, when Congress begins voting on spending bills for next year.
This means that, despite Thursday's bill signing, the fight over taxes is far from settled. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who last week became majority leader as Democrats took control of the Senate, has already promised to revisit aspects of the Bush tax plan. Conservative Republicans, meanwhile, have made clear they want more tax cuts. 
This is not a matter only of fiscal policy; taxes are the pivot on which a number of ideological debates turn, from the relationship between rich and poor, to the relative responsibilities of individuals and government. Bill Archer, the former Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said in an op-ed piece in The Wall Street Journal last month that only about 65 percent of working-age Americans have any federal income tax liability, creating the potential for class warfare between those who want government services and those who pay for them. (Because of credits and deductions, most low-income working families pay little or nothing in federal income taxes, although they pay payroll taxes.)
FISCAL conservatives in both parties think this tax cut will have the same effect as the last big one, signed into law by President Ronald Reagan nearly 20 years ago. It will ultimately weaken the country's fiscal health, they say.
"It's playing Russian roulette with the economy," said Warren Rudman, the former Republican senator from New Hampshire. 
Looking ahead two decades, the nation faces paying Social Security and Medicare benefits to a rapidly aging population, a challenge that would be difficult even if the current surplus projections prove to be correct, and perhaps overwhelming if the surplus evaporates.
"The American people may learn that even during good times, it might be prudent to broaden the horizon of public policy to incorporate down sides that at the time don't seem realistic," said Kim Wallace, a political analyst in Washington for Lehman Brothers, the investment firm. "That's a not very profound way of saying that even though Washington never finds a way to save for a rainy day, it rains often."
Maybe this time the rain won't come. Maybe the economy will rebound quickly and the budget surplus will continue to grow. Or maybe the surplus will turn out to be a mirage, and future Congresses and presidents will be forced to confront the tradeoffs that this Congress and president sidestepped.

HEADLINE: Obstacles to China's W.T.O. Entry Eased in Talks With U.S. 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, June 9 

 BODY:
American and Chinese trade negotiators said today that they had resolved most of the remaining issues that have held up China's entry to the World Trade Organization, including the degree to which China can subsidize its farmers as a member of the trade group. 
 The agreement has revived hopes that China can join the global trade club within months and take part in rule-setting negotiations by the group's members that could start late this year. 
 "This is a breakthrough agreement with benefits for American farmers, American exporters and U.S. companies doing business with China," said the United States trade representative, Robert Zoellick, in a telephone interview from Washington after arriving there from negotiations in Shanghai. "It moves China toward W.T.O. membership this year and further along the path of economic reform and the rule of law." 
China's state media quoted Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng as saying the two sides had "reached full consensus" on the outstanding issues at meetings that followed a conference of regional trade ministers here. The final agreement came during talks between Mr. Zoellick and Mr. Shi that began late Friday night and lasted until 3 a.m. today. Mr. Shi then took the agreement to China's president, Jiang Zemin, who was visiting Suzhou, near Shanghai. 
China has been working for more than a decade to join the organization, which regulates trade among its members. It has signed bilateral agreements with all key members, except Mexico, which expects to conclude negotiations soon and promised not to block China's entry. 
But efforts to draft a document stating the terms of China's membership foundered early this year on differences between the United States and China over the degree to which China will be allowed to use subsidies to support its farmers. 
China is already facing an economic crisis in the countryside, where its vast rural population is being squeezed between rising costs and falling prices for crops. It wants to retain as much flexibility as possible in subsidizing that population, an important mechanism in keeping rural unrest in check.
The United States, meanwhile, worries that subsidized farm produce from China could undercut American farmers, who are already under pressure from imports. 
As part of an overall agreement on the use agricultural subsidies, China had wanted the freedom to offer its farmers subsidies worth up to 10 percent of the value of their output, the level set by the trade organization for developing economies. The United States wanted to limit that to a maximum of 5 percent, the same restriction it operates under as a developed economy. 
Neither the United States nor China released details of the agreement today, but senior American officials said the final agreement gives China some of the flexibility it wanted on some farm products while setting tighter limits on the subsidies on others. 
With the issue settled, efforts to draft the necessary comprehensive document are expected to make swift progress at the 16th session of the trade organization's working group on China's membership, which will begin June 28 in Geneva.
The United States and other members are pushing for the organization to begin a new round of negotiations to set rules for the group later this year. They would like those talks to begin when the group meets in November in Doha, the capital of the Persian Gulf state of Qatar.

HEADLINE: Mildly Ambitious 

BYLINE:  By James Traub; James Traub is a contributing writer for The Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Senator Joseph Lieberman has always been a Republican's idea of a model Democrat. When Al Gore selected Lieberman as his running mate last summer, George Bush's spokesman remarked that Gore "has chosen a man whose positions are more similar to Governor Bush's positions than to his own." That was campaign hyperbole, but Lieberman had long occupied the conservative wing of his party on issues like defense spending, tax cuts, school vouchers and, notoriously, the entertainment industry. When Bush won and set about trying to define a new ideological center, Lieberman was one of the Democratic senators expected to join him there, at least on a number of key policy items.
 But he hasn't. Unlike such Senate Democratic centrists as John Breaux and Zell Miller, the 59-year-old junior senator from Connecticut voted against Bush's tax cut and against his budget. And he has, in his gentle and soft-nosed way, criticized the administration for extremism. 
 The decision of Senator James Jeffords of Vermont to leave the G.O.P. has provided extra-partisan authority for that critique. Lieberman says: "I was struck that in his statement Jeffords said, 'I'm not a Republican by birth; I'm a Republican because the party shared my values -- moderation, tolerance, fiscal responsibility.' The fact that he concluded that he could no longer stay in the party was a stinging indictment of the way the Bush administration has conducted itself." Since Lieberman's politics are probably more like Jeffords's than they are like either Bush's or Gore's, he understood the Jeffords defection as a ratification of his own position.
There is a battle under way now in Washington over ownership of words like "moderation" and "responsibility." It seemed at first that Bush was winning that battle, since most of the self-defined centrists in the Democratic Party voted for the fiscal package that was his foremost priority. But the Jeffords switch has tilted the balance in the opposite direction, toward ever-so-slightly-left-of-center figures like Lieberman (who were right-of-center figures until the spectrum shifted rightward). And Lieberman, like other senior Democrats, now has the opportunity to actually do something about his views. With the Democrats holding the majority, he has just become chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee. Lieberman says that he plans to use his power to investigate the Bush administration's response to the energy crisis in California, as well as its decision to reverse several of the Clinton administration's major regulatory initiatives -- in a constructive, nonpartisan manner, of course, but with recourse to his subpoena power as needed.
What is at stake in this game is, most obviously, control of the agenda, or rather the ability to deflect or frustrate the Bush administration's agenda. But among themselves, the Democrats are playing a fresh round of "Who's Presidential?" Having emerged from the 2000 campaign with his reputation enhanced rather than diminished (the same cannot be said of Al Gore), Lieberman is a figure to reckon with inside the Democratic Party. He makes all the lists of potential presidential candidates and stands at the top of some of them. Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster, says: "Other than Gore, Lieberman is the best known and the best liked of Democratic figures in the country. If you look at the realistic group of candidates, he's clearly the most popular." The speculation has advanced so far that Lieberman has stopped pretending that he isn't considering a run. 
I caught up with Lieberman recently at a child-care center near Hartford, where he had gone to announce a new piece of legislation. Lieberman is comfortable with little kids. His manner is Beloved Grandpa: squatting down on his haunches, he smiled and bantered and patted heads and talked softly and very slowly, as if he weren't quite sure that English was their first language.
Lieberman has that primal quality of almost all successful politicians -- he likes being around other people -- but he is at the far end of the spectrum from the proconsular, declamatory figures (think Fritz Hollings or John Kerry) who constitute the received image of the United States senator. Lieberman is a short man with the soft mouth and loosening jowls of a friendly basset hound. He has what must be one of the least compelling voices in the Senate, a whiny, crumbly textured, old-Jewish-man voice. He is, on the other hand, about as devoid of artifice and grandiosity as anybody you will meet on Capitol Hill. When he read to the kids, he was as gentle as Mr. Rogers.
After the event, we got into Lieberman's car. It was a few days after Passover, and the car had been victualed with a stack of matzos, an apple and a carton of kosher apple juice, which Lieberman now opened. I asked Lieberman about his vote against the budget resolution authorizing an initial $1.2 trillion tax cut -- the resolution that was later incorporated into the president's fiscal package. The measure had passed with the votes of 15 Democrats, including virtually all of the centrists and two potential presidential candidates (Evan Bayh and John Edwards). 
Lieberman pointed out that Bush had first proposed the tax cut during the campaign as a means to blunt Steve Forbes's yet more radical proposal for a flat tax. And though he did not, he said, want to question the president's motives, "here we are almost a year and a half later and this is the centerpiece of his economic and fiscal proposal to the Congress and the country. It learns nothing from the lessons of the immediate past. The most important thing we've got to do is to be fiscally responsible, to keep the government in balance, and a surplus if possible. The other part is, you invest in the seeds of the new economy -- education, basic research and development, job training. The Bush tax plan does the exact opposite."
This is, in a nutshell, the centrist, New Democrat position that Clinton championed -- anti-Keynesian, steeped in old-time Republican maxims about prudence, dedicated to achieving fairness through growth rather than redistribution. Lieberman would have happily voted for a $900 billion tax cut tilted toward the middle class rather than the rich and, unlike many Democrats, would have supported cuts in the capital gains tax as well as other taxes affecting investment. With Clinton gone, Lieberman is perhaps the most unabashed spokesman for this new, middle-class-oriented tax and fiscal policy. "One of the great thrills of the campaign," Lieberman says, "was to be speaking in front of a Democratic audience, a rally, and give a pitch for fiscal austerity and deficit reduction, and there would be enormous applause." This was probably not a rally taking place in, say, Detroit.
It was by no means obvious to Lieberman's colleagues that he would come down against the tax cut, and Republicans and even some Democrats are inclined to see it as an act of strategic repositioning. John Breaux of Louisiana, who has taken over the role of intraparty bridge that Lieberman himself might have filled, says with what is apparently meant to be sympathy, "Lieberman has a very difficult job now, being a strong potential presidential candidate and having to recognize that in order to get the nomination of the Democratic Party you have to run left of center." 
Lieberman does seem to be closing whatever space separates him from his party's leadership, sponsoring, for example, a Democratic education bill that does not include financing for school voucher programs. On the other hand, he seems persuaded that the Bush tax cut is reckless, and he argues that Democrats who voted for it are making a historic mistake on the order of those who voted for Reagan's tax cuts in 1981. Of course, it is fair to ask why a $900 billion tax cut is moderate and responsible and a $1.35 trillion tax cut reckless. Lieberman appears to be standing up for the economic principles of the first Bush administration against those of the second. But Lieberman, who has fine instincts in such matters, may have recognized that that is where the middle now lies. 
Joe Lieberman is moderate not only by conviction but by temperament. Life has treated him well, and he has returned the favor by being sunny as well as grateful. His father owned a liquor store, and Lieberman was reared middle class in an ethnically mixed neighborhood of Stamford. "There was a word you don't hear much any more," Lieberman said to me during a conversation in his office in Washington. "There were a lot of interfaith activities. Most of my friends were not Jewish. I didn't experience anti-Semitism at all. When I look back at my childhood, I feel like I was in 'Happy Days,' with the Fonz." Lieberman doesn't seem to have any anger in him at all, and so even at his most morally serious, he never seems particularly censorious. He is a creature of the New Testament rather than the Old, less Isaiah than the Rev. Billy Graham.
In late April, Lieberman, along with Senators Herb Kohl and Hillary Clinton, called a news conference to introduce the Media Marketing Accountability Act, a bill that would treat the practice of marketing violent or sexual material to children as a form of false and deceptive advertising. This is the issue that first gained Lieberman public attention; he was that rare Democratic politician able and eager to speak the language of personal values otherwise monopolized by Republicans. At the news conference, Lieberman repeated his usual criticisms of "obscenity-laced lyrics." Then, in answer to a question, he said that he had just returned from Los Angeles, where he had spoken to several Hollywood trade groups. "These folks are citizens and parents," he said, as if admonishing those of us in the media against undue severity. 
There is both a conservative and a liberal case that Lieberman is, at bottom, a pious hypocrite. The conservative case, which William Bennett, among others, loudly made last summer, is that he backs off when his principles get him in trouble with his party. In order to mollify the Gore people, he backed off on the critique of Hollywood, school vouchers and the partial privatization of Social Security. (Lieberman says that he continued to goad the entertainment industry, that he openly admitted that he and Gore differed on vouchers and that he had ultimately come down against privatization.) The liberal case is that Lieberman is a self-aggrandizing pol willing to attack his own party to burnish his moral standing. One senator says that he was disgusted by Lieberman's decision to denounce Clinton's affair with Monica Lewinsky as "immoral" in the well of the Senate. "I may feel strongly about the shortcomings of my neighbors," he says, "but I don't take to the pulpit to announce it."
Lieberman's problem, if it is a problem, is that he is a stern moralist with a gooey center. He believes devoutly in the politics of value now being propounded by groups like the Democratic Leadership Council, which he led from 1995 until last year; in his most recent book, "In Praise of Public Life," he inveighs against the "moral timidity" that prevents the secular-minded from criticizing destructive behavior. And thus, he says, he felt compelled to speak out against Clinton. But he is also the Fonz. He is inclined to think well of everyone and to think that everyone's better nature is their true one; he even told me that the reflective Tim Russert who appears on CNBC, rather than the pugilistic one on NBC, is the "real" one. 
Lieberman likes to mix it up politically, but he doesn't really have the stomach for combat. When, in 1995, he offered some rather equivocal praise for Proposition 209, the resolution banning affirmative action in California, the civil rights establishment came down on him like a ton of bricks, and Lieberman reeled in horror. "It was just about the first time in my public life that I was not on the civil rights side," he says. "Jesse Jackson spoke out against me." Lieberman quickly came to the conclusion that Clinton's "mend it, don't end it" policy met his concerns, though the policy had the effect of keeping the entire apparatus of affirmative action intact.
Lieberman's political prospects, his capacity for leadership, are bracketed by his Humphrey-esque enthusiasm on the one side and his distaste for combat on the other. Lieberman says that the one thing he didn't like about the presidential campaign was "the against part" in which he was instructed to lambaste the rich and the powerful. Lieberman, like his fellow New Democrats, doesn't have a problem with the rich and the powerful, and he plainly didn't like pretending otherwise. The script, he says, felt "too fixed, too 'inherent conflict,"' and he didn't deliver it very convincingly. 
Lieberman was a very happy warrior when he was working from a more congenial script, and he is widely credited with injecting life and even pleasure into a torpid campaign. Lieberman's supporters compare him to the ultimate athlete in the field, Bill Clinton ("in the good sense," they always add). But Lieberman lacks Clinton's inner drive, his passion, his genius for appearing fair-minded while he is sticking in the shiv. Lieberman really is fair-minded. There was that famously civil debate with Dick Cheney that Lieberman kicked off by saying that his mother had called him and said, "Sweetheart' -- as she is prone to call me -- remember, be positive and know that I will love you no matter what your opponent says about you."' This was classic warm-hearted Lieberman shtick, but it also amounted to unilateral disarmament. Lieberman seemed to be consciously offering a counterpoint to the growing bitterness of the presidential contest, which was not necessarily what the party needed. One former high-ranking Clinton aide, who professes the deepest personal admiration for Lieberman, says: "That was the night of Cheney's rehabilitation. Joe never said, 'How about those cop-killer bullets, Dick?' He should have taken the guy apart." (Lieberman says, and other campaign officials concur, that taking Cheney apart was not on the debate agenda.)
Lieberman and Al Gore made an odd couple -- perhaps anyone and Al Gore make an odd couple -- and with the campaign behind them they don't appear to be particularly close. The candidates and their wives had dinner a few months back; otherwise, Lieberman says, he and his former running mate "blackberry back and forth." But Lieberman says, rightly, that he would be just another senator if Gore had not plucked him from the ranks and that gratitude requires that he absolutely, positively, rule out a presidential bid if Gore decides to run. 
That, of course, is a great open question. Gore is already attending a series of non-fund-raising "thank you" events around the country, and he plans to establish a political action committee this summer. But many Democrats dread the prospect of Gore II and have encouraged the candidacy of virtually any Democratic senator with an idle presidential fantasy -- none of whom share Lieberman's sense of constraint. The current roster of wannabes and mightbes includes Senators John Kerry, John Edwards, Evan Bayh, Dick Gephardt, Joe Biden and Tom Daschle. One prominent Democratic fund-raiser and strategist puts Gore by himself in the first tier, Lieberman, Edwards, Gephardt and Daschle in the second, Bayh in the third and everyone else in the fourth. Others put Daschle in the second tier by himself, and still others take Kerry more seriously. The handicapping is all over the lot.
Lieberman's backers make the case that he is the one candidate who, like Bill Clinton, can hold on to the party's base and reach across to independents. He is a pro-business, pro-defense, pro-family-hour Democratic. For this very reason, Lieberman may have trouble with some of the party's interest groups. But his crossover appeal is unarguable, especially when it comes to matters of culture. As Al From, the founder and guiding spirit of the Democratic Leadership Council, says: "If you think about the liabilities the Democrats used to have running for president, it was always, 'Can't manage the economy' and 'Soft on crime.' Now one of the biggest vulnerabilities we have is that people who go to church regularly tend to vote Republican; married families with kids voted overwhelmingly for Bush. It's not the old economic issues; it's the new values issues. And that's Joe's strength."
Only a few skeptics believe that Lieberman's religion, or his religiosity, will count against him. Lieberman has a real gift, whether intuitive or conscious, for turning his supposed disadvantage to advantage. During the presidential campaign, he constantly repeated how very proud he was of the American people for taking an Orthodox Jew to their great Christian heart. This was, of course, transparent flattery, the idea being that the voter would be proud of him for being proud of them. Nowadays, he presents himself to audiences as a beneficiary of the great American tradition of tolerance for diversity, a man who stands on the shoulders of Martin Luther King Jr. and John F. Kennedy. I heard him tell a Jewish audience in Washington that his campaign "says to kids you don't have to hide who you are in order to be successful in America." It is sentiments like this that make even mildly ironic people wince.
Still, nobody ever got elected as the irony candidate. Lieberman is, in his own way, an all-American -- i.e., Christian -- character, earnest, hokey, friendly and sincere as all get-out. He is religiously Jewish and ethnically Fifties. If he has a drawback, it is probably not his religion; it is the Mr. Rogers thing. After all, nice guys don't always finish last, but they don't usually finish first either.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for GEORGE WARRINGTON; 
Amtrak, Pulled in Two Directions

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
AMTRAK is again in serious financial trouble, and last week, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta disclosed that the railroad was trying to mortgage part of Penn Station in New York to make ends meet until the next fiscal year begins in October. He suggested that the railroad consider giving up its national system and concentrate on the East and West Coasts, plus service from Chicago to Detroit, New Orleans and a few other cities. 
 George Warrington, Amtrak's president, was not thrilled to hear that from the secretary, whom President Bush is expected to appoint soon to Amtrak's board. Mr. Warrington has been pursuing an opposite strategy of adding service, while asserting for months that Amtrak should be free of federal operating subsidies by 2003. On Friday, he discussed some of his proposals. MATTHEW L. WALD 

Q. Why is Amtrak in bad financial shape?

A. For 30 years, Amtrak has suffered from mission conflict. From Day 1 it was undercapitalized, and it was directed and mandated by the Congress to run a national system. As Secretary John Anthony Volpe at that time indicated, it was expected to be profitable in a classic commercial sense in three years. Those expectations were always unrealistic. Overlayed on top of that in the late 1990's was an incompatible mandate from Congress of operating self-sufficiency. With those conflicting missions, all public policy makers have sidestepped the question of what they and America want from its intercity rail system.

Q. With the high cost of gasoline and the ordeals of air travel, this seems like a great opportunity for an expansion of train travel. Why hasn't this happened?

A. It's clearly happened in a number of corridors all across the country. We've had four consecutive years of record ridership and revenue growth.
There was a period of shrinkage in the mid-90's. One of the consequences of that was more revenue was lost than cost saved. We have worked very hard to transform both the service package, the image, the brand and the quality of train service, with very limited capital, with very little in the way of resources.

Q. Amtrak is preparing to mortgage Penn Station to raise the $300 million it says it needs to keep operating through the fiscal year. What are the risks of such a step?

A. There are no risks.
The structure of the transaction, which I can't discuss in detail, is very carefully designed to protect all interests, and those include all the users, the federal government, Amtrak and the investors.

Q. Will Amtrak have to go back to Congress and ask for more money?

A. No. We had a conscious choice we could have made a year ago: Would we behave like the old Amtrak and go back hat in hand and ask for a bailout to deal with unforeseen, or uncontrollable events, or would we behave in a much smarter and commercially successful way, and solve this problem ourselves? We made a conscious decision that Amtrak had a long history of expecting others to bail us out. Frankly, I made a decision that that's not the way we're doing business any more.

Q. What can be done to put Amtrak on the right financial track for good? And should it continue as a national railroad?

A. We spend about 1 percent of all federal transportation spending on intercity rail service. If you go to France or Germany, any of our global economic competitors, the share of domestic federal spending ranges between roughly 20 and 28 percent.
What we have urged is a 20-year plan that would raise that level of federal commitment from 1 percent, to 2.5 percent of all domestic federal spending on transportation infrastructure, to about $1.5 billion a year. Do we want to provide communities around America with essential rail service that links communities and provides choices, or some other sort of system, a handful of corridors, or some combination of both? Successive administrations and Congresses have basically sidestepped that question for many, many years. What I am urging is not only a discussion, but closure around what America wants and what policy makers want from an intercity system.

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH/BOB COSTAS; 
For the Prudent Son, All Risky Bets Are Off

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS 

 BODY:
THERE is no way that the television sportscaster Bob Costas, at 5 feet 7 and 49 years of age, could compete on a basketball court against Shaquille O'Neal, the star center of the Los Angeles Lakers. But Mr. Costas once went one-on-one against Shaq in an investment contest. And lost.
 Or did he? 
 In an E*Trade promotion in 1998, each celebrity picked a hypothetical portfolio of six stocks, aiming for the best performance in a typical time horizon for a day trader: six weeks. Mr. O'Neal, who bragged that he was a "digital type guy," posted an 18.7 percent gain by picking Cisco Systems, Microsoft, Dell Computer, EarthLink, Amazon.com and SportsLine USA (now SportsLine.com Inc.).
That dwarfed the 1.2 percent that Mr. Costas mustered from his choices: Quaker Oats, General Electric, Anheuser-Busch, Monsanto (now part of Pharmacia), the Tribune Company and Lucent Technologies. 
"I picked 'em the way an old lady picks horses at the racetrack: by personal connection and by whim," Mr. Costas said in a recent interview.
Yet considered in a real-life, longer-term investment horizon, Mr. Costas's picks are doing very well, thank you. His conservative choices would have shown a 34.2 percent gain by now, compared with a 12.8 percent gain for Mr. O'Neal's portfolio, according to Morningstar Inc.
Mr. Costas's approach to that contest says much about his attitude toward money -- a view heavily influenced in his childhood by a father who was an inveterate gambler. Mr. Costas, known for his preppy looks and astute interviewing skill, has avoided the speculative and flamboyant. He sought to minimize risk, invested for the long term and has been a disciplined saver -- strategies aimed at ensuring stability in his personal as well as his financial life.
As he built a national reputation in an industry where celebrity is mostly local, Mr. Costas amassed a fortune estimated at $15 million to $20 million -- neither he nor his advisers would discuss specific amounts -- more than enough to live a life of luxury anywhere in the world. Yet he lives with his wife and two children in a home built for the family in 1989 on an acre in Town & Country, Mo., an affluent suburb of St. Louis. That home, his sole residence, is probably worth about $2 million today.
Mr. Costas says he would not know what to do with a second home or with many of the other customary trappings of celebrity. Indeed, several years ago, he sold a vacation house in St. Petersburg, Fla., because the family used it so rarely.
Each year, he plows about 25 percent of his pretax income into investments. It is not that he is hoarding money toward an early retirement. He just wants to be assured of having the flexibility to make choices that are not dictated by money now, as well as of a comfortable lifestyle in the future.
That is where his father, John, who died in 1970, comes in.
One day last month, Mr. Costas recalled how, when he was 8, his father moved the family -- Bob, his younger sister, Valerie, and mother, Jayne -- from Long Island to Redondo Beach, Calif. To this day, Mr. Costas does not know whether they moved because his father got a new job as an electrical engineer or because he was fleeing angry bookies and gambling debts stemming from his obsession with betting on sporting events.
"There were times when we drove with my father to a doughnut shop in Brooklyn," Mr. Costas said during an interview in his unpretentious three-room suite in an office park here. "There, a guy named Al, trying to be casual, would slip a paper bag across the counter with $14,000 in it."
There were losses, too. Once, when Mr. Costas was about 11, he accompanied his father to a parking lot, where the elder Mr. Costas handed a man $5,000.
"I thought it was very weird," Mr. Costas recalled. "The guy was making small talk."
Mr. Costas recounted a boyhood that was punctuated by frequent moves and that lurched with the highs and lows of his father's wins and losses. He spoke with the blend of insight and professional distance that have made him one of the most successful and self-assured interviewers in professional sports -- a world filled with huge egos and hair-trigger tempers. It often seemed as if he had prepared as much for this interview as he does for his coverage of the Olympics, and yet his talk lacked the flashes of quick wit that characterize his on-screen persona -- perhaps because the topic made him slightly uncomfortable.
The financial swings in his childhood were clearly a source of tension. "My mother wasn't thrilled when you have to dip in to the family account to pay off some guys who don't like to be paid in installments," he said. "We always had food on the table and a roof over our heads, but there may have been some times when the bank account was spread thin, when we had to draw out a few grand out to pay off some guy named Lefty Luke."
Still, Mr. Costas and his father bonded over sports, and the family shared good times. "Growing up had anxiety and it was unsettling, but it was entertaining and colorful, and had a certain romance to it," Mr. Costas said. He expressed compassion for his father's obsession: "Gamblers say they are doing it for their family. They believe the family will be able to move to a better house. They will have additional security."
But his father never hit the jackpot, and he had been living so close to the edge that there wasn't much money left when he died of a heart attack at 42, when Bob was 18. He had to get several scholarships so that he could attend Syracuse University.
During summers, he worked at odd jobs; then, in his senior year, he snared one calling minor league hockey games on a radio station. That took some moxie: Lacking experience with hockey games, he sent off some tapes of himself calling basketball games, with the excuse that " 'I don't have any of my hockey tapes on hand at the moment,' " he said.
AS an investor, Mr. Costas is as patient and concerned with steady accumulation of investments as his father had been hooked on quick winnings. His strategy has centered on equities, broadly diversified to minimize cyclical market and economic risk. 
According to several people close to him, Mr. Costas now earns about $3 million a year, making him one of the highest-paid sportscasters in the nation. His income comes from his contract at NBC, where he is host for Olympics coverage and where he has recently worked on the Triple Crown and the N.B.A. playoffs, and from his 12-week HBO series, "On the Record With Bob Costas," first broadcast in February and scheduled to run next year as well.
Since 1985, his finances have been managed by Katherine Lintz. Ms. Lintz, who had worked with sports agents as a financial planner for their clients, founded Financial Management Partners, a St. Louis firm that specializes in advising athletes and other sports personalities.
Almost all of Mr. Costas's long-term investments are in plain-vanilla, liquid assets. Roughly 25 percent stays in blue-chip stocks like Cisco, Berkshire Hathaway, AOL Time Warner, Merck, Microsoft, Disney, Wells Fargo and Intel, Ms. Lintz said. His largest positions are in Johnson & Johnson, General Electric and Qualcomm.
For exposure to other industries, an additional 20 percent or so is in mutual funds like ICAP Equity Portfolio, a large-cap value fund run by Institutional Capital, of Chicago. The diversification program also includes putting 10 percent of Mr. Costas's capital in Oakmark Select, primarily a midcap value fund; 10 percent in international funds like ICAP Euro Select Equity Portfolio; 11 percent into technology funds and private equity and venture capital investments, 20 percent into municipal bonds and 4 percent in cash.
In 1998, his investments rose by a weighted average of about 18 percent, Ms. Lintz said. A year later, the gain was 34 percent. But last year, on a weighted basis, the portfolio lost 7 percent, as Ms. Lintz suffered what she called her first down year in 11 years of investment management. Still, that was better than the 10.1 percent decline of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. So far this year, the portfolio is down 1.6 percent, while the S.& P. has lost more than 3 percent.
Mr. Costas said he was definitely staying with Ms. Lintz. "Over all, she's done a very good job," he said, "and I feel comfortable with her."
The sportscaster's relatively modest style of living, meanwhile, gives him a freedom he highly values: to work only on assignments he wants.
Doing something he loves has always been crucial to Mr. Costas, and early on, he knew that meant doing something involving sports.
As a child, he would sit in his father's car in the driveway, twisting the radio dial to catch a game. At night, he would often crawl under the covers and sneak a listen to whatever baseball games his transistor radio could pick up. Baseball, with its rich history, has always been his favorite sport.
Determined to become a sportscaster, Mr. Costas began his career in 1974 with stints at the student TV and radio stations at Syracuse, which is known for turning out top sportscasters like Marv Albert. Mr. Costas quit college one semester short of a degree to do basketball play-by-play for KMOX radio in St. Louis. ("I don't have a sheepskin," he acknowledged a bit ruefully.)
Barry Frank, then head of CBS Sports, recalled hearing Mr. Costas in 1976. "He was the eighth man in a seven-man rotation of sportscasters." Two years later, after Mr. Frank had moved to IMG, the sports management firm, he called Mr. Costas. "I think you are going to go places," Mr. Frank said he told him. "You ought to have an agent." The men have worked together ever since.
Mr. Frank negotiated a contract with NBC for Mr. Costas to do play by play for different sports. "The rest is history," said Mr. Frank, whose clients also include the sports commentators Jim Nantz and Greg Gumbel.
INDEED, Mr. Costas has a 66 percent recognition rating among American adults, compared with 32 percent for the average national sportscaster. In addition, 16 percent of those familiar with Mr. Costas rate him as one of their favorite personalities -- compared to the 11 percent on this "Q" score for the average national sportscaster, according to Marketing Evaluations/ TVQ Inc., a Manhassett, N.Y., concern that tracks the popularity of TV personalities and performers.
Though neither Mr. Frank nor Mr. Costas would be specific about earnings, several sports experts said that in Mr. Costas's early years at NBC, starting in 1980, he made about $300,000, rising to $500,000 in 1983. By 1987, Mr. Costas had passed the $1 million mark, and by 1993 reached an estimated $2 million. Today he is said to earn about $3 million.
Mr. Costas said it was not so much the size of his paycheck as the growing interest in his work by several networks that made him first feel financially secure. "It was when you began to feel that there will be another contract, because you always got to prove yourself worthy of another one," he said.
That happened around the mid-1980's. "Even if the people you work with value your services and believe in their own hearts they want to be fair, you need another bidder" when you get into negotiations, he said.
Mr. Frank said Mr. Costas paid very close attention, not so much to the money as to the terms of any deal he struck. "To him, the things he had to do -- the assignments -- were more important," Mr. Frank said.
Mr. Costas added: "I have never subscribed to the notion that he who dies with the most wins. If you have enough to, on the spur of the moment, do something that you would enjoy or people you care about would enjoy, then you would have enough.
"That does not mean I am offering my services for free," said Mr. Costas, whose agent is one of the toughest in the business. "It just means that money is not the thing that guides me."
When he was negotiating to write "Fair Ball," an analysis of and proposed solution for problems facing baseball, several publishers were rumored to be willing to pay him as much as $2 million for an autobiographical book with some of his sports experiences."But that was not the book I wanted to do," Mr. Costas said.
To do the one he wanted, Mr. Costas signed with Broadway Books, for a reported $400,000. "Fair Ball," published last year, quickly became a best seller, which most likely meant several hundred thousand more in royalties. Mr. Costas donated it all to the Baseball Assistance Team, which helps retired baseball professionals.
Mr. Costas says his heroes are "people who honor a contract and live it out." He points to Mark McGwire, the St. Louis Cardinals first baseman who hit 70 home runs in 1998, erasing Roger Maris's record of 61 set in 1961.
"He was making $11 million and now he is making $15 million," Mr. Costas said. "It is a crazy world where someone making $15 million is seen as self-sacrificing, but relatively speaking, he is. What you look for in a hero is not some vow of poverty, but some sense of perspective and proportion."
And generosity of spirit.
At the 1995 funeral of another of his heroes, Mickey Mantle, Mr. Costas spoke of the former Yankee's role in the American consciousness: "When he was hot, we felt great. When he slumped or got hurt, we sagged a bit too."
Yet in a conversation about Mantle with a reporter from The New York Times soon afterward, Mr. Costas said it was not only Mantle's baseball skills that touched him. He recalled seeing Mantle carrying a box of leftovers from a restaurant to a homeless man living in a box on Madison Avenue. "The guy appeared to be startled, and saw it was Mantle," Mr. Costas said. "His face softened, and it was clear he'd seen him before, and he said, 'Oh, hi, Mick.' "
Associates say Mr. Costas is also very generous. Aside from helping his mother and other family members, they say, he has endowed a scholarship fund at Syracuse for undergraduates with an interest in broadcast journalism. 
But Mr. Costas bristles when asked for details. He has a charitable foundation, the associates add, but it is not in his name, and he will not discuss it.
"No matter how innocently you talk about it, it can seem as if you are talking publicly," Mr. Costas said.
THOUGH Mr. Costas joined the big leagues long ago, he still lives here, in the home he built 12 years ago, because his wife's family is nearby. When taping his HBO program, he commutes to Manhattan, staying at a hotel.
The house is nicely appointed in casual country style, but it does not boast costly or formal antiques, and is clearly a home designed around a young family. Not that it could be mistaken for a starter home: It has more than 7,000 square feet and a swimming pool. Mr. Costas drives a BMW 750 while his wife, Randy, has a sport utility vehicle.
"I don't think twice about spending money" for things that he and his family enjoy, he said -- for example, a monthlong trip to Australia centered on the 2000 Summer Olympics.
His offices are relatively simple, with a staff of two -- an executive secretary and an executive assistant -- and unremarkable furnishings. The office's special character comes from the photographs that cover its walls, including one of Bobby Kennedy with Mickey Mantle and a 1927 team photo of the Yankees; the cases of baseball bats, one signed by Ted Williams and another by members of the 500 Home Run Club; and a collection of sports books that overflows from the bookcases to piles on the floor.
Still, for all his unpretentiousness, Mr. Costas is hardly oblivious to his public image. He objects when described as a preppy dresser, for example, arguing that his taste is simply conservative. And his friend Maury Povich, the talk-show host, with whom he shares a makeup person, said Mr. Costas was "very serious about his hair."
"We all try to hide our ego," Mr. Povich said, unable to resist the opportunity to kid his friend. "But in the makeup room, it all comes out."
Mr. Costas's choice of Ms. Lintz's firm as the family's investment manager also shows his seriousness.
Financial Management Partners makes its money by charging a relatively modest 0.5 percent annually of the value of a client's portfolio. It maximizes its fee income by insisting that clients commit to aggressive savings goals. Ms. Lintz said she presses her clients to invest 25 percent to 40 percent of their pretax income with the firm.
She has become tough, she explained, because so many athletes spend their money as soon as they get it, leaving themselves no chance for financial security.
"If a sportscaster makes $2 million, he or she should save $500,000, or 25 percent," Ms. Lintz said. "In addition, there are a lot of business expenses, including an agent fee of 10 percent and expenses in running an office. Take away taxes and charity, and a person with that income should have a target budget of about $200,000 or $300,000. You can't have lifestyles of the rich and famous and still be saving a bunch."
Of course, the pressure to save is greater with athletes than with sportscasters, whose careers tend to last a lot longer. But Mr. Costas still meets the firm's aggressive annual savings target, Ms. Lintz says.
HIS relative lack of interest in conspicuous consumption seems to be shared by his family. Mr. Costas met his wife, a former third-grade teacher, in 1980 when he came to speak at the Weber School, which has since closed, in St. Louis. After they married, in 1983, she stopped working.
She does have some interest in investing. "She belongs to a little investing club," is how Mr. Costas put it. "It is more of a social thing, but it only involves a few hundred dollars."
But when it comes to the family finances, Ms. Lintz said: "Randy is as involved as Bob, and she gets pleasure out of investing for their children. I talk to them both about broad issues. I will call Bob on the big accounts and Randy on the kid accounts. She is very conscious of educating the kids on the value of money."
Their son, Keith, who is 15, and daughter, Taylor, 11, both of whom attend private school, "get a modest allowance," Mr. Costas said.
"We don't make a big deal over the family's means," he added. "And to the extent that we talk about work and career, it is with the idea of work and career that they would find interesting, not the money involved."
Making decisions without worrying about money is, of course, a far cry from from his own childhood.
