HEADLINE: BOOKS ON HEALTH; 
Birth Control, From 'Womb Veils' to Lysol

BYLINE:  By Annette Fuentes 

 BODY:
"Devices and Desires: A History of Contraceptives in America," by Andrea Tone, Hill and Wang, $30.
 In 1992, Dr. Andrea Tone was finishing her dissertation at Emory University in Atlanta and volunteering at the Feminist Women's Health Center. While her academic labors focused on the history of industry, her work at the clinic provided an entirely different kind of food for thought, and eventually for research. 
 "It opened my eyes to the gap between the availability of contraceptive technology and the lack of knowledge about how to use birth control products," Dr. Tone said. "There are problems with medical access to good products." 
Nine years later, Dr. Tone, an associate professor of history at the Georgia Institute of Technology, is publishing the book that was inspired by her sojourn at the women's clinic. In her history of contraceptives, Dr. Tone goes where other scholars of birth control have not ventured by exploring the business and practice of contraceptives, especially in the era when they were illegal.
"I wanted to shift the focus away from doctors and lawmakers and political activists to ordinary people who used the devices and the people who made and distributed them, often in violation of the law," Dr. Tone said.
She describes an 1800's birth control industry that profitably marketed an array of products -- douches, medicated sponges, animal-intestine condoms and other items. Diaphragms were "womb veils," made of rubber or a cloth membrane and advertised as "the wife's protector."
One early entrepreneur was Edward Bliss Foote, a medical college graduate who believed in the then-radical notion that women should control their reproduction. Mr. Foote made a one-size-fits-all womb veil in the 1860's and sold it for $6 at clinics and through mail order. Charles Goodyear's discovery of the vulcanization process started a new chapter in birth control, with the first rubber "caps" for men in the late 1850's and full-length condoms a decade later. 
The federal Comstock Act of 1873, however, changed for the next century the contraceptive industry and Americans' ability to control their fertility. Passed in a climate of Victorian dismay over perceived immorality in the nation's growing urban centers, Comstock prohibited the manufacture and sale of contraceptives, along with a range of printed materials deemed obscene. Many states adopted similar statutes.
Once outlawed, contraceptives went underground, becoming a black market commodity no different legally from pornographic materials. But even the morality crusader Anthony Comstock couldn't extinguish the flourishing industry or the popular demand for devices to prevent pregnancy.
Dr. Tone found archived letters from 1874 between one middle-class couple, Violet Blair Janin and her husband, Albert, a lawyer, revealing how they willingly broke the law against buying contraceptives. 
Mrs. Janin feared she would die in childbirth and had relied on the unreliable rhythm method of birth control. Unwilling to forgo sex, Mr. Janin took charge and bought condoms in New Orleans, writing cheerfully to his wife: "I have managed to procure some things I have once or twice spoken to you about. Can you guess what they are?"
Such evidence showed that the need for contraceptives could not be legislated away and that men had played larger roles in birth control than was usually assumed. "When I went into this, I thought it would be a straightforward women's history," Dr. Tone said. "I found if you look at men's letters instead of just women's letters or diaries, you see that men often had just as much expertise and certainly as much interest in the process of controlling fertility as women."
Dr. Tone's research took her to the National Archives, where she exhumed records from the Federal Trade Commission and the Postal Service. Each agency played an enforcement role related to contraception: the F.T.C. investigated health quackery and fraud against birth control manufacturers; the post office policed the mail for "pornographic" material.
Among the many colorful characters populating the black market trade in contraceptives, Dr. Tone's favorite was Julius Schmid, a German immigrant who arrived in New York in the 1880's and began making condoms with surplus animal intestines acquired from his job at a sausage-casing company. Mr. Schmid's sideline became his main business, and in 1890, Mr. Comstock raided Mr. Schmid's home in Manhattan and discovered 696 "skins," as condoms were referred to, and "one form for manufacturing same."
Dr. Tone gleaned such details from the arrest ledger of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice at the Library of Congress. Mr. Schmid survived the Comstock era and by the 1930's, after condoms had been legalized, he headed a prophylactic empire selling Sheik, Ramses and Fourex brands.
"He'd undergone this remarkable shift from an immigrant who had one working leg and was forced to sleep on a park bench because he was unemployed, to this millionaire -- with condoms," Dr. Tone said.
By the 1920's and 1930's, Margaret Sanger, the birth control crusader, had also achieved some success. Her mission was to legitimize diaphragms as a physician-prescribed device, distributed through clinics and doctor offices for poor women.
But diaphragms were never popular -- they accounted for less than 1 percent of birth control sales in the late 1930's, Dr. Tone notes. It was the over-the-counter products that exploded in popularity, grabbing 85 percent of all sales of contraceptives by 1938.
Advertisers came up with the euphemistic term "feminine hygiene" to describe them, evading laws still in force against selling birth control. Jellies, suppositories, foaming tablets and antiseptic douches were promoted to women as modern, scientific, medical solutions to vaguely defined marital problems. Such advertising exploited women's anxieties about unplanned or unwanted pregnancies with such titles as "Calendar Fear" and "Can a Married Woman Ever Feel Safe?"
Lehn & Fink Corporation, makers of Lysol disinfectant, was one company that employed such ad strategies. Dr. Tone found that from 1930 to the 1960's, Lysol was the leading feminine hygiene product in the country. "If you actually look at the product guidelines from the 30's and 40's, they say, 'You can use this to gargle with, to clean your toilet or as an antiseptic douche,' " Dr. Tone said. Evidence that women were burned by douching with Lysol was in consumer letters she found in the Food and Drug Administration and American Medical Association archives. 
With the arrival of birth control pills and the toppling of laws against contraceptive sales and advertising, the 1960's brought a new era of birth control technology and popular use. Plastic IUD's that offered improvements over their 19th century precursors seemed to be good choices in the 1970's until the widely used Dalkon Shield proved to be dangerous to thousands of women. In the last decade, the chemical contraceptives Norplant and Depo Provera were introduced for women, offering longer-term fertility control.
Still, many Americans do not get the contraceptives they need, sometimes because they lack access to doctors and sometimes because their health insurance policies do not cover birth control prescriptions. The answer, Dr. Tone said, is a greater investment in research and development. 
"It will take a shift in our thinking about what our priorities should be, maybe even some general agreement about holding back on consumer litigation," Dr. Tone said. "I hate to say that because historically litigation has been one of the few recourses women have had. But as long as that threat is pending for companies with cash to invest in this, you're probably not going to see this as a top R. & D. priority."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A montage of contraceptive items through the ages, taken from the book "Devices and Desires." (History of Contraception Museum, Janssen-Ortho/Toronto)

HEADLINE: Diesel Engines Get Spotlight in Fuel-Efficiency Contest 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: MILFORD, Mich., June 11 

 BODY:
Each of the 16 Chevrolet Suburban sport utility vehicles in a barnlike garage at the General Motors vehicle testing center here is painted a different bright color and festooned with the logos of sponsoring corporations. But the Suburbans are here not for a road race but for a different kind of competition: to see which can emit the least amount of global-warming gases.
 Designed by students at the nation's top mechanical engineering schools with cutting-edge equipment supplied by the world's largest auto parts makers, the Suburbans are part of a contest, Future Truck, that has become an annual showcase for what might be done by automakers to address global warming. Because automobiles emit 19.5 pounds of carbon dioxide, a global-warming gas, for each gallon of fuel they burn, the contest has taken on new prominence as Washington has become increasingly interested in global warming and in whether fuel-efficiency rules should be raised. 
 The entries here showed a striking split that is also apparent within the auto industry: whether to switch to diesel engines. Eight of the Suburbans burned diesel, which gives excellent mileage and produces minimal emissions of greenhouse gases but tends to produce more soot and smog-causing gases. The other eight used a variety of fuel sources, including two demonstration models of fuel-cell vehicles that did not work well enough to participate in various tests, like towing a 7,000-pound trailer.
Two gasoline-electric vehicles already on the market are the Toyota Prius and Honda Insight. G.M., Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler plan to introduce gasoline-electric hybrid sport utility vehicles within the next three years.
Diesel engines lack the sex appeal of fuel cells, which combine hydrogen and oxygen in a chemical reaction to produce energy to drive a vehicle's wheels. But diesels are technically feasible now, especially if their pollution problems can be fixed, and provide remarkable fuel economy. 
A diesel vehicle has nearly the same emissions of greenhouse gases as a gasoline-electric hybrid, said Robert Larsen, the director of transportation research at the Energy Department's Argonne National Laboratory. A diesel-electric does even better, with emissions of global warming gases almost as low as those of a fuel-cell vehicle, he added. Making hydrogen for a fuel cell requires some emissions of global-warming gases.
Preliminary figures showed that the Suburban that emitted the least carbon dioxide and other global-warming gases today was designed at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, Mr. Larsen said. The diesel-powered, four-wheel-drive Suburban got 28 miles to the gallon on the fairly easy course here, which involved driving at speeds no faster than 60 miles an hour and minimal stop-and-start driving. An unmodified Suburban got 17.3 miles a gallon on the same course, several miles a gallon better than most drivers achieve.
The Suburban from the University of Wisconsin did well partly because it was a hybrid and partly because it used a lot of lightweight aluminum, including an aluminum underbody frame. Mass-producing aluminum frames is extremely difficult, but Audi is already doing it for some cars, and American automakers plan to start trying it in the next few years.
Julie Marshaus, a graduate student in mechanical engineering who led the University of Wisconsin team, said that choosing diesel had been easy. "We used a diesel engine because they're more efficient than any other internal combustion engine," Ms. Marshaus said.
But while her team's Suburban emitted less smog-causing nitrogen oxides than any of the other diesel vehicles here, the big vehicle's emissions were still not low enough to meet tough new government regulations that will take effect in the 2004 model year. And her team's Suburban failed miserably on the soot test today, producing emissions of tiny particles that were off the top of the chart for the contest.
The poor pollution performance of the diesels left it unclear today which engineering school had won the competition. The results of the tests here, which have been taking place for a week, will be announced on Wednesday evening in Washington. G.M. plans to announce separately its own progress on fuel cell vehicles in separate news conferences on Tuesday in Warren, Mich., and on Wednesday morning in Washington.
G.M. gives a Suburban and $10,000 to each of the nation's top mechanical engineering schools for the contest. The students then raise up to $250,000 more each from other corporate sponsors to design a Suburban that gets the best possible mileage with the least pollution and no reduction in driving performance. The Energy Department is co-sponsor of the competition.
Automakers are lobbying for less strict pollution standards for diesels, contending that the rules in 2004 will effectively ban diesels. But Mark Mayer, G.M.'s director of North American engine development, acknowledged that recent innovations in pollution-control devices "will probably get us there, at enormous expense."
Europe applies less strict pollution rules to diesels, and sales of diesel cars are soaring there, claiming a third of the market compared with almost none here.
Environmentalists dislike diesels. Jason Mark, the director of the clean- vehicle program at the Union of Concerned Scientists, said that the real problem was that too many Americans prefer 5,800-pound Suburbans to cars, which get much better mileage with less pollution. Diesel engines are not the answer, he said, adding that "until they solve their public health liabilities, they shouldn't be in Suburbans and other vehicles."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Halfway through 2001, there are few signs that the media economy has hit bottom.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE first half of 2001 is drawing to a close with few if any signs that the weakening of the advertising and media economies will reverse itself anytime soon.
 The continuing softness was underlined yesterday when the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported that ad revenue and ad pages for leading magazines fell noticeably in May compared with May 2000. The results for May contrasted with those for April, which had been somewhat better than expected given the cutbacks many marketers have been making in print ad budgets. 
 "We're damn near in the second half now, and there are not many months left for good news to come out," said Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann in New York. 
Mr. Coen, considered the leading industry prognosticator, said that he planned to reduce for a second time his estimate for this year's total ad spending when he gives a presentation scheduled for Thursday. His first forecast for 2001, made in June 2000, was that ad spending would rise 6.5 percent from 2000. He reduced that estimate six months later to an increase of 5.8 percent after witnessing the decline in ad spending in traditional media by the dot-coms.
Now, with substantially further erosion in that spending, Mr. Coen said, he would lower his forecast again. Even if results began to improve in November or December because of easier comparisons to ad spending in 2000, he added, "it would not be good enough to pull this year out." Universal McCann is the media services division of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"Wall Street's perspective is that this is a lost year," said Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York who follows the advertising industry. "The less said about it, the better."
"Last year, a rising tide lifted all the boats," he added, referring to the strong spending by the dot-coms along with Olympics and election advertising. "Now, a falling tide is bringing all the boats aground."
One such boat, clearly, is magazines, where the declines in ad spending and ad pages last month were most evident in several large, important categories.
Among them were: financial, insurance and real estate, down 21.5 percent in ad revenue and 32.7 percent in ad pages; media and advertising, down 24.9 percent in ad revenue and 36.7 percent in ad pages; retail, down 38.4 percent in ad revenue and 32.1 percent in ad pages; and technology, down 45 percent in ad revenue and 52.7 percent in ad pages.
"That's a lot of 'downs,' " said Joe Mandese, who left Myers Reports in New York, where he was editor of The Myers Report, a media newsletter, to become editor of Media Buyer's Daily, a newsletter to be published by Brill Media Holdings in New York.
Weak ad spending by retailers has been crimping other media, Mr. Mandese said, like spot, or local, radio and television.
"Media go and in out of recessions at different rates," he added. "Now, you don't want to be retail-sensitive."
Another print medium, newspapers, is also suffering as a result of the belt-tightening by retail advertisers as well as other major spenders. For instance, Dow Jones & Company reported last week that ad linage at its flagship, The Wall Street Journal, fell 35.8 percent in May compared with May 2000, led by the financial category, down 36.1 percent, and general advertising, down 39.7 percent.
For magazines last month, according to the publishers' bureau, ad revenue totaled $1.5 billion, down 9.4 percent from $1.7 billion in May 2000, as ad pages fell 16.9 percent, to 22,368 from 26,928. Last month, the bureau reported that ad revenue in April fell 1.2 percent from April 2000 as ad pages fell 9.5 percent.
For the first five months of 2001, ad revenue totaled $6.7 billion, down 1.9 percent from the period a year earlier, the bureau reported, as ad pages totaled 101,990, down 9.4 percent.
"Like everybody else, we've seen a softer economy," said Ellen Oppenheim, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at the Magazine Publishers of America, the industry organization that administers the bureau.
"And while we don't predict," she added, "the messages we're hearing regarding spending in other media suggest the softness will continue."
A primary reason for the weakness, Ms. Oppenheim said, was the difficulty in making comparisons against the robust spending levels during most of 2000, which was "an unusual year in its strength," as she put it.
Another reason for the softness, Ms. Oppenheim said, was that "many advertisers are playing a waiting game," searching for signs that consumers are willing to resume spending before they commit scarce ad dollars.
That is also why the advance sale of commercial time for the 2001-02 season by the broadcast television networks, in what is known as the upfront market, is getting off to such a slow start.
"That's why the 'upfront' is so important," Mr. Russell said, "because it's a reflection in part on what 2002 will bring."
"If you don't have a value proposition," he added, referring to the ability of executives to present their media as sufficiently effective and efficient for marketers, "it may be difficult to come out of the current market with some vigor."

HEADLINE: Office Rents Fall for First Time Since 1993 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 11 

 BODY:
Office rents fell for the first time since 1993 in the first quarter as Internet, computer and technology companies laid off workers and gave up space, according to a study.
 Rents in the nation's downtowns fell an average of 0.52 percent in the first three months of the year from the end of 2000, according to the national real estate index, which is compiled in San Francisco. 
In the suburbs, rents fell 0.89 percent. 
 It was the first drop in rents since the second quarter of 1993, when the real estate market was starting to recover from recession.
"The dot-com meltdown is the main reason for the drop," said Jack Doyle, a spokesman for the index, which is managed by CB Richard Ellis Services Inc., the country's largest property broker. 
In the first quarter, the nation's office vacancy rate rose to 9.5 percent, its highest point since 1999. 
Rents for warehouse space fell 0.41 percent in the quarter, while they fell 0.38 percent for retail space. 
Apartments were the only type of commercial property to show an increase, Mr. Doyle said. Rents for the highest-quality apartments rose 0.465 percent, while apartments aimed at lower-income renters also had a gain, rising 0.66 percent.

HEADLINE: Tunnel Vision; 
Taking a Chance on Love and the No. 4

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Among good places for making a romantic connection, the New York City subway has long ranked down around the bottom of the list, just above jail or the proctologist's office.
 But along with the drop in crime, the rise in subway cleanliness and the herds of new riders who have discovered the trains over the last few years, there are signs that the subway as singles scene may also be having a renaissance. (The subway was once considered a place of romance, after all. Think of "On the Town," in which Gene Kelly spotted the love of his life on a subway beauty-contest poster.) 
 Examples of public transportation's newfound sexiness seem to be all over the place. A new television commercial in which a gang of D.J.'s commandeer a subway car and turn it into a dance club. Another in which a subway motorwoman stops her train to remark on the nice pants worn by the guy in the next train over. An article on the Web magazine Salon last year in which the writer bragged about how she and her friends were "collecting so many phone numbers on the subway these days."
The Tunnel Vision column began looking for a way to tap into this phenomenon, but it was a little awkward to interview people in the middle of hitting on each other. So it was decided that the best way would be to solicit letters from friends and acquaintances recounting their true tales of finding -- or even losing -- love on the subway.

Dear Tunnel Vision:
A good friend and I decided that reckless date-finding measures were in order, and so, on a mutual dare, we agreed that we would each accost and arrange a date with at least one stranger on the N.Y.C. subway. I was soon equipped with a business card on which I had written, "I swear I've never done this before, but call me?"
I never used the card because I ditched it after nearly passing it out at several important business meetings. Luckily, I was shortly thereafter caught kibbitzing on the platform at West Fourth Street by a woman more reckless than I. She had been ribbing her friend and noticed by my smirks that I admired her wit. The three of us began a jovial banter, and as I prepared to disembark at 23rd Street, the witty ribber said, "So how will my friend ever find you again?" I promptly produced a business card -- undoctored -- and slipped it into the friend's hand. Half an hour later I checked my voice mail and already there was a raucous message from the two of them, including a phone number for the promising ribbee.
She was only briefly promising, however, as subsequent communications revealed the existence of a "boyfriend" who, for whatever reason, had not merited previous mention.
Still, not bad for the subway. And, since it's essentially true, I now have another business card that says "I swear I've never done this before . . ."

ROBERT WOOD
Economist, 34

Dear Tunnel Vision:
I was on a train coming back home to Brooklyn and, at the Broadway-Lafayette station, I noticed a man who got on and sat near me. He was probably 19 or 20. I am 35, married and a mother. There was nothing flirtatious going on. You know how you get on the train and pick out those people who you think would be the ones who would help you if someone started to rob you? That's what I thought about this guy.
But as I started to get off, he jumped up and ran after me. I thought I had dropped something, but he handed me a card that said "Clean-cut kid." With a phone number. (Actually, he didn't look very clean cut. Maybe it's a generational thing.)
The card also said his name was Ben. Apparently, he was feeling a little Mrs. Robinson about me.

SARA GOODMAN
Film company employee, 35

Dear Tunnel Vision:
I was clutching at a string of hope. My boyfriend of six months, a lawyer, had just spent the night at my apartment. Now, on our walk to the Borough Hall train station, I was pondering things. Sure, we had our share of troubles, but we had fun together, and we had grown close over time. I was dreaming of a future.
But as the No. 4 train came screeching into the station, he was weighing the evidence: his idea of a holiday is Rollerblading across the country; mine is floating in tropical waters. His day at the beach is a triathlon; mine is a clambake. He is an exhibitionist; I am an extremely private person. As the car doors tried to close for the ninth time, he prepared his opening statement. An elbow jammed into my kidney as he listed the pros and cons of our relationship out loud. I heard a stomach grumbling behind me. I smelled someone's chewing gum.
Seemingly unaware of the commuters crushing around us, he kept building his case, telling me the reasons why it would never work out.
When he had convinced himself, he didn't bother with a closing statement. The No. 4 pulled into City Hall. As my boyfriend got off the train, he became my ex-boyfriend. I'd been prosecuted.

ANNA KOVEL
Chef, 35

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two tickets to happiness. One gets him on the subway, and the other promises that, despite appearances, Robert Wood has never before tried to pick up a date on the subway. "It's essentially true," he said. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Newark Arena Talk Spurs Anger Over Meadowlands 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 11 

 BODY:
When Gov. Christie Whitman, on her last day in office, unveiled a plan for a new sports arena for Newark, her successor, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, complained that the plan was doomed because it did not include a redevelopment plan for the Meadowlands, where the Continental Arena will go dark if the New Jersey Nets and Devils depart for Newark.
 Now, four months later, Mr. DiFrancesco has come up with his own plan. Critics, including many in his own party, are complaining that it is deeply flawed because it does not include a redevelopment plan for the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford. 
 Officials working on the project say Mr. DiFrancesco went public with his proposal last Wednesday because of pressure from the YankeeNets, the consortium that owns the Nets and the Devils, to come up with a firm arena plan before the legislative session ends this month. And they say Mr. DiFrancesco is trying to put together a proposal to turn the Meadowlands into a retail and entertainment destination accessible for the first time by commuter rail service.
The question now is what sort of assurances are needed between now and July 1 to persuade officials in heavily Republican Bergen County, which includes the Meadowlands, to support the Newark arena. In addition to the urban-suburban balancing between Newark and Bergen that is likely to be required in the Legislature, there is a north-south balancing act in which Mr. DiFrancesco will have to address southern New Jersey's quest for some kind of sports venue.
The Assembly majority leader, Paul DiGaetano, who represents the Meadowlands area, said that despite all the attention on the Newark arena, what happens with the Meadowlands will have a far larger economic impact.
"It's the tail wagging the dog, because the Newark arena is really the smaller of the pieces, and the Meadowlands has the capacity to be 10 times bigger," he said. 
Mr. DiFrancesco's proposal calls for a $355 million arena for the two sports franchises, financed with $190 million in state-issued revenue bonds that would be backed by an increase in the city sales tax to 6 percent from 3 percent. That tax would be charged by businesses within a newly created sports district in Newark. The YankeeNets would contribute $115 million to the cost of the 18,500-seat arena and be responsible for any cost overruns.
The proposal requires the Republican-controlled Legislature to pass legislation creating the sports district, the sales tax increase and a bill that would encourage hotel and other construction in the city.
The announcement outraged and baffled some Republicans, concerned that the acting governor was offering an economic development plum to heavily Democratic Essex County while ignoring the future of the Meadowlands in Republican Bergen.
But had Mr. DiFrancesco chosen, he could have given some tantalizing and perhaps soothing hints about what is in store for the Meadowlands.
Lewis Eisenberg, the investment banker and prominent Republican whom Mr. DiFrancesco put in charge of negotiating with the YankeeNets and planning the future of the Meadowlands, said that only the Newark part of the equation had a July 1 deadline.
But, he said, plans were progressing for a broad redevelopment plan for the Meadowlands -- a plan that envisioned its becoming a family sports, entertainment and retail destination. Progress was being made, he and others said, in talks with Nascar about the possibility of auto racing there, and the state had grown more serious about the prospect of giving the New York Jets a permanent home at the Meadowlands, along with the New York Giants, in a new stadium.
In addition, a nationally known planning firm has been hired to create a vision of a new Meadowlands complex. There is also broad agreement among Republican and Democratic officials to build a rail spur that would bring two of the region's commuter lines to the Meadowlands. "This means weaving the Meadowlands into the fabric of everyday life in the region," said Arthur Maurice, vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, who has been part of the negotiations on both the Newark arena and the future of the Meadowlands. "It has always been viewed solely as an events location. But part of DiFrancesco's vision is that this can be a seven-day-a-week destination."
Over the last two years, two of the Nets' co-owners, Raymond Chambers, the philanthropist behind a host of city redevelopment plans, and Lewis Katz, have been the YankeeNets board members most committed to a Newark arena. But as talks dragged on and one proposal after another collapsed, others on the YankeeNets board have raised concerns that the teams would not have an agreement in time to meet their goal of a new arena by 2004.
Harvey Schiller, the president of the YankeeNets, said the teams "would not like to talk about deadlines," and refused to confirm that there was one. But left implicit in the negotiations was the possibility that if an arena could not be built by then, the two teams might leave the state.
One lawmaker, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, suggested that Mr. DiFrancesco may have been acting shrewdly in not revealing more about possibilities for the Meadowlands. First, he said, Mr. DiFrancesco realized that it would be easier to draw up a plan by letting others come to him with suggestions rather than putting one forward that could be picked apart. The lawmaker added that the possibility of a Democrat in the governor's office after November gave Republicans in Bergen extra incentive to work out a deal with Mr. DiFrancesco.
Still, Assemblyman DiGaetano said that it would have been helpful if he and others in Bergen had heard more about the Meadowlands' possible future amid the fanfare last week over the Newark arena.
For his part, the Bergen County executive, William Shuber, said through a spokesman that he was cheered by talk of growing support for the nearly 15-year-old idea of a rail route. But the spokesman added that it would take more than talk.
"He wants to see plans, a map with the routes delineated and written commitments of funding," said Tom Amerato, the spokesman. "It can't be pie in the sky and a someday thing. But I think it can be done before the close of the legislative session."

HEADLINE: More Falling Behind on Mortgage Payments 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
With energy costs and unemployment rising, the number of Americans who are behind on their mortgage payments has increased sharply in the last year.
 The increase is particularly worrisome, housing analysts say, because it suggests that many of the new homeowners, who were part of a surge in house-buying during the last decade, may not be able to afford their current mortgages during slow economic times. Newly liberal lending standards, which often require only a small down payment, have in recent years allowed many people to buy their first house. 
 Over the last year, however, a growing minority of those homeowners have struggled to pay their bills.
In a popular government-insured program to help people buy moderately priced homes, the percentage of homeowners whose loan payments are more than 30 days late exceeded 10 percent for the first time ever at the end of last year, according to a survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. Even during the recessions of the early 1990's and the early 1980's, the rate did not exceed 8 percent. 
Over all, about 400,000 more families were at least 30 days late on their mortgages in the early months of this year than at the beginning of 2000.
Those statistics do not include "subprime" mortgages -- which generally go to people with low income or a spotty credit history -- and delinquencies among those homeowners have risen in the last 18 months, too, according to the Mortgage Information Corporation in San Francisco. Despite the wider availability of mortgages in recent years, subprime loans remain one of the only options for many minorities, studies have shown.
Foreclosure rates, which typically lag delinquency rates, remain low, but have increased slightly this year.
For the people who have been unable to pay their bills, the last few months have been a terrifying time, they said, in which they have begun to feel unsettled in the one place where they would expect to find solace: their home. 
"Never did I imagine I would be in a situation like this," said Alice F. Camp, who lives with her husband and three children in a two-story house -- the first she has owned -- near Atlanta. Last year, Mrs. Camp lost her job as a nurse shortly before learning she was pregnant, and the Camps quickly fell behind on their monthly payments of about $750. Their bank has threatened foreclosure twice this year.
"I've always been able to pay my bills, but I've just been kind of helpless," she said. "It's just been devastating."
The mortgage problems underscore one main reason many policy makers and economists are so concerned about whether the United States will enter a recession this year. In recent years, Americans have built up hundreds of billions of dollars of debt, and should the current slowdown worsen, many people could find themselves unable to pay their credit card, auto loan and mortgage bills, analysts say. Even those better positioned to ride out a downturn may be forced to cut back on spending to pay down debt, further weakening the economy.
The expansion of mortgage lending has happened as the federal government has pressed banks to make more loans available in poorer communities. On their own, bankers have also begun using sophisticated computer programs to identify new groups of potential homebuyers.
Between 1995 and the start of this year, the home ownership rate rose to a record 67.5 percent from 64.7 percent, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Between 1982 and 1995, it had fallen by a tenth of a percentage point.
But now, with companies eliminating jobs and overtime hours and with the costs of gasoline, heating and air- conditioning up sharply, many people who only recently grabbed onto the ladder to the middle class are struggling to hang on.
"This is the first time these loans have been tested," said Mark Zandi, an economist at Economy.com, a forecasting firm in West Chester, Pa. "The pace at which things have eroded reveals severe stress."
The level of delinquencies among the mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration is "outrageous," added Mark P. Vitner, an economist at First Union in Charlotte, N.C. Mr. Vitner said that banks would probably become stricter about lending if it remained as high as 10 percent. "It is a very disturbing trend," he said. 
Mortgage delinquency is especially high, and has risen especially fast, in the Southeast, home to a large concentration of manufacturing companies, which have cut tens of thousands of jobs since last summer.
In addition, almost 50 percent of all new homes built in the United States since January 2000 have been constructed in the region, defined broadly as stretching from Maryland to Florida to Texas, according to First Union. 
In DeKalb County, Ga., where the Camps live, the population surged in the 1990's, and upturned red dirt and billboards advertising new houses remain a common sight. "In every nook and cranny, they're building houses," said Jimmy Bennett, the executive director of the DeKalb/ Fulton Housing Counseling Center, a nonprofit group that helps new-home buyers and people with mortgage problems.
Mrs. Camp and her children moved into their home in Stone Mountain in 1996 and quickly made it theirs. They threw a small party to celebrate. Since then, she has often invited friends and family over for corn pudding or baked spaghetti, talking to them while she cooked and they sat in the family room next to the kitchen. Her new husband later refinished the kitchen cabinets, vanquishing the "ugly brown," she said, and replacing it with a more textured look.
Beyond all the details, having the house has just felt good. "It's a sense of owning something, a sense of belonging, a sense that your money is going into something rather than going out and you never seeing it again," Mrs. Camp said. "It's having something you looked for with your children and you grow in. It's a place of comfort."
That comfort began to seem fleeting last year, when she became sick with complications from high blood pressure and her boss then fired her without giving her a reason, she said. When she lost her job, she was earning $54,000 a year as the director of nursing at a nearby county jail. 
Soon after, she found out that she was pregnant, and the bills began to pile up. Friends, relatives and her church have helped the Camps out, and the family made a $3,500 payment in March, the last time they received a foreclosure notice. Although they remain $1,800 behind on their mortgage, Mrs. Camp said she was hopeful. The arrival of summer should help her husband, a carpenter, get additional work. And with her son, who was born prematurely, getting stronger, she hopes she will be able to look for work again soon.
So far this year, Atlanta newspapers have printed an average of 384 foreclosure notices for DeKalb County each month, up from 300 last year, according to the county's Human and Community Development Department.
Across the country, a drop in energy costs helped the delinquency rate for Federal Housing Administration loans fall slightly, to a seasonally adjusted 10 percent in the first quarter, from 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter, the Mortgage Bankers Association said yesterday. But since the first quarter of 2000 the rate has climbed from 8.4 percent.
The delinquency rate includes all mortgages that are at least 30 days' past due. 
Officials at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which administers the F.H.A. loans, said some of the mortgage problems could be expected because delinquencies usually rose between three and seven years after loans were made. They also said the department was working with families to design payment plans that would prevent foreclosures.
The delinquency rate on conventional first mortgages was 4.4 percent last quarter, up from 3.7 percent a year earlier.
Despite the problems, few people question whether the increase in home ownership over the last decade has been worthwhile. With more people owning homes -- 69.8 million last year, compared with 59 million in 1990, according to the Fannie Mae Foundation -- more people have a reason to work to improve their neighborhood, housing analysts say. And a house is the only significant long-term investment that many low- and moderate-income people have, said Chris H. Morris, the director of DeKalb's community development department.
But housing analysts are starting to ask whether the boom in home ownership can survive the current downturn.
Mildred Akins decided she wanted to move out of her Atlanta apartment and buy a house about two years ago, when her landlord failed to repair a hole in her ceiling. She had little money for a down payment, but by enrolling in a counseling program for new-home buyers, she received a $5,000 grant.
In December 1999, she and her two grandchildren moved in to a single-level beige brick house on the west side of the city.
"We absolutely love it," Ms. Akins said. "I've got nice big open windows where the light comes in beautifully. We've got hardwood floors. We've got a fireplace."
"It's like a sanctuary," she added.
It has been in jeopardy, however, since Ms. Akins's secretarial job at a bail bonding company was eliminated. Failing to find a professional job despite her college degree and 20 years as a teacher, she earns $9 an hour as a customer service representative at a Publix supermarket, she said.
"This is something to keep me from going down the tubes," she said.
But it may not be enough.
"By the time they take out the taxes, there's not a lot to take home," she said. Unless things change soon, she added, "with two growing children and clothing and food, I will not be able to cover the mortgage."

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
Dr. Pangloss, I Presume?

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Explaining the Bush administration's enthusiasm for nuclear power plants, Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill recently said: "If you set aside Three Mile Island and Chernobyl, the safety record of nuclear is really very good."
 Mr. O'Neill has an ear for the Bushian dialectic, having recently spent a great deal of time beating the drum for the tax-cut package, which was a great idea if you set aside the fact that it wouldn't stimulate the economy and we couldn't afford it. 
 His boss is off on his first trip to Europe, where this administration is very popular, if you forget about questions of defense, foreign policy, capital punishment and the environment. The president is going to have to sell our allies on his plan for a missile shield, which is an exciting new vision for arms control except for the fact that we don't know how to build it. 
We are hoping that Europe works out well for Mr. Bush even though he is said to be planning to use the same diplomatic strategy there that he employed in California, possibly the least successful good-will trip since Dad dined in Japan. The president left Washington on a conciliatory note, acknowledging that the greenhouse effect is not a figment of deranged environmentalists' imagination and promising more money for research. The administration must have given up hope of finding a scientific panel that felt global warming was no big deal if you set aside the fact that the planet is getting hotter. Still, who knows what might turn up? Extensive, painstaking studies should always precede action, missile shields of course excepted.
At home, the Senate will be operating under its new Democratic leadership. To everyone's relief, Senator Strom Thurmond, the 98-year-old senior Republican, is no longer president pro tem and thus third in the line of succession to the presidency. The new president pro tem is Robert Byrd of West Virginia. This is a great improvement if you skip over the fact that Mr. Byrd is an 83-year-old former Ku Klux Klan member who recently used the n-word repeatedly during a bizarre television interview in which he claimed to be demonstrating how much progress the country has made in race relations. 
Congress, meanwhile, is turning its attention to the patients' bill of rights, which is to health care reform what a gnat is to aviation. The president and Congress are very close on this issue, except that Mr. Bush is threatening to veto it. Still, the president has to do what he thinks best. He's the guy with the mandate, if you set aside the irregularities in Florida and the fact that he lost the popular vote.
Mr. O'Neill is onto something. This is a linguistic construct for our time:
* If you set aside the divorce, the "Love Nest" headlines, the cancer and the term limits, New York's Mayor Rudy Giuliani is in clover.
* If you set aside April and May, Jenna's been having a great freshman year.
* Maxwell Taylor Kennedy, a son of Robert Kennedy, dropped out of the Congressional race in Massachusetts yesterday. He had enormous political potential if you set aside an inability to read a prepared script, a tendency to giggle at inappropriate moments and an arrest record for an assault committed in the company of his cousin Michael Skakel, the current murder defendant. 
* Aside from the script and the actors, "Pearl Harbor" was one heck of a movie.
* A friend who had been watching the all-execution-all-the-time coverage on cable TV yesterday reported that someone had put in a good word for Timothy McVeigh by saying it was sad that a person's entire life would be judged by the worst thing he did. If you set aside . . .
Last month I wrote a column about Acting Gov. Jane Swift of Massachusetts, who was preparing to deliver twins and had to commute from the other side of the state because Massachusetts is the only state that does not provide its governor with subsidized housing. This was entirely accurate, except for the fact that Rhode Island, Arizona and Vermont don't either. 
Personally, I can see Rhode Island's point, but everybody else should think this through again. Really, you could just rent them a condo.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
More People Falling Behind On Mortgage Payments
With energy costs and unemployment rising, the number of Americans who are behind on their mortgage payments has risen sharply in the last year.
 The increase in the delinquency rate is particularly worrisome, analysts say, because it suggests many of the new homeowners who benefited from more liberal lending standards may not be able to afford their mortgages during slow economic times. Page A1. 

Not All Will Receive a Tax Rebate
More than one-quarter of all American adults will not get a tax rebate this year, and altogether nearly 40 percent will not get the full amount of $300 for individuals and $600 for couples, according to a research group. A24.

No Resurgence Seen in Advertising
The first half of 2001 is drawing to a close with few signs that the weakening of the advertising and media economies will reverse itself soon. The Publishers Information Bureau reported that ad revenue and ad pages for the nation's leading magazines fell noticeably in May compared with May 2000. And Robert J. Coen, considered the leading advertising industry prognosticator, plans to reduce for a second time his estimate for total ad spending this year. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Windows XP Improves Online Calling
Microsoft's Windows XP operating system for PC's goes further than ever before in commandeering the capabilities of the other ubiquitous desktop tool, the telephone. A1.

Difficult Steps for Social Security
The co-chairmen of President Bush's Social Security commission said that they would probably have to propose politically difficult steps like raising the retirement age and reducing cost of living adjustments to restore the system's long-term health. A1.

Stocks Fall in Technology Slump
Stock prices fell, pulled down by selling in the technology sector. The Nasdaq composite index fell 44.32 points, or 2 percent, to 2,170.78. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 54.91 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,922.09. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 10.57 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,254.39. C10.

Hughes Subscription Growth Slows
Hughes Electronics, which owns DirecTV, warned that it was adding subscribers at a considerably slower rate than it had forecast, attributing the company's poor performance in part to the amount of attention executives paid to negotiating a possible sale. C4.

F.E.R.C. to Review Pipeline Bidding
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission agreed to examine whether the El Paso Corporation skewed the bidding for a large amount of natural gas pipeline capacity. C2.

Amgen Drug Approved in Europe
Amgen said that it had received approval to sell a longer-lasting version of its anemia drug EPO in Europe, setting the stage for a fierce marketing battle with Johnson & Johnson, which now sells EPO there. The financial stakes are high because EPO is the biotechnology industry's best-selling drug. Shares of Amgen fell 70 cents, to $66.75. C7.

Diesel Engines Are Reconsidered
A contest to design vehicles that emit less global-warming gases showed a split that is also apparent within the auto industry: whether to switch to diesel engines. C5.

AOL Forms Joint Venture in China
AOL Time Warner said that it was teaming up with Legend Holdings, China's largest computer maker, in a joint venture to develop interactive services. World Business, Section W.

Eircom Accepts Offer From O'Reilly
Eircom, Ireland's former state telephone monopoly, accepted a $2.47 billion takeover bid from an investor group led by Sir Anthony O'Reilly. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Deutsch to Close Office in Boston

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Deutsch Inc. in New York, in its first significant contraction, said yesterday that it would close its Boston office, which has been open only since July 2000, on July 11.
 Because of the "overall softness in the Boston marketplace and tighter economic conditions," the agency said in a statement, executives thought it was best to "put our resources behind other areas and opportunities that present higher growth potential." 
 Deutsch will resign the Boston office's sole account, Homeruns.com in Burlington, Mass., an online grocery service with billings estimated at $3 million, and will try to place the office's nine employees at the Deutsch headquarters in New York; its Marina del Rey, Calif., office; or at agencies owned by the Deutsch parent, the Interpublic Group of Companies.
Posts are also being sought for the two executives in charge of the Boston office: Kathy Kiely, 44, executive vice president and general manager; and Kristin Volk, 48, executive vice president and strategic planning director.
The closing comes as Interpublic is considering a substantial reorganization that may ally Deutsch with large Interpublic agencies based in the Boston area, like Mullen and Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, which could make a Deutsch Boston office superfluous.
"None of our current clients require a Boston presence, so there's no need for us to have a partnership or anything," said Vonda LePage, a spokeswoman for Deutsch. "If any of that changes, we would look into it."
The closing of the Boston office is an unusual setback for Deutsch, which experienced tremendous growth before it was acquired late last year for about $250 million in Interpublic stock.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Decline as Outlook for Technology Stirs Concern

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday, pulled down by selling in the technology sector after two more companies forecast weaker-than-expected quarterly results, stoking investors' fears about the sluggish economy.
 The companies, Varian Semiconductor Equipment and DuPont Photomask, which make devices used in the production of computer chips, cited continued weakness in the semiconductor industry for their financial revisions. 
 The news came as many companies were beginning to project their quarterly results in what is known on Wall Street as the preannouncement season. Analysts said investors retreated because they were nervous about how bad the earnings forecasts might be. 
"I haven't seen any fundamental development," said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at the Waddell & Reed Investment Management Company in Overland Park, Kan. "The market's run up, and it's some profit taking as people scratch their heads and think about, 'What now?' 'When's the economy going to turn?' and 'What's the Fed going to do next?' "
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 44.32 points, or 2 percent, to 2,170.78. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 54.91 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,922.09. And the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 10.57 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,254.39.
James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, said investors, who have been hit by a barrage of negative economic data and company reports, were developing a "growing pessimism again on how fast the economy is going to recover." 
"The stock market is sort of treading water against continued disappointment of the economy," Mr. Paulsen said.
He said that the weakened economy was likely to encourage the Federal Reserve to cut short-term rates by as much as half a percentage point later this month, which would be its sixth rate cut this year. But investors are getting mixed signals.
"The tug of war is between profits, which are likely to stay somewhat disappointing, and yield and interest rates, which are likely to continue to be accommodating," he said.
Shares of Varian fell $3.22, to $39.25, after company officials said its third-quarter revenue was expected to fall 30 percent to 35 percent. The company previously forecast a decline of just more than 25 percent. Executives also said that since Jan. 1, they had cut the company's work force by 20 percent. The company is planning to shut down for two weeks in July.
DuPont Photomasks dropped $6.03, to $45.97, after executives said they expected it to break even or post a profit of as much as 19 cents a share for its fiscal fourth quarter. Analysts expected the company to earn 45 to 57 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. The company will also eliminate about 120 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force.
Neiman Marcus, the specialty retailer, fell 56 cents, to $33.74, after it issued a warning about an unexpected loss. Officials said the company would lose 10 to 15 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Analysts predicted a profit of 10 cents a share. 
Shares of Juniper Networks, a networking equipment maker, slipped $2.69, to $35.33, after analysts from Credit Suisse First Boston and Robertson Stephens cut earnings estimates for the company. On Friday, the company projected that its second-quarter earnings would be lower than previously estimated.
Among other technology losers, Qualcomm fell $1.46, to $59.78; Microsoft lost $1.07, to $72.12; Ciena dropped $3.15, to $52.99; and Intel was off 34 cents, to $30.33, four days after the company said that its second-quarter sales would be at the lower end of its previous forecast.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index fell 22.70 points, or 3.4 percent, to 653.00. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Bond prices rose yesterday as signs that Japan's economy was flirting with its fourth recession in a decade touched off concerns that weak global growth could impede a United States economic recovery expected later this year.
"The pickup in growth globally is going to be a lot slower than people think it is," said James Jackson, a senior bond portfolio manager at Brinson Partners in Chicago, which manages $50 billion in fixed-income assets.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note rose 16/32 , to 97 26/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.29 percent from 5.36 percent on Friday.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32 , to 95 17/32 . Its yield fell to 5.69 percent from 5.74 percent.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Citing Economy and Debt, Warnaco Files for Chapter 11

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The Warnaco Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday, blaming the economy and its heavy debt load, among other things, for its problems.
 Under the leadership of Linda J. Wachner, the chief executive, Warnaco was transformed from a $590 million underwear maker to a diverse $2.25 billion apparel company with a dedicated following in stores and on the stock market. 
 Brands like Speedo, Calvin Klein and Chaps by Ralph Lauren were part of the fold. The share price soared. 
Yesterday, as Warnaco sought bankruptcy protection, all trading was suspended in the New York-based company's stock, which had closed at 39 cents on Friday, down from a high of $44.44 in July 1998.
Mrs. Wachner, who owns stock and options worth 22 percent of Warnaco, intends to remain at the company's helm, and a spokesman said yesterday that Warnaco's troubles reflected the state of the economy, a soft retail environment and its heavy debts. Warnaco listed debts of more than $3 billion and assets of $2.37 billion in its filing in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York.
"She has the full support of the board," Warnaco's spokesman and general counsel, Stanley Silverstein, said, "and will continue to lead the company through these challenging times."
The company announced that it had $600 million in new financing from its banks, Citigroup, J. P. Morgan Chase and the Bank of Nova Scotia, to help it pay its bills and continue operating. It was given immediate access to $375 million yesterday, and a hearing is scheduled on July 9, when a judge will rule on release of the remaining $225 million, the company's bankruptcy lawyer, Kelley Ann Cornish, said. 
But the future of Warnaco remained unclear yesterday. The company is expected to become smaller under its reorganization, selling some assets and reducing its debt over all. 
Its history over the last 15 years has included some complicated transactions involving Mrs. Wachner in various ways. She led an investor group that acquired Warnaco in a hostile takeover in 1986. Four years later, she organized a new company, Authentic Fitness, to buy the Speedo brand from Warnaco for $85 million plus debt. In 1999, Warnaco purchased Authentic Fitness for $418 million in cash plus the assumption of $150 million in debt. 
Just which assets will now remain with Warnaco is uncertain. Some analysts questioned whether Calvin Klein Inc. would continue its licensing contract with the company. "The franchise may go to someone else," said one, who asked not to be identified. 
Mr. Silverstein said the license agreements that Warnaco has would not change under bankruptcy protection. "We intend to continue to take full advantage of the licenses," he said.
A spokesman for Calvin Klein did not return telephone messages yesterday seeking comment. 
Warnaco has other large problems to address. "It's not just a matter of having had too much debt at the wrong time," said Catherine Guinee, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service. "They used a lot of that debt to repurchase their own shares. It was unfortunate timing because the market turned. But if they had had the right products arriving on time at the right price point, and the right quality, it would have been fine." 
She added: "Their press release stated that the economy was bad, everything was wrong and outside their control. But that's not what tears apart a company. You have to be mismanaged first." 
Cutting ties to its chief executive could be costly for Warnaco, which is short on cash. Mrs. Wachner's contract calls for her to be paid five times the highest annual salary and bonus she received at the company, which would be about $44 million, some experts estimate. Warnaco has far less than that in its reserves these days -- about $11 million. 
Mrs. Wachner has lost still more as the share price plummeted, with her stake now worth a tiny fraction of what it was worth even six months ago. 
Burt Flickinger III, a retail consultant with Reach Marketing, predicted that despite the high price to Warnaco for a split with Mrs. Wachner, some board members and investors might want to start over with someone new. "The whole issue of whether Linda stays or leaves will be World War III in terms of this bankruptcy reorganization," he said. "The department stores are furious. There will be a posse." 
Analysts and retail experts said the bankruptcy filing was hardly a surprise, given the steep slide of Warnaco's stock in recent weeks. At the end of March, the company warned that it would not meet Wall Street expectations, which caused a 60 percent drop in the share price. A few days later, Warnaco released fiscal fourth-quarter results, saying that it had lost nearly $195 million in the quarter ended in March, and $338 million for the fiscal year. It said it would not be profitable this year, either. 
The slowing economy has hit the retail industry especially hard, and many stores and manufacturers are battling the sudden turn in their fortunes. Warnaco was hardly immune, and the company cited the economy, among other factors, for its bankruptcy. 
"This was a confluence of a number of things," Mr. Silverstein said. "The general economic conditions, the retail environment, the company's debt load -- all of these contributed to the filing." 
Mrs. Wachner, 55, has been criticized for her management style, with lavish pay for herself as well as perks like gold-colored limousines and a company jet, and poor relationships with other senior executives. Some divisions at Warnaco have had rapid top-level turnover in recent years, which some people trace to Mrs. Wachner. 
For years, Warnaco was a cash lode for investors, churning out big dividends and rising share prices. Investors like Sid Bass bought big stakes in the company, and pension funds like the California Public Employees' Retirement System invested as well. Even when the situation started to sour, Mrs. Wachner maintained a certain base of support. 
"People had a lot of patience with her, but ultimately when the money runs out, the patience runs out," Mr. Flickinger said. "When she's making three times more than the president of Wal-Mart, and Warnaco has pillaged its partners to a large extent, it's difficult to make a case for C.E.O. continuity." 
The company's debt has dug into its earnings. It borrowed money to buy back shares in the last few years, only to see their price dive. And it has struggled through a lawsuit in recent months brought by Calvin Klein, the designer whose Calvin Klein jeans are made and distributed by Warnaco to department stores and discount outlets. The two sides settled the suit in January, but Warnaco blamed the negative publicity in part for its slow sales in the fourth quarter. 
For some, Warnaco's bankruptcy seemed inevitable. "The bank debt has been trading at 30 cents on the dollar since the beginning of the year," an analyst said, "and you knew this was going to be a problem."

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD: Toronto, That Familiar Screen Face; 
As Movie Production Booms, a New Vitality Is Tempered by Location Fatigue

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
Sylvester Stallone is working out in the health club at the Four Seasons Hotel. Down the street, the singer Bono is sipping cappuccino in an outdoor cafe. Sophia Loren is having a news conference at the Windsor Arms Hotel to talk about her newest picture, "Between Strangers," written and directed by her youngest son, Edoardo Ponti. At Trattoria Sotto Sotto on Avenue Road, Robin Williams, Michael Douglas and Liam Neeson are sitting at a corner table, eating pasta.
 "It used to be an extremely quiet city," said Marisa Roca, the owner of Sotto Sotto. "Not any more. Nowadays we stay open until midnight, even one in the morning. It's alive now." 
 The source of Toronto's new vitality is easy to discern. About 40 television and feature film productions are being made here, most of them set in New York, Chicago or other cities in the United States or Europe, an increase of nearly 40 percent in the number of television and film productions made from January to March last year. (One reason for the increase was the threat of strikes by writers and actors, which led networks and studios to rush productions.) Over all, about 300 American movies and television shows are made in Canada each year, with Toronto getting the largest share. 
The influx of television and film production from the United States because of tax incentives and the cheap dollar has plainly altered the city's hotels and restaurants and served as an economic boon to the city of 2.5 million. But some people see a downside to the boom and wonder whether Toronto hasn't overextended itself to accommodate film and television production companies.
"It's getting more expensive, said Ed Gernon, executive vice president for movies and miniseries at Alliance Atlantis, a top Toronto-based production company that has helped finance and develop numerous television and feature films. He added: "It's become a very savvy town, and that has its good and bad sides. Talented folks here are either unavailable now or you're bidding for their services. There's a certain end of innocence. The talent pool may have grown too quickly. We've had to bring in crews from Montreal and pay their hotel costs and per diem.
"And the city is getting to look familiar. On more and more movies that are set in New York or other cities, you can recognize the Toronto locations. It's become so photographed, it's hard to get a distinctive look."
Recently, for example, CBS and Alliance Atlantis executives were looking at the footage of "The Jenifer Estess Story," a true story about an Off Broadway producer who with the help of her sisters battled amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease. "We were looking at the dailies, and suddenly we were all shocked to see trolley tracks in the middle of what was supposed to be a street in Manhattan. We had become so inured to the trolley tracks." The tracks were removed digitally.
Similarly, Tom Russo, senior vice president for long-form programming at Paramount Network Television, said he was watching "Exit Wounds," a recent Steven Seagal action movie in which there was a high-speed chase set in Detroit. The only problem was that the cars swirled past Pizza Pizza, a Toronto fast-food franchise, and a Tim Horton's doughnut shop, another Toronto chain. "I can tell most of the time when I see a feature film or TV movie if it's been shot in Toronto," Mr. Russo said. "Toronto is no longer a well-kept secret."
Even if local residents sometimes grumble about movie trucks and trailers disrupting their neighborhoods, Toronto seems alternatively blase and welcoming toward film crews. For one thing, several television and film executives said, people in Toronto are far more low-key, friendly and even pliant than New Yorkers or Angelenos in similar circumstances. Nonetheless, last October a 52-year-old woman was handcuffed, strip-searched and jailed overnight for whistling on the street in Kensington Market and interrupting the filming of "Claire's Hat," with Juliette Lewis and Gina Gershon. The woman has filed a civil suit against the film company and the Toronto police seeking 500,000 Canadian dollars ($330,000) in damages.
"There are certain areas that are more sensitive than others, but we really try to manage that," said Rhonda Silverstone, Toronto's film commissioner. "So if we get a request, and we know they're going to have trouble, we say: 'Look for something else. It's not worth pursuing.' " Similarly, Gail Thomson, a director of the Ontario Media Development Corporation, acknowledged that she had heard of "location fatigue" in some areas of the city. "Some neighborhoods that have certain unique characteristics are weary now of being visited and revisited," Ms. Thomson said. "Take period churches. We only have so many. We're not New York. Or take a great alleyway. We don't have a huge number of those. So we have to approach things in a careful way. We have to protect our resources." 
"We are a much smaller city than New York or L.A., but we do have the ability to be a chameleon, to dress ourselves up and be another city," said Ms. Thomson. "And we do have the creative talent and the crews because of our live theater and the CBC." The CBC, the Canadian Broadcasting Company, has served as a training ground for performers as well as film and television crews.
"There are challenges in dealing with success that we have to face," she added. (Lately, additional financial help has been offered to filmmakers to make movies outside of Toronto.)
Certainly the residents of Toronto and the local government are aware of the economic benefits of film and television production here. Last year film and television production activity, as well as commercials, surpassed 1.3 billion Canadian dollars (about $856 million), an increase of more than 8.3 percent from the previous year. The city can also count on tens of millions of dollars from related expenditures on hotels, food bills, car rentals and other costs of doing business. Other Canadian cities, like Montreal (often used to replicate Paris and other European locales), Vancouver (used for Seattle and other northwest cities) and Halifax and Winnipeg have also expanded as filmmaking centers for American networks and studios.
The reasons for the shift northward over the last few years are entirely financial. A film costing $60 million in the United States can be made in Canada for $40 million in American dollars. American producers said that costs were at least 30 percent higher in the United States. The reasons are tax-credit subsidies granted here to foreign film and television companies as well as the cheap Canadian dollar. (One American dollar is now about $1.50 Canadian.) "We've seen growth every year: it's a great business and the city welcomes it," said Ms. Silverstone. "People have been learning their craft for 20 years. We see no reason why it can't continue growing."
Labor unions in the United States have reacted somberly to the flood of production into Canada. A Commerce Department report in January concluded that tens of billions of dollars in television and movie work, and 20,000 jobs had been lost to Canada. Jack Shea, president of the Directors Guild, has referred to the shift as a "grave threat to the future of film and television production in the United States." Those especially hurt are "below the line" people on television and film productions -- not the high-profile actors, actresses and directors and producers but the directors of photography, the art directors, boom operators, sound mixers, grips, costume designers, makeup artists and prop builders.
Seeking to curb the exodus of American filmmakers, a Congressional task force on the entertainment industry has proposed legislation giving tax breaks to American companies that remain in the United States to make films.
Toronto, meanwhile, has itself undergone something of a transformation because of the flood of entertainment-related business. Hotels like the Four Seasons and the Sutton Place -- where nearly 40 percent of the rooms are occupied by Americans and others making movies in town -- along with a number of restaurants that have become hangouts have turned parts of the city into a low-key version of Los Angeles or New York.
"It's sort of a Disney version of New York," said Mr. Gernon, of Alliance Atlantis, who lives in Los Angeles. "It's cleaner, it's more polite, it's better designed, and it's not overcrowded. What's not to like?"
Even by the live-and-let-live standards of Toronto, however, some requests by movie stars have amazed hotel managers. Klaus Tenter, the longtime general manager of the Four Seasons, said it was a "real misconception" that most movie stars were impossible people. But he did note that one actress (he declined to identify her) insisted that her bedsheets not be tucked in and that her teddy bears be placed on pillows a certain way every night. The most bizarre request came from the wife of a movie star; their young daughter had made a design with yellow Post-Its on the marble floor of their suite. She asked Mr. Tenter to rip up the floor and send it, intact, to the star's home in Los Angeles. Mr. Tenter declined.
Similarly, Nick Vesely, the general manager at the Sutton Place, said he had accommodated virtually every odd request, including that of a star who wanted a raw spinach sandwich at 4 a.m. But one plea was turned down. A movie actor wanted to bring a pet lion to the hotel. "We do a lot of animals," said Mr. Vesely. "Not lions. I said, 'Forget it!' "
Across the street at Bistro 990, Fernando Temudo, the general manager, said there were unusual hazards to serving all the movie stars that showed up at the restaurant. Recently Goldie Hawn had dinner there, and a crowd of paparazzi gathered outside. Ms. Hawn asked Mr. Temudo to escort her past the photographers and assist her across the street to the Sutton Place hotel. As they left, their photo was taken. Within days, an Australian tabloid had a big photo of Ms. Hawn and Mr. Temudo, who was unidentified but listed as the actress's new boyfriend.
"I showed the picture to my wife," said Mr. Temudo. "What did she say? Like any wife, she asked me how long it took me to get to the hotel and where did I drop Goldie off." He laughed. "Can you imagine? After 21 years of marriage, my wife still asks me questions like that."
