HEADLINE: FINANCE; 
How Big Is Our Endowment? Ask Me at the End of the Month

BYLINE:  By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
AS the director of trusts and investments administrator of Berea College in Kentucky, Barry D. Poynter has a lot of money to invest, almost $800 million. But do not ask him exactly how much his portfolio is worth. He finds that out once a month through the mail.
 Mr. Poynter and his peers -- investment directors of what are considered midsize institutions, like hospital foundations, smaller university endowments and private pension funds, are by and large a buy-and-hold lot, wedded to tradition. Even so, their patience is wearing thin. 
 After all, far smaller investors, and bigger institutions, have such information at their fingertips through the Internet. For individual investors, a raft of sites put trades and data at their beck and call. Institutional investors holding a billion dollars or more plus public and private retirement funds, which often manage their own portfolios, have for years tapped the Internet to make trades and check values without waiting for a monthly statement. 
The luxury of real-time information is only reaching many medium-size institutional investors, those with less than $1 billion in assets. A small foundation's trading orders are still generally executed in a blizzard of faxes and phone calls to money managers. One index fund manager alone can receive 200,000 orders a year, most involving a score or more of transactions.
In the next three years, analysts expect a change to occur as more investment managers offer clients the conveniences that individual investors now expect. 
Just as brokers like Charles Schwab and E*Trade stepped up to help individual investors trade online, new Internet competitors are emerging to serve institutional investors. These competitors are taking on old-line consultants that advise institutions on how to invest and with whom. 
The stakes are high. The top 20 consultants represent institutions with assets of $6.2 trillion, according to a pension consultant survey by Nelson Information, which tracks investment management firms.
The biggest repercussion may be cultural: better informed pension and foundation investment officers may demand more of consultants and money managers.
It is easy to see why institutional investors want to jump online. 
Mr. Poynter's portfolio -- the college's $791 million endowment, which provides 75 percent of the institution's budget -- is divided among several investment managers, as are the holdings of most midsize institutions. Four times a year, Mr. Poynter receives a complete picture showing how markets are affecting holdings. Then, he receives a quarterly report from Berea's pension consultant, who consolidates results from the various investment managers and provides comparative results. The rest of the year, monthly updates on each manager's results must suffice.
The exception is Barclays Global Investors, which introduced Web-based accounting last fall and limited online trading in January. 
"I can't get intermonth totals from any other managers," Mr. Poynter said. "It would be useful to have. I feel more comfortable being in control, rather than waiting until I get a paper statement. I would suggest other money managers might move in that direction, but we're not too pushy."
More pressure is coming from Washington. By 2004, the Securities and Exchange Commission is pressing the industry to settle transactions within 24 hours instead of the three days now allowed.
Online accounting is a step toward that goal, but progress is piecemeal. 
Douglas J. Gorence, the chief investment officer for the University of Minnesota Foundation, would welcome more online tools to avoid clerical errors that can be introduced when rebalancing the foundation's $750 million portfolio. 
Just one of the foundation's 12 money managers provides online account access and trading. "We know more about what we own and don't have to wait for Fedex," Mr. Gorence said, of the $50 million in index funds that can be reviewed online.
So far, the foundation has not traded online, which reflects the divergent investing styles of an institution with fiduciary responsibility, in contrast with the more trigger-ready individual investor. It also suggests that online access by institutions is not likely to result in a raft of day-trading by pension fund managers.
For many funds, the crucial decision is not what stock or bond to buy, but which investment managers to divide its holdings among. 
Typically, a pension fund or foundation hires a consultant to suggest a portfolio strategy and select a team of money managers to carry out different investing assignments, like hedge funds or real estate. Annual mean consulting fees for medium-size institutions are about $100,000, according to William Slocum, a spokesman at Greenwich Associates, a financial research consultant in Greenwich, Conn. Money managers earn fees based on a client's assets and can range from 0.09 percent for passive funds to 0.88 percent in emerging markets.
Most institutions trade quarterly to rebalance holdings. "We set our allocation and stick with it," Mr. Gorence said.
Only the small and midsize institutional investors of less than $1 billion are still consigned to the old economy partly for cultural reasons, said Robert M. Hegarty, the research director of TowerGroup, a financial services consultant, in Needham, Mass. "They hire investment managers to do everything for them." 
Yet, those traditionally passive managers see the Internet putting tools within reach and undercutting the expertise of their consultants. "The old line that wants direct access is a very big shift," Mr. Hegarty said, referring to pension managers who once let consultants handle the administration of investment portfolios. 
For asset managers like Barclays, the transition to online trading and reporting should result in savings and the ability to serve smaller clients.
Late last year, institutional clients of a Mellon Financial Corporation unit were able to receive a real-time look at their bond holdings. Now, about half of Mellon's equity funds are online and the rest will soon be, said Ronald P. O'Hanley, the president of Mellon Institutional Asset Management. 
Clients of the Northern Trust Corporation want the same, said Arch King, a senior vice president and director of the company's e-commerce investment management. To accommodate them, Northern, which is based in Chicago, recently started subscribing to a multimedia site that permits investment managers to provide real-time performance updates. 
But Mr. King said that in his opinion, "it's not that burdensome to work with them with old economy solutions of fax and letter."
That view is apparently widespread. Only half of the nation's institutional investors subscribe to online analytic services, a tool for adjusting portfolios, said William C. Pryor, the chief executive of Russell/Mellon Analytical Services in Tacoma, Wash.
A different strategy for the more hands-on institutional investor was introduced in November by Investorforce.com in Wayne, Pa., whose financial backers include Mellon and the California Public Employee Retirement System, known as Calpers. 
Its plan is giving institutional investors a way to track financial results online by integrating data from different investment managers. Managers, particularly smaller time-pressed shops, seem willing to provide their data and even pay a fee to be included in Investorforce's online database of money managers. (This is used by institutional investors to compare managers' performance.) 
"Money managers reach large plans, like Calpers and G.M., easily," said Jim Morrissey, the president and chief executive of Investorforce.com. "It's easier to focus on the elephants. But it's very expensive to reach smaller ones." 
Still, performance charts are no substitute for body language and eye contact, said James Normandin, the vice president of the Memorial Medical Center Foundation in Long Beach, Calif. 
"My investment committee likes it when the investment manager defends what they buy and sell," Mr. Normandin said. In his view, the Internet is a second-rate substitute for a consultant's ability to select compatible managers.

HEADLINE: SHOPPING; 
New Tools Are Born To Orbit Around EBay

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN MIHM 

 BODY:
THE exponential growth of the auction company eBay remains, even in the wake of the Nasdaq crash, one of the more notable success stories of the new economy. Less well known, however, are the many companies that have profited by supplying eBay's customers with everything from imaging services to insurance to appraisals.
 In some cases, these companies, having been bought or acquired by eBay, serve the auction house's clientele exclusively. Others, like SquareTrade, an online dispute resolution service based in San Francisco, serve multiple partners. Still, as Steve Abernethy, the president and chief executive of SquareTrade, said, "EBay was our first and only customer when we launched." 
 Thanks to that affiliation, he said, particularly eBay's decision to make SquareTrade its exclusive dispute resolution service, "we've expanded to a much broader base of partners." As he explained, "Other markets emulate eBay, they look to them as the biggest marketplace. So if eBay adopts something, other markets and businesses will adopt those practices and tools as well."
Munjal Shah, the president and chief executive of Andale, an auction-services company in Mountain View, Calif., agreed. "Our original beachhead was auctions on eBay," he said. But he hopes the company can expand to other markets.
Here's a sampling of the different types of companies that have emerged to service the buyers and sellers on eBay -- and beyond:

PICTURE SERVICES: No one wants to bid on something sight unseen, but posting pictures can be cumbersome. That is why several companies have sprung up to offer what is called dynamic imaging. The oldest company is Pongo, which has been marketing image hosting to eBay users since 1996 for 50 cents a picture. More recently, Ipix has entered a strategic alliance with eBay, offering sellers the option to "drag and drop" images from their desktop to their listing for a small fee.

COUNTERS: Other companies offer eBay merchants additional tools like counters, which keep sellers apprised of how many bidders have viewed their items. The most ubiquitous is an "honesty" counter distributed by Andale. "We offer the counter for free to get people to try our other services," said Mr. Shah of Andale. Another popular counter is sold by Andale's competitor, AuctionWatch.

APPRAISALS: A number of appraisal companies market their services to buyers on eBay, many of whom are not certain how much they should bid for, say, an antique ottoman. Eppraisals.com has emerged as the premier provider, thanks to its status as eBay's principal online appraisal service. The company, which taps more than 1,000 experts in antiques, fine arts, coins, stamps and other collectibles, gives online estimates of items up for auction for $20 each.

SNIPING: Not all the companies that feed off eBay's transactions have formal partnerships with the company. So-called "sniping software," available from WinningBid Pro! (www.umklaydet.com) and iSnipeit.com and others, helps buyers by automatically submitting the winning bid within seconds of the auction's completion. ISnipeit says that its software "allows you to rest easy knowing that your competitors will have literally no time to react to your bid." While eBay is neutral on the subject of sniping, its use by auction sophisticates has stirred debate in eBay chat rooms.

ELECTRONIC CHECKING: Since eBay's inception, several companies have marketed a variety of electronic payment services. For several years, PayPal has been the most popular service, charging a small fee to sellers in exchange for vetting and processing the buyer's payment by credit card or by check. More recently, eBay has instituted its own electronic-payment service by acquiring Billpoint, thus joining forces with Wells Fargo, which also bought a stake in Billpoint. The new service, prominently featured throughout the eBay site, offers many of the same services as PayPal, but with the eBay imprimatur.

ESCROW: Other companies market escrow services, promising to keep buyers and sellers honest. Ebay's preferred provider is Tradenable, which for a small fee holds the buyer's payment until the seller meets certain conditions, like shipping the item in one piece. If you are shipping something big -- a car, for example -- Escrow.com markets itself on the home page of eBay Motors.

SHIPPING: Assuming that everything works out and the check clears, the seller inevitably looks for an appropriate shipper. Several companies meet that need. The most prominent is United Parcel Service, which eBay has integrated into its site, enabling buyers and sellers to calculate rates in advance. Other shippers include Simply Postage, which enables users to print their own postage; IShip, which provides shipping estimates; Mailboxes Etc.(www.mbe .com); and E-Stamp.com.

MEDIATION: A final subindustry has marketed itself to eBay users who find themselves enraged when, say, the dish they ordered arrives with a crack down the middle and the seller refuses to refund the money. SquareTrade, an online dispute resolution service, has emerged as eBay's primary provider of such services. Customers can use an automated service that allows each party to establish how far it is willing to go to settle the problem. If that does not work, the disgruntled party can request a professional mediator for $15, drawing on the company's network of 250 professional mediators worldwide.

HEADLINE: ON A SHOESTRING; 
Skip the Climbing Wall: This Start-Up Just Wants to Hang On

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago, Michael Hejtmanek sat in the tiny conference room of his fledgling company -- the same room he shares with two other companies -- and talked about timing. He shies away from calling his lousy.
 "There's no more funding for two guys and a business plan," he said quietly. "It's just not there, so starting when I did was rocky. It was definitely tough." 
 What Mr. Hejtmanek did was quit a high-paying job at BackWeb Technologies to create a wireless software company called Enterprise Air. This was in November, several months after the stock market began suffering 100-point drops and a full two years after many of his entrepreneur friends captured and then lost their digital gold mines. In November, he knew that potential investors and employees would be skittish. He also knew that office space -- even without Foosball and climbing walls -- would be expensive. 
Still, Mr. Hejtmanek, 32, blue-eyed and well-spoken, decided it was time to tackle the technology industry. Since then, his efforts typify the new-style start-up. He maintains a shoestring budget. He rents two workstations in a sunny office on West 27th Street in Manhattan, though he often works in his Upper West Side apartment. He spends hours talking on the phone with advisers and he searches everywhere for financing, venture capital or otherwise. He compensates his six full-time staff members with small salaries and big pep talks. He prints his business cards at home.
"We would be happy if it were two years ago and people were throwing money at us, but maybe this will be better," he said. "Now, we're only dealing with serious people, the ones who really have the wisdom and the chutzpah to make it happen."
Gone are the days when investors thought the Internet was touched by Midas and amateurs could start wireless companies, said Christopher Mutkoski, the founder of Angel Alliance, a New York-based consortium that invests in early-stage companies. Today, a start-up must be operated by an experienced technologist, he said.
Mr. Mutkoski said that $5 million was now a common first-round investment. "We used to invest in the $40 million range -- it was amazing," he said. "Companies were getting cranked out and we were getting locked out of deals. Now, the climate is negative, but good people with good ideas can find money. I'm still optimistic."
So is Mr. Hejtmanek. His idea is to make business applications for wireless devices, like Palm organizers, that do not have to connect to the Internet. That way, people working outside the office, for example, will not have to endure time-consuming downloads to send orders or messages to company headquarters. (CodeWarrior by Metrowerks and ScoutBuilder by Aether Systems use similar technology.)
Mr. Hejtmanek came up with the idea for Enterprise Air in September, having spent several years developing and managing software in Switzerland for the Bossard Group, a tool manufacturer, and Oracle, the software company. He moved to New York in 1997 to attend Columbia University School of Business. He joined BackWeb Technologies after graduation in 1999.
"Those were the industry's golden days," Mr. Hejtmanek said, recalling how BackWeb's sales jumped to $40 million from $8 million almost overnight. He traveled constantly and kept apartments in New York, Toronto and San Jose, Calif. "It was exciting," he said, "to get a product together, release it and -- boom! -- watch the dollars roll in."
Today he is a salesman, fighting for every cent. He left BackWeb in September 2000 with $100,000 in his savings account. Since then, he has been spending about $20,000 a month of his own money building Enterprise Air. Much of it pays the four software engineers, including his chief technology officer, Michael Uffer, who was formerly the director of technology at Rare Medium.
Mr. Uffer is 49 and has spent nearly 20 years in the software business. He lost his job at Rare Medium in October and then joined Enterprise Air. He agreed to a 40 percent pay cut, he said, because he needed the work and he believed in Mr. Hejtmanek's dream. "It's a sacrifice," Mr. Uffer said. "But it's also exciting to be here early on, to feel an ownership."
Mr. Uffer and the rest of the staff work mostly from home and could command salaries above $200,000. Instead, most work for $40,000, with equity and options. They all agreed to the salary because they have bought the dream, he said. (There are also some unpaid interns.) Twice a week, they gather in the conference room on West 27th Street to talk and plan.
They leave the financing to Mr. Hejtmanek, though, and this search fills his days and nights until 2 a.m. He needs $600,000 in seed money to keep the company running through August, and for this he looks to business competitions, angel and student investment groups, and, soon, venture capitalists. He has called on Columbia alumni and peddled his plan in five business competitions, once traveling to Amsterdam, where his presentation won second place. More recently, he won $16,000 from the Columbia Organization of Rising Entrepreneurs and was given $50,000 by the Eugene M. Lang Center for Entrepreneurship at Columbia.
The windfalls will grant Mr. Hejtmanek entry to what he calls the "tweed coats," the angel investors who give money to new companies. But Elaine Gilde, a member of the New York New Media Association's angel group and president of Grove Street Capital, said such access no longer guaranteed millions anymore.
"Right now, a lot of people are pretending they are investing but aren't really putting out a lot of money," Ms. Gilde said. "They're just a little gun-shy. But if you can find a business application that cuts cost and saves time, it should be a good investment."
Streamlining the inefficiencies of the digital world -- this is what most new-style start-ups are trying to do, including Enterprise Air. The profile is lower, and the need for high-dollar advertising almost nonexistent. But if such a company can help much larger companies make sense of all the new technology, investors say both are more likely to survive the economic tremors.
For Mr. Hejtmanek, this also means wooing customers. He made a list of 300 potential partners in April, winnowed them to 10 -- he wanted small companies based in New York -- and began meeting with several of them regularly, starting in May. All he needs is one or two to commit, he said, and his company's footing will feel more assured. Until then, he keeps at it. He recently scheduled a presentation for the day before his wedding, planned for June 30. He has yet to tell his fiancee. He hopes she will understand.
Michael Meyer, one of Mr. Hejtmanek's advisers and a creator of a defunct e-business called Snickelways, said this determination was necessary at all new start-ups. "You can never foresee the future," Mr. Meyer said. "That's what makes an entrepreneur: he has a vision and he fights for it against all odds."
Mr. Hejtmanek said he called Mr. Meyer nearly every day, seeking counsel. They talk about the possibility of renting a bigger office. They also talk about the software prototype, and about not making mistakes. The conversation always ends the same way. 
"So are you still having fun?" Mr. Meyer will ask.
"I'm really tired," Mr. Hejtmanek will reply, "but, yeah, I'm having fun."

HEADLINE: SHOPPING; 
Direct to You From Rajasthan

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
LOVE the sound of Panamanian molas, those colorful fabric panels with their handstitched charms? Like the idea of Haitian tin sculptures? African carved soapstone dishes? Indian beaded necklaces?
 International crafts, with their one-of-a-kind aura, have joined the Internet marketplace. But like swiftly shifting sands, the final shape of these sites is still not clear: while a handful of sites, like Novica.com and eZiba.com, are still open to consumers, others have become wholesalers, and at least one has gone out of business. 
 The idea behind the sites is appealing: a chance to buy crafts directly from artisans around the world, bypassing the limited selection (and markup) of importers. 
Then there are the pledges from the sites to not just make money but to do good: they say they are helping to keep the artisans out of factories and sweatshops -- and endangered habitats. For instance, a small site that sells woolen hats and gloves, Irbis Enterprises (www.irbis-enterprises.com), has made a deal with the Mongolian villagers who make them that their wares will be sold internationally and, in return, the villagers will not kill the snow leopards that eat their sheep.
Despite the idealistic intentions of many of the people involved, questions remain about the amount of money the artisans are paid. These sites also face a problem that has been bedeviling other e-tailers: selling handmade products when there is no way to touch the goods.
Evie Black Dykema, a senior analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said there was "obviously a significant demand for crafts that is not being met." And whether it is necklaces from Indonesia or plastic scrimshaw from Spain, a craftsman has the potential to earn "70 times what he could make working in a local factory," Ms. Dykema said. But for now, the international crafts scene on the Web is so small, "it's under the radar screen," she said.
Ms. Dykema and others in the crafts market point to several issues, including the margins between an object's selling price and the amount paid to the craftsman: is he getting a fair price? For the consumer, there are questions of quality, especially with handmade objects, which do not always match their pictures, as well as concerns about international credit-card security.
Most of the sites push their mission to "empower" the world's poor artisan, but it is hard to judge who is really doing good.
"Yes, the perception is that there's a lot of stuff out there and you don't know what's behind it," said Amber Chand, a co-founder and "vice president of vision" at eZiba, a major site for crafts. "But eZiba is committed to fair practices and exemplary trading; we build alliances with respect."
Ms. Chand, an anthropologist, concedes that things are not cheap on eZiba. "Why should we be cheap?" she said. "It takes months and months to make a good basket."
Novica.com, another well-known crafts site, had been struggling but received an infusion of support in December, when the National Geographic Society bought a 19 percent stake in the company. At Novica, Rob Milk, a founder, asserted that his site's prices were lower than those of other sites: the company's dozen regional offices, he said, make it easier for artisans to mail and store their objects.
Other sites are finding their way, said Rochelle Beck, the director of the Artisan Enterprise Network, which a year ago was awarded a grant by the World Bank to combat poverty through marketing indigenous crafts. The network uses the Internet to educate artisans. 
The task is huge. "We're teaching them about trade shows, retail outlets, the laws that affect international property rights -- after all, they're exporting goods overseas," Ms. Beck said. "If we're nervous about sending our credit-card number to a site in the United States, imagine people worrying about sending their credit-card number overseas."
Ms. Beck's group is developing an entrepreneurial curriculum for the workers. "How to run their business better," she said. Recently, the Artisan Enterprise Network set up a craft fair in La Paz, Bolivia -- the city's first, Ms. Beck said.
The Enterprise network and other, more profit-oriented middlemen -- eZiba and Novica, among them -- are also coaching artisans on what sells in the United States. "You and I might like some of the crafts the way they are produced, but many others have different taste," Ms. Beck said. Some Americans and Europeans might like brighter colors -- or conversely, less bright colors, depending on the country.
"It's a very sensitive issue that must be considered case by case," she added. "When we're dealing with old cultures -- to ask for blue instead of beige would be a travesty."
But some crafts workers in certain cultures do not have the same creative flair as others do, Ms. Beck said. Their items might not sell at all in America. 
"Do they stop making crafts and go to work in a factory?" she asked. "Or do they use their skills to make something more salable? You don't choose for them."
That approach has its drawbacks. "It's an age-old problem," said Caroline Ramsay, the president of the Crafts Center, a nonprofit clearinghouse for technical assistance and information. "You want them to continue their work without compromise, but that must be weighed against the realities of the marketplace."
THEN there is the question of labor standards. For instance, do the artisans use children to help, Ms. Ramsay asked, "or are they using sewing machines?" (Consumers generally prefer hand-sewn items.) EZiba, Ms. Chand said, checks every supplier and has a strong policy against child labor. But not all sites may be as cautious, Ms. Ramsay said.
The money is tempting to villagers. Although they receive a fraction of what the items sell for, it might be as much as they could make in a month, or even a year, selling locally.
With an item selling for $200, the artisan -- the worker sitting on the ground making a terra-cotta pot, say -- gets an average of $25, Ms. Beck said.
"Let's say it is a big ceramic, fragile pot," she said. "It will cost another $25 to pack and ship it. The wholesaler wants to double his money so he'll charge $100. The retailer will tack on another $100, so that's $200. That's standard in the field. A lot of people don't understand that. They think if they could only get rid of the middleman, they could get it for $100."
But the middleman may find financing for the craftsman and obtain a credit line so he can buy supplies, she said. The middleman also handles bookkeeping chores -- paying the exporting duties, taxes and advertising, fielding complaints.
Those numbers help explain the recent shakeout, and why several of the larger sites have gone from selling retail to wholesale: if you don't own a business (like a shop or museum gallery) don't bother signing in. Viatru.com, one of the best-known crafts sites, began in retail, switched to wholesale and is now out of business, though it hopes to return as a nonprofit entity, said Michelle Long, one of the site's founders.
As Ms. Beck said: "There are advantages and there are risks to selling handmade articles. A lot of companies feel more comfortable just dealing wholesale."
In a quest to discover the vagaries of shopping for handmade crafts on the Internet, this reporter ordered items to judge delivery times, service and quality of the merchandise. Orders were placed with Novica, Global Crafts (www.net-kenya.com /globalcrafts/) and Peoplink (www. peoplink.org). I ordered a pair of handblown Mexican vases from Novica, jewelry from Peoplink and two soapstone covered dishes with carvings from Kenya from Global Crafts.
They all arrived quickly. The vases were said to have up to three-weeks' delivery time, but they came in three days. The other items came almost as promptly. All were in great shape.
It was hard to judge the quality, however. The vases, unfortunately, were not the greenish-yellow in the picture but brownish-yellow. Asked about the problem, representatives of the sites blamed the computer screen or the transmission. The jewelry looked a little cheaper, less well made than the pieces in the photographs, but there was not enough difference to complain about. The soapstone dishes turned out to be my favorites: the carved images on the lids are primitive and unusual, different from anything I have ever seen. 
Even though I was ordering these items for a newspaper article, I chose crafts that I might order for myself. I also noticed during my shopping that there were a lot of overpriced wall hangings and other useless objects for sale.
But those just may be the items designed with Americans in mind.

(Photographs by Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SOFTWARE; 
If You Like This Story, Click Here to Pay Me

BYLINE:  By ANDY WANG 

 BODY:
THE financing dried up, Web advertising was not generating enough money, and there were no potential investors in sight. So I did what all good Americans should do in time of need: I begged. Almost anybody with a Web site can do the same.
 Just go to Amazon.com and sign up for its Honor System, which allows visitors to donate money to participating Web sites with their credit cards. Since the service started in February, several thousand sites have signed up to receive money, according to Jonathan Leblang, the director of the Honor System at Amazon. 
 Being on the receiving end of this service is a bit like being a panhandler with a high-priced agent, because Amazon gets more than 15 percent of each transaction. Still, it is found money. And the donations have definitely been put to good use. 
Starting a daily, advertising-supported online magazine seemed like a smart idea when I founded Ironminds.com in August 1999. At the very least, I thought, it would be a way to make a living while publishing what I wanted.
Ironminds still seemed like a great idea in March 2000, when the site was acquired by an Internet media company. After the acquisition, I stayed on as editor in chief. In April of that year, the Nasdaq imploded, and much of the Internet industry, including the new parent company, followed suit. I bought Ironminds back last August, five months after it was acquired and two months before the parent company went out of business.
Ironminds continues to publish, thanks to the kindness of the magazine's contributors, who are now working without being paid. Web hosting and other costs are paid by me, which is where the Honor System has come in handy.
Within two days of signing up for the system and publishing an editor's note asking readers for money, I got $400 in donations. For a moment, I (almost) forgot all the long hours and money I had poured into the site. While the money I was making through the Honor System was nowhere near the amount I have put into the site, I was elated.
Matt Haughey was similarly pleased when he used the Honor System. The owner of Metafilter.com, a collaborative Web log in which members post interesting links they have found, Mr. Haughey was used to spending a couple of hours each day working on the site for little more than the gratitude of visitors. He signed up for the Honor System and raised $700 the first day. His reaction was "total surprise," he said. "It was just so much so quickly for something I've always done for free."
The Honor System, however, is not really a viable way to finance a business. It is primarily useful for a one-time cash infusion, according to Dan O'Brien, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "It's better than nothing, I suppose," Mr. O'Brien said. "But it's not really contributing to a sustaining flow of revenue."
Still, Mr. Haughey, who has also used the Honor System to create a college scholarship fund, is not complaining. His site, like many that use the Honor System, is a labor of love and not an actual business. Mr. Haughey, a programmer in Silicon Valley who worked on Blogger, the Web-log publishing service, said he started Metafilter.com to learn a new programming language and did not consider the notion of making money from the site until it started consuming his life.
Some sites are more ambitious, with results that are still uncertain. Perhaps the best-known Honor System participant is Andrewsullivan.com, the commentary site-Web log of the writer Andrew Sullivan. Visitors have the option of contributing through the Honor System or through the mail. Since it signed up with Amazon in March, the site has raised more than $7,000 through the Honor System and several thousand dollars through the mail, Mr. Sullivan said. (Mr. Sullivan is also a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine.) 
"I really didn't know what to expect, but the enthusiasm from my reader e-mails suggested we'd do well," Mr. Sullivan said. "The sums we raised gave us leverage to redesign the site and upgrade it -- so that we can now go to advertisers. I'm determined not to lose money on this thing."
Breaking even sounds good to Al Sacui, a Philadelphia artist who fell victim to his site's popularity. Mr. Sacui created a cat animation and put it on his site, Nosepilot.com (visitors are now redirected to Gisol.org). Many people shared his feline fixation, and he soon found himself with a Web hosting bill of more than $16,000. That bill is in dispute, but to help pay for future Web hosting and animation costs, Mr. Sacui is asking visitors to the Gisol.org site to make donations through the Internet payment service PayPal or the mail. So far, he has raised more than $3,000.
Mr. Sacui's predicament, unheard of during the dot-com boom, is now increasingly common. Not long ago, huge traffic numbers were considered a road to financial success. Now, they can lead to an unmanageable bill for a project like Mr. Sacui's, which generates little or no revenue. In such cases, asking for donations seems suitable, especially when the goal is to remain noncommercial.
"There should be a safe haven from advertising," Mr. Sacui said. "If art can't be there without advertising, then there really isn't anything out there."
Which is not to say that Mr. Sacui is oblivious to financial concerns. For his next major piece of online artwork, he plans to ask viewers for a $1 donation. 
Mr. Sacui said he had considered using the Honor System but that he "sort of has a problem with the fees." Amazon charges 15 percent of each donation plus 15 cents. PayPal charges 30 cents for donations under $15; for larger sums, it charges 2.2 percent of the transaction plus 30 cents. Of course, there is a much larger base of potential online philanthropists at Amazon, which has about 32 million registered users, compared with about seven million at PayPal.
In defense of Amazon's fee structure, Mr. Leblang said: "The money that people are receiving to support their Web site is, in my opinion, incremental money. It's the money they wouldn't have had before. We think we're offering a valuable service for the additional few percent we're charging." Mr. Leblang added that the service could handle small transactions.
For now, Mr. O'Brien of Forrester Research does not envision the Honor System transaction fees generating major revenue for Amazon. "They'll start to make significant money if people pay every month," he said. "And I don't see that built into the system."
While generating revenue through donations has limitations, for some sites (mine included), it has meant an injection of much-needed capital at a crucial time. Sean Forman, a math teacher at St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia, who runs Baseball-reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia, found himself in a crunch in April. His site was taken down by its Web hosting service after traffic spiked at the start of the baseball season and after the site was mentioned in Sports Illustrated.
Mr. Forman explained his financial situation to his readers, who donated about $1,500 through the Honor System and PayPal. Baseball-reference.com is back on the Web, with an upgraded hosting service. 
"I've been pleasantly surprised," Mr. Forman said. "I knew I had a site that people enjoyed using. I just wasn't sure people were willing to pay."

HEADLINE: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; 
Flying Higher In Cheap Seats

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
IN the three years since SouthTrust Bank's most frequent travelers began booking their corporate travel online, the company has enjoyed what it described as "significant savings." And three months ago, after allowing -- encouraging, actually -- those employees who travel on business to book online, the bank, based in Birmingham, Ala., found that the percentage of those who used the service soared to about 40 percent from about 1 percent. 
 More to the point, at a time when corporate America is scrambling to rein in expenses by cutting back on all but essential travel, SouthTrust, with 14,000 employees in nine states, has been able to cut as much as 30 percent from its multimillion-dollar travel budget, said Katie Bearden, the bank's corporate travel manager. 
 The Xerox Corporation, with 90,000 employees worldwide, is also using the Internet to cut costs. In addition to reducing the number of employee trips, the company has required since last fall that domestic travel be booked through Xerox Travel On-Line, its proprietary Web-based system that allows employees to check, schedule and book flights electronically. And by using the Internet and telephone conferencing, it has pared by 25 percent the number of sales and training meetings for employees. 
In the process, said Bill McKee, a company spokesman, Xerox reduced travel spending 26 percent in the first quarter over the same period last year, thereby contributing handsomely to the $22 million that the company plans to save in its travel budget this year. 
Like a growing number of corporations, Xerox is economizing in other areas as well, including requiring employees to buy airline tickets 21 days in advance when possible, to obtain the lowest fares. Some corporations no longer allow employees to fly business class on flights less than nine hours, while others decree that employees take connecting flights instead of nonstops, which are usually more expensive. And many companies insist that employees fly low-fare airlines like Southwest and Frontier.
Corporate travel departments are doing what Xerox, South Trust and others are doing -- turning more to Web-based programs, where they can negotiate discounts with airlines, hotels and rental car companies in return for guaranteeing a certain number of bookings over a specified period. 
Some Web-based programs alert corporate travel managers by e-mail if employees insist on booking other airlines, staying at other hotels or renting from other rental car companies. But most companies monitor noncompliance by examining the monthly reports generated by the programs.
Corporate travel is an especially inviting target for the budgetary knives, because it is widely said to be a corporation's second-largest controllable expense, after salaries. Last year, for example, businesses spent $185 billion on travel and entertainment, including a relatively piddling $4 billion booked on the Internet.
But Internet bookings are almost sure to increase. According to a forecast in April by Jupiter Media Metrix, which measures online audience data, Web-managed business-travel bookings will soar to $32 billion in 2006.
Much of that growth will come from small businesses, like C/A Communications, a 31-year-old Dallas company that integrates data communication equipment. With about 8 of its 19 employees traveling regularly, the company recently joined the American Airlines Business ExtrAA for small companies. For every $10,000 spent on flights during a quarter, companies receive 1,000 of the 2,000 points that can be exchanged for an economy class ticket for travel in the continental United States, Canada or Mexico.
"By booking online," Jerry Brown, the president of C/A, said, "our employees get to keep their frequent flier points and the company also gets 1,000 points. So when we have to send somebody to New York at the last minute, instead of having to pay $1,700 we can use 2,000 of the points we've accumulated to get a free ticket." EDWIN McDOWELL

HEADLINE: Dress-Down Is Down if Not Quite Out 

BYLINE:  By AMIE PARNES 

 BODY:
At the height of the dot-com boom, Raymond Nasr felt like a fashion misfit. Everyone else at work seemed to be wearing jeans and sports shirts, and there he was, resplendent in his blue double-breasted jacket, dress shirt with knotted cuff links, dress slacks and red bow tie.
 "It was out of the norm," said Mr. Nasr, 38, director of government affairs at Novell, a provider of networking software in San Jose, Calif. "But I think people liked it because I looked refreshing." 
 These days, fewer colleagues are ribbing him and more are emulating him. As the economy sours, they are rediscovering an old-economy truism. Formal dress often makes a better impression than casual wear on the people who matter most in their careers: customers and bosses.
Mr. Nasr, whose clients range from state governors to heads of foreign governments, says he never lost sight of that rule. "I guess you could say I appreciate the importance of presentation," he said. "Now I look around and there are many more people who look like me."
The demise of so many Internet start-ups that flaunted a do-your-own-thing workplace culture has robbed casual dress of its cachet, experts say. "Looking like a dot-comer was very fashionable once upon a time," said David Wolfe, the creative director for the Doneger Group, a New York fashion consulting firm that analyzes retail trends. "It's obviously not fashionable anymore."
More important, many managers view casual dress as a failed experiment that is more likely to foster laziness than creativity. In a recent poll by Jackson Lewis, a national employment law firm, 45 percent of human resource managers said casual attire contributed to employee tardiness and absenteeism, 40 percent thought it promoted workplace laxity and 25 percent said it encouraged flirting.
"Casual has become misinterpreted as sloppy and unfocused," said Eric Hertz, president of the Fashion Association, a trade group in New York. "Company managers got annoyed by the laxity in the workplace. It's gone as casual as it can go, and now this is the beginning of the trip back."
The dressing-down trend probably peaked in 1999, when 95 percent of the companies polled by the Society for Human Resource Management, a trade group in Alexandria, Va., said they allowed some form of casual attire. Last year, that dropped to 87 percent, the society said.
Since then, George W. Bush has become president and instituted a strict dress code for members of his administration. "It was driven by a sense of decorum that honors the tradition and majesty of this place," said Tucker Eskew, deputy assistant to the president for media affairs. Fashion experts say the presidential example exerts a powerful influence on popular culture.
But the biggest factor in the return to workplace formality is probably the economic downturn, which has driven many people back to ties and pantsuits as armor against job insecurity.
Take Nick Goodman, 27, director of business development at Tutor.com, a homework help and tutoring Web site in Manhattan with 20 employees. He has been with the company for just a year and a half.
"I do see many more people wearing blazers and ties in our office, sometimes even suits," Mr. Goodman said, even though Tutor.com has no dress code. "I think a lot of people want to position themselves as edgier, and more professional. They're taking a back-to-business approach."
So is he. "More often than not, I dressed more casual in the beginning," he said. "Now, I wear a blazer, khakis and a pair of loafers. We have spur-of-the-moment meetings with libraries, universities and colleges, and I need to be dressed appropriately."
Some people are actually revolting against their laid-back dress policies at work. Garri B. Hendell, 31, a lawyer in Toronto, says he wrote a letter to his firm's senior partners last summer protesting their new anything-goes dress code. "Credibility is a suit," he said. "Since I am a lawyer, I depend on the audience, and I know the audience would prefer I wear a suit and tie. So if I am meeting with clients, I wear a suit."
On the other hand, he adds, he is a team player, and because the new policy remains in force, he goes along. When he is not with clients, he said, he cuts loose. "I'll wear a dress shirt, dress pants and some pretty funky shoes," he said.
For retailers, the turn back to tradition is good news, especially in a softening economy. Sales of men's dress shirts rose 4.2 percent last year, to 107.4 million, reversing a decline of 2 percent in 1999, for example, while sales of men's dress pants shot up 11.6 percent, to 62.1 million, in contrast to an 11 percent drop the previous year, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm in Port Washington, N.Y.
"We've seen a definite increase in suits," said Jim Dowling, a sales associate at Joseph Scafidi Inc., a custom tailor and shirtmaker in Cleveland. "Suits and ties are definitely on the comeback. I think people are starting to realize that there's a global economy now and you gain more respect and credibility for looking sharp."
That is music to the ears of the fashion-conscious Mr. Nasr of Novell. "A pair of khakis and a short-sleeve polo shirt just doesn't cut it anymore," he said. "Now, in the last year, I see people lining up at Nordstrom and making trips to the airport just to get their shoes shined."
To be sure, America is not returning to the conformism of the Eisenhower years, when dark suits, black wingtips, white shirts and dark ties were de rigueur in the mostly male white-collar work force. For one thing, business suits today are more comfortable, lightweight and not as stiff-looking as those made just a few years ago.
And experimentation -- for example, mixing an expensive suit with a polo shirt or turtleneck sweater -- remains an option for even the most fastidious dressers. "Elements of both dress and casual are coming together," Mr. Wolfe of the Doneger Group said. "What we did is learn how nice it is to dress up and still be comfortable in our clothes. It's the new era of smart-casual."
Even so, he expects the shift to start to accelerate. "We never hear about the term 'interview suit' anymore, but we will," he said. "Interview suits will be back in our vocabularies and in our closets."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
I.B.M. Plans To Expand An Alliance In Germany

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
International Business Machines and SAP, the German business software giant, are planning to substantially broaden their longstanding, if not always smooth, partnership over the next three years.
 The new links, which will be made public today at an SAP-sponsored trade show in Orlando, Fla., include an I.B.M. commitment to train more than 5,000 of its service employees on the entire suite of SAP products that support business activities on the Internet. In the past, I.B.M.'s work with SAP had been heavily focused on SAP's popular enterprise resource planning, or E.R.P. software, an integrated package of basic business software programs for traditional corporate computer users. 
 In addition, the new agreement calls for crosslicensing and software development efforts by both companies that will integrate SAP more closely with Websphere, I.B.M.'s package of so-called middleware programs that help server computers play host to business applications on the Internet. And SAP will tell customers that I.B.M. Global Services is qualified to act as host and to maintain their SAP applications in its computer centers. 
I.B.M.'s relationship with SAP products helped generate more than $2 billion in sales of I.B.M. hardware, software and services to SAP customers last year, said Steven Mills, I.B.M.'s senior vice president for software. I.B.M. was involved in one way or another in roughly 26 percent of all of SAP's sales. Mr. Mills said the new links were expected to add five percentage points to that share over three years, generating more than $400 million in new revenue.
Mr. Mills and Stephan Rossius, SAP's vice president in charge of alliances, said in a joint telephone interview that the expansion of their partnership was driven by demand from customers for complete solutions to the complicated task of moving business activities to the Internet. "It's reinforced to both companies the need to reinvest in our relationship," Mr. Mills said. 
SAP, which had revenue last year of 6.27 billion euros, is based in Waldorf, Germany. It has been working with I.B.M. since the late 1970's, but the relationship was strained during the 1990's when I.B.M.'s software group was trying to sell products that competed with SAP's. In recent years though, I.B.M. has sold off or dropped much of its software portfolio and concentrated on forming partnerships with leading software vendors. 
I.B.M. has enlisted more than 50 software vendors in its strategic partner program, which is based on three-year deals that set specific growth targets and investment requirements for both parties. SAP's products compete with many of them, though, which could create new tensions for I.B.M. managers overseeing partner relationships with companies like Siebel Systems, which is best known for customer management software; Ariba, a procurement software vendor; and I2, a major I.B.M. partner in the supply chain management sector.
"This represents a new dimension in the SAP relationship," said John Madden of Summit Strategies in Boston, one of several analysts I.B.M. informed of its planned announcement. "I.B.M. has good intentions but some partners will be worried."
Some customers may also be a bit confused. Through its partnership program, I.B.M. has been championing the idea that customers should buy "best of breed" software programs from different vendors that I.B.M. or other consultants can then help them integrate. SAP's sales pitch that customers are better off with a broad suite of products designed by one company to fit together sounds much more like the approach of Oracle, an archrival of I.B.M. in the database sector.
"It's a validation of our strategy," said Mark Jarvis, chief marketing officer at Oracle.
Analysts say the clearest benefit of the new links for I.B.M. will be the added support for Websphere. The Websphere family of products is growing rapidly but still trails BEA Systems, based in San Jose, Calif., in the lucrative market for software that provides the underlying infrastructure for e-business applications. 
SAP also stands to gain on the e-business front. "The conventional wisdom is that they were slow to embrace e-business," Mr. Madden said. "They've turned the corner and this will push them further along."

HEADLINE: Europe's East Sees AIDS On the March 

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: DEBE, Poland, June 9 

 BODY:
It did not seem pleasant for Krystyna Sokolowska to put her life on display -- the youthful year of heroin addiction that led to catching the virus that causes AIDS, to shuffling around homes for the infected that were never popular with scared neighbors. 
 But she agreed to do so at a conference here as an early example of a trend that is alarming health officials in the region: How intravenous drug use is driving an epidemic of people becoming H.I.V. positive in Eastern Europe, and especially in the countries that used to be part of the Soviet Union. Nowhere else in the world is the virus that causes AIDS spreading so quickly, and this is the only place where the sharing of needles during drug use is the major route of infection, United Nations experts say. 
 When Ms. Sokolowska found out she was H.I.V. positive, in October 1989, AIDS was hardly known in Eastern Europe, except as a disease of gay men in the United States. 
"Well, it definitely did not make me feel American," said Ms. Sokolowska, now 32, who lived at the time in Silesia, in southwestern Poland.
But changes since the collapse of Communism -- say health officials who gathered here, just outside Warsaw, at the first regional conference on AIDS -- have created conditions ripe for the spread of the virus: Borders opened, burrowing out nearby trade routes from the major supplier of heroin, Afghanistan. Police control, which brutally curbed prostitution and drug use in the past, receded. At the same time, the economic troubles in the transition out of Communism have left many young people without jobs. 
Now the number of people becoming H.I.V positive has been rising steeply. Thought to be first in the region were two brothers in Ukraine, businessmen who traveled and dabbled in drugs, health officials said. The first sizable number of people found to be H.I.V. positive occurred in late 1995 in the Ukrainian port cities of Odessa and Nikolayev. 
Now, in Ukraine, there are 38,632 people registered as H.I.V. positive -- two thirds of them drug users -- while there were fewer than 300 before 1995. In Russia, 58,000 people were reported to be H.I.V. positive in 2000 -- triple the number in 1999 and two times all the cases reported since 1987, according to Russian health officials here. 
And while in some countries, like here in Poland, the numbers are relatively flat, many others show similar increases.
"It looks much more like a regional pattern," said Dr. Karl L. Dehne, the United Nations AIDS program's coordinator for Central and Eastern Europe. "All regions in Ukraine are affected. Most regions in Russia. The Baltics are affected. Now the first outbreaks are happening in Central Asia. 
"In intensity and geographic spread, it's evolving," he said. "It's worrying." The overall rates of infection in the region are still low when compared with Africa, where the AIDS epidemic is by far the worst, according to United Nations officials. While the number of pregnant women who test positive in some African countries is near 25 percent, the number is less than 1 percent in Ukraine, one of the worst-hit former Soviet states. 
But people at the conference said the limited scope has, in some ways, made containing the virus's spread more difficult, because the problem is perceived to be confined to small groups of social outcasts like drug users. The H.I.V. rates have also been creeping up among prostitutes, especially in Moscow, St. Petersburg and Kaliningrad. And drug use in prisons is high. 
"Intravenous drug users and commercial sex workers are blamed for spreading the epidemic, so there is a backlash," said Robin Montgomery, an official with AIDS Infoshare, a group in Russia that works with prostitutes, among others. 
But health officials here said there are early signs of the disease spreading beyond drug addicts and prostitutes. Dr. Olena Purick, a consultant with the International H.I.V./AIDS Alliance in Ukraine, said she is seeing more cases of the virus being transmitted not by drug use but through sexual contact -- from men who are drug users to wives or girlfriends who are not. 
"These were absolutely normal women," Dr. Purick said. "That was a new phenomenon in Ukraine. In maybe Africa or Asia you have the same thing. But it was new for us."
The conference, which attracted health officials from 27 countries in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet states, was sponsored by several groups that support containing the virus that causes AIDS through what is known as "harm reduction." In theory, this approach aims less at law enforcement than at finding ways to improve the health of people who use drugs or are H.I.V. positive and to check the virus's spread.
Other countries, they said, do not support initiatives like needle exchange or methadone treatment because such programs are perceived as helping drug users in their habits. 
"It's not about needles," argued Kasia Malinowska-Sempruch, director of the International Harm Reduction Development Program, part of the Open Society Institute, a sponsor of the conference. "Needles are part of a bigger package to help incredibly mistreated, marginalized drug users."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 15, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Wednesday with an article about the spread of HIV infection among intravenous drug users in Eastern Europe carried an erroneous figure for Russia. While statistics vary, the latest United Nations estimates suggest that intravenous drug users account for 50 percent to 80 percent of new infections in Russia, not 11 percent.

HEADLINE: A City Parks Revival 

 BODY:
With great fanfare, Madison Square Park reopened yesterday, offering a quiet and elegant refuge in Manhattan's bustling Midtown. The facelift for this 19th-century oasis is a credit to civic-minded neighbors and corporations, which raised enough money and pushed enough of the right levers for a quick and thorough restoration of the six-acre park near the old Flatiron Building. But the revival of Madison Square is also a vivid reminder of the shabby state of many of the public parks elsewhere in New York City. The restoration of these vital public spaces is an issue that ought to rank much higher on the agenda of every mayoral candidate. 
 The percentage of the city budget spent on the maintenance and operation of the city's 1,700 parks has dropped dramatically over the last 15 years. Private donations have grown, but two-thirds of these have gone to two parks in Manhattan, Central Park and Bryant Park. For those parks without angels, the city has been an exceptionally stingy custodian. After years of cuts, there is now only one park worker for every 43 acres of parkland, one gardener for every 1,000 acres. Since 1970, full-time park staff has been reduced by two-thirds. 
 An advocacy group called Parks 2001 has undertaken in recent months to define the scope of the problem in an effort to persuade the political structure to give the parks the attention they deserve. Photographic evidence assembled by the group presents a devastating portrait of a system in crisis -- broken water fountains, soccer fields littered with trash or huge stones, locked rest rooms, piles of garbage. An oily stream oozes along the entrance to Red Hook Park in Brooklyn. An abandoned homeless camp litters Claremont Park in the Bronx.
The parks are not, as many politicians believe, a frill. They are the city's lungs, essential components of its health and quality of life -- cleaning the air, breaking the heat, breathing life into a neighborhood. They can provide recreation and a crime-free environment for schoolchildren and their families, an avocation for gardeners caught in their boxy apartments. Safe and improved parks can also improve surrounding real estate values, which in turn improve city revenues.
With the city electing a new mayor and City Council this fall, parks now belong high on the political agenda. Education, public safety, the economy -- all are obvious priorities. But what the politicians overlook is that healthy, attractive parks can help the city make good on all three of those goals. The parks, finally, deserve their due.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Outlast an Early Sell-Off to Close Little Changed

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The stock market recovered yesterday from an early sell-off. The main gauges ended little changed, as investors regained their footing after Nokia became the latest technology company to warn that its second-quarter earnings and revenue would be weaker than expected.
 Some analysts noted that stocks had picked up strength after William McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said in a speech that the economy was likely to improve in the second half of this year and in 2002 and that inflation was not a matter of concern now. 
 "Even though the numbers don't show up, and certainly the earnings are not anything to talk about and the economic numbers remain dismal, the fact is that the first rate cuts that we got back in early January, the 50 basis points, should now begin to kick in," said Peter Cardillo, chief strategist at Westfalia Investments. "The fruits of the lowering of interest rates should begin to show up." 
After falling as much as 3 percent yesterday morning, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index closed down just 0.8 point, at 2,169.95. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.29 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,948.38. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.46 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,255.85. A surge in General Electric helped lead the Dow and S.& P. higher as investors speculated that its planned acquisition of Honeywell International might be in trouble.
Nokia, the world's largest maker of mobile phones, unnerved the stock market yesterday after it projected that its sales growth would be slightly below 10 percent, instead of the expected 20 percent. It also lowered its second-quarter earnings forecast. The American depository receipts of Nokia fell $5.45, to $23.26.
Nokia's disclosure came in the heart of the earnings preannouncement season, when companies provide projections of their financial results ahead of the end of the quarter. Several companies, including Juniper Networks, have cut their forecasts in recent days, raising investors' concerns about weakening corporate profits.
Shares of Nokia's competitors dropped as well, with Ericsson falling 20 cents, to $5.30, and Motorola slipping 86 cents, to $14.
G.E. gained $1.37, to $48.77. The European Commission is evaluating the proposed G.E. takeover of Honeywell, and there was speculation that the commission's demands might be too stringent. Honeywell fell $1.78, to $43.47.
Shares of Affymetrix, a maker of gene chips that are used in biotechnology research, plummeted $14.94, to $26.01, after executives warned that its revenue would be below previous estimates. 
Biotechnology companies were mixed yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration rejected plans by two drug makers to develop a medicine to treat prostate cancer. Amgen gained 17 cents, to $66.92, but Praecis Pharmaceuticals dropped $6.04, to $16.55. 
Analysts said investors would continue to be skittish in their trading until the economy showed signs of sustained improvement. 
"We're going to do this for a while -- up and down and up and down and up and down -- until we get some clear information one way or the other that things are picking up or that they are not," said Mary Lisanti, chief investment officer at ING Pilgrim Investment. "They will pick up, but the question is do they pick up in the fall or do they pick up in the summer? That's the issue."
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices rose yesterday on speculation that falling corporate profits will prolong the economic slowdown and prompt at least two more Federal Reserve interest rate reductions this year.
Investors are "pushing the recovery to later this year, or even the first quarter" of 2002, said Keith Karlawish, who oversees $3 billion at BB&T Asset Management in Raleigh, N.C. That helps bonds because the Fed is set to cut its target rate to as low as 3.5 percent from 4 percent, he said.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note rose 10/32, to 98 4/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.25 percent from 5.29 percent on Monday.
The 30-year bond rose 17/32, to 96 2/32. Its yield fell to 5.65 percent from 5.69 percent.

HEADLINE: Nokia Lowers Forecasts; Its Shares Dive 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 12 

 BODY:
Nokia of Finland, the world's leading maker of mobile phones, warned today that its sales and earnings would fall short of estimates in the second quarter, surprising investors and sending the company's stock down more than 22 percent.
 For a time, markets in Europe and the United States fell broadly in response, then recouped much of their intraday losses. 
 The warning by Nokia, whose fortunes were once seen as almost impervious to a global economic slowdown, illustrates the depth of the troubles threatening Europe's vaunted lead in wireless technology. Many of the leading telecommunications companies are struggling with huge debts from last year's auctions of wireless licenses and grappling with delays in introducing a new generation of wireless technology. Their troubles are now being felt throughout the industry, from producers of computer chips to makers of network equipment and handsets. 
"These are the kinds of earnings shocks we're going to see a lot more of out of Europe over the next few months," David Bowers, chief global investment strategist for Merrill Lynch, said on the CNBC cable channel. "There's no doubt in my mind that the European economies are slowing very, very fast, and we don't think the technology sector in Europe is immune to what's happened in the U.S."
In a clear sign that the expansion of wireless technology has been reined in, British Telecommunications and Deutsche Telekom, huge former state monopolies, announced a deal today to cut the costs of building new networks by sharing base stations, masts and antennas and save as much as $4 billion over the next 10 years.
The announcement followed a statement by German regulators last week that phone companies would be able to share parts of the networks for so-called third-generation phones and other mobile devices that are linked to the Internet at much higher speeds than are currently possible.
Adding to the troubles of technology stocks, shares of the Vodafone Group, the world's largest wireless operator, slid to a 30-month low here today as "lock-in agreements" with KPN Telcom of the Netherlands and Telia of Sweden expired, meaning that the two companies might now sell some 366 million Vodafone shares they are holding. The possibility of shares flooding the market sent Vodafone stock down 3.7 percent, to $:1.680 -- less than half its record high of $:4.015 in March 2000.
But that drop paled in comparison with the plunge in Nokia shares after the company halved its previous forecast that second-quarter sales would grow 20 percent. Nokia shares closed down 7.87 euros in Helsinki, to 26.52 euros, or $22.62. In New York, its American depository receipts -- each representing one share of common stock -- fell $5.45, or nearly 19 percent, to $23.26.
Just a year ago, Nokia reported a 55 percent surge in second-quarter sales, cementing a reputation as one of the few telecommunications companies strong enough to reward its investors consistently.
Today, it reduced its earnings forecast for the second quarter, to the range of 0.15 to 0.17 euro a share, compared with a previous expectation of 0.2 euros. In the corresponding period of 2000, each Nokia share earned 0.21 euro.
"Events catch up even with the best companies," said John Tysoe, an analyst with WestLB Panmure here. "It would have been increasingly difficult for them to buck the trend."
Nokia explained its troubles by saying that "the general economic slowdown in the U.S. has recently shown signs of extending to other regions and to the wireless communications industry as a whole." In a statement, its chief executive, Jorma Ollila, also blamed the wireless industry's faltering efforts to harness the Internet for mobile use and less aggressive marketing by mobile communications operators.
Nokia controls some 35 percent of the world market for wireless handsets. In April, it estimated that 450 million to 500 million handsets would be sold this year compared with 405 million in 2000, but it toned down that forecast today to say that growth would be "very modest."
Nokia is vulnerable because, like other manufacturers, its sales rely on customers' regularly upgrading old models and trying innovative new phones. But many customers now say that they are holding on to their old handsets as they await more advanced technology providing a wider range of services and speedier Internet access.
Beyond that, in the heyday of mobile phone growth until a year or so ago, producers effectively subsidized the cost of new handsets as they scrambled for market share -- seeking to lure customers onto their networks and their billing systems by offering handsets at discounted prices, sometimes as low as $30. But, as companies like British Telecom confront huge debts and slowing business, they are less prepared to subsidize such costs, further reducing the demand for new handsets from Nokia and its chief rivals, Ericsson of Sweden and Motorola of the United States.
Shares of Ericsson fell 5.7 percent today in Stockholm; in New York, Motorola declined 86 cents, or 5.8 percent, to $14. British Telecom and Deutsche Telekom closed modestly higher after announcing their agreement to share parts of their new wireless networks. Both have suffered large losses in market value in recent months.
Some analysts viewed the deal as a sign of weakness after the two companies and other European telecommunications carriers incurred huge debts, bidding some $100 billion for the third-generation licenses -- only to find that they had overpaid for the permits long before they acquired the technology to exploit them.
In the last few months, British Telecom and NTT DoCoMo of Japan have been forced into embarrassing delays in introducing ballyhooed third-generation projects, and most companies say that the networks are unlikely to be up and running commercially before 2003.
European regulators initially opposed shared networks because the savings could give operators an edge in the price wars that are likely to erupt as these companies seek to recruit third-generation customers.
Today's agreement means that British Telecom's Viag Interkom unit in Germany will share masts with Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile, while Deutsche Telekom's British unit, One2One, will share equipment with British Telecom's BT Cellnet. 
"This deal doesn't threaten either of them," Mr. Tysoe of WestLB Panmure said, because Deutsche Telekom is much bigger than Viag Interkom and BT Cellnet is aiming at a richer customer base than One2One. "Both sides of the deal are positive." BT Cellnet is the No. 2 wireless operator in Britain while One2One ranks fourth. Similarly, T-Mobile is Germany's second largest while Viag Interkom is fourth. Vodafone is the leader in both countries.
The deal with Deutsche Telekom raised questions about how Vodafone would respond. The company declined to comment. Vodafone thinks that it "can build their networks without compromise to optimize those networks for their own customers," Mr. Tysoe said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Lucent Credit Rating Is Cut To Junk Status by S.& P.
Standard & Poor's lowered the credit rating of Lucent Technologies to junk-bond status, a move that could make it more costly for the company to borrow money.
 While the downgrade was expected, analysts said it could be more than a symbolic blow. Some investors voluntarily avoid buying securities issued by a company that is not considered investment grade; others are forbidden to do so by their own rules. Page C4. 

H.M.O. Suits Are Dismissed in Part
A federal judge partly dismissed lawsuits that challenged the managed care practices of six big health insurers but said he would allow plaintiffs to amend their cases. C6.

Contrasting News for Two Drugs
Two leading biotechnology companies reported contrasting news. Amgen said the F.D.A. had rejected a new drug for prostate cancer that it was developing with Praecis Pharmaceuticals. But Biogen said that its psoriasis drug succeeded in clinical trials and that the company would apply later this year for permission to sell the drug in the United States and Europe. Shares of Praecis plunged $6.04, or 27 percent, to $16.55. Amgen's stock, after initially falling, closed at $66.92 a share, up 17 cents. Biogen rose $1.45, to $64.97. C4.

Stocks Rebound From Early Sell-Off
The stock market recovered from an early sell-off caused by a profit warning from Nokia. The Nasdaq composite index closed down 0.83 point, to 2,169.95. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.29 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,948.38, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.46 points, to 1,255.85. C8.

Auto Insurer to Leave New Jersey
State Farm Indemnity, New Jersey's largest insurer of motorists, said that it planned to withdraw from the auto insurance business in the state because of persistent losses. B1.

Programmers Leave Disney Unit
An influential group of computer programmers led by Alan Kay is leaving Walt Disney's research division, where the team has worked on an educational programming system for the last five years. C5.

I.B.M. and SAP to Expand Links
I.B.M. and SAP, the German business software giant, are planning to broaden their longstanding partnership substantially. C4.

A Voracious Craving for Energy
Meyer Feldberg, dean of the Columbia University Business School, said he derived energy from several sources, including going out socially with his wife several times a week to keeping in touch with friends. "You need a lot of fuel to live and work in the city with the most energy anywhere and to make things happen," he said. Also, he tries to surround himself with talented, upbeat people. The Boss. C5.

Ford Turns to Six Sigma for Help
Ford's hard-won reputation for quality has been tarnished by setbacks. Now it has seized on Six Sigma, a quality-control method for increasing efficiency. Management. C5.

Argentina Sells $700 Million in Bills
Argentina's government succeeded in auctioning $700 million in treasury bills at far lower interest rates than it has been forced to pay in recent months. World Business, Section W.

More Cutbacks Hurt Travel Industry
As corporate travel departments react to impending sags in profits and put the brakes on spending, airlines and hotels are feeling the pinch. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C6.
