HEADLINE: WAY OUT WEST; 
There's Silicon in Them Thar Hills, or Will Be Soon

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: PROVO, Utah 

 BODY:
IN the 1860's, this Mormon settlement lost its bid to be a transcontinental railroad stop. This time, it is smack dab on the tracks of technological progress.
 Not that the world passed it by in the meantime. Even as farms and mines multiplied, Provo kept its local flavor. 
 "There was a time when you walked down the street where you knew everyone," said Mel Hudman, 69, who has been having lunch at the Provo Pharmacy, established 1885, since he was a student at Brigham Young University in the 50's. Despite the presence of Wal-Mart and shopping malls, the downtown still has family-owned businesses in red brick buildings built more than 50 years ago. 
Now, however, this city nestled against snowcapped mountains has undergone a transition from industrial to high technology. Geneva Steel, whose furnaces once spewed smoke into the Utah Valley, used to be the area's largest employer. Now, it has been overshadowed by high technology. Spurred by Brigham Young University and Novell spinoffs, Provo and the surrounding valley have become home to several technology start-ups in the last decade. Today, Brigham Young students do research for Adobe Photoshop and are building a virtual tour of the 2002 Winter Olympic sites.
Provo's future can be seen in its neighbor to the north, Orem. A complex built there by the software company WordPerfect is home to a little more than a dozen technology companies, and the orchards of Orem have been replaced by cookie-cutter houses, malls and schools -- transformations that garner mixed reactions.
"I guess all of us live with a little bit of nostalgia," Mr. Hudman said. "I'm from a rural background. Naturally I don't like to see the farmland going to city, but the developers think it is wonderful."
There is little farmland left. In the last 15 years, Provo and Orem have grown together -- now often represented by a hyphenated name -- and pushed north along Interstate 15, engulfing other towns. The population of the Provo-Orem region jumped nearly 40 percent, to 369,000, in a decade.
"Driving around here, it is identical to my eyes to Silicon Valley 30 years ago, the mix of residential, industrial and rural," said Charles Connoy, who is the chief information officer at PowerQuest, a technology company in Orem, and who worked for I.B.M. in 1968 in San Jose, Calif. 
That mix will continue to shift toward development if businesses succeed in turning the region into an annex for Silicon Valley -- or, as they like to say, a "grow-out center." 
Utah's governor, Michael O. Leavitt, makes monthly trips to Silicon Valley to lure more companies to Utah. "It has become clear to me that Silicon Valley has a challenge," Mr. Leavitt said. "They have reached natural boundaries geographically. Traffic has become a huge problem. Those have become significant inhibitors." 
The pitch to Silicon Valley decision makers: Salt Lake City is cheaper than Seattle, closer than Austin, not as hot as Phoenix or as Albuquerque, and the ski slopes are much closer to downtown than in Denver.
"We have workers, we have space, we have proximity," Governor Leavitt said. In the last couple years, Utah has attracted a spectrum of technology facilities: from eBay's main customer service center to Intel's new research operation, which is to have 8,000 employees. 
"Plus we have electricity," said James Oyler, chief executive of Evans & Sutherland, a computer graphics company that is considered the first generation of Utah's technology companies.
In addition, Salt Lake City is a Delta Air Lines hub and less than 90 minutes by air from Silicon Valley. About two dozen flights connect Salt Lake City and the Bay Area every day. The 8:15 a.m. flight to San Francisco is crowded with executives on their way to work who will fly back that night.
Governor Leavitt is considered a technophile himself. When eBay narrowed the finalists for its service center to three Western cities, the governor called the chief executive of eBay, Meg Whitman, and asked her to check how many other governors had eBay accounts.
Today, 12 percent to 15 percent of Utah's economy is based on high technology, dominated by small and medium-size companies in software, electronics and biotechnology. Venture capital investment in Utah was nearly $1.1 billion in 2000, up 70 percent from $598 million in 1999 and up about 400 percent from $219 million in 1998, according to MountainWest, a nonprofit business group that promotes development in Utah.
When Ray Norda, the former chief executive of Novell, graduated from the University of Utah after World War II with a degree in engineering, he could not find a job in Utah. "I had to leave the state because no jobs were available," Mr. Norda said.
Now, Salt Lake City periodically makes its way onto lists of the best cities for business or technology (ranking No. 3 on Fortune magazine's list in 1998), and has ranked among the best cities to live because of its low cost of living and outdoor activities like skiing, hiking and mountain biking.
As prominent as the mountains are, but more controversial, is the state's Mormon presence. One effect is an unusual demographic profile: with a population of 2.2 million statewide, Utah has the highest birthrate in the country and the greatest percentage of people younger than 18.
"We need to find a place for these people to work," said Christopher Roybal, the president of the Economic Development Corporation of Utah. To expand its technological work force, the Utah Legislature recently allocated about $100 million to universities so they could double the state's number of computer science and engineering graduates in five years and triple them in eight. (Some of this allocation is to be matched by the universities.)
Despite its racial homogeneity -- Utah is 91.1 percent white -- the large number of people who do two-year missions with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has led to a linguistic diversity in which residents speak everything from Spanish to Japanese to Farsi.
There is also a different work ethic, with far lower rates of turnover. "If you look at the resumes in Silicon Valley, they're littered with job after job, as opposed to stability," said Bill Wesemann, the president and chief executive of NextPage, who commutes by air from Silicon Valley to the company's headquarters in Lehi, north of Orem.
But perceptions of Mormon culture may also be a stumbling block. Salt Lake City is about half Mormon, while the Utah Valley area is about 90 percent. Critics say that if Utah wants to become a top-tier technology center, it needs to change its conservative culture.
Consider the state's liquor laws. Bruce Albertson, the former chief executive of Iomega, which makes the Zip drive, who resigned in May, said in an article in The Salt Lake Tribune that the liquor laws made it difficult to attract out-of-state workers. 
Others agree. 
"Despite the draw of mountains and the wildlife, the liquor laws will be the kiss of death for Utah to be able to compete in the high-tech world," said Steve Pronovost, a biotechnology researcher who moved with his wife to Salt Lake City from the Bay Area three years ago because of the outdoor lifestyle. 
"There's a permeation of Mormon culture into every aspect of life," Mr. Pronovost said, "which I think affects day-to-day life here." 
Starbucks has a thin presence in Utah because the Mormon culture frowns on the drinking of caffeine. Utah's family mores have also been cited as an impediment for attracting workers who are single and non-Mormon.
"Religion is definitely still a barrier for companies who have no operations in Utah," said Dennis Donovan, a corporate location consultant.
More than 80 percent of Utah's population growth has come from its high birthrate. Many of the transplants are Mormons from other parts of the country. But that could change after the Olympics and more people learn about the Salt Lake area. 
"I have mixed emotions about the Olympics," said Kent Prows, a corporate strategist for Novell. "We have been able to keep this quiet. But when people come here it'll explode."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Lucent's Credit Rating Downgraded by S.& P.

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Standard & Poor's lowered the credit rating of Lucent Technologies to junk status in a move yesterday that may make it somewhat more costly for the beleaguered company to borrow money. 
 S.& P. said in a statement that falling demand for Lucent's communications equipment products would make it harder for the company to increase cash flow and report a profit. The move by S.& P., which had already said it was considering lowering Lucent's rating, was widely expected. 
 "We knew this was a possibility," Mary Lou Ambrus, a Lucent spokeswoman, said. "We don't expect it to have a significant impact on our business."
But analysts said the downgrade to junk-bond status could be more than a symbolic blow to Lucent, which was once held in esteem as one of the nation's leading technology companies. Some investors voluntarily avoid purchasing securities issued by a company that is not considered investment grade by large credit rating companies; others are forbidden to do so by their own rules.
Many investors have already been treating Lucent as if it had junk status for several months; the pricing of its bonds reflects that treatment. And in February, Lucent's debtors provided the company with $4.5 billion in short-term credit lines only after it agreed to conditions normally reserved for junk-status borrowers.
The immediate impact of the cut in Lucent's rating by S.& P. to BB+ from BBB- may increase some of the interest rates the company pays on routine financing costs, but the shift will probably not affect Lucent's larger borrowing needs, analysts said. Fortunately for Lucent, the company raised a large amount of money earlier this year with its banks.
"Every notch down increases the difficulty of raising capital," said Anthony Klarman, a debt analyst at Deutsche Bank. "But this is more of a formality than anything else." 
Still, the lowering of Lucent's debt rating highlights the company's need to cut costs further and raise additional money. Last week Lucent said it would offer early retirement packages to more than 10,000 managers in the United States, in addition to its plan to eliminate 10,000 jobs by the end of July. 
Lucent needs to raise $2 billion of nonoperating cash by the end of September, or its spinoff of Agere Systems, a chip-making company, could run into problems. 
Lucent is in negotiations with several companies to sell its fiber optic operations, but with the downturn in the telecommunications market it is unlikely that the unit will fetch more than $4 billion, down from earlier estimates of as much as $7 billion, according to a report by Joseph Wolf, an analyst at UBS Warburg.
One Lucent spinoff, Avaya Inc., which makes office phone equipment, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 3,000 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force. Avaya issued a statement that it expected sales this quarter to fall 4 percent to 6 percent. Avaya was spun off from Lucent in September 2000 as part of the company's restructuring.

HEADLINE: ABC's of EBay: Auction, Bid And Conquer 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY 

 BODY:
IT was 9 a.m. on a Sunday here. Hundreds of people had gathered, mostly middle-aged or older, though there was an occasional young couple who had brought their toddler. 
 Speakers testified to how their lives had been changed by the community they had discovered. It is, they said, a powerful grass-roots movement that is transforming America and beyond. "We're trying to take over the world, and we want your help," one said, and listeners nodded in agreement. 
 A sense of fellowship permeated the gathering. Some had long since joined the community, while others were being introduced by friends. The event may have been evangelistic, but the topic of discussion was not spirituality. It was eBay. 
From coast to coast, in a different city almost every weekend, hundreds of people gather for eBay University, a roving crusade for the eBay philosophy. Last time it was Charlotte. After Salt Lake City, it moved on to Minneapolis, and after that, Cincinnati. Around the country, there has been an outpouring of interest in the company's year-old outreach effort, which is part instructional and part philosophical.
On average, 500 people pay $25 each for the privilege of attending classes, on one or two days, on how to buy and sell better on eBay. 
The hotel setting, the lackluster pastries and the overhead PowerPoint presentations give eBay University the air of a professional convention mixed with a spiritual revival. Classes range from the basic, like "Browsing and Buying," to the more advanced, like "Improve Your Listing With Photos/HTML."
The audience is hobbyists, homemakers and entrepreneurs. The instructors are eBay employees and enthusiasts who consult or write books about the auction site. They share their eBay successes and disappointments. For some, eBay is entertainment. For others, a livelihood. 
"I don't think you see anyone here not smiling," said Stephen Higginson, who makes his living selling computer equipment on eBay, after he took the Advanced Selling Tips class. "We know something that the average public doesn't know. We're free." 
For Mr. Higginson, eBay is not simply a Web site but a lifestyle that will soon give him the freedom to be a stay-at-home father. 
"EBay has changed my life," said Mr. Higginson, who is an avid buyer as well as seller. His largest purchase was a 1993 Isuzu Rodeo sport utility vehicle for $4,000. The independence theme is often repeated in the classes and in the hallways between sessions. 
Only a fraction of the attendees are eBay PowerSellers, an elite status for certain high-volume sellers that entitles them to special services. Many of the rest, like Mark Lee of Eagle Mountain, Utah, are aspiring sellers looking to eBay to change their lives.
"I want eBay to replace my income," said Mr. Lee, who has turned video equipment sales on eBay into a family endeavor. His wife monitors his e-mail while he is at work as a video technician, and his children help him take photos of his items.
"You hear a lot of variations on being down on the luck: between careers, out of money, not sure what to do," said Jim Griffith, who was one of eBay's earliest employees and has become what the company calls an eBay Ambassador, traveling around the country to spread the gospel of eBay. "Then they find a way to turn the Internet into a tool not only to earn an income but feel like they have a purpose in life." 
"I really believe that the world needs to know more about this kind of community," Mr. Higginson said. "This is a very unique community. There is nothing like it anywhere." 
Since its creation five years ago as a site for trading Pez dispensers, eBay has lodged itself in the cultural and economic consciousness of an Internet generation. The number of registered users has grown to 29 million. 
EBay University was created by the eBay educational department last June as a way to reach out to eBay users, or "community members" as they are called, said Tom Cotton, director of offline education at eBay. 
In a community built by users with ID's like luv2shop and flygirl, some are drawn to eBay University for the novelty of a fellowship based on physical objects.
"EBay is something where everybody is invisible since it's on a computer," said Gayle Nikolaisen of Kearns, Utah, as she looked around. "To see somebody visually is kind of a neat thing." Mrs. Nikolaisen was waiting with two of her sons to attend a class on using eBay software. She is a PowerSeller and sold a 1960's Liddle Kiddles infant's toothbrush for $380 last fall. 
Life philosophy aside, the classes focus on the nuts and bolts of eBay strategies. The instruction is part marketing advice ("L@@K!!!" and "WOW!!!" are a waste of valuable title real estate), part Martha Stewart (how to build a mini photo studio) and part motivational speaking ("I quit my job to sell on eBay, and so can you"). 
After a lunch break, Marsha Collier, an eBay instructor and co-author of "eBay for Dummies," shared a treasure trove of tips with a class of about 100 people. "Use your mind," she said, wearing a black shirt with an eBay logo. "Think like a buyer." 
Her students listened attentively. They asked perceptive questions. They took notes diligently, scribbling in their notebooks or typing on their laptop computers or Palms. 
She offered strategies for bidders: stake out auctions that expire at midnight Pacific time (when the East Coast is in deep sleep); look for misspellings (Thimkpad and Mickey Mantel) because they can lead to items overlooked by other shoppers' searches.
For sellers: set minimum bids low to create momentum. Identify your target audience: Men or women? People who buy at home or at work? Look at the closing times and days of the week that produced the highest prices for similar items. The heaviest traffic times are 6 p.m. on Sunday, Monday morning and Thursday night (before the site goes down for maintenance during the wee hours of Friday morning). She encourages sellers to ship internationally.
"International buyers are serious buyers," she said to some skeptical audience members. "They never back out of the deal. I've never had an issue with foreign buyers. I love them." 
For advanced students, there is a class on Seller's Assistant Pro, software distributed by eBay that helps high-volume sellers automate the eBay sales cycle, from bulk listings through item shipping. David White, the instructor, had been a paramedic for 30 years when he quit to become a full-time software consultant for Seller's Assistant. He bounced around, telling sellers to play down tackiness. "Avoid using music and animated images," he advised. 
Originally known as Auction Assistant, Seller's Assistant changed to a subscription-based fee in February. That decision left many long-time users irate when Auction Assistant stopped working on their computers a few weeks ago: not subscribing meant not receiving necessary updates. 
This, and rising listing fees, have left some eBay users grumbling that eBay cares more about the bottom line than the community. 
On auction message boards, eBay users have complained about increased fees and growing competition from big businesses. I.B.M., Sun Microsystems, the United States Postal Service, the National Football League and the Oregon State government are among eBay's registered users. Rosie O'Donnell is a member, as is Utah's governor, Michael O. Leavitt. 
"I'm an eBay addict," said Governor Leavitt, in an interview in his office. He has bought things wholesale with his sons and then auctioned them one by one on eBay. "We were spending a fair amount of energy on this," he said.
He has even used his eBay credentials to his state's advantage. When eBay had narrowed down the finalists for its customer service center to three western cities including Salt Lake City, Governor Leavitt called Meg Whitman, chief executive of eBay, and told her to see how many of the other governors had eBay accounts.
His interest made a difference, eBay said. The customer service center opened in 1999 in Draper, a nearby suburb, and now has 500 employees. 
EBay users even have their own status symbol: not wealth or fame, but feedback from other users, which is protected jealously. Different standings are rewarded with colored stars. Currently, more than a dozen users have achieved the highest status, a shooting star that represents at least 10,000 positive comments. 
"It is definitely a pride issue," said Mark Lee, who said he had never received negative feedback. Mr. Lee said he had bent over backwards to protect his rating. Once, for example, after he inadvertently sold one more poster than he had, he bought an additional one at a loss to fill the order.
Mr. Lee said that selling on eBay was also an art. "Presenting an item is a delicate balance between being sophisticated yet appealing to buyers' bargain-hunting instinct," he said. "Also, there's color coordination. When I sell photos, the color of the background affects the price. When I have brighter colors, I have less bids. When I used more neutral tones that complemented the photo, the number of bids tripled for the same photo." 
Many participants agreed that a sense of interdependence with eBay emerges out of their buying and selling. In a morning class, the computer failed. The class looked up to see the overhead PowerPoint presentation replaced by a vacant blue screen. "Now you know how it feels when eBay goes down," a student chirped. 
"Exactly," the instructor said sheepishly.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rise, Holding Recession at Bay 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13 

 BODY:
Retail sales rose last month after increasing more in April than first reported, a sign consumers are still willing to spend and keep the economy out of a recession.
 Sales rose 0.1 percent after a 1.4 percent increase in April, which was the largest since January and bigger than the 0.8 percent rise initially estimated, the Commerce Department said. The April figure had been revised to a 1.1 percent gain earlier this month. 
 Retail sales increased at a 4.8 percent annual rate in the first two months of the second quarter, compared with a 5.2 percent first-quarter pace. May's gain was the fourth in the last five months even as unemployment and prices rose.
"Households seem committed to keeping the economy afloat," said Steven Wood, chief economist at Financial Oxygen Inc. in Walnut Creek, Calif. "Spending is holding up remarkably well given the emerging weakness in labor markets."
The May sales report is the first using a more detailed system for classifying businesses that are tracked by the government. For instance, electronics and appliance stores are now broken out, rather than being embedded in a broader category. Bars and restaurants continue to be included but in a new category of "food services."
The numbers in the report suggested that Federal Reserve officials might limit future interest rate reductions. Still, there is some risk an economic rebound will be slow in coming, Roger Ferguson, the vice chairman of the Fed, said today. And the Fed's latest regional economic report card showed the economy was little changed or had slowed in the last two months.
"We are in a period where the economy is growing quite slowly, and I believe that is still the case," Mr. Ferguson told the Senate Banking Committee at a hearing on his nomination to another term.
The Fed's so-called beige book of economic conditions said manufacturing "has declined or remained weak," construction "appears to have leveled off," and retail sales "have been slow to flat."
The report comes two weeks before Fed officials meet to decide whether to lower rates for a sixth time this year.
As for inflation, it continues to be contained, a separate report indicated. The Labor Department said prices of imported goods excluding petroleum fell 0.2 percent in May, the fourth consecutive monthly decline. Including petroleum, import prices increased 0.3 percent, the first rise in eight months.
The Commerce Department's report showed that excluding a decline at automobile dealers, retail sales rose 0.3 percent after a 1.1 percent increase in April.

HEADLINE: Backing Sought for Offshore Tax Initiative 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 13 

 BODY:
Tax officials from the United States and other countries ended a meeting here today and returned home to seek political agreement for proposals under which the United States and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development would cooperate on reducing tax revenue lost to offshore havens.
 "Many of the countries wish to go back to their governments to seek political backing for the proposals under discussion," said Nick Bray, a spokesman for the O.E.C.D. 
 Those proposals, made to secure American cooperation, are likely to include the removal of a threat of sanctions against offshore tax havens if they fail to commit themselves to requested changes by July 31.
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said last month that he had "serious reservations" about the plan by the O.E.C.D. to reduce "harmful tax practices" carried out by offshore tax centers. New agreements for the plan are likely to concentrate on greater transparency and exchange of information, which the United States supports.
The United States, which backed away from the initiative under lobbying from low-tax advocates, signaled today that its involvement in the talks did not mean that its stance had softened.
"It is not a softening, but a redirection," John Taylor, the Treasury under secretary for international affairs, said in a briefing for reporters.

HEADLINE: Archer Daniels in a Venture on Cooking Oil 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: DECATUR, Ill., June 13 

 BODY:
The Archer Daniels Midland Company is teaming with the Kao Corporation of Japan to make and market a cooking oil that is already a top seller in Japan, where health officials have said it may help to lower body fat. 
 The joint venture, announced today by Archer Daniels and its Japanese partner, will be based in Decatur, where Archer Daniels is based, and will be called ADM Kao L.L.C. Construction will begin this summer on a pilot plant that is intended to be running by November. 
 The plant will manufacture the oil, called diacylglycerol, and the joint venture will market it in North and South America, Europe, Australia and New Zealand. 
Archer Daniels said several clinical studies in Japan had shown that the oil assisted in lowering body fat content.
The company also said that the regulatory body in charge of health food products in Japan had approved the oil to manage serum triglycerides, or fat levels, in the blood after a meal. Controlling those levels could lead to less buildup of body fat. 
John McNamara, president of Archer Daniels, said that the company believed that the oil could become a major new product line with sales of more than $150 million. 
The oil, which is made from soybeans or canola seeds, can be used as a home cooking oil or an ingredient in packaged foods like frozen dinners, cookies, margarine, snacks and salad dressings, Archer Daniels said.
Marketed in Japan as Healthy Econa Oil, it has become the best-selling premium vegetable oil in that country, the companies said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Spate of Profit Warnings Sours the Mood on Wall St.

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The mood on Wall Street soured yesterday on a series of profit warnings that intensified worries that corporate earnings would remain weak into 2002.
 Blue-chip and technology stocks tumbled in a sell-off that accelerated as the session wore on. In contrast to their moves on Monday, bargain hunters failed to step in and reverse the downward momentum. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 76.76 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,871.62. Broader stock indicators also lost ground. The Nasdaq composite index slid 48.29 points, to 2,121.66, for a 2.2 percent loss, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.25 points, to 1,241.60, down 1.1 percent. 
Although investors had been expecting second-quarter results to be dismal, the severity of recent warnings as well as several layoff announcements unnerved them and raised worries that a recovery would not come by year-end.
"With the pressure of all these earnings preannouncements, which are going to continue unabated for the next few weeks, it's going to be very difficult for stocks to make progress," said James M. Meyer, director of research at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia.
The telephone equipment maker Avaya tumbled $1.64, to $13.36, after it lowered revenue estimates and announced nearly 3,000 job cuts late Tuesday, citing slow sales.
Investors also punished Maytag, sending it down 31 cents, to $32.17, after it said second-quarter earnings would be 25 percent lower than expected.
Some of the strongest selling came in technology. Intel dropped $1.07, to $29.06, for a loss of 3.6 percent.
But the camera and filmmaker Polaroid rose 20 cents, to $3.73, after it said that it would cut 2,000 jobs, or 25 percent of its work force, to reposition itself as a digital imaging company.
Stock prices have lost ground after a huge rally in the spring, when many investors were optimistic that earnings would improve by year-end. They have turned pessimistic, however, over the last few weeks, as earnings warnings have increased.
"People are now beginning to worry that the economy may not recover as early as they had been estimating," said Bill Barker, an investment strategy consultant at Dain Rauscher. "I also think some of this is due to the expiration of stock futures and options this week. This is something that occurs quarterly and usually causes a lot of volatility."
Also yesterday, there was lukewarm enthusiasm for the initial public offering of Kraft Foods, which was spun off by Philip Morris. Its shares rose 25 cents, to $31.25, after being priced at $31 Tuesday. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices fell slightly yesterday as cautious comments from a top Federal Reserve official and a Fed report showing economic stagnation left investors uncertain about how soon the economy would recover from a deep slump.
Government data showing retail sales grew modestly in May after a strong rise in April caused selling as it had assuaged some investor concerns that the slowdown, so far centered in manufacturing and business investment, would soon spread to consumer spending.
But those losses were mostly recouped by late afternoon, keeping shorter-dated yields pinned near their lowest levels in a month, after warnings about the economy from the Fed vice chairman, Roger W. Ferguson Jr., and the Fed's beige book report, which showed economic weakness across the nation in April.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 2/32 , to a price of 98 2/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.26 percent from 5.25 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 3/32 , to 95 31/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.66 percent from 5.65 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Polaroid to Cut 2,000 Jobs; Instant-Photo Woes Are Cited 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation, acknowledging that its ailing instant photography business is unlikely ever to recover, said yesterday that it would cut 2,000 jobs, at least half in Massachusetts. The cuts are in addition to the 945 jobs Polaroid said it would eliminate in February. Together the cuts will reduce the global work force of Polaroid, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., to 5,500 by the end of next year. 
 Polaroid would not elaborate, but analysts speculated that most of the cuts would come from sales and marketing, and that manufacturing operations would take the second-biggest hit. "I don't know why it took them so long to realize they are overloaded with people," said Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Buckman, Buckman & Reid. 
 Investor patience clearly has run out. With the exception of a small spike in May, Polaroid's shares have declined steadily this year. "The analysts have been saying, loud and clear, 'sell this stock,' " said Charles L. Hill, director of research at Thomson Financial/First Call. Shares closed yesterday at $3.73, up 20 cents. 
Although digital cameras have cut into every film company's sales, companies like Eastman Kodak can still make money from chemicals and paper to print snapshots. Polaroid's instant cameras both take and print pictures, so digital photography has dealt it a lethal blow. 
For a short while, Polaroid seemed to hold the digital juggernaut at bay. In 1999 Polaroid turned its first profit in four years, on the strength of hugely popular new cameras like the I-Zone, which made tiny pictures. But I-Zone sales have softened with the economy, and the margins on I-Zone films never approached those on Polaroid's older instant films. Moreover, real estate agents, insurance adjusters and other big users of Polaroid's older instant cameras have defected to digital cameras. 
The upshot is that Polaroid lost money in the last three quarters, and expects to lose money for the year.
"We've finally acknowledged that instant photography will continue to decline," said Herbert N. Colcord, a Polaroid spokesman. "Digital imaging is the primary factor causing that decline, but it also promises to be Polaroid's salvation."
Indeed, on May 31 Polaroid executives told analysts and reporters that it would trim costs associated with its instant photography business, and milk it for cash to pay down debt and finance its own digital technologies. At that meeting, Polaroid unveiled new digital technologies that would, for the first time, let Polaroid printers and papers make prints from other company's cameras. 
The new technologies, called Opal for multicolor printing and Onyx for monochrome printing, do not use conventional ink or toner cartridges. Instead, the printer uses a thermal process to thaw out molecules of frozen ink that have been imbedded in thinly coated papers. 
Analysts say the technology prints much faster than inkjet printers, and yields a picture of higher quality at a lower cost per print. They also say that the paper is thin enough to fit into hand-held wireless devices like cell phones, and can thus be used to print directly from such devices, once telecommunications companies master the art of transmitting and capturing wireless images.
"This is one of the most significant technologies to come out of this industry in 30 years," said Robert L. Renck of the brokerage firm R. L. Renck & Company, who is one of the few analysts who suggest that investors buy Polaroid stock. 
But it will be a while before Opal or Onyx add much to Polaroid's bottom line. Mr. Colcord said Polaroid will probably introduce a product based on the Onyx technology before the year is out, but that it is still negotiating with possible partners for future products. 
For now, Polaroid is racing against a financial clock. It has nearly $550 million in debt coming due in January. "We are working daily with our banks to restructure our debt, and we are not filing for bankruptcy," Mr. Colcord said.
"These programs will catch on, and Polaroid will show profits," said Mr. Yannas, another of the company's few fans. "This could be a $16 stock in 12 months."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
A study looks at an eagerly sought but hard-to-reach group.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
BOMBARDED by media messages since they were born, consumers 21 to 25 years old are a particularly difficult group for advertisers to reach. But as these consumers begin to spend money, they are also much sought after by marketers, who are looking for ways to understand them better.
 Many are finishing school or are recent graduates and have started a first full-time job. They are beginning to make large purchases like cars and furnishings. But basic characterizations only scratch the surface. How do they live and work? What about their friends and social activities? And what are their priorities? 
 "What you need, I think, to be profitable and have a chance at relating to this group is a very, very strong human sense of who they are," said John P. McManus, editorial director and chief operating officer at Simba Information in Stamford, Conn., a media and marketing trends newsletter that is part of the Media Central unit of Primedia.
"I think the 21-to-25 age group certainly has had, by volume, a higher level of exposure to media messages," he said. "There's been no generation coming of age in adulthood that has had such exposure to media messages."
To develop an in-depth look at this age group for strategic planners at agencies, PortiCo Research, a marketing research company, interviewed 16 young adults who live in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York. Staff members ranging from a cultural anthropologist to a brand planner delved into the daily lives of the group. The researchers explored their homes, workplaces and parties, met their roommates and friends, listened to their music and talked with them about decisions they made and plans they had.
The 43-page report that resulted, called "Coming of Age in the Age of Possibility," is intended to be sold to agencies, along with a 30-minute documentary that illuminates the participants through discussions of their impressions of themselves and the world around them. The report and the video cost $25,000, and include a presentation of the findings and a brainstorming session with a PortiCo staff member. PortiCo can also work with an agency or marketer to develop the findings further and do more specific research.
"One reason our clients, the ad agencies, the brands that we work with, are targeting this group is that they're young enough to still have a lot of room in their life to make decisions and old enough to be consumers," said Caroline Gibbons Barry, the president of PortiCo, which is based in Chicago and has offices in Los Angeles, New York and Paris.
This is the first study PortiCo has compiled independently to sell to agencies or marketers rather than as a result of a commission for a specific project or brand. Ms. Gibbons Barry said the growing importance of focusing on the age group, as well as a weakening economy that could impede an agency's doing its own research, helped motivate the study.
The findings, developed over four months at the end of last year, depict the group as people who see their lives as opportunities for self-expression, self-fulfillment and self-reflection.
"I didn't get the impression that they were self-centered, but very reflective and introspective," Ms. Gibbons Barry said. "What they do in life really matters to them and really fits who they are. They're always sort of checking that this is the path that they want to take in life."
Melanie Fallon, a project analyst at PortiCo's New York office, said the open-minded attitude was not "just youthful optimism."
"They have a savvy perspective on the world; they know all about money and finance," she said.
The research highlights four categories in which the group reveals its values: being real, being a good person, expanding their horizons and having fun. It also shows how their independent attitudes can lead them to think that anything is possible, and that the possibilities can be overwhelming.
"I've always had an obsession for being very successful, not like successful with your job or something, but like being somebody big in the world," said Ruben, a media executive interviewed on the video, which identified the participants by only their first names. "I'm not making a lot of money, but it's a challenging job, and I'm doing things that are important."
So far, offices of three agencies have bought the information: BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which works for marketers like the Pepsi-Cola brand of PepsiCo and the Wrigley's brand of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company; J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, with clients like the Lipton brand, owned by Unilever, and United Distillers and Vintners, part of Diageo; and Rubin Postaer & Associates, with the American Honda Motor Company and the VH1 cable television unit of Viacom.
The kind of research that PortiCo developed, Mr. McManus said, "gives more of a human dimension to what all the quantitative data would be telling you."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sixteen people ages 21 to 25 were interviewed for a report and video, above, intended to give advertisers insight on how to sell to them. (PortiCo Research)

HEADLINE: Uneasy Partners Seek Ways to Make Mideast Truce Last 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, June 13 

 BODY:
Palestinians and Israelis began the delicate search today for ways to carry out the American-brokered agreement reached earlier in the day to extend the truce that has reduced Middle East violence during the last 12 days.
 The formal cease-fire went into effect at 3 p.m. In the next 48 hours, the two sides are required under the agreement to begin serious cooperation on security issues and to enforce a complete cessation of violence, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials who participated in the negotiations. 
 In the next phase, the Palestinians are required to prevent any terrorist activities and take practical steps to arrest anyone engaged in terrorism or planning an attack. The Israelis must begin to ease their tight restrictions on Palestinian villages and cities and start withdrawing their soldiers to positions they held before the violence started last September.
In addition, both sides agreed to participate in a cease-fire committee that will be directed by an American intelligence official, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials. The Palestinians interpret the American role as monitoring the cease-fire, but the Israelis said it would not involve observers on the ground. The committee is expected to meet on Friday. 
The initial timetable was set at a meeting today of security officers from both sides. George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, conducted the meeting to develop steps for carrying out the agreement reached this morning. After persuading the two sides to grudgingly consolidate their independently declared cease-fires, Mr. Tenet concluded his six days of intense negotiations and returned to Washington.
"It was a productive, constructive discussion," a senior American diplomat said after today's meeting. "We are now looking for mutual steps on the ground to fulfill the immediate requirements of the work plan."
President Bush said in Brussels today after a meeting with NATO leaders that both sides should take "concrete actions" to carry out the cease-fire and added that Mr. Tenet had told him he was "cautiously optimistic" that the plan would lead to a sustainable truce.
Mr. Bush said he would decide whether Secretary of State Colin L. Powell would get involved in trying to transform the cease-fire into renewed peace talks after assessing the efforts of the Palestinians and Israelis to calm the violence.
Mr. Tenet's trip represented the Bush administration's most active intervention in the region. But senior officials from both the Israeli government and the Palestinian Authority warned that the agreement he left behind was precarious and would require renewed sustained American involvement.
"This is the first serious and comprehensive attempt to calm the situation and, contrary to previous efforts, this one has a chance to succeed, but nothing is guaranteed," a senior Israeli military official said.
Mr. Tenet arrived on June 6, five days after 20 young people were killed in a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv. He wanted to put a formal agreement in place quickly before another episode of violence destroyed the fragile cease-fire adopted independently by the Israelis and Palestinians. A key was concentrating on security issues and delaying talks abut political matters.
After several meetings with both sides, he presented the security chiefs with a proposed agreement to end the violence and renew cooperation on security matters on Friday, according to two participants in those meetings. Both sides expressed objections and reservations.
Over the weekend, Mr. Tenet revised his proposal and on Monday evening he handed it to the negotiators. His message was essentially "take it or leave it." The two sides debated for nearly four hours at the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, sometimes exchanging angry words.
On Tuesday morning, however, the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, accepted the Tenet plan. Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, balked, worried that it would create a backlash among his most militant supporters because it lacked any political concessions by Israel, the participants said.
Details of the agreement have not been made public, but an American diplomat said the language was deliberately vague on some central issues, like the requirement that the Palestinian Authority arrest suspected terrorists.
The Israelis had insisted that the Palestinians re-arrest dozens of terrorists released since the Palestinian uprising began last September. The Palestinians countered that they would not make arrests based on outdated allegations.
In the end, the agreement requires the Palestinians to renew cooperation with Israeli security officials and take all practical steps to arrest anyone planning terrorist actions or carrying them out, according to people familiar with the language.
The agreement lacks the link the Palestinians had sought between the cease-fire and their demands that Israel stop all construction on settlements in the West Bank and that international observers be brought in to monitor compliance.
Mr. Arafat accepted the plan in principle early this morning after Mr. Tenet made a last-minute trip to his headquarters in Ramallah. But the Palestinian leader continued to push for solutions to political issues like the freeze on settlement construction and the pullback of Israeli troops in keeping with recommendations in the report prepared by the commission headed by former Senator George J. Mitchell.
"Settlements are the obstacle that will endanger this chance," Yasir Abed Rabbo, the Palestinian minister of information and one of the negotiators, said at a news conference.
Even agreeing in principle carries risks for Mr. Arafat. Apparently trying to reduce those risks, he gave Mr. Tenet a letter in which he said he had raised several objections to portions of the agreement.
Israel also has reservations. Though Prime Minister Sharon was quick to embrace the Tenet proposal, officials of his government said today that the timing for easing restrictions on Palestinian cities and villages and pulling back troops would depend on how well Mr. Arafat controlled the violence from his side of the dividing lines.
Even during the three decades that Israel controlled the entire West Bank there were sporadic outbreaks of violence, and achieving a total cessation of attacks seems extremely difficult given Palestinian factionalism and the deep resentments engendered in the last eight months.
Mr. Sharon has come under increasing pressure from West Bank settlers, who fear that the Palestinians will not observe the cease-fire. This morning a young Israeli woman was wounded in a shooting attack at the West Bank settlement of Ofra and a Greek Orthodox monk was shot dead outside Jerusalem late Tuesday.
Hamas and the Islamic Jihad, the two militant organizations that have claimed responsibility for most of the attacks against Israel in recent months, rejected the American-backed cease-fire and Hamas vowed to continue the uprising.
Although the agreement requires Israel to ease the restrictions and reduce checkpoints within 48 hours, the extent will be decided by the Israelis and the new cease-fire commission.
The checkpoints and blockades are the most visible sign of the restrictions, which have brought economic progress to a virtual standstill in the West Bank and made everyday life difficult for those who live here.
The escalation of violence has toughened the attitude of most Palestinians toward Israel and made terrorist attacks more acceptable, according to a poll released on Tuesday by Bir Zeit University in Ramallah. The poll of 1,184 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip found that 75 percent supported suicide attacks against Israelis, up from 18 percent in 1994 when the Oslo peace talks began. Two-thirds of the interviews took place before the June 1 suicide bombing in Tel Aviv.
The poll found middle class Palestinians moving toward the hard-line views more often found among militants and younger people, with declining backing for peace talks.
"Our popular resistance should continue until we get rid of the last Israeli soldier in the West Bank and Gaza strip," Nazer Hamdan, a middle-aged businessman, said in an interview here this afternoon.

HEADLINE: Defense Dept. Panel Seeks Changes to Keep Military Personnel 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13 

 BODY:
An advisory panel to Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the military was losing too many of its most experienced and skilled people because of low pay, poor housing and rigid retirement rules, and it called for a sweeping overhaul of longstanding Pentagon personnel policies to stem the losses.
 The panel, which based its recommendations on a study by the RAND Corporation, also determined that black and Hispanic people will become the majority ethnic groups in the armed services within two decades, and it urged the Pentagon to begin aggressively promoting minorities into senior officer positions. 
 The panel, led by a retired admiral, David Jeremiah, concluded that the Pentagon's policies on a variety of issues, including pensions, retirement and relocation had not kept pace with major political and demographic changes in recent decades.
"What you have is a system that is basically 50 years old and has been Band-Aided over the years to accommodate different stresses and strains on it," Admiral Jeremiah said in a Pentagon news conference. "It needs to be looked at in a totality, restructured, and new proposals brought forward to change the way we do business." 
Admiral Jeremiah declined to provide an estimate on how much the panel's recommendations would cost. But he said that just making pay for midcareer officers competitive with equivalent private-sector jobs would cost billions of dollars. President Bush, who made military quality of life a major theme of his campaign last year, has already proposed adding $1.4 billion to the budget to improve military pay.
Although the panel's conclusions are advisory only, Mr. Rumsfeld has made it clear that he considers improvements in recruiting, retention and morale to be among his top priorities in the coming months. Mr. Rumsfeld's impending request to Congress to augment the 2002 Pentagon budget, for instance, is expected to be heavily weighted toward health care, building repairs, training and spare parts -- the kinds of unglamorous programs that can affect morale.
Many military experts and officials say that with all of the political and fiscal obstacles that Mr. Rumsfeld will face in trying to overhaul the Pentagon's war-fighting doctrine -- an effort that will probably involve contentious battles over weapons programs -- he may find it easier, less costly and less controversial to focus on improving quality of life for the troops.
There is, for one thing, bipartisan support in Congress for rebuilding housing, raising pay and improving health services for the troops. And there is a potential political payoff for the Bush administration, because those in the service are widely thought to vote heavily Republican.
"It's looking more and more likely that one of their major legacies could be to make the military more family friendly," said Loren Thompson, chief operating officer for the Lexington Institute, a military policy group. "Part of the appeal of changing personnel policies is that it costs relatively little money and it benefits people who vote."
Among its 64 recommendations to Mr. Rumsfeld, the panel called for revising the Pentagon's longstanding requirement that officers retire if they fail to be promoted after a certain number of years, a policy known as "up or out." 
"Here's a perfectly solid, well-serving officer who, because he's hit an age wicket, we say goodbye," Admiral Jeremiah said. "Why are we doing that?"
The RAND study also found that pay for midcareer military personnel tended to stagnate, falling significantly behind private-sector salaries for people with comparable education. Admiral Jeremiah said the panel recommended that future pay increases be targeted to people in that group, who typically have served between 10 and 20 years.
To improve housing, the panel recommended that the Pentagon move more aggressively to allow private companies to build off-base housing for troops, an idea that has strong support in the White House.
It also urged Congress to close unneeded military installations -- always a contentious issue on Capitol Hill, where bases are equated with jobs -- and to invest money in upgrading base facilities. To emphasize its point about decaying infrastructure, the panel cited the case of an F-15 fighter jet that suffered $185,000 in damage to its landing gear after breaking through a decrepit sewer grate near the runway.

HEADLINE: Essay; 
Bush Unifies Europe

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
Western Europe was unified for two generations by a fear of the Soviet Union. Now that Russia's economy is dependent on high oil prices, its population plunging to half that of the U.S., and what's left of the Red Army mired in Chechnya, the glue holding together Europe's fragile supranational identity is resentment of the unrivaled power of the United States.
 Americans should not be offended at being the object of the unifying force of envy. As George W. (Don't Call Me Unilateralist) Bush does the New Grand Tour (Spain, Sweden, Poland and Slovenia rather than France, Germany and Britain), he supplies our allies with a necessary psychological substitute for their former fear. 
 Accordingly, ex-Trotskyites in France consider us barbarians for imposing the death penalty on a mass murderer, though more prisoners in French jails committed suicide in the past year than were executed in the U.S. And European greens recite their mantra that the U.S., with only 5 percent of the world's population, produces 25 percent of the pollutants -- though this is hardly surprising from the nation that produces 25 percent of the world's goods and services.
A pair of defense issues provide Europeans with a satisfying irritation with the U.S. One is their desire for a non-American "Rapid Deployment Force," even as European nations reduce their spending on defense. We see this as a bureaucratic device for them to use NATO assets without American participation in military decisions.
The other irritant is our desire to be able to defend ourselves against dozens of missiles coming into the hands of rogue nations. Though such basic defense would not affect the strategic balance between Russia and the U.S. (both nations have thousands of missiles to overwhelm any limited defense), Europeans have bought Vladimir Putin's line that any change in the cold-war deal might "lead to a new arms race." 
After all the posturing is over, here's the deal that may well be struck:
Americans strongly doubt that Europe will put up the money to pay for an independent force; such talk of a force independent of NATO will never amount to more than talk. Therefore, we'll withdraw our objection and smilingly wish them well -- provided they don't use NATO equipment or endanger U.S. troops.
For their part, many Europeans have fervently bought the notion that we're nowhere near developing a system that will shoot down incoming missiles, or that we will find it too expensive. Therefore, they will withdraw their objection to our withdrawal from the old ABM treaty and will patronizingly wish America well -- provided we promise to placate Putin and, on the off chance that we ever achieve what now seems technologically impossible, to use our missile shield to protect them.
Thus, with Europeans and Americans both saying "Sure, go ahead, it'll never get off the ground," we will strike a grand strategic bargain. It took shape at NATO in Brussels yesterday as some of our allies showed an interest in defending their own cities from nuclear blackmail. 
Because European expectations have been so contemptuously low, and because Bush has done serious homework, the new American president is likely to get a first-impression "bounce." That should serve him well in Saturday's non-summit in Slovenia with Putin. But Bush's performance will ultimately be rated not on his ability to project humility in meetings or plunge into affectionate crowds in Warsaw. 
Will he politely tell Putin that the ABM restrictions are a dead letter, and that we will pay no price in economic aid for his assent? Will he make clear that the U.S. never recognized the deal the Soviets made with the Nazis to swallow up the Baltic nations, and that Russia has no say in when Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia become members of NATO? Will he say that U.S. relations with Russia will reflect Putin's policy toward sales of technology into dangerous hands, toward brutality in Chechnya, toward his suppression of the press? 
Such unilateral honesty might bestir the resentment that unites many Europeans. But we can dispense with the blather about "personal chemistry" and the supposed value of "looking him in the eye." Only if Bush plainly asserts our national interests will his first foray to Europe be judged a success.

HEADLINE: Report Outlines the Abuse of Foreign Domestic Workers 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12 

 BODY:
When Juana Condori received the job offer back home in Bolivia, it seemed like a dream come true -- fly in an airplane for the first time, live in the United States, work for a diplomat.
 But after arriving in Washington to work as a nanny and housekeeper, Ms. Condori, now 33, began to feel like a prisoner. She said her employer, a diplomat with the Organization of American States, forced her to work seven days a week and did not let her leave the house unescorted. The diplomat's family, she said, took her passport, did not give her a house key, did not let her attend church. 
 During 16 months on the job, she said, she often worked 90 hours a week and was paid $220 a month, a fraction of the minimum wage.
"I was really excited about coming here," she said, "but now I see you suffer a lot in the United States."
Behind the glamour of Embassy Row are many unhappy stories like Ms. Condori's. In the past decade, more than 35,000 domestic workers, almost all of them young women, have received special visas to work for diplomats in Washington and New York City, often working far longer hours for far less pay than they were promised. 
Human Rights Watch, the human rights group, is to release a report on Thursday that accuses the United States government of doing too little to protect these workers.
"These domestic workers come to the United States to escape poverty in their countries of origin," the report states. "All too often, however, they become some of the world's most disadvantaged workers held captive by some of the world's most powerful employers."
The report, "Hidden in the Home: Abuse of Domestic Workers with Special Visas in the United States," found that these workers' median workday was 14 hours and that their median wage was $2.14 an hour, including room and board.
Human rights groups, immigrants rights groups and women's groups are seeking to pressure the State Department and international organizations like the World Bank and Organization of American States to do more to protect these workers, who usually have little idea of their rights or where to turn for help.
In interviews, these workers spoke of being slapped, yelled at and sexually assaulted. Some women have even filed lawsuits charging involuntary servitude, saying they were barred from leaving their employers' houses.
Lydia Altamirano, who left college in Nicaragua to work for an official with the Inter-American Development Bank, said she had to work every day for her first three years in Washington, often until midnight when the family gave dinner parties.
Hapsatou Sarr, a nanny and housekeeper from Mauritania, said she was never paid during nearly eight months of working for a World Bank official. She said she slept on the floor in a child's rooms. Her employer, she said, once slapped her because she forgot to give him a fork. 
She said that when she complained, the family often withheld food from her. She was not allowed outside by herself, she said, and the official's wife listened to her telephone conversations to make sure she was not planning to escape.
"I didn't know who to explain problems to," Ms. Sarr said. "I was feeling like I was going to kill myself every day." 
Many diplomats say that workers often exaggerate or fabricate abuses when they file lawsuits.
Paul Reichler, the lawyer for Edmundo Jarquin, the diplomat sued by Ms. Altamirano, said that her claims of overwork were false and that she was trying to blackmail the family.
The Human Rights Watch report concluded that a major cause of abuses was the special visa granted to these workers, which lets them remain in the United States only while working for a diplomat. Thus, the workers know that they can be deported if they quit.
"They can stay in the abusive situation or go back to their home country, which typically has very poor economic conditions, or they can leave their job and stay here undocumented," said Kimberley Propeack, a lawyer for Casa of Maryland, an immigrants rights group.
The report recommends that Congress give the workers the right to get new jobs if their employers violate wage and hours laws or abuse them. Noting that many diplomats sign contracts promising 40-hour workweeks and the minimum wage of $5.15 an hour, Human Rights Watch also said the government should make adequate resources available to enforce those provisions. 
"You would think that because these workers follow the rules and come to the U.S. legally, the U.S. government would try to protect them from abuses," said Carol Pier, author of the report.
The visas "become coercive tools on the part of the employer," Ms. Pier said.
Philip Reeker, a State Department spokesman, said, "We take this issue quite seriously." He said the department was urging diplomats to comply with labor laws and was notifying domestic workers of their rights when they applied for visas.
Confronted by accusations that its employees have abused their housekeepers, the World Bank requires its employees not to take away the workers' passports and to sign contracts guaranteeing the minimum wage. The bank also requires its employees and their domestic workers to attend seminars where the workers' rights are explained.
"There is a difficulty because these are not our employees," said John Donaldson, a World Bank spokesman. "They are employees of our employees. We expect our employees to abide by U.S. law."
Advocates for immigrants praise the World Bank's moves, but say that the bank and the International Monetary Fund should do more. For example, they said, the organizations should interview domestic workers about whether there are abuses.
In addition to her claims of labor violations, Ms. Condori said that an acquaintance of the family she worked for raped her, and that the diplomat, Jaime Aparicio, would not contact the police or arrange for her to see a doctor. 
She has charged him with violating wage laws, failing to provide her with medical care and covering up for the rapist.
Through a lawyer, the Aparicios denied Ms. Condori's accusations about wages and hours and said they had no knowledge of her rape claim.
Ms. Condori said she fled the Aparicio home and now cleans the house of a business executive. She said she hoped to return to Bolivia, once she saw her lawsuit through.
"I want to stay here until I make sure that the man who did this to me goes to jail," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Juana Condori has sued her former employer, a diplomat with the Organization of American States. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: California Signs Expensive Energy Deals 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, June 13 

 BODY:
California signed long-term electricity contracts at prices higher than those available on the daily market, state officials said today as they prepared to release details of the pacts between the state and power generators.
 But they said the contracts helped break the spiral that had driven electricity prices to record heights. 
 Critics said Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat, was foolish for locking in long-term rates at the market's peak.
A spokesman for Governor Davis, Steve Maviglio, said the contracts would stabilize the fluctuating market, although at a cost that might exceed market prices in years to come.
The governor planned to release details of 38 long-term contracts between the state and power generators as early as Thursday. The contracts, valued at nearly $43 billion, could burden consumers with relatively high rates if the recent decline in electricity prices continues.
Peter Navarro, an economist at the University of California at Irvine, said the Davis administration negotiated "from a position of severe weakness."

HEADLINE: Energy Agency Is Set to Monitor Prices in West 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13 

 BODY:
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is expected to approve a plan proposed by Congressional Republicans that would significantly expand the agency's efforts to limit electricity prices in California and other Western states.
 The plan is part of the Republican response to a Democratic political offensive on energy, which both parties say could prove key in deciding control of the closely split House and Senate in elections next year. 
 Under a plan expected to be adopted on Monday during an extraordinary meeting of the federal agency's five commissioners, the regulatory body would begin monitoring and potentially curtailing all wholesale electricity prices that generating companies charge California and 10 nearby states. Currently, the agency seeks to limit electricity prices only in California and only when the state declares a power emergency because of acute shortages. 
Democrats have pressed the agency for months to do more to control electricity costs in California, where a shortage of power plants and a flawed wholesale electricity market have led to high prices. Some Democrats say that until California fixes its market, the agency should set prices based on each generator's cost of producing power. They are unlikely to be satisfied by the agency's latest price-monitoring plan.
The White House has steadfastly opposed price controls of any kind, saying they distort the market and worsen supply shortages. But some Congressional Republicans have taken a softer line and have urged federal regulators to battle what they say may be price gouging.
The proposal now before the agency is the result of a collaboration between House Republicans and Curt Hebert Jr., the Republican chairman of the commission, people involved with the plan said.
Many measures the agency is considering were first proposed by Representative Doug Ose, a California Republican, as a compromise between Democratic calls for aggressive price controls and a more laissez-faire Republican approach. A group of 17 House Republicans endorsed the ideas in a letter to Mr. Hebert this week.
The agency does not discuss pending orders, but several people at the agency said they fully expected the plan to reflect the main points suggested by the Republican legislators.
"This is a good plan because it inhibits bad behavior but relies on the economics of the market," said Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and who wrote the letter to Mr. Hebert. 
Mr. Hebert's apparent embrace of the Republican position on price mitigation may be part of an effort to cultivate support on Capitol Hill.
Vice President Dick Cheney has said that the Bush administration intends to name Pat Wood III, a former Texas regulator whom Mr. Bush recently named as a commissioner of the agency, to replace Mr. Hebert as chairman.
But Mr. Hebert counts Mr. Tauzin and Trent Lott, the Senate Republican leader, as key supporters, and all three are eager to show they care about the situation in California, Republican aides said.
House Republicans have moved in other ways to blunt Democratic momentum on energy issues. Tom DeLay, the majority whip, set up a task force today to coordinate energy legislation in several committees. The goal is to pass a broad package containing many of the administration's energy priorities by July, a Republican aide said.
With several polls showing that Americans have grown wary of the administration's hands-off approach to energy prices, Democrats are promising relief. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, head of the Government Affairs Committee, held the first of two hearings on electricity markets today. Mr. Lieberman said he opposes price caps in general but supports controls in this case, arguing that without them, "We put our economy at risk."
The energy agency ruled late last year that California's electricity market had broken down and that power generators were no longer charging "just and reasonable" prices, a threshold for federal action. But the agency has moved to impose controls reluctantly.
Under pressure to act, the agency decided in March to monitor prices and order generators in California to pay refunds for electricity sales deemed overcharges, but only in Stage 3 emergencies, when supplies fall to within 1.5 percent of demand.
That action was broadened in late April, when the agency adopted a new formula that moderated prices whenever supplies fall to within 7.5 percent of demand. Even when it acts to review prices, the agency only limits prices above what it determines to be the highest costs of the least efficient generator serving the market, ensuring a hefty profit margin for most power companies.
If the commission votes to adopt the Republican plan, the agency would begin examining a larger universe of electricity sales. The plan would aim to discourage "megawatt laundering," in which power companies channel supplies to out-of-state marketers to avoid price control in California. Policing of prices would expand to the entire 11-state region that makes up the Western grid.
But the plan presents immense challenges to an agency that has had difficulties carrying out past price monitoring plans. And details remained vague today because the agency's staff members were still scrambling to figure out how it would work and had not yet circulated a plan for commissioners to examine.
The agency appears set to take its biggest steps to help California even as electricity prices there show signs of moderating. This week, prices on the state's spot market fell to less than $100 a megawatt-hour for the first time this year. Earlier in the year, prices often surpassed $300 a megawatt hour.
California officials credit several factors for the lower prices. The state has signed some long-term supply contracts with generators, easing its daily demand for power on the volatile spot market. And the supply has risen as generators complete maintenance programs to prepare plants for peak summer months. Natural gas prices, a key input for electricity generation, have also declined as the supplies rise nationally.
But federal regulators claim that their earlier price-mitigation plan, though limited in scope, helped to force generators to curtail prices.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
KGA Shuts Its Doors After a 22-Year Run

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
KGA Advertising in Middletown, Conn., which at its height had more than 40 employees and billings estimated at $35 million from clients like Bob's Stores and Pilot Pen, has closed after about 22 years.
 "It's because the president and C.E.O. made a stupid mistake," said Ken Gronbach, who held those posts at KGA. 
"I wonder how many people admit their mistakes." The closing stemmed not from the slowing economy, Mr. Gronbach said, but from complications that arose after he bought the building in which the agency was housed. 
 After losing longtime clients like Bob's and Pilot, Mr. Gronbach said, KGA is closing with more than a dozen employees and billings estimated at $5 million from clients like the National Kidney Foundation. The closing was reported by the online edition of Adweek.

KLINGER, TATHIANA S. (TOMI)

 KLINGER-Tathiana S. (Tomi). Died Tuesday, June 12, 2001 in Concord, NH. Devoted wife of Dr. Leo Klinger for 61 years. She is survived by her husband, her children and their spouses: Ann and Dana Turner of Austell, Ga., Charles and Carol Klinger of Honeoye Falls, NY and Bernard and Eda Klinger of White Plains, N.Y. Beloved grandmother of Maria and Daniel Barr, David Follman and Michael and Rebecca Klinger.

Known to many as "Ma Klinger" she delighted in her hobbies of quilting, knitting, needle crafts and baking "kurls." She will be greatly missed. Funeral service at Temple Beth Jacob, Concord, NH on Thursday, June 14th, at 2 PM.

HEADLINE: Optimism Recedes as Europe Faces Long-Term Issues 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 13 

 BODY:
Confronted by ever more numerous signs of slower growth and rising prices, European leaders are once again brooding about long-term "speed limits" on their economies.
 Until a few months ago, European officials and private economists thought the Continent would expand faster than its long-term rate of about 2.5 percent a year. Governments had cut deeply into budget deficits, inflation had almost disappeared and excitement about a technology-driven "new economy" had taken hold among consumers and businesses. 
 But that optimism has receded sharply. Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, warned in an interview today that Europe had yet to break out of its old rut, and that last year's relatively robust growth might have been "an exception rather than a new rule." 
The new economy has not yet arrived in Europe, he said, and it probably will not arrive until European governments clear away many of the regulations that hamstring markets for goods and labor.
"If we look at last year, we could think that a so-called new economy -- one with a lasting, higher rate of productivity growth -- had arrived," Mr. Duisenberg said, "but we have no evidence that that has happened in practice."
Last year was the first time in 13 years that European growth significantly exceeded the long-term speed limit, reaching 3.4 percent. Signs point to slower growth this year.
"The potential rate of growth certainly could be higher in Europe," Mr. Duisenberg said today. "But monetary policy can do nothing about that. That would involve eliminating many of the rigidities that still pervade the 12 market economies -- rigidities in labor markets, rigidities in product markets. And that is a long, drawn-out process."
Others share his pessimism. The Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels published a report on Monday concluding that European productivity has declined in the last six years and that "Europe's speed limit is unlikely to have increased very much."
Mr. Duisenberg and other central bank officials have become even more concerned by new signs of inflation, a plague Europe thought it had banished.
On Monday, the German government reported that consumer prices increased at an annual rate of 3.5 percent in May, the most in eight years. In France, which lately has had one of the lowest inflation rates in Europe, consumer prices jumped 2.5 percent in May.
The numbers were worse than analysts had expected, and central bank officials now predict more bad news to come: Figures for the 12 euro nations as a whole, scheduled for release later this month, are expected to show inflation over 3 percent, well above the European Central Bank's goal of 2 percent.
"We have some more months of bad inflation figures in front of us," Otmar Issing, the bank's chief economist, said on Tuesday.
Bank officials said that recent price increases stem mainly from factors outside their control: high oil prices; meat prices driven up by mad cow disease and foot-and-mouth disease; and the weak euro, which makes imports cost more.
But others wonder whether Europe may simply have reached its speed limit. 
"Could it be that the euro area cannot grow any faster than 2 to 2.5 percent without igniting inflation?" the Center for European Policy Studies asked in its report. "Are European labor markets so distorted that unemployment cannot fall much below 8 to 10 percent?"
Mr. Duisenberg, in his office atop the Eurotower headquarters of the European Central Bank, suggested that recent rises in the cost of oil and food would take longer to absorb than first thought. But he said the bank faced a difficulty in trying to communicate two seemingly conflicting messages: that inflation was still a concern, but that it would also probably moderate over the next year.
For a sustained improvement in European growth to take hold, Europe must change the way it works, he said, with more flexible work rules, greater competition and less government spending.
"We have a feeling it has happened to some extent in certain regions of Europe," he said, citing Ireland and the Netherlands. "And it happens in regions within regions -- in parts of France, for example. It may have happened in Bavaria. But it is not across the board."
Even so, he said, Europe will not sink into a recession and will grow faster in 2001 than the United States, for the first time in many years.
Early this year, Mr. Duisenberg said, the bank foresaw expansion in the 12 euro nations of 3 percent in 2001 and 2002, but that is now out of reach.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, said that for Europe to maintain its economic growth, the Continent must change the way it works, with more flexible labor rules, greater competition and less government spending. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
MORTON'S RESTAURANT PREDICTS LOSS FOR THE QUARTER

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The Morton's Restaurant Group said yesterday that it expected a loss for the second quarter because of the weakening economy, higher operating costs and reduced business travel. 
Analysts had expected the company to post a profit of 34 cents to 44 cents a share in the second quarter, compared with a profit of 43 cents a year ago, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Shares fell $2.76 yesterday, or 9 percent, to $22.74. Morton's, based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., said it continued to experience "weak revenue trends," with sales at restaurants open at least a year off about 9.5 percent in the second quarter.
