HEADLINE: Trenton Projects Shortfall Totaling Almost $1 Billion 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 13 

 BODY:
With just over two weeks to go until the deadline for New Jersey's next budget, the DiFrancesco administration acknowledged today that the state is facing a shortfall of nearly $1 billion.
 At a budget hearing in late May, the administration refused to provide legislators with updated tax revenue projections, saying economic conditions were too uncertain, even as independent fiscal monitors predicted a gap of nearly $1.6 billion. 
 Today, Acting Treasurer Peter R. Lawrance provided those updated estimates, reducing the combined tax revenue projections for 2001 and 2002 by $948 million. The reduced tax income means that Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and the State Legislature will have to scramble to cut spending for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. As it stands, the proposed budget is $23.2 billion. 
But even as the administration confirmed that New Jersey had to cut back, it showed continued reluctance to face questions from the Assembly Budget Committee. Tonight, Assemblyman Leonard Lance, the committee chairman, abruptly canceled a hearing scheduled for Thursday because Mr. Lawrance said he would not attend.
"I am disappointed that they will not appear," Mr. Lance said. "I will continue to work with the administration on a prudent, balanced budget." 
But the ranking Democrat on the committee, Assemblywoman Barbara Buono, said, "The administration is leaving New Jersey taxpayers in the dark and in a lurch with a mound of debt."
A spokesman for the Treasury Department, Dan Bledsoe, said Mr. Lawrance considered the hearing unnecessary. "The treasurer doesn't see a need to testify before the committee," Mr. Bledsoe said. "He spelled out his revenue figures. The figures are what they are."
At the Budget Committee's last hearing in late May, officials in the Office of Legislative Services, which provides independent budget analysis, said the state would face a shortfall of nearly $1.6 billion next year.
Alan R. Kooney, the legislative budget officer, said the agency stood by its prediction. "The estimates that we made in late May were done very carefully, and nothing has happened since that time that would lead us to raise any of our revenue estimates," he said, noting that the economic outlook had not improved.
The revenue estimates for the current fiscal year presented by Mr. Lawrance today were actually $42 million lower than the estimates by the Office of Legislative Services. And his numbers are based on figures that are more up-to-date.
But the administration differed sharply with the independent monitors over state income tax revenue for next year. Mr. Lawrance projected income tax revenue in 2002 of $8.61 billion, compared with $8.16 billion projected by the Office of Legislative Services. 
Treasury officials did not offer any detailed explanation for the difference in the projections. Tom Wilson, a spokesman for the acting governor, said Mr. DiFrancesco planned to meet with legislative leaders on Thursday to revise the budget.

HEADLINE: Some Russians Are Alarmed At Tighter Grip Under Putin 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 13 

 BODY:
It is not an easy thing to quantify, much less to prove. But among intellectuals and advocates of a democratic Russia in the Western mode, a gnawing concern is arising that the relative freedom from state surveillance and restriction that citizens have relished in the last decade may be drawing to a close.
 Supplanting it is a resurgent government obsession with internal security and threats from abroad -- a phenomenon that they say has set off a limited but growing crackdown on supposed challenges to the state. 
 The evidence itself is scattered. It ranges from a string of arrests of Russian scholars, to the revival of old curbs on international scientific cooperation, to the seeming harassment of some political critics and dissidents, to a growing conviction among some intellectuals that their telephones are again being tapped and their e-mail read. 
As much as any crackdown, what unsettles them is the failure of President Vladimir V. Putin, himself a product of the state security machine, to restrain or even speak out against it.
"It has not yet acquired the scope which would go deep under the skin of ordinary Russians. They have known much worse," Georgi Arbatov, the director emeritus of the government's Institute of U.S.A.-Canada Studies and a veteran analyst of East-West relations, said in an interview. "But there are some not very good signs.
"Having become the leader of this country, he has to explain that he does not want to return to some past practices. The sooner he dispels all these rumors, the better."
Never far from the surface of these concerns, of course, is the memory of Russia's seven decades as a rigid and ruthless police state. Virtually no one believes that a return to those days is either contemplated or even possible; whatever the flaws in Russia's justice system and its press, most Russians, though not all, enjoy basic civil liberties.
The Kremlin proposed judicial reforms this month that should underpin those liberties if carried out.
But Mr. Putin himself has rung alarm bells by suggesting that Russia requires what he calls a "managed democracy" headed by a strong central government. Over the Kremlin's insistence that it is irrevocably dedicated to basic freedoms, some liberals here call that a euphemism for authoritarian rule.
Top government posts have increasingly been filled by veterans of the military and intelligence, agencies that clung to a cold-war notion of security even in Russian democracy's most liberal days.
Many liberals question whether those and other officials, often steeped for decades in the Soviet bureaucracy before making quick changes in ideologies and jobs, have put the paranoia and xenophobia of Communist days behind them.
"They do just what they have been taught to do," said Sergei Kovalyov, a dissident who survived imprisonment in the infamous Perm-36 gulag in Siberia and is now in Parliament. "It's the only thing they can do. And that's why there is nothing surprising in the way they understand order in this country and what kind of order they are going to bring."
In the eyes of Mr. Kovalyov and other activists, a flurry of events in the last year are evocative of a dormant era when all outsiders were viewed as potential enemies -- and challenging the established order could easily make one an outsider.
Some of those events, like the military's insistence that the nuclear submarine Kursk was probably sunk 10 months ago by a collision with a foreign sub spying on naval war games, amount to little more than words. Others have more serious consequences.
Only today the Federal Security Service's Omsk regional office announced that it had reprimanded Elizabeth Sweet, an American lecturer at the State University of Omsk, after counterintelligence officers learned that she had asked students to examine the economic health of local businesses. Most of the region's industry is military-related.
The security service said that such information could harm the image and competitiveness of businesses if published abroad, but it stopped short of expelling Ms. Sweet. It said, though, that the renewal of her teaching contract was now in doubt.
In Kaluga, 85 miles west of Moscow, Igor Sutyagin, a Russian military analyst at the Institute of U.S.A.-Canada Studies, Mr. Arbatov's old agency, is on trial for high treason, accused of passing state secrets. 
International scientific organizations and Mr. Sutyagin's colleagues call the proceeding a sham, noting that he had no access to classified information. The charges appear based on his acceptance of a contract with a London consulting firm to write military analyses.
In Krasnoyarsk, in southern Siberia, a university scientist was charged with high treason in April for fulfilling a contract with a Chinese company to supply research on shielding satellites from radiation. His colleagues said the information was based on documents declassified 10 years ago.
In Vladivostok, a military court is beginning a second trial of Grigory Pasko, a military journalist accused of treason after helping Japanese television journalists report on the Russian naval fleet's dumping of nuclear waste at sea. Mr. Pasko was acquitted on the same charge in 1999; the Supreme Military Collegium ordered a retrial this year.
Civil rights advocates disclosed last week that the Russian Academy of Sciences had ordered scientists and their supervisors to restrict contacts with outsiders, report on trips abroad and submit potentially sensitive scientific papers for prepublication review, among other curbs.
The academy has not commented on the rules, some of which are said to apply only to classified scientific work and others to all scientists. Privately, civil liberties advocates here say similar restrictions have been put in place in other government agencies that have regular contact with foreigners.
Right or wrong, many intellectuals and activists now take it as a given that their telephone conversations and e-mail are monitored -- something that, while surely not unthinkable, was hardly a major concern even two or three years ago.
Since 1995, Russian law has required all telephone and Internet services to maintain devices that allow the Federal Security Service, the post-Soviet evolution of the K.G.B., to monitor any and all transmissions. The service is required to seek a warrant before conducting a wiretap, but because it wields almost complete control over the process, it is not known how rigidly that requirement is followed.
The United States government has recently advised certain private entities that maintain regular contact with Russian officials, academics or businesses to assume that the Russians are monitoring all conversations.
Leaders of Yabloko, one of the political parties that promote Western-style democratic values, worried at a meeting in St. Petersburg on Saturday that Russia was becoming a society with the trappings of freedom, but controlled in reality from the top.
The Union of Right Forces, the other major liberal party, has publicly expressed concern of late that Russia could become a liberal economic state controlled by an authoritarian leadership.
Still, many in Russia's democratic elite are reluctant to tie the resurgence of suspicion and security measures directly to Mr. Putin, a former K.G.B. agent who was director of the Federal Security Service not six months before becoming president.
The more benevolent view is that his ascension has been read by Russia's security organs as a green light to return to old habits -- or that the crackdown is a ham-handed attempt by midlevel bureaucrats to curry favor with the new president.
"During the 90's they were on the periphery of the establishment," said Igor Bunin, the head of Moscow's nonpartisan Center for Political Technologies. "Suddenly, they were all taken inside, right into the core of it. And they all decided that they have to prove that they are in demand, that they are needed by the state."
What is very likely under way, Mr. Bunin said, is a spate of muscle-flexing by the old crowd that has returned to control in some of the most powerful cabinet agencies.
"It also must be admitted that nobody has tried to cool them down and tell them they shouldn't be too zealous about it," he added.
That troubles many democratic and civil-rights advocates most of all. Many, though hardly all, of the best-known incidents involve the Federal Security Service -- the closest modern equivalent to the domestic arm of the K.G.B. that once weeded dissenters and wrong-thinkers out of Soviet society and into gulags.
By not speaking out, they say, Mr. Putin has tacitly endorsed actions that seem devised to send a public message that there are limits to challenging the state and to consorting with the potential enemy.
"Some people are concerned," Mr. Arbatov said. "And it's not good. I think with the history we have, you cannot play games with such issues."
One who knows that history well is Sergei Grigoryants, another prominent dissident, who spent 10 years in Soviet prison camps in the 1970's and 1980's and who has been a fierce critic of the reluctant way that Russia has introduced democracy.
On June 4, he publicly accused the Federal Security Service of harassing Russian youth groups that did not display government-approved ideological bents. Two days later, after passing customs, passport and security controls at Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow, he was approached by some 10 security officers as he sat in a boarding lounge, awaiting a flight to Washington. He was taken away and interrogated for five hours and his airline ticket and $3,000 in cash were seized.
The next day he made his trip to Washington. In a telephone interview from Washington, he insisted that he had violated no rules, but that when he arrived home from the airport he was unable to make telephone calls and that when his Washington host called him, the line went dead in midconversation. 
Michael McFaul, a scholar at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who had invited Mr. Grigoryants to a Washington seminar discussing Russia's decade of independence, was the caller. In an interview, he said the incident fit a pattern of increasing surveillance and harassment.
"As for what has concretely happened, the incidents are few," he said. "But the atmosphere they have created is one of paranoia." People were now worrying about what would happen to them, he said, adding: "They have a lot more to lose now. It's amazing how fear can make you do certain things."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sergei Grigoryants was detained when about to go to Washington. (Linda Spillers for The New York Times)(pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Bloomberg's Challenge: Be a '93 Giuliani, but in '01

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Of all the candidates seeking to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, no one is trying to tie himself as closely to the outgoing mayor as Michael R. Bloomberg.
 He repeatedly praises Mr. Giuliani's tenure and has largely modeled his candidacy on Mr. Giuliani's first successful run for office. Mr. Bloomberg and his advisers look to the electoral success of Mr. Giuliani -- a Republican in an overwhelmingly Democratic city, a man who had never held elective office -- as a reason for confidence in what might otherwise seem a slightly far-fetched candidacy. 
 "Nothing has really changed," said David Garth, who was Mr. Giuliani's chief consultant in 1993 and who is serving in the same capacity for Mr. Bloomberg this year. "Nobody knew Rudy Giuliani. Nobody knows Mike Bloomberg. He was a dynamic prosecutor. Bloomberg is a dynamic industrialist."
Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Giuliani are indeed both iconoclastic Republicans with distinctive careers and credentials, running as outsiders against familiar figures of the Democratic establishment.
But that may be about as far as it goes. These are very different men, running in very different times, and in a city that is changing politically in ways that most politicians are only beginning to understand.
To a limited extent, these changes may work to Mr. Bloomberg's advantage. It is not as odd as it was a decade ago for a Democrat in New York City to consider voting for a Republican for mayor, one of the legacies Mr. Giuliani has left for Mr. Bloomerg (or for Herman Badillo, should he defeat Mr. Bloomberg in the Republican primary).
In addition, many old-line Democratic voters -- the kind of loyal Democrats who prompted Mr. Giuliani to seek the Liberal Party line so they would have a place to vote for him -- are being displaced on the voting rolls by first-generation immigrants. Their party loyalties are not so deeply rooted as the ethnic Democratic constituencies, from blacks to Jews to the Irish, who once made up the building blocks of New York's mayoral race.
What is more, Republican and Democratic strategists say that partisan considerations have been increasingly supplanted in mayoral elections, even in New York, by more fundamental questions of competence and management ability.
"There aren't any partisan elections here anymore," said Kevin McCabe, the former chief of staff to one of the Democratic candidates, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker. That is particularly obvious this year, when there is no crisis commanding the attention of voters.
So it was that even before Mr. Bloomberg got into this race, his Democratic opponents -- notably, Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, and Mark Green, the public advocate -- had based their campaign appeal on their experience and competence. Advisers to Mr. Bloomberg say his single biggest selling point is his record as an entrepreneur.
Still, there are some substantial differences between now and 1993 that have led many politicians to argue that Mr. Bloomberg would be making a mistake if he tried to win simply by repeating Mr. Giuliani's campaign of that year. The differences range include the particular electoral circumstances that permitted Mr. Giuliani's narrow victory over Mayor David N. Dinkins in 1993, like a Staten Island secession referendum that produced a spike in Republican voters, and changes in electoral forces that appear to be guiding this election and the way the Democratic candidates are approaching it.
"It's a totally different race," said Edward I. Koch, the former mayor, who is supporting Mr. Vallone in this election. "Giuliani became mayor by 2 percent of the vote, reversing an earlier defeat by 2 percent because David Dinkins was not worthy of a second term. The only way he can win is to take strong positions that he believes in and that makes sense and that are not run of the mill."
In 1993, voters chose Mr. Giuliani as the right man for the right time. He was a prosecutor who defeated Mr. Dinkins, a mayor who seemed overwhelmed by events, in a charged and nervous city alarmed by a crime rate that seemed out of control.
Mr. Bloomberg has sought to make both his experience as a successful businessman and the condition of the city's schools his equivalent issue this year. But even his supporters acknowledge that in doing so, Mr. Bloomberg is joining a long line of Democratic candidates. More than that, Mr. Bloomberg and education do not seem to go so well together as Mr. Giuliani and crime.
"The environment is totally different," said Douglas Muzzio, a professor of public affairs at Baruch College. "Crime is down. There is no compelling issue. And Bloomberg's story doesn't work -- a successful businessman who built a billion-dollar industry? His story doesn't fit the time."
What is more, at least three of the Democrats -- Mr. Green, Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone -- have clearly taken some lessons from Mr. Giuliani's years in office and his back-to-back victories over Mr. Dinkins and Ruth W. Messinger, the former Manhattan borough president.
They are running campaigns that emphasize issues like police protection and the quality of life, and are far more moderate in tone than any Democrat since Mr. Koch.
Unless Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president who has run a more traditional Democratic campaign, wins his party's nomination, even Mr. Bloomberg's advisers acknowledge that he would have a hard time doing to his Democratic opponent what Mr. Giuliani succeeded in doing to Mr. Dinkins.
"Now I think the entire Democratic Party is more moderate," said Mitchell Moss, the director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University and a paid adviser to Mr. Bloomberg.
Bill Lynch, who was Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, said Mr. Giuliani had also had the advantage of a previous run, in 1989, against Mr. Dinkins, and four years to prepare for the rematch. 
"Rudy spent four years working his base, when we were in City Hall," Mr. Lynch recalled. "And when the economy went south, there wasn't much we could do to get people's attention. We got hurt by some of the bad stuff that went on there. And he took advantage of that."
There are other practical difficulties as well. Aside from crime, Mayor Dinkins had alienated many Jewish voters over the Crown Heights disturbances. The Staten Island secession vote, Mr. Lynch estimated, brought out as many as 40,000 extra votes for Mr. Giuliani in 1993.
And Mr. Bloomberg failed to win the Liberal Party line the way Mr. Giuliani had. The party provided Mr. Giuliani with only 62,469 votes in 1993, but it had offered a way for Democrats to support Mr. Giuliani, a Democrat who had just turned Republican.
Mr. Garth acknowledged the advantages that Mr. Giuliani had had, calling them "legitimate breaks."
Mr. Garth asserted that Mr. Bloomberg had the advantage of both his professional business record and, he noted wryly, one other potentially important weapon: a large fortune to finance his campaign.

HEADLINE: The President's Serenade Tour 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "President Facing Skeptical Europe on Trip This Week" (front page, June 11): 
 If American policy on various matters is regarded by the European Union as a challenge to European values and interests, the same United States policy may be acknowledged as a chance for change and hope by other countries, like Poland, Slovenia, the Baltic states, Hungary and the Czech Republic. 
On Friday, President Bush will deliver an important speech on Europe not in Paris or Berlin, but in Warsaw. 
Although Poland is aspiring to become a member of the European Union, the vital interests of Poland and many other countries in eastern, central and northeastern Europe are still harmonious with the foreign policy goals of the United States government. 
And to some extent, the economic policy of the United States is much more attractive to Poland and other European countries than the bureaucratic policies of Brussels. 
Therefore, "Euro-skepticism" toward the trip of the American president could be said to be limited to the major states of the European Union.

DAVID M. DASTYCH
Warsaw, June 12, 2001

The writer is a freelance journalist.

HEADLINE: Bush Aide With Intel Stock Met With Executives Pushing Merger 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13 

 BODY:
President Bush's top adviser, Karl Rove, who owned more than $100,000 of stock in Intel Corporation, met in March with the company's chief executive and two lobbyists as they pushed for federal approval of a corporate merger. The administration approved the deal less than two months later.
 White House officials said that Mr. Rove referred the executives to others in the administration and that he played no part in the approval. The officials said Mr. Rove did not recall raising the issue with the president. 
 "He offered no advice or counsel with regard to this decision," said Dan Bartlett, a White House spokesman. Mr. Rove continued to receive copies of correspondence from Intel and its trade group until the decision was made in early May, documents show.
Mr. Rove sold all of his stock last Thursday, unloading a portfolio of holdings in defense, technology, energy and banking companies valued at between $1 million and $2.5 million.
Some legal experts said Mr. Rove should have removed himself from the discussion with Intel to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest under federal ethics laws. Those laws prohibit an official with an economic interest in a decision from participating in recommendations, advice or rulings.
Intel's chief lobbyist, Jim Jarrett, said that he, another lobbyist and the company's chief executive, Craig Barrett, met separately on March 12 with Mr. Rove and Vice President Dick Cheney at the White House. The meetings, requested by Intel, also covered Mr. Bush's energy, tax cut and education plans and were "quite useful" in the effort to win federal approval of the merger between one of Intel's United States suppliers and a Dutch company, Mr. Jarrett said.
The deal was subject to government approval because it involved foreign ownership of a United States computer company whose sensitive technology is relied upon by the military.
"I don't know that you can say that any one meeting tips the balance, but certainly when the C.E.O. comes to call and makes this one of his priorities, it demonstrates to him that we think it's important," Mr. Jarrett said.
Company executives said that they were unaware that Mr. Rove owned between $100,000 and $250,000 in Intel stock at the time. 
The only way Mr. Rove could have avoided violating federal ethics laws was "if he were truly mute and he offered no comment then or later" on the Intel matter, said Stephen Gillers, a professor of law at New York University.
Creating a blind trust or divesting months earlier should have been a "no-brainer," said Sheldon Cohen, who set up the first presidential blind trust, in 1963, for President Lyndon Johnson.
A White House spokeswoman, Anne Womack, said that Mr. Rove decided last December to sell his stocks but was advised in January by the Bush transition counsel, Fred Fielding, that he should wait. Ms. Womack said that Mr. Fielding suggested the White House counsel's office should obtain a government certificate of divestiture that would allow Mr. Rove to defer paying capital gains taxes on the stock sales.
White House officials said the request for the certificate was delayed because the counsel's office was inundated with the work of a new administration, like arranging security clearances for nominees and developing employee ethics standards.
During that time, the value of Mr. Rove's stock fell about 20 percent and then recovered. An Associated Press analysis of stock prices indicates the stocks that Mr. Rove valued on his ethics form last December at between $1.2 million and $2.8 million had dropped in value to between $896,000 and $2.2 million by mid-March. At the time he sold, they were between $1 million and $2.5 million.

LENGTH: 899 words

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL; 
Two Goliaths, And Neither Is the Bad Guy

BYLINE:  By Mike Wise 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
Within 55 seconds of the opening tip, Shaquille O'Neal wheeled his dump-truck frame into the key, Dikembe Mutombo backpedaled to keep up with his counterpart, and the two largest men left standing in the N.B.A. collided in midair.
 More than a Kobe Bryant runner or an Allen Iverson 3-point bomb, two powerful O'Neal dunks very likely swung the pendulum in the league championship series, two displays of ferocity that shook the backboard support and the confidence of the Philadelphia 76ers. 
 The immovable object climbing over the irresistible force set the tone in the Lakers' 100-86 victory in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals.
O'Neal, on his way to a second straight Most Valuable Player award in the league championship series, went into the Land of Mutombo and did not wince. He ended with 34 points, 14 rebounds and 5 assists, providing all the brute force and skill needed for his team to grab a three-games-to-one lead. 
When the 76ers ignited the First Union Center with a dramatic run in the fourth quarter, cutting the lead to 7 points, O'Neal came out of a timeout and dunked again, another thunderous slam with less than nine minutes left.
"The big guy makes everybody better," Ron Harper said. "During that timeout when they made their run, he said: 'Give me the ball. If you guys move your feet, I'll get you some shots.' Shaq wanted it."
Mutombo was more than decent. With 7 minutes 17 seconds remaining in the third quarter and the 76ers trying to crawl back, he brushed aside the Laker frontline and dunked ferociously himself. 
Finishing with 19 points on 9-of-11 shooting and 9 rebounds, he did what he could under adverse conditions, and managed to hold his own against O'Neal on many possessions.
He did not put stock in the notion that O'Neal's power had somehow emasculated the 76ers. 
"Any basket counts 2 points," Mutombo said. "All you can do when you play against someone is fight through him and try to keep him from getting close to the basket. He's a great player.
"He's going to get his dunks, regardless. No one ever say, 'Mutombo will step on the floor and Shaq won't get his dunks.' "
They kept doing this dance, using their pivot feet and their right forearms, their hips and their wrists, a waltz for men over 7 feet tall.
Not since Hakeem Olajuwon and Patrick Ewing battled in 1994 or Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Robert Parish did in the 1980's have two perennial All-Star centers met in the finals, and now they have only one game left.
On and off the floor, the theater will be missed.
Bill Walton, the Hall of Fame center and NBC analyst, said: "It's a thing of beauty to have two top-flight centers playing in the finals again. Everybody always says, 'You don't need a great center.' But during the Jordan era, Michael and 6-foot-6 guys controlled the basket area. It's part of why the Bulls were so great. Now you've got legitimate 7-footers, and it adds a different dimension."
Before they renewed their duel last night, the O'Neal-Mutombo matchup had been heightened by rhetoric on both sides, the two waging a competitive yet entertaining battle in the news media.
Shaq says Dikembe flops. Deek, the nickname Mutombo is referred to by friends and teammates, says O'Neal is just frustrated because he has had it easy until now.
And yet, beyond the chatter, the economical use of the pivot foot -- beyond the hyperbole and the technique -- there is something more. It's less a good vs. evil matchup than Deek, the intellectual do-gooder, against Shaq, Earth's biggest goofball. Mutombo is so much more than his steel-tipped elbows; O'Neal more than his pulverizing dunks.
"Nobody loves Goliath," the late Wilt Chamberlain once said. He probably never saw these two work a crowd.
They battle on the court, but at some point in their lives they both learned to use the game as a tool to help others, not just themselves.
O'Neal has been comedy relief the past week, busting up the news media with his humor. On Tuesday, he smiled as only a 5-year-old trying to impress his relatives at a summer cookout could. "You guys like my quotations," he said. "I'm very quotatious."
Quotatious could hardly compare to Mutombo's gem, which won the interview title the same day. In referring to the Lakers' first three playoff opponents as easy, Mutombo said they were "like a walk in the cake." 
From the man who speaks five languages, it was a well thought-out malapropism. And if it was not, we can hardly wait for, "You can't have your park and eat it too."
When Walton began his career in the 1970's, few teams had 7-footers on their roster. Before people around the globe routinely grew past 6-11, Chamberlain, Abdul-Jabbar and Bill Russell were viewed as somewhat freakish. All the gawking, the incessant "How's the weather up there?" refrains. 
"I was the worst," Walton said. "I couldn't speak, I had this horrendous stuttering problem and I was unwilling to share any of my thoughts about the opponent because I thought it might hurt me. I treated them like the enemy."
So Shaq and Deek went elbow-to-elbow in Game 4, trading shots, shoves and hard fouls before the Lakers pulled away for good. If their footwork and their contrasting styles were on display, so, too, were their personas -- Goliaths worth embracing, appreciated for more than their ability to play basketball.
"I told you all I was coming back with vengeance," O'Neal said. "That's just the type of guy I am. Sorry."

LENGTH: 879 words

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
One Love, One Heart, Or a Sweatshop Economy?

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
The term "globalization" is so tinged with rosy one-world optimism that it's easy to assume the essential benignity of an economic philosophy whose name vaguely connotes unity, equality and freedom. But as Stephanie Black's powerful documentary "Life and Debt" illustrates with an impressive (and depressing) acuity, globalization can have a devastating impact on third world countries. The movie offers the clearest analysis of globalization and its negative effects that I've ever seen on a movie or television screen.
 "Life and Debt," which opens the Human Rights Watch Film Festival this evening at the Walter Reade Theater and continues its run on Saturday at Cinema Village, focuses on the deeply troubled economy of Jamaica and how that country's long-term indebtedness to international lending organizations have contributed to the erosion of local agriculture and industry. 
 Far from being a dry exegesis crammed with graphs, pie charts and talking heads spewing abstract mumbo-jumbo, the film goes directly to the farmers and factory workers whose livelihoods have been undermined. In basic everyday language, they explain how high interest rates have helped devalue the local currency, raising prices for their produce and permitting wealthier countries to import the same products and sell them more cheaply.
The hard-nosed lending policies of organizations like the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank may not deliberately set out to undermine fragile third world economies dependent on their aid. But as the movie shows, the market forces that operate once these organizations become involved are an economic form of Darwinism. The fittest economies prosper while the weaker ones tend to be snared in an endless and escalating cycle of debt repayment that eventually erodes the debtor country's economic base. The banks' lending policies are, of course, determined by the wealthier countries, especially the United States and those of Western Europe.
These dry economic realities are leavened by the cool, ironic lyricism of a voice-over narration by Jamaica Kincaid, who adapted the text from her nonfiction book, "A Small Place." Adopting the alluringly soothing tone of a subversive tour guide, Ms. Kincaid informs potential tourists of the things that will be hidden from sight should they visit Jamaica.
"When you sit down to eat your delicious meal, it's better that you don't know that most of what you are eating came off a ship from Miami," she says.
That's just one of a long list of things she mentions -- from primitive hotel sewage systems that empty directly into the ocean to the dire poverty of Kingston's slums -- that all but the most intrepidly curious visitors to the country will not see. Recurring through the film are unsettling images of jolly, overfed American tourists engaged in activities like beer-drinking contests in Jamaica's luxury hotels.
One result of the country's crumbling economy is the vulnerability to exploitation of Jamaica's needy labor force. A segment about Jamaica's free trade zones introduces us to workers who toil five or six days a week in near-sweatshop conditions for the legal minimum wage of $30 a week sewing garments for American manufacturers. No unionization is permitted in these foreign-owned garment factories where shiploads of material arrive tax-free for assembly before being transported back to foreign markets. Those who dare to make waves are fired.
The movie visits a plant that used to sell high-quality chickens for Jamaican consumption but whose business has been undermined by the dumping of cheaper, low-grade chicken parts from the United States under the guise of free trade. And until recently, Jamaica's banana industry flourished thanks to an agreement with Britain allowing a tax-free import quota. But through the World Trade Organization, the United States has protested the agreement, forcing Jamaica to compete with multinational corporations based in Central and South America where labor is cheaper.
These are just a few of the stories told in a film that despite all the bad news it delivers refuses to raise its voice. Among the prominent Jamaicans interviewed the most eloquent voice belongs to Michael Manley, the former prime minister who reluctantly signed some of the agreements that have damaged the country's economy.
Speaking more in sorrow than in anger, he acknowledges that his country made mistakes along the way. But the overall impression left by this devastating film is of the global economy as a dog-eat-dog world where the usual culprits, the United States and its multinational corporate clients, have the advantage.

LIFE AND DEBT

Produced and directed by Stephanie Black; narration written by Jamaica Kincaid, based on her book "A Small Place"; directors of photography, Malik Sayeed, Kyle Kibbe, Richard Lannaman and Alex Nepomniaschy; edited by Jon Mullen; music by Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers, Bob Marley, Dean Fraser, Buju Banton, Sizzla, Harry Belafonte, Mutabaruka, Rolando E. McLean, Peter Tosh and Anthony B.; released by Tuff Gong Pictures. Opens tomorrow at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Running time: 86 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Belinda Becker (narrator).

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene in a Jamaican sweatshop in Stephanie Black's documentary "Life and Debt," which opens the Human Rights Watch Film Festival. (Jeremy Francis)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 35

LENGTH: 6335 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through July 22). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, tries to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Smith).

* AFRICAN GALLERIES, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (on long-term view). The museum has one of the oldest and most important collections of African art in the country. Just a few years ago, 250 objects from the permanent collection were installed in revamped first-floor galleries; now two dozen pieces have been added and the space has been redesigned again, this time with multicolored walls, mural-size color photographs, documentary films and ambient sound. Added works expand the definition of African to include both Morocco and ancient Nubia. And the overall selection, from familiar friends to treasures recently acquired, is thrilling. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter)

* "AFRICAN, OCEANIC AND ANCIENT AMERICAN ART: RECENT ACQUISITIONS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 28). One of the best new group shows in the city -- stimulating to mind and eye -- is sitting smack in the middle of the Michael C. Rockefeller wing at the Met, and you've probably never seen the like of much of what's in it. The 70 pieces all came to the Met as gifts or purchases over the last five years. They take many forms, from devotional icons to notebook drawings to Sunday-best hats, and they span centuries and continents, from a tiny Mexican ceramic mask made around the ninth century B.C. to a hummingbird-colored silk mantle woven in Madagascar in 1998. A bottom line to such diversity? Almost everything here was meant to have some contact with the human body: to be worn, carried, caressed. This is art with the velvet ropes down. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "WILLIAM BLAKE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 24). A touching and beautiful show if you have a taste for Blake's art, which strives for ecstatic revelation on the level of his famous visions and rises to the heights of his verse, sometimes. From the Age of Aquarius to New Age, he has come to serve as the patron saint of flower children, Jungians, Freudians, occultists, spiritualists, nudists, unpublished authors, animal lovers, socialists and teenagers of the sort who read Hermann Hesse. By turning our attention to his laborious illustrations and watercolors, the exhibition compels us to think about him as a serious and original visual artist, which is to say as a more idiosyncratic and substantial figure than the cliches suggest. He truly believed that the world was ending and that he had been sent to set things right at the last minute. Whatever else he may or may not have been, Blake was the most genuine and uncompromising artist you can think of. Hours and admission: See above (Michael Kimmelman).

"MARC CHAGALL: EARLY WORKS FROM RUSSIAN COLLECTIONS," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Oct. 14). When Chagall returned to Russia in 1914 after four years in Paris, he intended to marry his beloved fiancee Bella Rosenfeld and then hurry back to the French capital. Instead World War I and the Russian Revolution kept him in his homeland for eight years, during which he did some of his greatest work. The 60 artworks here, most being exhibited in the West for the first time, form a series of intense Chagallian doses rather than a comprehensive overview. They are accompanied by nine paintings by Chagall's first teacher, the sensitive realist Yehuda Pen. The show culminates in the seven large, deliriously inventive murals Chagall made for the Jewish State Chamber Theater in Moscow during three feverish months in 1920. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50, students and 65+ ($2 surcharge for "Chagall") (Smith).

* "EL GRECO: THEMES AND VARIATIONS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 29). This gemlike single-digit exhibition (just seven canvases) outweighs some of the more grandiose shows in New York museums at the moment. It brings together, mostly for the first time, four versions of the artist's tumultuous "Purification of the Temple," which provide a vivid timeline of his transcultural development, and three versions of his resonant portrait of St. Jerome as a cardinal, which were all painted toward the end of his life when he skillfully copied -- always with interesting differences -- his works for private patrons. The show makes its small oval gallery reverberate with thoughts about painting: as craft, thought, commodity and lifelong pursuit. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* "FREESTYLE," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through June 24). Spring in New York brings new-talent museum surveys, and this spring, "Freestyle" is the one to catch. The museum's curator, Thelma Golden, working with Christine Y. Kim, has brought together 28 young or youngish black artists from across the country, some of whom are appearing here for the first time. The show is, for the most part, punchy to look at (painting dominates), full of ideas and, with the intriguingly complex notion of a "post-black art" in the air, completely of this American moment. Not to be missed is the spicy magazine-style catalog with essays by some of the best young art curators and critics around. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 62+ (Cotter)

* "FRANK GEHRY, ARCHITECT," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Aug. 26). A full-dress retrospective that showcases history unfolding, even as we walk through it. Mr. Gehry has shown that even in architecture, a form notoriously resistant to creativity, it is possible not only to realize a personal vision but also to gain wide public support for it. The show is a tribute to the ideal of service: to an art form, to the city and to the continuous reconstruction of a democratic way of life. Nothing, not even familiarity with Mr. Gehry's buildings, can prepare you for the impact of seeing his work presented in Frank Lloyd Wright's magnificent rotunda. The energy hits you on entering the show and increases as you proceed. Hours: Fridays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Herbert Muschamp).

"LEON GOLUB: PAINTINGS, 1950-2000," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 19). Now 79, Mr. Golub is best known for paintings done in the 1970's and 80's, raw, awkward figurative works that seek to illuminate his basic theme, man's inhumanity to man. They include huge, engulfing canvases of Vietnam War scenes, riots, interrogations, death squads, racial face-offs and other grim tableaus in which power confronts the powerless. The set piece here is the enormous "Vietnam II" (1973), whose cinematic-scale canvas depicts two groups of figures, a trio of soldiers and a tank pointing guns at a scraggly group of terrified Vietnamese, led by a young man screaming. As a graphic rendering of might asserting its rights over weakness, it delivers its message with impact. Recently he has dwelt with wit more on philosophical themes, referring often to the frailty of the individual and the inevitable end. Whatever the infelicities of his style, he has steadfastly stuck to his role as witness to the world's evil workings. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge addresses in searing images South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses during the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-1511. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude itself, a powerful, ingeniously posed figure that emphasizes the sculptor's magnificent grasp of anatomical rendering. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene, and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there is enough great stuff from other eras to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "UNIFORM: ORDER AND DISORDER," P.S. 1 Center for Contemporary Art, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sept. 3). Originally shown in Italy, this exhibition traces the changing forms and symbolism of the modern military uniform as it progresses through and is transformed by the larger culture -- alternately respected and violated, examined and absorbed, abbreviated and exaggerated. The perpetrators include artists like Wolfgang Tillmans, Vanessa Beecroft and Maurizio Cattelan; fashion designers like Prada, Versace and Donna Karan; and scores of terrorists, punks and nameless teenagers. Eight well-stocked vitrines present a plethora of supporting material, much of which is also reproduced in a stylish catalog. The exhibition ends with the real thing: a gantlet of the uniforms and head gear -- from fatigues to parade dress -- worn by members of the different Italian military services. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5 (Smith).

"FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AND THE ART OF JAPAN: THE ARCHITECT'S OTHER PASSION," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through July 15). Some shows are like a vigorous read; you have to concentrate and try to follow the plot. Wright, an architectural colossus and a wily diva of a man, is the main character. The story of his infatuation with Japanese art, and of how he turned that love to lucrative ends by moonlighting as a top-dollar dealer in woodblock prints -- at least until disaster struck -- is a rich one. It's told through dozens of architectural drawings, documentary photographs, woodblock prints and a superb accompanying book by the curator, Julia Meech, that wraps wide-ranging art historical research in a nimble, personable style. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 students and 65+ (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

JOHN DUFF, Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through June 29). Mr. Duff displays his enduring involvement with industrial materials, geometric form and philosophical conceptions of order. Sculptures from the late 1960's and 70's that are on view here include elegant distorted cylinders or double-ended boat shapes made of rough fiberglass (Ken Johnson).

RICHARD L. FEIGEN, 34 East 69th Street, (212) 628-0700 (continuing). Virtually every inch of the gallery -- upstairs, downstairs, in between -- is hung with something, and the accompanying labels amount to a dizzying roll call of art historical names from Titian to Edward Hopper. Certain religious paintings cut through the clamor, among them two dark, intense pictures of a vision-enthralled St. Francis of Assisi, by Annibale Carracci and Orazio Gentileschi. The real attention-grabber, though, is on the side of the sinners: Jacob Jordaens's mammoth "Twelfth Night Feast," with incontinent babies, puking revelers and a Falstaffian central figure, all executed with astonishing virtuosity (Cotter).

KEITH HARING, Skarstedt, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street, (212) 737-2060 (through June 30). Promiscuously generous an artist as he was, Haring was also very uneven. This exhibition of just four medium-large canvases from the early 1980's shows him at his best. Two in particular suggest the vision of a modern Bosch. Densely populated by manically interactive demons, monsters and little men, they combine graphic ingenuity, mythic narrative and erotic polymorphism to exhilarating effect (Johnson).

ALEX KATZ, Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338 (through July 13). Though famous mainly for his large, elegantly flattened and simplified pictures of beautiful, well-to-do people, Mr. Katz also has a lovely touch on a small scale. This modest but rewarding show of mostly small pictures of women, plus some funky little collages from the 1950's, shows to advantage his delicate brushwork, perfect compositional sense and controlled eroticism (Johnson).

MAX KUEHNE, "Artist and Craftsman," Hollis Taggart, 48 East 73rd Street, (212) 628-4000 (through June 23). A student of Robert Henri, Kuehne (1880-1968) was a competent painter, but his most distinctive contribution was his production of well-made richly decorative furniture, picture frames and wood carvings. Under influences ranging from Japanese to Art Nouveau, he incised outlines of flora and fauna into gessoed surfaces and added colored glazes and burnished metal leaf. The most engaging pieces here are a pair of smoothly carved, elegantly humorous silver giraffes (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through June 30). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Among the signature works are Warhol's serial extravaganza, "200 Soup Cans" (1962); Mr. Rauschenberg's "Broadcast" (1959), a combine painting with a working radio attached; and Mr. Oldenburg's soft "Drum Set" (1967), a bodylike sendup of a professional drummer's instruments in vinyl and canvas that droops on a platform in a metaphor for its own spent energy. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit into an art of their own (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

* VIJA CELMINS, McKee, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 688-5951 (through June 30). Ms. Celmins just keeps making the same old thing: paintings that are at once rigorously formal and expansively illusory, quietly transcendental and materially sumptuous. This spare, beautifully installed exhibition features eight easel-size paintings: six of starry night skies and two of blurrily luminous spider webs. In the print room, crisp wood engravings of rippling ocean surfaces look like 19th-century illustrations for "Moby-Dick" (Johnson).

RALSTON CRAWFORD, "Phantom Forms," Laurence Miller Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through June 29). This hard-edge painter often used his camera to record subjects taken up in paintings, but more often his photographs stood on their own. This small show of a dozen or so is a sampling from thousands produced by the artist over the years. His focus in most of the pictures is the play between light and shadow, as in "Buffalo" (1942), a view of the complex linear patterns cast by iron gratings and a lighting fixture on sunlit cement walls. More mysterious is "New Orleans" (circa 1961), in which a wall of peeling paint contrasts with a smooth white one. The appeal lies in the ambiguity of the hard-edge markings on the walls: shadows or substance? (Glueck)

CONRAD MARCA-RELLI, "Canvas Collages," Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through June 29). Marca-Relli ran with the Abstract Expressionists in the 1950's, but while his collage-based work always had a bold, rough-hewn immediacy, he was driven more by interest in structure than gesture. His compact, puzzle-like compositions of canvas, paper, mattress ticking and other materials from the 1960's hark back to the glory days of Cubism (Johnson).

ANDREA MODICA/ VICTOR SCHRAGER, Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through June 30). A series of close-up antique-looking photographs of 100-year-old human skulls, exhumed from a mass grave on the grounds of a Colorado mental hospital, is a radical departure for Ms. Modica but lacks the intense humanistic poetry of her justly celebrated "Treadwell" series. Mr. Schra ger's quasi-antique photographic still lifes of flowers and old books suggest an Emersonian wedding of nature and culture (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

PHILIP AKKERMAN, Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through June 30). Mr. Akkerman, a 40-year-old Dutch artist, has painted self-portraits, and only self-portraits, at the rate of one a day, since the mid-1980's. Within this Conceptual framework, he invokes the entire history of portraiture, displays a terrific color sense (especially where skin is concerned), makes good use of his extensive hat collection, and subjects his somber face to an impressive range of physical and formal distortions. (In the project gallery, unusually personal photographic works by Julie Bamber and Catherine Opie are being exhibited together, their common theme being the artists' fathers.) (Smith).

REED ANDERSON, Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-5937 (through June 23). Perforation is Mr. Anderson's beat. Punching small holes in large sheets of paper, he creates lacy, enthrallingly complicated images of odd cartoon characters. At this point, the technique and the abstract, optical effects are more interesting than the images, but the possibilities for further development are exciting to contemplate (Johnson).

ROSS BLECKNER, Mary Boone, 541 West 24th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through June 23). One simple technique is about all there is to Mr. Bleckner's big, inert new paintings: he makes a little puddle of paint and hits it with a shot of compressed air to create a roundish cellular form. Accumulated into allover fields, these elements should create a dazzling opticality; but the light and color are dull (the color of dried blood in two cases) and the repetition monotonous (Johnson).

RICHMOND BURTON, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 242-7727 (through June 30). Mr. Burton's new paintings speed up his calligraphic strokes and commas to good effect. His palette of silver and gold mixed with red, turquoise or purple also helps to create the impression of decorative and somewhat Middle Eastern imagery -- graceful Persian texts or Byzantine mosaics -- converted pure molecular energy (Smith).

"CLENCH, CLUTCH, FLINCH," Paul Rodgers, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 414-9810 (through June 30). Organized by the critic Dominique Nahas, this 13-artist show makes little sense thematically, but it offers a number of interesting things, including Julianne Swartz's peep-hole view of a bright interior with mirrored balls and fluttering tinsel; Monica Castillo's video of a woman painting on a man's genitalia; Melvin Way's small, diagrammatic, Outsider-like drawings; an inflated man by Tim Hawkinson; a big, wildly elaborate doodle by Diana Cooper; and a set of calligraphic drawings by Henri Michaux (Johnson).

* STEPHEN DEAN, Henry Urbach Architecture, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-0974 (through June 27). One of the most impressive debuts of the season is that of Mr. Dean, a young French-American artist whose obsession with intense, saturated color has taken him to India, where color is intrinsic to daily life. The result is "Pulse," a painterly, almost unbelievably gorgeous video of the annual spring Holi festival, when residents douse one another with colored powders and water until the streets flow with color (Smith).

CARLO FERRARIS, Esso Gallery, 211 West 28th Street, (212) 560-9728 (through June 23). This maverick multimedia artist, who is Italian, works in photography, video and installation -- always with a wry sense of humor and a knack for visual surprise (Smith).

* JASON FOX, Feature, 530 West 25th Street, (323) 675-7772 (through June 16). In his latest paintings Mr. Fox brings the monstrous and the beautiful into a better balance while also splitting the difference between drawing and painting more effectively. His new images depict a motley crew of cyborgs, action heroes, sports stars and misfits; they are depicted with itchy-looking lines and textures and carefully painted details, usually pixelated grids that block out the subject's features or genitals. (In the second gallery, Richard Kern's photographs evince their own brand of hard-core, which often means pictures of porn actresses engaged in strange or mundane activities, like flossing or enjoying a Jacuzzi.) (Smith).

JUDITH LINHARES, Edward Thorp, 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street, (212) 691-6565 (through June 23). With works painted in broad juicy strokes and luminous colors, this may be the most assured show yet from the respected California-born artist. Images include a woman floating languidly in a lake sans swimsuit and a glowing coral-colored dune fence surrounded by starfish. There is also a group of still lifes that suggest attention to the American modernist Marsden Hartley (Smith).

CHUCK NANNEY, Debs & Company, 525 West 26th Street, (212) 642-2070 (though June 30). "Everything I do was done by a feminist artist in the 1970's" is the stance taken by one of the drawings in this show, and it's not far wrong. But Mr. Nanney's crudely stitched together pouches, cardboard pedestals displaying crumpled balls of aluminum foil or bright little pom-poms, have plenty of riffs of their own. Most notable is an overreaching attraction to glamour, attained by the simplest of means. Excess is rarely so economically achieved (Smith).

* SHIRIN NESHAT, Barbara Gladstone Gallery, 515 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9300 (through June 29). Three videos isolate themes or devices that Ms. Neshat previously deployed in combination, to more impressive effect. The strongest video is "Possessed," which gains from its Philip Glass score and touches on the artist's main theme -- the plight of women in traditional Muslim societies. The near pitch-dark "Pulse" creates an aura of poetic ambiguity for the viewer to unravel, while "Passages" has groups of bare-headed men and chador-clad women, in separate groups, in a dramatic setting. United, these qualities succeed; divided, they are far less engaging (Smith).

* EDUARDO SARABIA, I-20 Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 645-1100 (through June 23). Animated by walls painted with green vines, this impressive debut roams freely across several mediums, the artist's Mexican roots and the Los Angeles cityscape. The centerpiece is a festival-float cornucopia that has references to sex, violence and the materialistic American dream (Smith).

ANDREW TOPOLSKI, UCU, 507 West 24th Street, (212) 727-7575 (through June 23). Mr. Topolski draws like a 21st-century Neo-Platonist. Circles, spirals, geometric figures and curious, quasi-scientific symbols, all made with exquisite precision, create the enigmatic impression of some cosmic theory of universal being. A little music box that produces a sound like hundreds of bells is worth a listen, too (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* "BETWEEN STREET AND MIRROR: THE DRAWINGS OF JAMES ENSOR," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through July 21). The show's pleasure partly involves serendipity. This feels like the perfect moment for an oddball like Ensor, but maybe any time would feel like the right time for somebody whose work, whether it is appalling or fantastic (and it can be both simultaneously), looks eternally modern. The drawings are from the 1880's and 90's. Some started out as ordinary sketches of household objects to which faces and monsters were added, like Rorschachs of the artist's imagination. They somehow become more luminous and translucent the more densely they are drawn, an extraordinary paradox. On the other hand, when the drawings aren't dense, they can be vaporous like Turners, with an effect akin to looking back on a dream: you can't quite place what you are seeing. But the emotion the images provoke is stronger precisely because of the frustration attached to it. Ensor is one of those artists Americans tend to forget or never really knew properly. A hero in Europe, he is vastly deserving of reappraisal here, and this excellent exhibition is a place to start (Kimmelman).

DEBORAH BROWN, "Shelter Dogs," Cheryl Pelavin, 13 Jay Street, TriBeCa, (212) 925-9424 (through June 23). Known for her public mosaic murals, Ms. Brown here presents paintings of dogs that she got to know while working as a volunteer walker for the Humane Society's lost-dog shelter. In squarish easel-size pictures, basset hounds, miniature greyhounds, Jack Russell terriers and various mutts, viewed from above and faithfully rendered in muted hues with a painterly touch, are positioned on monochromatic fields. Sentiment is checked by formalist distance (Johnson).

WILLIAM N. COPLEY, Nolan/Eckman Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-6190 (through June 29). A patron of artists and a painter himself, Copley (1919-1996) worked in a witty frou-frou style heavily influenced by decorative patterning a la Vuillard and Matisse. His life, he said, was "a quest for the ridiculous image," and he often found it, giving lighthearted treatment to brothels, prostitutes, priests and policemen, along with themes from the work of Robert Service, a once popular versifier who wrote "The Face on the Barroom Floor." The wacky spirit in this work tickles rather than bites, and like these two indulgences, a little goes a long way (Glueck).

Other Galleries

"FACES AND FIGURES: CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHY IN SCANDINAVIA," Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, near 38th Street, (212) 779-3587 (through July 29). Nordic photography makes a good showing here with a mix of established and lesser- known talents using a range of approaches, from documentary to personal diary. The aim is to dispel stereotypes about "coolness, control and psychic remoteness" in the words of Ann Sass, chief curator. And the show succeeds, with a humanscape of transvestite haunts in Paris, high jinks in Swedish suburbs, hunting and farming in Iceland, plain folk at home in Sweden, Christmas in Finland, prostitutes plying their trade in Denmark and children frolicking in Norway (Glueck).

JENNA SPEVACK, "Sticks and Stones and Superstrings," Here Art, 145 Avenue of the America, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 647-0202 (through June 30). In a written statement, Ms. Spevack makes the dubious claim that her tiny drawings of imaginary stones, sticks and lengths of rope in precariously balanced arrangements illustrate advanced scientific theories. Nevertheless, her finely drawn, whimsical pictures have considerable faux-innocent, comic appeal (Johnson).

Last Chance

IDA APPLEBROOG, "Early Works," Ronald Feldman, 31 Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 226-3232 (through tomorrow). With deceptive simplicity, Ms. Applebroog's cartoon theater sequences of the 1970's explored states of ambiguity and anxiety. Featured here is an expansive project subjecting the life of Galileo to
feminist debunking. Discursive and tendentious, it lacks the enigmatic drama of the artist's more modest works, like one included in the show in which a naked woman demands of a headless and pantsless man: "Don't you want me? Say something" (Johnson).

* THE CENTER FOR LAND USE INTERPRETATION, "Formations of Erasure: Earthworks and Entropy," Storefront for Art and Architecture, 97 Kenmare, at Lafayette Street, SoHo, (212) 431-5795 (through tomorrow). The environmentally inclined quasi-art collaborative known by the acronym of CLUI (pronounced CLOO-ee) has trained its sights on Earthworks, surveying the degree to which they have been affected by entropy, the principle of constant decay that inspired many Earthworks artists in the first place. The results, offered in a dry Conceptual text-photograph format, are informative, amusing and philosophically intriguing, and are further enhanced when the Storefront has its many doors swung open to the spring weather (Smith).

JENE HIGHTSTEIN, Grant Selwyn, 37 West 57th Street, (212) 755-0434 (through tomorrow). Mr. Highstein's sculptural fusion of Minimalist and organic form rarely fails to be elegant and evocative. This exhibition includes a mysterious low-lying dome made of black granite and a rugged three-cornered muffin shape carved from a chunk of white poplar. Such works need more breathing room than this overcrowded installation affords (Johnson).

* GLENN LIGON, "Colored," D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 352-9460 (through today). In his fifth solo gallery show in New York, Mr. Ligon departs radically from his brooding black-on-black text canvases with a series of contentious paintings on enlarged pages from black-themed coloring books of the 1970's. To outlined images of Malcolm X or Harriet Tubman, he adds "color" in all senses of the word, including life, feeling, personality and race, with scribbles and blots of color. The combination has precedents in the work of Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Cy Twombly and Jean-Michel Basquiat. But as usual, Mr. Ligon layers familiar forms with new meanings and moves the viewer's mind all over the charged psychic landscape of American history, life and art (Smith).

MARY ELLEN MARK, "American Odyssey," International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Saturday). There's a lot to absorb in this big show, the first by this photojournalist to deal exclusively with her American subjects. It covers some 40 years of picture-taking in every region of the country. Children, the elderly, Coney Island, hot tubs, beauty contests, the fat, the skinny, prostitutes, churchgoers, the insane and the imprisoned, Ku Klux Klan members, marathon dancers, transvestites, the unknown and celebrities make not unfamiliar grist for Ms. Mark's lens. More seasoned photography buffs may feel at times that the show is a wade through a stack of old Life magazines. But in her best work, portrayals of downscale people with whom she seems to have a deep rapport, Ms. Mark gets so close to the skin of her subjects it's as if the boundaries that distinguish a photograph from life have all but disappeared. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $4, students and 62+ (Glueck).

* RON MUECK, James Cohan Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, (212) 755-7171 (through tomorrow). One of the memorable solo debuts, this show by a British "Sensation" star consists of two works: a gigantic head on its side, asleep -- Goliath with a touch of saliva in the corner of the mouth -- and a miniature supine mother with newborn, the umbilical cord still connected. Mr. Mueck manages to breathe life into discredited 60's sculptural super-realism. His strategy partly entails greater precision and altered scale, scale being, as artists know, a reliable trickster and emotional provocateur. But there's awe, too: the mother's expression, conveying exhaustion and dumbstruck wonderment, is a lightly comic, ultimately grave miracle of minutely reproduced observation. It is hard to think of the last realist sculpture that comes close to its forensic lucidity, wit and humanity (Kimmelman).

"PANAMARENKO: ORBIT," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through Sunday). This exhibition presents "The Aeromodeler," arguably the masterpiece of the flight-obsessed, mechanically inclined Belgian sculptor who goes by the evocative invented name Panamarenko. It is a giant zeppelin that the artist made mostly of plastic and tape between 1969 and 1971 and tried to fly, unsuccessfully, to its first exhibition. With its beautifully distressed translucent surface, chrysalislike shape, rickety-looking motors and silver wicker gondola, it transforms Dia's spacious, wood-ceilinged annex not only into the runway hangar it has always resembled but also into a slightly hallucinatory dreamscape, one that evokes the sense of romance, wildness, grandiosity and play at work in much of the European art of the 1970's. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 60+ (Smith).

* BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through Sunday). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but a beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* LYLE STARR, Kagan Martos, 515 Broadway, near Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 343-4293 (through tomorrow). Mr. Starr takes 2-D design to sumptuous extremes. With meticulous care, he paints fields of overlapping silhouettes: flat, colored shadows of animals, human figures, cartoon characters, cars and trucks, plants and bugs. Where these shapes overlap, colors mix and you have the illusion of disembodied transparencies layered in an indeterminately shifty and luminous space. Up close, however, you discover carefully sanded surfaces of sensuously tactile opacity (Johnson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: A study by Raphael from "Master Drawings From the Cleveland Museum of Art," the current show at the Morgan Library. (Photographers Gallery, London); A scene from "Passage," one of three videos by Shirin Neshat at the Barbara Gladstone gallery in Chelsea. (Larry Barns/Barbara Gladstone)
