HEADLINE: Misrepresenting the ABM Treaty 

 BODY:
Arguments over the merits of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty between Washington and Moscow have been a feature of President Bush's European trip this week and could affect the atmosphere of his meetings tomorrow with Russia's president, Vladimir Putin. The Bush administration would have Americans believe that the treaty is a discredited cold-war relic that bars the way to a new era free from fear of nuclear missile attack. That is bad history and bad policy. 
 For decades, the ABM treaty restrained competition between the United States and the Soviet Union to build increasing numbers of offensive missiles. Since the cold war's end it has allowed Russia and America to dismantle significant portions of their nuclear arsenals without fear that they would be unable to respond effectively to a surprise attack. 
 In future years the ABM treaty could serve as a bridge to a new era in which further reductions in offensive missiles could be accompanied by the testing and building of limited defensive systems to blunt emerging threats from unpredictable countries like North Korea, Iran and Iraq. But to arrive at that desirable result the administration will have to stop maligning the treaty and engage in constructive discussions with Russia and China. The goal of this diplomacy should be agreement on how to either amend the treaty or supersede it with a new agreement that can regulate the development of reasonable missile defenses.
As it now stands, the ABM treaty allows testing and construction of missile defenses, but under very strict limits. No nationwide coverage against long-range warheads is permitted. Mobile-based interceptors, like those launched from ships, are prohibited and cannot even be tested, although mobile defenses against short-range missiles are allowed. These rules were designed to assure that neither Washington nor Moscow could launch a nuclear attack without fear of suffering effective retaliation. Without the treaty, both would have faced irresistible pressures to build thousands of additional offensive missiles to overwhelm any defensive system. With the treaty in place, additional agreements were reached that limited, then sharply reduced, the number of offensive missiles on both sides. 
Since the end of the cold war, new kinds of missile threats have arisen from smaller, more erratic nations, and new defensive technologies have been designed that may prove able to counter them. Those technologies still need further testing. But if they do prove workable, the treaty would have to be modified or replaced to permit building them. The ABM treaty has already been amended once before, in 1974, and a second set of agreed changes was negotiated in 1997 but never ratified. 
Amending or replacing the treaty is a better course than simply abrogating it. Russia fears that if there were no agreed limits on missile defenses, future technological improvements could render even its present missile force of several thousand inadequate. China has more immediate fears that even a limited missile defense could nullify its far smaller number of long-range missiles. These concerns are legitimate, and the United States, along with the rest of the world, has an interest in these countries' feeling secure with the lowest possible number of intercontinental missiles. 
But Washington is right to seek new scope to develop limited missile defenses. The answer is to seek a new strategic equation that encourages the United States and Russia as well as China to field a minimal number of offensive weapons and reasonable defensive systems. The groundwork for this can begin to be laid when President Bush meets Mr. Putin for the first time in Slovenia tomorrow. That meeting is planned primarily as a chance for the two men to get acquainted. But they will meet again at next month's economic summit conference in Italy. By summer's end they could be ready to designate representatives to begin substantive talks.
The Bush administration ought to stop demonizing the ABM treaty and start building on it.

HEADLINE: Time for Bloom to Resume His Everlasting Odyssey 

BYLINE:  By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
"Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed. A yellow dressing gown, ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him by the mild morning air. He held the bowl aloft and intoned: 'Introibo ad altare Dei.' "
 Today it is Marian Seldes's turn to take up the torch and read the opening of James Joyce's "Ulysses" at the annual Symphony Space Bloomsday celebration. Ms. Seldes is one of a group of actors who have come to this theater on upper Broadway for nearly 20 years to join in daylong "Ulysses" marathons, without getting paid, and before increasingly larger audiences. 
 Every year around the world there are more and more celebrations of Joyce's epic novel about a Jewish advertising salesman, Leopold Bloom, who is beset by thoughts of his infant son's death and his wife's infidelities, and Stephen Dedalus, a young writer so alienated from his native culture and religion that he refuses to pray for his dying mother's soul.
"Ulysses" follows the two men's navigations and chance encounters in Dublin on June 16, 1904, the date of Joyce's first real outing with Nora Barnacle, who left Ireland for good with him and became his life's companion in Europe.
Joyce's 76-year-old nephew, Ken Monaghan, who described himself as "laughingly referred to as the cultural director of the James Joyce Center" in Dublin, estimates that there will be at least 200 Bloomsday celebrations today, including events in Paris, Zurich and Glasgow. In Tokyo, the James Joyce Society of Japan's celebrations will include a workshop on (borrowing Joycean wordplay from "Finnegans Wake") "The Ondt and the Gracehoper: Bauck to Baugsics." Eidsvoll, Norway, will stage events, and so will Prague. Brazil will have four. In Sydney, Australia, there will have readings, music and re-enactments of scenes from the book.
Dublin, where Bloomsday has almost become a national holiday, will have the most, including readings at the James Joyce Museum, a lecture by Mr. Monaghan at the James Joyce Center, street theater and walking tours of places mentioned in the book.
Morris Beja, recording secretary of the International James Joyce Foundation and editor of its newsletter, said, "I won't even report on Bloomsday events anymore because there are so many." 
The celebration at Symphony Space, at 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, was started in 1982 by Isaiah Sheffer, the theater's artistic director, and the radio personality Larry Josephson, and will go on for 12 hours starting at noon. For the first five and a half, actors including Lois Smith, Fritz Weaver, Barbara Feldon and David Margulies will read from the book's 18 episodes, with explanations by Mr. Sheffer and his co-host, the writer and actor Malachy McCourt.
There will also be a performance of "Molly Manybloom," Victoria Bond's musical setting for soprano and string quartet of Molly's final monologue. At 7:15 p.m. Mr. McCourt and 13 others will read a collage of food-and-drink passages from "Ulysses," beginning with Stephen's breakfast -- "Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea coloring faintly the thick rich milk . . ." -- and continuing through Bloom's culinary preferences for "the inner organs of beasts and fowls" and ending with Bloom, who has rescued Stephen from a drunken brawl with some British soldiers, making him hot cocoa.
The Symphony Space event and, inevitably, almost all Bloomsday celebrations will end with Molly's soliloquy: "I put my arms around him yes and drew him down to me so he could feel my breasts all perfume yes and his heart was going like mad and yes I said yes I will Yes." 
The proliferation of festivities seems to underscore that "Ulysses" is capable of withstanding almost infinite exploration. It is as if each successive generation must ask its own questions of the book. Jacques Lacan, Jacques Derrida and feminist and postcolonialist scholars, for instance, have all found grist there. And a new, more widely educated generation of readers, conditioned by postmodernism, seems to have discovered in the novel's episodic form, its lack of a single controlling intelligence, its mockery and ironies and its jumble of references, a perfect analogue for their own experience.
"In its own way, it's hypertext," Mr. Beja said. "Everything links to everything else. There is very little that appears that doesn't come again."
"It's like a big search engine," he said. And the Web itself has scores of sites devoted to the book at which enthusiasts communicate about its minutiae and celebrations. 
Simon Loekle, secretary of the New York Joyce Society, pointed out that people also have more free time now to read a big book like "Ulysses." And the changing nature of bookstores, he said, "with their coffee bars and easy chairs and their like, encourages the gathering to celebrate literary events."
For decades after it was written, few people in Ireland read "Ulysses." The Roman Catholic Church had enormous influence, and the book, with its anticlerical and sexual content, was banned from the country. "My mother used to say to us, 'Never deny you're related to James Joyce, but you don't have to advertise it,' " said Mr. Monaghan, whose mother, May, was one of Joyce's sisters. (He never met his uncle). 
But over the years, social attitudes have of course become more liberal. In 1982 the International James Joyce Symposium held its conference in Dublin. Now the places mentioned in the book are tourist attractions.
Like much of Irish literature, "Ulysses" is built on themes of poverty and oppression. Ireland today has a booming high-tech economy, so the work has also become a touchstone as the Irish search for a new identity.
For the Symphony Space actors, the music of Joyce's language is the lure, and the impassioned audience members follow the proceedings, novel in hand, like worshipers at church. (Tickets are $15, with discounts for Symphony Space members, students and seniors.)
Ms. Seldes said that the reading led her to think of her father, the critic Gilbert Seldes, who once attended the Russian Ballet in Paris with Joyce and Barnacle on Bloomsday. "He wrote one of the first articles about Joyce in The Nation on June 16, 1923," she said. "The name of James Joyce was constantly mentioned." 
Mr. Weaver has never missed a Symphony Space Bloomsday, once flying back from Florida so as not to miss one. "Joyce is a lord of the language," he said. This year he is reading from the Scylla and Charybdis episode, which contains Stephen's theory of "Hamlet." "Dedalus was the last word in Shakespeare criticism," Mr. Weaver added.
The actress Kathleen Chalfant will read from "Ithaca." Her nephew is being married on Saturday, and afterward she and the groom's family will head for Symphony Space. Another "Ithaca" reader is Frances Sternhagen, who says she does it for the challenge: "Reading out loud is a lost art."
Mr. McCourt advised: "It's like sitting under a waterfall on a hot summer day, and the words flow over you. I say, just enjoy it."

HEADLINE: U.S. Industrial Output Falls For 8th Consecutive Month 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15 

 BODY:
Industrial output fell for the eighth consecutive month in May and plants operated at their slowest rate since 1983, the Federal Reserve said today.
 The Fed's report showed a drop of 0.8 percent in industrial production. Analysts had expected a decline of 0.4 percent. The weakness was broad based with the exception of autos. 
 "It was a disaster," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union in Charlotte, N.C. The sustained decline exceeded the six-month drop in the last recession, in 1990-91, he said.
The report fed expectations among some economists that yet another aggressive half-point cut in interest rates might be in store when Fed policy makers meet on June 26 and 27 rather than the slimmer quarter-point reduction the markets are now anticipating.
Adding weight to this view were tame numbers on underlying inflation released by the Labor Department today, as well as a drop in a crucial measure of consumer sentiment.
The Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in May, the Labor Department said, matching expectations. But that increase was mostly because of higher energy costs.
The closely watched core C.P.I., which strips out volatile food and energy costs, rose only 0.1 percent.
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, meanwhile, fell to 91.6 in its preliminary June reading from a final May reading of 92.0. While not as weak as the 88.4 scored in April, it was below consensus forecasts for 91.9.
Within the industrial production report, the May drop in output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities was twice as steep as the decline of 0.4 percent forecast by economists in a Reuters survey. The May decline followed a drop-off of 0.6 percent in output in April.
Factory production, the largest component of industrial output, fell 0.7 percent in May after sliding 0.6 percent in April.
In May, industrial concerns operated at 77.4 percent of full capacity, down from 78.2 in April and the lowest since August 1983. The high-technology sector, which includes computers, semiconductors and communications gear, continued to slow, with production slipping 1.2 percentage points, to 70.3 percent, the lowest rate in 25 years, the Fed said.
Auto output, on the other hand, churned out a 2.4 percent increase. Vehicle assembly rose to an 11.84 million annual rate, up from an 11.54 million annual rate in April.
But manufacturers have been able to keep cars rolling off the assembly lines mainly by offering buyers big rebates and other incentives -- a trend that might not last.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall on Slow Growth in Phone Equipment Sales

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday as Nortel Networks said it was taking a $19.2 billion charge and sees no "meaningful growth" in customer spending on new phone equipment until the second half of 2002.
 The Dow Jones industrial average lost 66.49 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,623.64. The Nasdaq composite index fell 15.64 points, or 0.8 percent, to 2,028.43, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 5.51 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,214.36. 
 Treasury bond prices fell as reports showed the economy slowed further in May, raising expectations the Federal Reserve will trim interest rates a half-percentage point for a sixth time this year when it meets later this month.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 11/32, to a price of 98 7/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.24 percent from 5.22 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 15/32, to 95 23/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.67 percent from 5.64 percent on Thursday.
Mark Bronzo, who helps manage $5 billion at Groupama Asset Management in New York, explained the decline in the market by saying investors are losing patience with disappointing earnings. "They keep expecting a recovery but they aren't seeing it," he said.
Concern that profits will not rebound later this year sent the Nasdaq down 8.4 percent this week, the biggest loss since Dec. 15. The S.& P. 500 fell 4 percent for the week while the Dow lost 3.2 percent.
Nortel fell 74 cents, or 6.9 percent, to $9.86. The company said its second-quarter loss would be $19.2 billion, and its operating loss would be wider than expected.
JDS Uniphase dropped $1.37, to $12.44. The maker of fiber optic equipment parts cited slowing demand for telecommunications gear. Its shares have dropped 70 percent this year.
"The optical market's looking even worse than we expected," said Paul Kleiser, who helps manage $4 billion in the Henderson Global Technology Fund, the largest British technology mutual fund. 
Ciena, the American maker of fiber optic equipment, fell $4.53, to $40.14, while Corning, the biggest maker of fiber and cable used in optical networks, fell $1.50, to $14.50.
Among other fiber optic and networking-equipment stocks, ONI Systems fell $2.04, to $24.65, and Applied Micro Circuits retreated $1.17, to $15.42.
The slowdown in phone-equipment spending also hurt the Andrew Corporation, which fell $1.15, to $16.50. The maker of wireless-communications systems cut its earnings and revenue forecasts for this quarter.
Cisco Systems, the biggest network-equipment maker, fell $1.09, to $16.65, and was the most active stock. Only 2 of the 10 most active stocks climbed: Oracle, which reports earnings after the market closes Monday, rose 15 cents, to $15, and Intel gained 7 cents, to $27.68.
International Rectifier plunged $18.05, or 33 percent, to $37.20, after the maker of computer chips for power supplies said sales this quarter would not meet expectations because of reduced demand from makers of communication equipment.
Microsoft fell 88 cents, to $68.02, amid speculation that the company would say earnings would not meet expectations. A Microsoft spokesman, James Blamey, declined to comment.
About 1.6 billion shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, up 31 percent from the daily average of the last three months.

HEADLINE: Boston Journal; 
Minder of Misplaced Apostrophes Scolds a Town

BYLINE:  By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: BOSTON, England 

 BODY:
They jump out everywhere at John Richards, silent testaments to the declining standards of our time.
 Just four blocks from his house, for instance, is the Print Xpress copy shop, with its sign offering to print "menu's." 
 That's just the beginning, Mr. Richards said recently, his Brezh nevian eyebrows beetling indignantly as he conducted an annotated tour of the neighborhood, on the outskirts of this busy Lincolnshire town. There was Sweeney Todd, "the modern mans barber shop." There was a store featuring "ladies fashions" and a pub whose weekly current events board was titled, shockingly, "whats on." 
"It's irritated me for years and years," Mr. Richards, 75, a retired copy editor and reporter for various local newspapers, said of public apostrophe misuse -- the rampant absence of apostrophes that are needed, the presence of those that are not. 
A few weeks ago he decided to put his irritation to work. Under the auspices of his newly formed Apostrophe Protection Society (number of charter members: two, Mr. Richards and his son, Stephen), he drew up a form letter and began delivering it to offending businesses in the area.
"Dear Sir or Madam," the letter begins. "Because there seems to be some doubt about the use of the apostrophe, we are taking the liberty of drawing your attention to an incorrect use." 
After explaining the punctuation rules, the letter concludes, "We would like to emphasize that we do not intend any criticism, but are just reminding you of correct usage should you wish to put right the mistake."
The campaign has had limited success so far, with only one establishment -- the local library, which expunged the errant apostrophe from its "CD's" sign -- actually taking remedial measures. In general, Boston business owners do not share Mr. Richards's passion for punctuation.
"Sounds to me like this man wants a bleeding job," Reginald Dunmore, a local butcher whose van advertising "carvery's" earned him a letter from Mr. Richards. 
Interviewed later as he prepared to enter the van in question, Mr. Dunmore's son, Stephen, deflected responsibility. "The person who put the sign up should have known, shouldn't they?" he said.
But if Mr. Richards is a man with an obsession, it is an obsession many Britons share. The morning after The Telegraph carried an article about the Apostrophe Protection Society, he received 50 letters from well-wishers, many of whom joined the group on the spot. So far he has received 450 letters, along with nearly $:100 (about $140) in unsolicited cash. Membership has swelled to 257 people.
The issue is an emotional one, judging from the writers' accounts of their own apostrophe-related battles.
"Some of them are quite a bit more militant than I am," Mr. Richards said. "One person said he carries round sticky bits of tape with apostrophes on them, and sticks them on as required."
One woman wrote movingly about her outrage when a pub in her area displayed signs for "todays menue's" and "Nigels special pudding's."
"I tried to correct the notices but was restrained by my husband," she related.
In another case, a letter writer described her fruitless battle with the local branch of Sainsburys, a supermarket chain that removed the possessive apostrophe in its name but put it in the wrong place in the parking lot, where the sign reads "shopper's car park."
"I suggested they were perhaps being too modest in only expecting one shopper to turn up," the woman recalled. "They didn't even reply."
Mr. Richards has the erect bearing of a man used to standing up for himself. He is all too aware that his fight against the greengrocers' apostrophe, as it is known because of the tendency of fruit-and-vegetable stores to advertise "apple's" and "orange's," is not universally popular. Even some experts seem unbothered by this casual use of apostrophes in nonpossessive plural situations.
"Greengrocers might do it out of ignorance, but it is also being used intentionally to draw attention to what you are selling," Jean Aitchison, the Rupert Murdoch professor of language and communication at Oxford University, told The Telegraph. "In the informal setting you can do what you like. That's the way language works."
But for every loose constructionist, there is also someone like Ian Senior, an economic consultant who seethes daily at the fact that his village is called Kings Langley, having long ago dropped an apostrophe (unlike Boston's neighbor King's Lynn).
Six years ago his campaign to reinstate the original punctuation culminated in a vote at the annual meeting of the parish council. But when the villagers voted in favor of apostrophe restoration, 80 to 8, they were overruled by the council.
"They initially said they would have to change all the stationery," Mr. Senior said in an interview. "I said, 'Let the current lot run out and print new paper,' and then they said, 'What about the road signs?' There was no appetite for making a change."
As for Mr. Richards, the correspondence spurred by his apostrophe campaign has reminded him that there is a big, imprecise world out there, with many outstanding grammar and punctuation problems.
"The incorrect use of 'fewer' and 'less' is another thing that annoys me," he said, warming to that subject but checking himself just in time. "If I carry on, I'll get quite worked up."

HEADLINE: Computer Consulting Firm Lowers Forecast 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 15 

 BODY:
DiamondCluster International Inc., which advises companies on computer and communications systems, cut its fiscal first-quarter sales forecast as much as 19 percent today because of weak demand in North America and Europe. 
 Sales for the quarter ending June 30 will be $57 million to $60 million, down from the company's previous forecast of $70 million, a spokesman, David Moon, said. 
 DiamondCluster and rivals like Razorfish Inc. have seen their sales fall as large companies have scaled back plans to expand their Internet operations and smaller Internet companies have gone out of business. Declining telecommunications and financial businesses also trimmed sales, the company said. 
"Our results this quarter are due to general economic conditions, particularly in the U.S.," the chief executive, Mel Bergstein, said in a statement. 
DiamondCluster, which is based in Chicago, will take a charge of $3.7 million in the quarter to adjust the value of stakes in two companies. Excluding the charge, it expects cash earnings per share of 2 cents. The company was expected to earn 4 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Europe Electronics Maker Expects a Loss

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 15 

 BODY:
Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's biggest electronics manufacturer, warned today that it was losing money in the current quarter and might finish the year in the red because its semiconductor business was slumping. It was the second warning in three months. 
 The news amplified the troubles of Europe's battered technology companies, hit by an economic slowdown spreading from the United States to Europe and dampening sales of computers, mobile phones and other products built around chips. On Tuesday, Nokia, the world's biggest mobile phone handset maker, lowered its estimates of sales and earnings in the second quarter. 
 About half of Philips's sales are in Europe, so its troubles are indicative of how the ebbing American tide is affecting Europe. But it is far from alone: two other chip makers, United Microelectronics of Taiwan and General Semiconductor of the United States, also issued warnings of weak second-quarter results.
Philips's share price took a drubbing after the announcement, falling about 4 percent in Amsterdam, and it helped generally drag down technology stocks, already unsettled by dire news from Nokia, Nortel Networks and other major players.
Jan Hommen, Philips's chief financial officer, told reporters that net income for the year would "be close to break-even or a small loss," with sales from its semiconductor division falling as much as 25 percent in the second quarter from the quarter before, leading to an operational loss of around $150 million. Losses for the quarter would be significant, he said. A full-year loss would be the first for Philips in five years. 
Last year, the semiconductor division was a bright spot at Philips, contributing half the company's record profit of $8.5 billion. 
The decline at Philips has come far more rapidly than analysts had expected, and it highlighted the weakness in the semiconductor business, whose up-and-down cycles are largely dictated by demand in the mobile phone, computer and consumer electronics industries. A milestone of sorts came in April, when the company said it would cut 7,000 jobs in its consumer electronics and mobile phone units. A further 250 job cuts, all in the United States, were announced today.
The company has been trying to shed its money-losing mobile phone division, which until today was seen as the core of the company's problems. Analysts expect word soon on how Philips will exit the business -- perhaps giving an opening to Asian phone makers seeking a European toehold, according to Daan Muusers of Friesland Bank Securities in Amsterdam. Mr. Muusers said Philips's troubles reflected industry trends.
"It's mostly a problem of cyclicality," Mr. Muusers said, adding that there was therefore no likelihood of a quick turnaround. "You have to make a calculation when European telecommunications companies will get into better financial shape. That could take a year." Similarly, computer companies have little prospect of a quick rebound, he said.
A new chief executive, Gerard Kleisterlee, took over at Philips from Cor Boonstra on May 1, and the company has just completed a management shuffle that also included naming Scott McGregor to head its semiconductor division. "They are riding rough waves," Mr. Muusers said.

HEADLINE: Small Jets' Big Stake in a Strike; 
Comair Pilots' Pay Seen as Key to Future of the Planes

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
If the pilots' strike at Comair, the largest regional unit of Delta Air Lines, does not end soon, industry analysts have repeatedly warned, it could cause the entire division to shut down. Or if the strike, 83 days' old today, ends with huge raises for the pilots, it could make the operation of small regional jets so expensive that Delta and other airlines would stop the recent rapid growth in their use.
 But yesterday, with leaders of the pilots' union voting unanimously to endorse a tentative contract that their negotiators had agreed to Thursday with Comair's executives, both worrisome outcomes became far less likely. Pilots will vote on the offer next week. 
 The agreement, if quickly approved, should allow Comair, with hubs in Cincinnati and Orlando, Fla., to resume flying its fleet of approximately 80 regional jets, known as R.J.'s, in the next three weeks. While the contract is expected to increase the salaries of Comair's pilots significantly, the raises will probably not greatly exceed the recent big pay increases that large-plane pilots at Delta and United Airlines have received. 
As a result, the smaller jets should continue to be a cost-effective way for airlines to sell tickets to and from small cities, analysts said.
"The question is whether the gap between R.J. captains' pay and main-line captains' pay will shrink," said Jamie Baker, who follows regional airlines for UBS Warburg. "At this point, I've seen nothing to suggest the gap will shrink."
Glenn D. Engel, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, added, "If you're an airline right now and you say, 'Do I have an incentive to fly regional jets?' the answer is very much yes."
Before the strike, Comair flew dozens of 50-seat flights each day out of Cincinnati -- Delta's second-largest hub, after Atlanta -- and Orlando. In the early 1990's, Comair became the first American carrier to fly the small jets, and they have surged in popularity over the last five years because passengers prefer them to noisy, slow turboprops and because they allow airlines to fly routes that are not busy enough to support a large jet.
Many people never know they are traveling on Comair because the planes operate under the Delta Connection name. Last year, Delta bought the 78 percent of Comair which it had not already owned.
Neither Delta nor the pilots' union, the Air Line Pilots Association, released details of the tentative deal yesterday. The union's executive council, which voted 8-to-0 to endorse the pact, will hold briefings next week to describe the contract to pilots, said Max Roberts, a pilot and union spokesman.
But the history of the negotiations suggests that the chief difference between the tentative deal and previous proposals made by Comair was in retirement benefits, work schedules and back pay, rather than in regular wages. In May, the pilots rejected by a 10-to-1 margin a settlement suggested by federal mediators. "It was not the pay," Mr. Roberts said yesterday. "It was everything but the pay."
Under their old contract, Comair pilots earned an average of about $45,000. A first-year co-pilot made about $16,000 a year, and a captain with at least 12 years of experience earned $69,000. By contrast, pilots who fly Delta's large jets average about $150,000.
The rejected deal would have raised the pay of rookie co-pilots at Comair to $21,000 and of the most senior pilots to more than $100,000. Delta executives said they could not afford to offer nearly as much to Comair pilots as they pay the pilots of big Delta planes, which often carry hundreds of passengers and, in the process, earn the carrier far more money than regional jets. Last month, Delta's president, Frederick W. Reid, said the company would consider selling Comair's assets and closing it if the pilots rejected the mediators' proposal.
Delta's management team, however, apparently decided it was willing to make some changes to its earlier offer.
The new pact "differs substantially from the other settlement proposals," said J. C. Lawson, the chairman of the Comair pilot's union, in a joint statement released yesterday by the airline and the union.
Under current Comair rules, pilots could work a maximum of 16 hours in a day. Mr. Roberts, the union spokesman, said he believed that the new pact would limit the work day to about 14 1/2 hours.
The pilots also sought to improve their retirement pay, which had been limited to a 401(k) program to which the company contributed no more than 2.5 percent of a pilot's salary, the union said. In the rejected contract proposal, Comair offered to add to the program by setting aside 2 percent to 6 percent of a pilot's annual salary in a pension fund.
In the new agreement, "I think it's the same type of program," Mr. Roberts said. "It's just that the scale goes higher."
The third major issue was the amount of back pay that the pilots would receive for the three years since their contract expired. (Under federal law, many airline employees, including pilots, cannot strike even when their contract ends. Before a strike can begin, mediators must declare the negotiations to be at an impasse.)
In the rejected deal, the pilots would have received two payments adding up to 3.5 percent of their total pay over the last three years, the union said. Union officials declined to say what the percentage was in the new agreement but said it was higher than in the previous deal.
Analysts said that even if Delta agreed to improve its offer in all three areas, it would not jeopardize Comair's future so long as the new salary structure did not differ much from the one in the May proposal.
"Delta would quickly dilute the economics of regional-jet flying if they didn't stay pretty firm on the pay," said James M. Higgins, an airline analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Pilots will vote by phone on the contract, starting Tuesday afternoon and ending Friday afternoon. The union plans to announce the results Friday night.
If the pilots approve the contract, they will then begin catching up on the regular government-mandated training sessions they have missed while on strike, and the airline can start operating by next weekend, Mr. Roberts said.
The Comair strike has received close attention from executives and pilots at other airlines because of the tremendous recent growth of regional jets. A decade ago, no commercial carrier in the United States flew small jets. At the end of 1999, 427 were in operation. At the end of last year, the number had grown to 630, and by 2005 it is likely to increase to 1,400, according to UBS Warburg.
With greater range than turboprops, the jets have allowed airlines to fly to small cities that are more than just a few hundred miles from a hub. Another Delta subsidiary, for example, recently began flying from Atlanta to Corpus Christi, Tex. -- about 870 miles away and a city that had been dominated by American Airlines and Continental Airlines. The new route thus allows Delta to sell expensive overseas trips leaving from Atlanta to people in Corpus Christi. 
"The geographical lines between hubs are blurred as R.J.'s are added to the system," Mr. Baker said.
The contract settlement, if approved, is likely to affect coming negotiations at other regional carriers, like SkyWest Airlines. Already, the Comair strike played a role, analysts said, in Northwest Airlines' decision earlier this week to abandon a plan to purchase the portion of Mesaba Holdings, one of its regional airline partners, that it does not own.
For Delta, however, it was too late to avoid costly, drawn-out negotiations. Even as negotiators were putting the final touches on their agreement yesterday, the airline sent a letter to investors saying the combination of the economic slowdown and the Comair strike would cause it to lose $140 million to $160 million in the second quarter, about twice as much as it had previously indicated.
Investors did not seem surprised. Delta's stock edged up 19 cents, to $42.95.

HEADLINE: Turning a Friendlier Face to Iran 

BYLINE:  By Lee H. Hamilton and James Schlesinger; Lee H. Hamilton was chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee from 1993 to 1995. James Schlesinger was energy secretary and defense secretary under Jimmy Carter.

 BODY:
In the presidential election this month, Iranians voted overwhelmingly in favor of reform and democracy. The landslide victory of Mohammad Khatami, the candidate identified with reform, provides an opportunity for the United States to respond to the Iranian people's desire for change. The current stalemate in American-Iranian relations does not serve overall American interests. The United States should relax its economic sanctions against Iran and take other steps to foster an improved relationship, without weakening efforts to advance Middle East peace and prevent terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear weapons. 
 Our current policy is focused on important American security interests -- combating terrorism and containing nuclear weapons -- but largely neglects our geopolitical, energy and economic interests. The sanctions, driven by the desire to isolate and punish Iran, have scant international support and have made it more difficult to advance our interests in the region around Iran. 
 Major nations, including Russia and China, are cultivating Iran as they compete for influence in the Middle East and Central Asia. Unilateral sanctions are shutting us out of this competition while encouraging potential strategic alliances to develop among Russia, China and Iran. The sanctions are also a major source of friction in our relations with Europe and Japan.
A less confrontational approach to Iran would make it easier for the United States to develop more effective and timely policies in the Middle East, since America and Iran share some common interests: for example, concern about Saddam Hussein in Iraq and the Taliban in Afghanistan.
Our current policy also has substantial economic costs. American companies are missing opportunities to invest in Iran and develop its vast oil and gas resources. At a time when we need to ensure more diverse and reliable sources of energy, Iran's natural resources could be of great benefit to the United States and the world. Iran is not a likely exporter of oil to the United States, but easing the sanctions would allow American development to increase Iran's production, raising its exports to Asia and thus helping to stabilize oil supplies and prices worldwide.
It would be a strategic blunder to ignore the Iranian people's clear call for reform by simply maintaining and renewing existing unilateral sanctions. And an opening to Iran now would make it harder for those Iranian leaders who oppose reform to make the United States a scapegoat for Iran's problems.
How to move forward and get beyond the current stalemate? A recently completed three-year Atlantic Council study, which we helped lead, concludes that American engagement is best begun by allowing the private sector to invest in Iran and make American products and ideas available to Iranians. This would require that economic sanctions be relaxed, a step that need not be contingent upon the actions of Iran or any other nation.
Additional steps should, however, depend on Iran's responses. The current political climate in Iran precludes direct government-to-government relations or the implementation of a specific plan for normalization, so realistically we should not expect extraordinary short-term results. The relationship is likely to remain difficult for some time. Nevertheless, if both nations are willing to compromise, what is impossible to envisage today could become a reality tomorrow: a relationship between the United States and Iran that permits the "dialogue of civilizations" that Mr. Khatami has called for and that meets our common interests. 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The June 16 op-ed page misidentified James Schlesinger as defense secretary under Jimmy Carter. He was defense secretary under Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford and energy secretary under Mr. Carter.

HEADLINE: Source to Sell Five Properties 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, June 15 

 BODY:
The Source Interlink Company, which has purchased nine companies in the last three years, plans to sell five properties obtained through the acquisitions for $25.3 million to reduce debt and increase its working capital. 
 The buyer was not disclosed. 
Source -- which is based here and is a provider of information, retail display and management services for magazine sellers and publishers -- said it would get $19 million in cash at closing and a 20-year, $6.3 million note. 
 The properties, which will be leased back to Source as part of the agreement, total more than 700,000 square feet of manufacturing and office space. They are located in Philadelphia; Carson City, Nev.; and Rockford and Quincy, Ill. 
The transaction is expected to be completed in about 60 days.

HEADLINE: Vendors Feel They've Been Struck Out 

BYLINE:  By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, Anna Ellison, who owns a furniture store on the site of what was in happier days the Luna Park amusement area at Coney Island, got a call from the city reminding her it was time to renew her dealer's license.
 A few days later, on May 26, a team of city inspectors dropped by and delivered a very different message to Ms. Ellison: her business, Coney Island Furniture, was illegal. So were several other established furniture stores on the same strip of Surf Avenue. 
 And so were her other neighbors' businesses, dozens of vendors of everything from used balalaikas to badminton birdies who have been operating a colorful, if messy, bazaar out of metal cargo containers for more than 20 years.
All are charged with selling the wrong kind of merchandise in an area zoned for amusement-related businesses, or with running businesses out of the containers.
Their real problem, though, seems to be baseball. The Brooklyn Cyclones, a farm team of the Mets, are opening their new stadium a few blocks away on June 25, after a parade down Surf Avenue. The city hopes the Cyclones will lead to the economic renewal of Coney Island, a plan that does not apparently include the merchants who line one side of the street.
"What's happening now is that it's shape-up time," said Chuck Reichenthal, the district manager of the local community board, which requested the city sweep. "We're expecting a very busy summer, and the members of the community and the members of the board would like to see Surf Avenue clean and spruced up and ready for the fun."
Yesterday, Lew Bergstein, the landlord for the merchants using 12 of the containers, was not ready for fun. "We've had inspectors in and out of here for 20 years and no one has ever told us what we were doing was in violation of the zoning law," he said. "How could you be here for 20 years, in a high-profile location, and all of a sudden they're telling you to get out?"
The inspectors returned on June 6 and saw that the businesses were still operating. So they started handing out pink summonses to come to criminal court and pay fines of up to $2,500.
Ms. Ellison's father and landlord, Victor Egorov, was baffled by his sudden criminal status.
"What do they want us to do, just shut our doors?" Mr. Egorov said. "The furniture business is not Chinese-food business. I have people who bought on layaway plan. I have people waiting on deliveries that take two, three weeks. Why could they not give us any warning?"
The merchants in the Stillwell Avenue subway terminal next door, which is being renovated, were given several years to find alternate locations, Mr. Egorov said. "Even on 42nd Street, they gave people two or three years' notice and they were pornographic movie theaters. These people sell furniture."
Mr. Reichenthal said that the strip had been a source of complaints for years. The merchants do not dispute that. The container vendors get frequent tickets for displaying their wares on the sidewalk or not having price tags on them. There has been some construction that was not entirely legal. But that is not the same thing as declaring an entire business district invalid, they said.
The merchants pointed out that they took a chance 30 years ago on a block that was desolate and ridden with drugs and crime, and built something there. They noted that although Coney Island has come back a bit, it is still not quite Fifth Avenue, and the decayed amusement park across the street, eerily quiet at 2 p.m. on a sultry Friday afternoon, is not exactly Bloomingdale's.
They pointed out that unlike the midway and the shiny baseball stadium, their businesses bring traffic to Surf Avenue seven days a week, winter and summer. The merchants fumed and raged, and the ones who have lawyers have called them.
When Surf Avenue was a pit, said Alex Renkovski, the owner of Luna Park Furniture, the city welcomed him. He was granted a permit to put up a blue and yellow awning that spans the sidewalk in front of his store.
"We even named it Luna Park Furniture," he said. "Our logo has the Ferris wheel. What bad could it be? We blend in with this community."
In another commercial zone, Luna Park Furniture would be a respectable, large furniture store. Unlike some of its neighbors, it is kept in relatively pristine condition. Shoppers there yesterday were puzzled to learn they were buying from scofflaws.
"After all these years?" said June Oliansky, who had just picked up a sleek sofa bed -- "I think it's Danish modern" -- for what she called a bargain at $359. "This is a tradition. I've been shopping here for years."
A spokeswoman for the Buildings Department, Ilyse Fink, could not confirm yesterday whether any of the stores had been hit with zoning violations before, but said that it did not matter. "Irrespective of what the history may be, this is the present condition," she said.
The merchants ask whether the city would rather see empty lots than hardscrabble businesses.
Mr. Reichenthal said that developers have already been inquiring about several of the sites. "It won't be an empty lot for long," he said.

An article and a picture caption on June 16 about an effort to remove some merchants who are charged with doing business illegally on Surf Avenue in Coney Island misstated the role of Lew Bergstein. He operates a flea market there; he is not the merchants' landlord.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Nortel Expects to Report $19 Billion Loss in Quarter
Nortel Networks of Canada said it expected to report one of the biggest losses in corporate history -- $19.2 billion this quarter -- attributing it largely to an accounting move to reflect a decline in the value of the companies it acquired recently. Nortel also plans to cut 10,000 jobs around the world, close some units and suspend its dividend.
 The announcement by Nortel and its chief executive, John Roth, above, is the most striking evidence yet of how the bursting of the dot-com bubble has begun to contaminate the bricks-and-mortar economy. Page A1. 

360networks missed a debt payment and said it was considering the option of filing for bankruptcy protection from creditors. C2.

Industrial Output Fell Again in May
Industrial output fell 0.8 percent in May, the eighth consecutive decline, and plants operated at their slowest rate since 1983, the Federal Reserve said. Also, the Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in May, the Labor Department said, matching expectations. And the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index fell to 91.6 in its preliminary June reading from a final May reading of 92.0. C4.

S.& P. 500 Drops 4% for the Week
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4 percent for the week, as investors worried that profits would not rebound later this year. Other markets fell as well. The Nasdaq composite index tumbled 8.4 percent, the biggest weekly loss since Dec. 15, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 3.2 percent. Yesterday, the S.& P. dropped 5.51 points, to 1,214.36; the Nasdaq fell 15.64 points, to 2,028.43; and the Dow declined 66.49 points, to 10,623.64. C3.

California Releases Details on Pacts
Gov. Gray Davis released details of the $43 billion in contracts that California has signed with 18 companies to supply much of its power over the next decade, prompting a debate over whether the contracts have stabilized the state's electricity market. A10.

A Profit Warning From McDonald's
McDonald's said its second-quarter profit will fall more than expected because of declining currencies including the euro, higher costs and consumer concern about mad cow disease in Europe. McDonald's said its earnings would be 34 cents to 35 cents a share, below the 38 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. McDonald's earned 39 cents a year earlier. C3.

Another Warning From Royal Philips
Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's biggest electronics manufacturer, warned that it was losing money in the current quarter and might finish the year in the red because its semiconductor business was slumping badly. It was the second warning in three months. C2.

Coal Reclaims 21st Century Future
Switch on a light somewhere in the country and the odds are strong that it will be powered not by oil, natural gas, uranium, water, wind or anything else but coal, that Industrial Revolution-era fuel that seems, at least for now, to have reclaimed a 21st century future. A1.

New Charges Against Sony Pictures
Sony Pictures Entertainment, still reeling from revelations that its advertising department had concocted a phony film critic and used him to promote four Columbia Pictures releases, has now admitted that two of its own employees posed as ordinary moviegoers in interviews to promote another Columbia release, "The Patriot," last summer. B11.

French Acquisition Is Approved
A $7 billion bid by Schneider Electric of France for a domestic rival, Legrand, is expected to proceed after the French stock market regulator gave the green light to a sweetened offer by Schneider to minority shareholders of Legrand shares. C2.

HEADLINE: Former Rising Star on Wall Street Is Arrested in Arms Sale Inquiry 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
An undercover investigation into suspected arms sales led to the arrest this week of a man who was once a rising star on Wall Street and a promising player in the resurgence of Harlem. 
 On Tuesday, Kevin Ingram, who was named one of the top 25 African-American "movers and shakers" on Wall Street by Black Enterprise magazine in 1996, was arrested by federal agents in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after agreeing to launder $2.2 million that had been described to him as proceeds from arms shipments, according to court papers filed in Federal District Court in Miami. 
 He was charged in a two-and-a-half-year sting operation that also brought the arrest of two suspected arms dealers from Jersey City who inspected a Stinger missile at a West Palm Beach, Fla., warehouse for possible sale to an unnamed foreign country, according to the court documents.
In 1999, according to the court documents, Mr. Ingram and one of the Jersey City men, Diaa Mohsen, laundered nearly $350,000 in two wire transactions by transferring the money from the United States to an account in London. 
Last week, after being approached by an undercover agent, Mr. Ingram arranged for a pilot, Walter Kapij, of Weathersfield, Conn., to take $2.2 million to Amsterdam on a chartered Lear jet. On Tuesday, agents handed them two bags of cash at the airport in Fort Lauderdale and arrested them.
Mr. Ingram's lawyer, Richard G. Lubin of West Palm Beach, said Mr. Ingram would plead not guilty at his arraignment next month. He was released from jail yesterday on a $250,000 bond. 
According to the court documents, the Jersey City men -- Mr. Mohsen and Mohammed Rajaa Malik, also known as Mike Malik -- said they were acting as intermediaries for foreign buyers. They held numerous meetings with undercover agents posing as arms dealers in New Jersey, in Florida and at the TriBeCa Grill restaurant in Manhattan. During those meetings they promised to buy a laundry list of high-tech military weapons, offering to pay for part of the shipment in heroin, the documents said. 
Mr. Ingram ran the mortgage trading practice at Goldman Sachs from 1992 to 1996, when he joined Deutsche Bank as head of its mortgage-backed securities department, making deals involving hundreds of millions of dollars.
Seeking to play a role in the resurgence of Harlem, Mr. Ingram had plans in 1999 to reopen Minton's Playhouse, the birthplace of bebop, and to expand and renovate Wells Famous Home of Chicken and Waffles, a restaurant and nightclub at 132nd Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard that drew an international after-hours crowd in the 1940's.
The Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, an economic development program in Harlem, had agreed to lend Mr. Ingram's development company $570,000 to renovate Minton's, on 118th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Frederick Douglass Boulevards, but it withdrew the offer last year after Mr. Ingram failed to raise additional capital, according to Terry C. Lane, the agency's president. The Wells project is also at a standstill and the restaurant is closed.
The Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, which had agreed to a $375,000 loan for the Wells construction, has begun legal proceedings to recover $200,000, the amount that had been disbursed.
In January 1999, Mr. Ingram was forced to resign from Deutsche Bank under pressure after his division suffered costly losses.
He then helped found TruMarkets Inc., an online bond trading venture that was able to attract some prominent Wall Street figures as board members, including Herbert Allison, a former president of Merrill Lynch. But the company sought bankruptcy protection in March.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
PHONE GEARMAKER EXPECTS HUGE LOSS AS SLUMP SPREADS

BYLINE:  By By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Nortel Networks of Canada said yesterday that it expected to report a loss that would be one of the biggest in corporate history, increasing concern over the troubled telecommunications industry.
 Nortel, the world's biggest maker of communications equipment, expects to post a loss of $19.2 billion this quarter, largely because of an accounting move to reflect a decline in the value of the companies it acquired in the last two years. Nortel also plans to cut 10,000 jobs around the world -- added to 20,000 positions already eliminated this year -- close some units and suspend its dividend. 
 The announcement by Nortel, which makes fiber optic products and old-fashioned phone switches at factories around the world, including several in the United States, is the most striking evidence yet of how the bursting of the dot-com bubble has begun to contaminate the bricks-and-mortar economy. Nortel and other big established companies that feverishly sought to supply infrastructure for the Internet have experienced dwindling futures in recent months as boom turned to bust. 
Nortel's loss is the biggest in recent years, second only to General Motors' loss of $19.2 billion in the first quarter of 1992, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. G.M.'s loss, however, was for items that had accumulated over many years.
Nortel's stock soared to $87 in July 2000 on hopes that the Internet boom would continue indefinitely. And with its richly valued shares, it bought smaller equipment companies that were also riding the Internet wave. Now, most of those smaller companies are virtually worthless -- and so is most of Nortel's investment in them. Nortel's shares closed yesterday at $9.86, off 74 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, down more than 88 percent from their peak.
The news from Nortel helped pull the Canadian benchmark exchange to a two-month low, but major United States stock indexes fell only slightly.
Formerly known as Northern Telecom, Nortel began when Bell Telephone established an operation in Montreal in 1880, four years after the invention of the telephone.
Though it has had two quarters of losses and its stock is down 70 percent this year, Nortel shook the telecommunications world with its loss and dire description of its business.
Nortel pointed to a steep decline in spending by many of its customers, especially start-up phone companies and operators of fiber-optic networks. There has been a string of bankruptcies this year after financing dried up for such ventures.
"The market is contracting at an alarming rate," said John Roth, Nortel's chief executive.
In a conference call yesterday with stock analysts, Mr. Roth revealed a troubling finding for Nortel's business and the industry in general. The company calculates that Internet traffic, which has climbed sharply in recent years, declined slightly in the most recent quarter, Mr. Roth said. Many communications companies have been pinning their hopes of recovery on steady increases in Internet traffic.
About 75 percent of North American Internet traffic is estimated to travel through equipment made by Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario. The company makes fiber optic systems used in the communications networks built in recent years to rival the old-fashioned circuit-switch networks, constructed over the last century. Nortel still produces the relatively staid switches used in older networks.
By the time 10,000 additional jobs are cut, Nortel will have reduced its work force of 95,400 at the beginning of the year by a third. About 30 percent of Nortel's work force is in the United States, with concentrations in Texas, North Carolina, Georgia and California. A company spokesman said the job cuts would take place throughout Nortel's worldwide operations.
The company's announcements signal a far deeper revamping effort than had been outlined in previous months. Nortel is seeking a replacement for Mr. Roth, who is planning to step down as chief executive by next April. Clarence Chandran, Nortel's chief operating officer, resigned in May for medical reasons.
"Ultimately, this is an acknowledgment that investors will bear the brunt of Nortel's missteps," said Philip Olesen, who follows telecommunications debt at UBS Warburg.
Nortel is overspending by about $2 billion this quarter, which means that the company could not generate enough revenue to cover its considerable expenses. The company said that the cash burn would decline in the months ahead. Company executives said they hoped to return to profitability next year if Nortel sold $5 billion of equipment a quarter and cost-cutting efforts succeeded, but it remains to be seen if this strategy is viable.
"It will still be a while before the dust settles and we know if this is as bad as it gets," said Richard Shannon, an analyst at Epoch Partners. 
It does appear that Nortel is lowering the bar so future quarters will not look so bad in comparison. The accounting writedown of $12.3 billion invested in technology companies is in addition to an ongoing $2 billion amortization of items; a $950 million charge for bad debts, inventory and investments; an $830 million charge resulting from job cuts; and a $2.6 billion charge related to the closing and disposition of some businesses, the company said. 
Excluding all of these charges and tax consequences the company said it would have an operating loss of $1.5 billion on $4.5 billion of sales in the quarter.
Nortel spent more than $19 billion in the last two years to acquire companies like the Qtera Corporation, a producer of optical networking equipment. Nortel spent $3 billion in stock to acquire Qtera, which had only $33 million of tangible assets at the time. Qtera's value within Nortel is now apparently worth much less than its initial purchase price.
Other big technology companies may have to write off their acquisitions of smaller concerns whose valuations were wildly inflated at the height of the technology stock bubble. JDS Uniphase, a producer of fiber optic lasers, said in April that it was seeking guidance from the Securities and Exchange Commission on how to engineer a large write-off to reflect the diminished value of the assets it had acquired. 
Wary investors drove down Nortel's most widely traded bond, due in 2006, and drove up its yield. The spread between the yield on the Nortel bond and comparable Treasury securities widened to 4.5 percentage points from 2.8 percentage points, illustrating the additional risk in the company's business. 
Nortel said yesterday that it had secured $2 billion of one-year financing from J. P. Morgan Chase and Credit Suisse First Boston. But the company may have a harder time financing its operations if its credit rating is lowered. Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's said yesterday that they were considering such a move.
If the rating agencies lower their ratings, Nortel could effectively be shut out of the commercial paper market, market analysts warned. Such a move would force Nortel to pledge assets to secure financing and to accept terms usually accorded to companies in the junk world. Lucent Technologies of Murray Hill, N.J., recently had to comply with such requirements after its ratings were cut, increasing its borrowing costs.

GENERAL SEMICONDUCTORSAYS IT EXPECTS LOWER SALES

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 General Semiconductor said demand for its power-management components remained weak and second-quarter sales would be lower than in the first. 
Sales are expected to fall as much as 17 percent this quarter from $102 million in the first quarter, a spokesman, Jonas Leddington, said. The company, based in Melville, N.Y., had forecast sales to be unchanged to slightly lower. Profit is expected to be 1 cent to 3 cents a share. Slower-than-expected demand is hurting profit, though customers are canceling fewer orders. Also, the number of new orders increased in May and early June from April, the chief executive, Ronald Ostertag, said in the statement.

HEADLINE: Catholic Bishops Adopt a Call for Action on the Climate 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 15 

 BODY:
While stopping short of endorsing any particular prescription, America's Roman Catholic bishops voted unanimously today to issue a statement calling for immediate action to mitigate the effects of global climate change.
 Meeting in an Atlanta suburb, the bishops steered clear of the roiling debate between the Bush administration and many environmentalists over the 1997 global warming agreement known as the Kyoto Protocol. Mr. Bush opposes that agreement, which was negotiated by the Clinton administration to set mandates for the United States and other countries to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide. Mr. Bush's reversal of the United States' stance has angered many allies in Europe, where he traveled this week. 
 Rather than entering that politically sensitive debate, the bishops set down principles for guiding the country's approach to what they acknowledge is a complicated issue. But the statement by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, titled "Global Climate Change: A Plea for Dialogue, Prudence and the Common Good," also asserts that the United States, because of its wealth, its position in the world and its record as a heavy producer of heat-trapping, or greenhouse, gases, must play a special role in protecting the planet.
"Historically, the industrialized countries have emitted more greenhouse gases that warm the climate than have the developing countries," the document states. "Affluent nations such as our own have to acknowledge the impact of voracious consumerism instead of simply calling for population and emissions controls from people in poorer nations."
Although the document is unique in terms of its subject, it follows more than a decade of increasingly outspoken interest by the bishops on the environment. By 1993, the United States Catholic Conference had begun an environmental justice program that encouraged local action by Catholics to protect the environment, with a special eye toward helping the poor. The church has also encouraged priests to take up local concerns, like sprawl and industrial pollution of watersheds.
Bishops in the Northwest, for example, adopted a pastoral letter in February urging the protection of the Columbia River and its tributaries as God's creations.
Last fall, Cardinal Bernard F. Law of Boston and all 20 bishops in northern New England, citing the need for "moral evaluation" of environmental issues, called for protecting fish stocks and condemned "personal habits of overconsumption and waste." They called on parishes to include references to the environment in their religious programs.
Connecticut bishops spoke out in April, calling for reduced automobile emissions and more attention to the problem of pediatric asthma.
Throughout the document put forth today, the bishops take a particular interest in the potential harm of global warming on the world's poor. It says that poorer nations have a "right to economic development" and that their wealthier counterparts ought to help them develop technologies that would produce lower emissions of heat-trapping gases.
The statement, which took three years to produce, was adopted on a voice vote by the 217 bishops present.
The document makes no independent judgment about global warming, but accepts that numerous scientific findings point to significant evidence that human behavior and activity have contributed to it.
The bishops also discuss the need to protect the environment as a means of exercising stewardship of God's creation.
And the statement calls on the United States to "undertake reasonable and effective initiatives for energy conservation and the development of alternate renewable and clean-energy resources."
Cardinal Roger Mahony, the archbishop of Los Angeles and chairman of the conference's committee on domestic policy, said the bishops did not believe they had the expertise to take a stand on the Kyoto accord or any other detailed plan to combat global warming. He described the Kyoto agreement, and a previous accord reached in Rio de Janeiro, as helpful, but said continuing research and discussion were needed.

HEADLINE: Helping New York Grow 

 BODY:
For decades, New York City struggled to arrest a long-term economic decline and prevent jobs from going to the suburbs. Today the city faces a new set of problems resulting from an improved economy: businesses that want to expand in the city but lack the space to do so. This week Senator Charles Schumer and former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin issued a report urging that the city employ its zoning, taxing and condemnation powers to speed office construction within its borders, particularly the West Side of Manhattan in Midtown. It was a welcome suggestion that should help stir an overdue debate on development priorities. 
 The report resulted from a study of office needs by 35 business, labor and academic experts over the last year. This "Group of 35" recommends a major effort to develop office space in Long Island City, Queens and downtown Brooklyn as well as on Manhattan's West Side. 
 The group's proposal for the West Side encompasses various ideas put forward by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and others to build offices on a platform constructed over the West Side rail yards and to build new transportation links to the area. Mr. Giuliani, however, also wants to put a football stadium for the Jets on the Hudson River below 34th Street. So does a committee that hopes to win the 2012 Olympics for New York City and would adapt the stadium for Olympic purposes. The Schumer-Rubin group takes no position on the stadium, but its clear implication is that office space would be a better use for that area.
The needs as portrayed by the Schumer-Rubin group are compelling. Last year The Times reported that more than 20 major companies were seeking to move to New Jersey because of space shortages. Mr. Schumer and Mr. Rubin say that 60 million additional square feet of office space would be needed in the next 20 years to accommodate some 300,000 added office jobs. Their proposals add weight to a growing consensus to develop the West Side, with or without a stadium.
The most promising idea for the area is a proposal floated by the Olympics committee for construction to go up on a platform over the railroad yards, much the way the skyscrapers of Park Avenue were built over the New York Central railroad yards nearly a century ago. City Hall is studying a plan to finance construction of the platform as well as transportation improvements by selling development rights and issuing bonds that would be paid by tapping future tax revenues flowing from the increased property values.
The Group of 35's proposal to use zoning and other powers to encourage development outside of Manhattan is not new. The city's Planning Commission has approved new zoning for Long Island City and downtown Brooklyn to encourage office construction. The West Side stadium proposal has not been sufficiently fleshed out, and the potential cost for taxpayers is far from clear. Although Mr. Giuliani and the Jets propose that it be used for conventions, the authorities at the Javits Convention Center are not at all convinced this idea will work. The proposal by Mr. Schumer and Mr. Rubin provides the basis for a debate on the city's future needs. It is time for the mayoral candidates to end their silence on economic issues.
